HEADLINE: Bush Aides Increase Estimate of Projected Deficit

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
Bush Administration officials told Congressional budget negotiators today that costs for bailing out the savings and loan industry could add $61 billion to the Federal deficit in the next fiscal year, which is about $11 billion more than the bailout cost estimated by the Administration just a week ago.
The more pessimistic assessment came as lawmakers and White House officials opened their second week of budget talks still lacking agreement on what figure to use as the starting point for deficit reduction, let alone any consensus on the spending cuts or tax increases that will be needed to reach a specific deficit target.
Their difficulties have been compounded by uncertainty over the seemingly open-ended estimates for rescuing the savings and loan industry and by opposition to an earlier strategy that would not count some of the bailout costs in figuring the deficit.
''They said it was a hit-or-miss number, like playing the stock market,'' said Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee. ''The estimated cost of the S.&L. bailout is still a very flexible figure,'' said Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, who is chairman of the Senate budget panel. 
New six-year figures provided by the budget director, Richard G. Darman, to the negotiators today seemed to indicate that the total cost to the Government of propping up the troubled industry would be more than twice what the Government initially estimated.
The Chicago Tribune reported today that about $50 billion was available in accounts of various Federal agencies and could be used to offset the Federal deficit. Both the stock and bond markets jumped in early trading in reaction, but experts on the Congressional budget committees and at the General Accounting Office said the report was inaccurate. [Business Day, pages D8 and 16.] Earlier Spending Estimate Last year, when President Bush signed the law providing Federal money to rescue the savings and loan industry, the legislation called for spending $82 billion over the next six years to cover losses of depositors' money at hundreds of insolvent institutions.
Mr. Darman's new figures estimated that the cost would be $167 billion through the 1995 fiscal year.
Part of the cost involves paying off depositors when institutions fail, and this amount is relatively easy to establish. But in addition the Government must spend money each year, called working capital, to buy the assets of failed institutions, like branches and repossessed property. Some of this money will be recovered when the assets are sold. The difference, which is the eventual cost to the Government, is difficult to estimate, since the value of the institutions' assets is not clear.
Moreover, the buying and selling do not necessarily occur in the same fiscal years, so the transactions can skew annual budget accounting.
The Treasury plans to announce on Wednesday, in its first official acknowledgement that the cost of the savings and loans bailout has risen sharply, that losses to the taxpayers could be as much as $50 billion more than expected. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady will testify before the House Banking Committee and acknowledge that the money appropriated last year for the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency responsible for managing the bailout, will fall far short. It will be a clear admission that Congress will have to appropriate more for the rescue.
The Treasury is expected to say it does not know what the exact loss will be, but it will offer a broad range of possible new losses, ranging from about $15 billion to more than $50 billion above its previous estimates.
Since much of the money to finance the bailout is borrowed by the Treasury from the investing public, some analysts calculate the interest costs on that borrowing as part of the overall cost. The Treasury's numbers do not include interest expense.
 
Issue on Bailout Funds
Earlier this year, Mr. Darman and Congressional leaders in both parties agreed in principle that operating costs for the agency handling the bailout should not be counted as part of the budget deficit. But objections from rank-and-file Democrats and Republicans have made that approach and the task of the budget negotiators far more difficult.
''It's a major issue that has to be resolved,'' Mr. Panetta said. ''Even if there is a consensus among the negotiators to take it out of the budget, we face very difficult opposition.''
Much of today's three-hour negotiating session was devoted to what the deficit would look like if items like the trust funds for Social Security, highways and airports were removed from the computation. A number of lawmakers outside the negotiating team have argued that surpluses in these trust funds are being used to mask the true size of the Government's yearly deficit and should thus be taken out of the deficit calculation. At the same time, they argue that a failure to include the costs of the savings and loan bailout in the calculation further masks the real deficit problem.
According to the Administration estimates today, the deficit for the 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, would be $199 billion, including the $61 billion for the savings and loan bailout. That estimate assumes that the various trust funds and the operating costs for the agency handling the disposition of assets of the failed institutions remain a part of the budget.
The deficit would rise to $276 billion if the trust fund surpluses and the bailout costs were removed. It would swell to $337 billion if the trust fund surpluses were removed but the costs of the bailout were retained.
 
Updated Forecast Sought
Negotiators said they had asked the Congressional Budget Office and the Administration's Office of Management and Budget to prepare updated economic forecasts over the next several weeks in hopes of arriving at an agreement on the true size of the deficit. Assumptions about interest rates, inflation and economic growth have a direct bearing on the size, and the Administration has acknowledged that the forecast on which its January budget was based is outdated.
The swelling estimates of the deficit make it increasingly likely that Congress will have to stretch out the yearly deficit goals imposed by the budget-balancing law. The law sets a deficit target of $64 billion for the fiscal year 1991 and requires automatic spending cuts in military and domestic programs if Congress and the Administration cannot agree on deficit-cutting measures of their own.
The negotiators have already acknowledged that even their best efforts would be unlikely to yield enough spending cuts or tax increases to reach the $64 billion goal.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 26, 1990, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the effect of the savings and loan bailout on the Federal deficit described effects of accounting differences incorrectly in some copies. The deficit projected by the Bush Administration for the 1991 fiscal year would reach $199 billion if $61 billion in bailout costs were included in the deficit calculations. If those costs were not included, and surpluses in the Social Security and other trust funds were also not counted, the deficit would reach $276 billion.

HEADLINE: A German Quid for a Moscow Quo

 BODY:
Two out of three isn't good enough for Secretary of State Baker's critics. He has returned from Moscow having made welcome progress toward agreements on strategic arms and also on chemical weapons, but little progress on cutting conventional forces in Europe. Though he offered new and accommodating ideas, Moscow proved unresponsive. 
Not surprisingly, arms control critics in and out of the Administration jumped all over Mr. Baker. The dust they raised obscured what went on in Moscow. Clearing the air is important before the Bush-Gorbachev summit meeting next week.
That can be done by assessing these key questions: Are the Soviets ''stonewalling,'' as charged by Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser? If so, why? And if conventional force cuts are delayed, does it make sense to hold up the Start treaty to reduce nuclear arms?
In the 23-nation talks on Conventional Forces in Europe, the two sides are close to agreement on reducing most forces - by about half for the Warsaw Pact and a tenth for NATO. In Moscow, Mr. Baker offered ideas to break the key deadlock, on aircraft. The Soviets explored these suggestions without accepting or rejecting them. That hardly amounts to stonewalling.
With Moscow facing so much economic and nationalist uncertainty, it's possible that the Soviets just needed more time to evaluate the offer. Perhaps they haven't yet figured out what to do with all the troops they would bring home from Eastern Europe. And Moscow has to assure itself that a united Germany, probably in NATO, won't put the Soviet Union at a decisive military disadvantage. To deal with this problem indirectly, Moscow proposes to limit NATO and Warsaw Pact troops in Central Europe to about 700,000 each.
The West Germans have announced a troop cutback, and Foreign Minister Genscher had indicated a willingness to negotiate reductions, if other NATO allies reduced their forces too. But Chancellor Kohl has now overruled his coalition partner and wants to defer any limits on German troops until after a conventional forces treaty is signed. A week ago, he won President Bush's backing. That tough stance surely helps explain Moscow's unresponsiveness.
Some critics urge holding up strategic arms reductions until Moscow comes around. They say that cutting the Soviet superiority in conventional arms should come first. But the two presidents can initial a strategic arms agreement in principle next week in Washington, and sign a finished treaty this fall. Delaying that would give the U.S. no added leverage over a conventional arms deal.
Such an agreement will take more time than originally anticipated because of German unification. The most important way to expedite this treaty is for Bonn to accept modest limits on its troops in return for Moscow's effective withdrawal from the center of Europe.

HEADLINE: The Pitfalls of U.S. Strictures on China Trade

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Recent Congressional hearings and public debate over whether the United States should renew the most-favored-nation (M.F.N.) status for China have brought Sino-American relations to a new crossroad. As a Chinese scholar studying Sino-American relations here since January, I feel the gravity of the issue compels me to put in a few words.
Those opposed to the renewal argue that the United States must use this opportunity to clarify further its indignation and opposition to Beijing's allegedly worsening human-rights record since last June, to exercise more pressure on Beijing to behave, to discredit Beijing's leaders and if possible to bring down the Beijing Government, which they believe has lost legitimacy to rule in China. 
While sharing their distaste for Beijing's suppression of the student demonstrations last June and their dissatisfaction with its human-rights record since then, I feel their argument is very debatable.
To begin with, as many people have pointed out, suspension of most-favored-nation status for China will more likely hurt the Chinese people on the mainland and in Hong Kong than the leaders in Beijing. Furthermore, this action will more likely undercut China's remaining reforms and open policy than promote them. And it will more likely provide the Beijing leadership an excuse for their failure in managing China's economy than it will discredit them.
Moreover, it will damage U.S. business interests and make China's existing cooperation with the U.S. in such areas as nuclear nonproliferation, arms sales to the Middle East, East Asian stability, anti-drug efforts, etc., less likely.
Finally, such action probably will not change Beijing's behavior, let alone bring down the Government. The U.S. tried to use economic pressures in the 1950's and the U.S.S.R. in the 1960's, and both efforts ended in failure, with the Chinese people suffering the consequences.
An externally imposed drastic change in China is more likely to reduce China to political chaos than to bring about a democratic and effective government there. After all, it is dictatorship, not democracy and freedom, that political chaos usually produces. In this regard, one shold also bear in mind that China is a nuclear power. Political chaos there will not only cause pain and suffering to the Chinese people but also increase the likelihood that Chinese nuclear weapons fall into irresponsible hands. While not questioning the intentions of those opposed to renewing M.F.N. status for China, I want to point out the complexity of the issue and the limits to what the U.S. can do. This is not to say that Washington should not maintain its position and express its dissatisfaction with developments in China since last June. Rather, the U.S. should do it in other ways, such as a conditioned renewal of the M.F.N. status, as Winston Lord proposed in recent Congressional hearings.
In sum, the means must serve the end. As one American put it recently: in this case, suspension of the M.F.N. status for China now is simply not a good means.
 
QINGGUO JIA
 Ithaca, N.Y., May 17, 1990
The writer, an associate professor at Peking University's Institute of International Relations, is a visiting faculty member at Cornell University.

HEADLINE: OBSERVER;
Golden Red-Ink Oldie

BYLINE: By Russell Baker

 BODY:
Speaking of death and ruination, has it been generally observed that the Democratic Party is now worried about the budget deficit? There is no surer sign of a party drifting toward the ultimate coma.
Not that there has been much doubt for several years about the Democrats. Aside from occasionally stirring just long enough to make life hellish for some luckless soul like Judge Bork or John Tower, theirs is a party happy in the torpor of incessant re-election to Congress.
A clash of ideas may revive a dying political party, as the battle between Goldwater and the internationalists brought life back to the Republicans 25 years ago. The Democrats, however, are not simply threadbare of ideas; they seem to like it that way. 
When somebody brings them one, as Senator Moynihan did by proposing to cut Social Security taxes, they flee. Instead, they have decided to be alarmed about the deficit. Ignorance of history must run as deep among Democratic politicians as among modern schoolchildren.
Doesn't anyone remember that Republicans campaigned against deficits for 30 years, warning that red ink threatened the country with doom and that only good old Republican fiscal responsibility could save us?
America responded to these alarms with yawns and went right on electing Democratic Presidents, except for the intermission in which it gave its heart to its favorite war hero, General Eisenhower.
This history suggests there is absolutely no political mileage in stewing about budget deficits. Yet the Democrats now stew away as though utterly ignorant of their own party's past triumphs over Republicans fearful of deficit finance.
The beauty part of the joke is that it was the Republican Reagan who created the present deficit. Reagan made all the orthodox Republican sounds about the sacred need for balanced budgets while serenely ignoring his own jaw music and following the traditional Democratic route to victory via Red Ink Turnpike.
The Roosevelt and Truman deficits, which had once left Republicans terrified, were infants compared with the Reagan creation, which is now being expanded under President Bush. Comparatively speaking, this magnificent Republican construction is the very father and mother of deficits.
Or is it? The numbers are grandiose, but it would take a doctorate from one of the fancier universities to understand the economists' debate about whether it is terrifying or just more proof of Washington's power to mislead humanity with arithmetic.
Not surprisingly, many people find it easier not to worry about deficits. There are good reasons for this, including the natural human impulse to leave impenetrable economic debates to economists and a tendency to nod toward slumber when the word ''budget'' is spoken.
Since most people are not passionately interested in balancing their own budgets, their desire for balancing the Federal Government's tends to be secondary, and maybe even tertiary if the question becomes, ''Are you so worried about the deficit that you're ready to reduce it by paying more taxes?''
In brief, the party of fiscal responsibility is likely to be a loser. Yet we now find the Democratic Congressional leaders sufficiently worried about it to confer with White House Republicans on ways to cut the deficit.
Worse luck for Democrats, this has produced speculation that the real purpose is to get both parties lined up behind new taxes. So far they have produced only farce, with Republicans and Democrats both ostentatiously declining to be the first to say: ''Taxes! That's the way to go!''
The Democrats having been mercilessly shellacked year in and year out by low-tax and no-tax Republicans, the question is why they are even participating in this exercise. The Republicans have masterful image manipulators who will surely find it easy to portray them as incurable tax lovers (bad, bad people!) if they agree to some bipartisan scheme to levy new taxes.
Well, aside from the party being bankrupt of ideas, perhaps the Democrats entered this baited trap because they are good patriots alarmed by the deficit.
If it really is alarming, however, surely it's the Republicans who ought to be worried about the deficit. They made it and they have so far insisted on living with it rather than tax to cut it. Holding the Presidency, they are also supposed to be leading the country.
The Democrats need a political earthquake to save them. It is not in the Republicans' interest to let one happen.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Plan Approved in Albany Seeks To Restore Faith in State Finances

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 22

 BODY:
Putting the finishing touches on New York's budget, the State Legislature approved a measure today aimed at restoring faith in the state's finances.
The measure calls for the state to end its longstanding practice of borrowing billions of dollars each spring to finance routine expenses like school aid and tax refunds. It also imposes guidelines for state spending that would link its growth to the growth in the economy. 
The outlines of the plan were agreed on last month, when state leaders announced that they planned to phase out the annual spring borrowing. But a final accord on the measure was delayed by a broader dispute over the state budget, which was finally approved on Saturday, seven weeks late.
Even some of the harshest critics of the state's financial practices have responded warmly to the plan to eliminate the spring borrowing, and today several politicians, including Assembly Speaker Mel Miller and State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, tried to elbow each other out of the way to take credit for it.
The adoption of the plan, Mr. Regan said, ''will mark the culmination of a 10-year effort'' by his office.
 
'Positive First Step'
Cynthia Green, a financial analyst for the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit watchdog group, termed the plan ''a positive first step toward fiscal reform.''
Under the measure approved today by the Assembly and the State Senate, the state would issue bonds to replace the money from its annual spring borrowing. The terms of the bonds would severely limit the amount that the state could borrow in the future.
The spring borrowing has enabled the state to roll forward an accumulated deficit that now approaches $5 billion. By issuing long-term bonds to replace the borrowing, the state would eliminate this deficit over the lifetime of the bonds, 30 years.
The measure approved today calls for one-quarter of the revenues from the state's 4 percent sales tax to be earmarked to pay off the bonds.
Because there is no mechanism yet for issuing the bonds, the state is still expected to have to borrow about $4 billion next month to meet its expenses this spring. It is expected to take at least three years to issue all the bonds to eliminate the spring borrowing.
 
Spending 'Targets'
As part of the ''fiscal reform package'' approved today, lawmakers also enacted restrictions limiting the growth in state spending. Restrictions had been demanded by the Republican-led Senate, which made them a condition of passing the budget.
But the spending restrictions approved today are far less stringent than those called for by the Senate. Instead of a statutory spending cap, the restrictions call for spending ''targets'' to be set in 1991 and 1992. The targets, which would not be binding, would limit state spending to 10 percent of the total personal income in the state.
In 1993, a statutory ceiling on spending would be established. The terms of the cap have not yet been set. Legislative action would be required to extend the spending cap beyond 1993.
George Leung, managing director for state ratings at Moody's Investors Services, a major credit-rating agency, said that although the spending restrictions were for the most part only advisory, they could help to restrain state spending.
''If they serve to enforce some kind of spending discipline,'' he said, ''that's positive.''

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 987 words

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Two weeks after some critics complained that Mayor David N. Dinkins was piping a quiet obbligato from the back rows on race relations in New York City, he now finds himself leading a brass band of parades and posters, blue ribbons and bromides, whose effectiveness remains uncertain.
 
The latest effort in the
Mayor's campaign was a ''town meeting'' at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine last night, a blend of camp revival and campaign rally that echoed Mr. Dinkins's well-oiled field effort for last fall's elections.
''It's almost like a political campaign,'' said Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, who managed Mr. Dinkins's election campaign. ''We're going on a similar kind of outreach, where we're trying to get what the Mayor has called the silent majority involved in trying to do something about racial tensions in our city, pulling folks together to say, ''Let's hear from some other voices.' '' 
But even Mr. Dinkins's aides concede that it is too early to assess how effective the campaign will be.
''We're not proclaiming that there are going to be any easy answers to the questions raised, or that the moral tone raised by a broad range of community leaders will give answers,'' said Ken Sunshine, the mayor's senior special adviser. ''But it can certainly help set a climate.''
But Mr. Dinkins's calls for calm and unity have drawn fire from members of his core constituency - from the Rev. Herbert Daughtry and the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d to his close friend Percy Sutton - some of whom have suggested that he bent over backward to palliate whites at the expense of blacks.
The Mayor is in a bind. He is trying to resolve tensions that grew over many years and are rooted not only in race and ethnicity but economics. As he prepares to issue a budget tomorrow that will surely be full of bad news and little new spending in the face of fiscal constraints, there is concern about too few jobs, too few initiatives and too few changes.
''Bensonhurst, Howard Beach -those are overt racial acts easy to pinpoint,'' said Peter Williams, a project associate at the Center for Law and Social Justice at Medgar Evers College. ''But the more systemic, institutionalized racism existing in New York City has not really been addressed by anybody. It's been studied, but implementation to change the policies and the practice has not been as urgent, and they have as much to do with the creation of a colorful mosaic as anything else.''
To be sure, Mr. Dinkins mentions those problems in almost every speech, but perhaps inevitably he has not managed to do much about them, in just under five months in office. Into the breach, he has thrown a formidable publicity blitz.
In the last week, as New York was transfixed by the split verdicts in the Bensonhurst murder trial, Mr. Dinkins appeared live on three national television news programs, a cool presence trying to defuse an image of the city as a tinderbox. He was interviewed by news magazines and stumped around the city Sunday, from a Harlem church to a Norwegian festival in Brooklyn.
 
High Notes in Blue
The city printed 10,000 posters proclaiming ''Respect and Unity'' in seven languages. John Cardinal O'Connor said he would ask Roman Catholics to take an oath of tolerance. Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez urged students to wear blue ribbons as an emblem of racial harmony. Yesterday, The New York Post, the same newspaper Mr. Dinkins recently chided for prominently quoting the Rev. Al Sharpton, announced the Mayor's rally in a bold blue headline on its front page.
After all the shouting on both sides, Mr. Dinkins's modulation may be a relief.
''I think that rallies that are held in a way that don't inflame people's feelings make a big difference,'' said William Kornblum, director of the Center for Social Research at the City University Graduate Center in Manhattan. ''Strategies like the ribbons are very important, because the more we can show each other that we reject hatred and want more lines of understanding among ourselves, the better off we'll be.
''These things are no panacea,'' he said, but added: ''We have to figure out ways of wearing our hearts on our sleeves.''
 
Change Since Howard Beach
The Mayor's aides insist that he has persisted in the low-key style he has always favored. ''I remind you of Howard Beach, in which he interceded and got things going,'' one senior aide said yesterday.
But some things have changed. After a black man was chased to his death by a gang of whites in Howard Beach in 1986, Mr. Dinkins helped arrange a meeting between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and lawyers for another victim who had been mishandled by the police and was refusing to cooperate in the investigation.
Now, after the Mayor criticized a black-led boycott of two Korean groceries in Brooklyn, one of those lawyers, C. Vernon Mason, said Mr. Dinkins had ''no African left in him'' and ''too many yarmulkes on his head.''
That hurt Mr. Dinkins but may have had the unintended effect of solidifying his support among moderates of all races. Undoubtedly the more he says and does as Mayor, the harder it will be for him to keep the position above the fray from which he has so far strived to conduct his career.
Moreover, the grocery boycott in Flatbush continues, despite lengthy negotiations led by the Mayor's aides and a personal discussion between Mr. Dinkins and the lawyer for the Haitian woman whose dispute with a store manager started the protest.
In the coming weeks, Mr. Dinkins's aides said yesterday, he will step up his appearances in various neighborhoods around the city, and urge ministers, politicians and community leaders to keep up their sermons against hate.
Mr. Lynch said: ''At least we've gotten local and national awareness as to what's going on. The debate is being waged, and we hope that we can bring forward some concrete things, programs that will alleviate the problems.''

HEADLINE: Procedure Is Upheld For Staten Islanders To Vote on Secession

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
A lengthy process under which Staten Islanders could seek state approval to secede from New York City was upheld yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.
Under legislation signed in March by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the Governor and the Legislature would have the final authority on whether Staten Island could become independent. First, Staten Islanders would have to approve two secession referendums. 
Justice Herman Cahn ruled yesterday that the first referendum could be on Nov. 6, as part of the general election. If a majority approves, a city commission would be established to report on the fiscal effects of secession.
Staten Islanders would then vote again. With voter approval, the issue would go to the Legislature and the Governor. The process could take three years.
 
Opposition at City Hall
Supporters and opponents of secession said yesterday that they thought the question would face considerable legislative opposition.
In upholding the secession legislation, Justice Cahn rejected the Corporation Counsel's contention that the law was unconstitutional. Mayor David N. Dinkins opposes secession, contending that voters citywide should participate in any secession referendum. Corporation Counsel Victor Kovner said he would appeal to the Court of Appeals.
''We are hoping to expedite the appeal, so we can get a decision before Staten Island goes through the expense of preparing for a referendum this fall,'' Mr. Kovner said. ''It is our contention that secession would have an enormous economic impact on the city as a whole, and equal protection requires an equal opportunity for all New Yorkers to vote.''
Borough President Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island predicted secession would mean property taxes in the borough would double or triple. He added that he did not expect the Legislature to approve secession, no matter how the island voted.
With 352,121 residents, the borough has 5.2 percent of the seven million New Yorkers.

HEADLINE: Education Chief Suggests Schools Minimize Tests

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 22

 BODY:
New York State's Education Commissioner said today that the state's public schools should adopt a far broader measure than standardized tests in assessing student performance.
The proposal by the Commissioner, Thomas Sobol, appeared to echo recent moves by other states, including Vermont and Connecticut, to use more intensive ''portfolio'' evaluations of a student's work and to de-emphasize test results in promoting from grade to grade. The portfolios require successful completion of projects, like research reports or science projects, rather than scoring well on tests.
Educators ''cannot achieve the results we desire through top-down regulation alone,'' Mr. Sobol said, adding, ''It's important that children be assessed by the quality of their work over a sustained period rather than the snapshot in time that a test will give.'' 
 
Obstacles Are Noted
The Commissioner's approach is outlined in a memorandum that he will present to the Board of Regents here Wednesday night. He said there would be no changes in state mandates until a thorough review was conducted with teachers, administrators and other school officials.
Educators familiar with Mr. Sobol's proposal said it would provoke a wide debate about the wisdom and the practicality of portfolio assessments.
Some educators noted that while the system had produced promising results in some school districts and in small pilot programs, it required intensive involvement by teachers with individual students. It is by no means clear, they said, that the approach could succeed on a large scale, particularly in places like New York City, where crowded classrooms are a constant problem.
Grant Wiggins, a former research associate with the Rochester-based National Center on Education and the Economy, who is now a private consultant to several school districts that are experimenting with portfolios, said: ''You ask, 'Can it work?' The answer is yes, if there's constant supervision, if there's ample time to look at a student's results and give feedback. Those are a lot of ifs.''
Mr. Wiggins said that for many schools it remained ''technically easier and more cost-effective to do what they're doing now'' - relying heavily on test results to evaluate students.
 
Broad Goals Stir Dissent
The almost informal way that Mr. Sobol offered his suggestion was in keeping with the approach he has taken in the last year to several major reforms of the state's education system. He has outlined basic goals but left the specifics to a large group of experts.
Mr. Sobol said last summer, for example, that there should be a huge decentralization of the New York City school system. And earlier this year he called for revision of the state's educational curriculum to put more emphasis on the influence of non-Western cultures on American life.
Supporters praise Mr. Sobol for trying to build a consensus, while critics deride him as ineffective. The decentralization proposal was widely denounced at the time and has gone nowhere, while the curriculum revision was tentatively approved by the Board of Regents and is being drafted.
Mr. Sobol's proposal today would seem to coincide, at least in part, with recent moves by the New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, to end the city's long-standing policy of automatically holding back failing students after certain grades.
 
Need to Encourage Stressed
With the use of more subjective criteria for advancement, Mr. Sobol said, some students may be encouraged to develop their skills rather than feel they are failures on the basis of a test score.
''What you're encouraging kids to do is their very best work,'' he said. ''You want the teacher intent on building upon what a child can do rather than rubbing his nose in what he can't do.''
Mr. Fernandez has also urged more positive approaches to reduce the dropout rate in New York City, where nearly a third of students leave before finishing high school.
The Chancellor's executive director of strategic planning, Robin Willner, said today that Mr. Fernandez had not seen a copy of Mr. Sobol's proposal. ''We're very interested in authentic assessment,'' she said, using a term for a range of alternatives to standardized tests. ''We also need to be clear that to move in that direction would require a lot of resources and support from the state.''
 
Some Skepticism Apparent
Still, standardized tests have strong defenders, and some educators today indicated they were skeptical about the portfolio approach.
''I hope this isn't going to be looked at as a way to lower standards,'' said Louis Grumet, executive director of the New York State School Boards Association. He also questioned the contention that reduced emphasis on tests would inspire more students to excel.
''The child who is going to do poorly on standardized tests is usually going to do poorly on portfolios,'' he said.
But Mr. Wiggins, the education consultant, said Mr. Grumet's observation was true only for the ''very worst and the very best'' students.
''In the middle range you see a tremendous response in many cases to the portfolios,'' he said.
Under Mr. Sobol's plan, the state would ultimately create new standards for passing students through each grade, with a particular emphasis placed on the fourth, eighth and 12th grades. Those are the grades that President Bush and the nation's governors have said should be the target for new national standards in education.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas Sobol, New York State's Education Commissioner, said yesterday that public schools should adopt a far broader measure than standardized tests in assessing student performance. (David Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WINE TALK

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
THE wine on the table was Chateau Bois de Notre Dame, 1970, a Haut-Medoc. Never heard of it? Neither had I. Neither had Orley Ashenfelter, who brought it to the noisy little West Village restaurant.
''Hundred bucks a case at an auction in San Francisco,'' Mr. Ashenfelter said, chuckling.
It was delicious, and at $8 and change for a good 20-year-old wine, he was entitled to be a bit smug. 
But that wasn't why we were there. The idea was to talk about the Ashenfelter Theorem, sometimes referred to as the ''Bordeaux equation.'' Mr. Ashenfelter teaches economics at Princeton, a calling that, to hear him tell it, pays just below a subsistence wage.
Combining a marginal wage and a fondness for claret is no easy task. Mr. Ashenfelter discovered early on that the place to go was the auction hall. Most stories about wine auctions dwell on owners of fast-food franchises who snap up ancient Lafites at $20,000 a bottle. Hardly anyone knows about the genuine bargains that regularly go on the block. Orley Ashenfelter knows. Witness the Bois de Notre Dame. As a wine lover, he had stumbled on a good thing. As an economist, he couldn't leave well enough alone: he had to turn it all into a formula.
It was that formula, or equation, that sent a frisson through the wine world recently when it was outlined in an article in The New York Times.
What Professor Ashenfelter has done is this: create a formula based on winter rainfall and growing-season temperatures in the Bordeaux wine region that, he says, enables him to predict the quality of the annual wine vintages.
For some reason, this rather obvious bit of cerebration has prompted an astonishing outflow of consternation, not to mention indignation, in the wine establishment.
To be sure, Mr. Ashenfelter has fine-tuned his formula and spiced it up with some forbidding jargon. But the fundamental relationship of which he writes, the connection between weather and wine quality, is well known to any fourth grader in the Bordeaux schools.
By applying his formula to the heavy winter rains and exceptionally hot summer of 1989, Mr. Ashenfelter has concluded that the 1989 Bordeaux vintage could be the finest of the century. Well, great, but he's hardly going out on a limb. Everyone in France has been raving about 1989, most of them since last fall when the grapes came in.
So why all the fuss? Two reasons. Some elements of the wine trade are angry because the Ashenfelter equation could be helpful in identifying lesser vintages they have promoted. For example, he is down on 1986, a year praised by more conventional commentators. Mr. Ashenfelter, or at least his numbers, say the vintage will be the worst of the 1980's.
Secondly, and more seriously, he is accused of relegating the whole wine- tasting mystique to a minor role. Supposedly, the sipping, spitting, sniffing and note-taking so dear to wine romantics have all been rendered obsolete by mathematics.
The pessimists are wrong on both counts. In the first place, Mr. Ashenfelter is not doing anything new; he's refining techniques that winegrowers have been using for centuries.
And the tasters are far from obsolete. Mr. Ashenfelter can tell you that 1989 is going to be good. But there are going to be some 89's that are better than others and his formula can't identify them. He can argue that 1986 is poor, but there are some very good 86's and his formula can't single them out.
The professional tasters, those who buy from the chateaus, begin their work in the early spring after the harvest. They already know what the overall quality of the vintage is; their work - deciding which wines to buy, which to reject - is with the individual chateaus.
So, too, the critics, like Robert M. Parker Jr., whose numerical ratings virtually dictate what fine wines are sold in this country. If someone - Mr. Ashenfelter, for example - can help everyone get a better fix on the individual vintages, Mr. Parker's ratings will be more valuable than ever.
A vintage assessment is merely another tool in judging wine. Since there are good wines in poor years and vice versa, the job of the traditional critic will always be important.
The people who worry most about vintages are those who invest in wine futures. They buy early in the expectation that the value of their wine will go up. An early assessment by Mr. Ashenfelter might influence people's decisions to get into the market or not. A few people invest in Burgundy and California but most wine futures business is in Bordeaux.
And what about the good Bordelais? Will a word or a number from Orley Ashenfelter consign whole vintages to the distilleries? Not too likely; much of Mr. Ashenfelter's work was originally done by Bruno Prats, the owner of Chateau Cos d'Estournel.
Mr. Prats has been making calculations like Mr. Ashenfelter's, though admittedly not as precise, for years. So far, his effect on the market has been minimal.
Which brings us back to that bottle of Bois de Notre Dame. Mr. Ashenfelter gives 1970 a quality rating of 43. The control is 1961, with a rating of 100. It was really good, even if neither of us could locate the chateau. Mr. Ashenfelter gives 1989 a rating of - get this -149.
Let's not be angry at him; let's hope he's right. If he is, we're going to be in for some great Bordeaux wine in a few years.
 
TASTINGS
 
Spanna Piemonte 1982, Antonio Vallana; about $7.
The nebbiolo grape is the basis of all the great traditional wines of the Piedmont region of northwestern Italy. ''Traditional'' is the buzzword here because cabernet sauvignon is creeping in at a few of the more pioneering wineries. Fortunately, the Piemontese are conservative and slow to change, so the old-style wines will be around for a long time. Nebbiolo, which comes from the word for fog, is the grape in the greatest Piedmont wines, Barolo and Barbaresco, but it shows up, too, in many lesser-known but marvelous wines like Ghemme, Gattinara and spanna. In fact, spanna is another name for the grape. Because it is still little-known and also, of course, because it is not made with the care of a great barolo, spanna is a fine bargain. This one from Vallana has depth and richness. The finish is a bit rough, but that goes with nebbiolo. The taste is that of a wine at three times the cost. A true bargain.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Where Legends Were Born, Ghosts of Glory Linger

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW

 BODY:
The marquee at the Lyric Theater on West 42d Street often promises ''Two Horrifying Hits.'' But inside, once past the garish posters, the popcorn and video games, a theatergoer can look up at the wide arching ceiling and feel emanations of the performers who once played the Lyric and who helped to make 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues a theatrical crossroads during the early half of this century.
Fred Astaire danced on this stage. The Marx Brothers clowned in ''The Cocoanuts,'' and Douglas Fairbanks performed feats of derring-do. They were all Broadway stars before they went to Hollywood.
Wherever one looks in these theaters, there is a memory or an artifact, followed by nostalgia for a time when the theaters were opulent as well as hospitable. Inside the Lyric and the neighboring theaters, it is possible to feel the colorful presence of a Broadway past. Beneath the peeling paint and crumbling walls there are still remnants of sculptured cherubs, flowery sconces, opera-style box seats and faded murals. 
The area has, of course, gone far downhill. Starting in the late 1920's, with the country struck by the Depression and with the introduction of talking pictures, some of the theaters were converted into movie houses while several turned to burlesque. By 1934, the New Amsterdam was the only one still presenting legitimate plays.
Those still operating today are movie theaters specializing in kung fu and horror films. Some of the theaters are barren and boarded up, but most are still standing. Each has at least a sign of its former splendor, unlike the former theatrical centers on 14th Street and Madison Square, or the first Metropolitan Opera House -historic buildings razed years ago.
The original spirit of the street was partly recaptured in ''Crowbar,'' the Mac Wellman play produced this season by En Garde Arts, which briefly returned the Victory Theater to legitimacy. In slides shown during the performance, one could see the Victory (formerly the Theater Republic) at its height, with formally dressed theatergoers arriving for gala evenings on West 42d Street.
This is an astonishing thought when one considers the prostitution and drug traffic on the street today. But in the 1920's, the Paradise Roof Garden crowned the Victory with a miniature Dutch village complete with water mill, a rooftop space where patrons dined and danced.
Douglas D. Durst, vice president of the Durst Organization, recently led a tour through the Lyric, the Victory and six other theaters, from roof to basement. The Durst Organization held the lease for those buildings until last month when the State Urban Development Corporation took title to a large section of the 42d Street property for a $2.5 billion urban renewal project. Though the urban development project calls for the theaters to be preserved and renovated (and for office towers to be constructed), the future of the theaters still remains in question. Were they to be destroyed, the loss would be irreparable. Despite their dereliction, these theaters have the classic dimensions of their Broadway and London counterparts.
For years, people have been divided about what to do with these buildings. Some planners say the cost of renovation, estimated at $4 million for each theater, would be prohibitive, and they note that there are already Broadway houses in good condition that are empty.
The New York State plan is intended to preserve the theaters, says Frederick S. Papert, the head of the 42d Street Development Corporation, the independent organization that created Theater Row, farther west on 42d Street. Surrounding the theaters with office buildings would make the neighborhood more commercially attractive, Mr. Papert said. He added that he also favored adapting some of the theaters to alternative uses.
Under the plan, the theaters would become a nonprofit cultural center. The New Amsterdam, the most prized of the houses and the only theater of landmark status on the street, would once again become a legitimate theater as would several others. Other buildings would be converted to be used for opera, ballet, rehearsal space, nightclubs, comedy clubs and various business enterprises. Whatever happens to the theaters, some traditional aspects of the street will, of course, never return. On the roof of the Victory, all traces of the Dutch village disappeared long ago. The bare tarred surface is indistinguishable from any tenement roof. Across the street is the New Amsterdam Theater, owned by the Nederlander Organization and for years the home of the ''Ziegfeld Follies.'' One could imagine Florenz Ziegfeld glaring across the street at his rival, David Belasco, in his roof garden. In common, both producers had apartments in their theaters, supposedly reserved for their mistresses.
Belasco's apartment - 3 rms, no vu - still exists, high above an interior cupola in the Victory, but like the building itself it is badly in need of an overhaul. From a window in the apartment, one can peer down to the stage, as Belasco did, to check up on a performance in progress.
From here, it is a long walk down seemingly endless staircases to the dingy basement. Beneath a large trap door are old planks and broken seats and other pieces of unused furniture. There is a general state of dampness in this vault, indicating what was once an underground stream.
Many years ago, Houdini performed in the Victory, and in one of his most famous tricks, he made an elephant vanish. Supposedly, the animal was slipped down this trap door, and then was sneaked out of the theater to be dried off to await the next performance. Deep in the vault, a phantom of the opera might have traveled among subterranean islands. Asked if the stream originally led to the Hudson River, a theater worker said, ''More likely it led to the sewers.'' If so, the phantom might find himself in a rowing competition with the teen-age mutant ninja turtles.
A network of doors and narrow alleys links several theaters so that the entire area has a feeling of catacombs. In towers aligning the walkways are dressing rooms once occupied by performers like George M. Cohan and Lillian Russell.
The history of the theaters and of their time can be traced through programs, reminding theatergoers that in the 1920's tuxedoes cost $50, after-theater suppers were $1.25 and corsets shared advertising space with cigarettes. In the boxes containing Between-the-Acts small cigars, there were collectors' cards illustrating the facades of American theaters, demonstrating that theater was once as popular as baseball.
''The Front Page'' and ''Private Lives'' (starring Noel Coward, Gertrude Lawrence and Laurence Olivier), opened at the Times Square Theater, and Lionel Barrymore portrayed ''Macbeth'' at the Apollo. At the Harris (formerly the Wallack), Lynn Fontanne had her first success in ''Dulcy.'' The Empire was once the Eltinge, named after Julian Eltinge, a foremost female impersonator of his time.
Estelle Winwood and John Drew played in ''The Circle'' at the Selwyn, also the home of the original production of ''The Royal Family.'' At other times, there were performances by Mrs. Patrick Campbell, Beatrice Lillie and Fred Allen. Today the Selwyn is closed. On its marquee, it blithely recommends the attractions at other theaters: ''Enjoy a movie on 42d Street and bring the family.''
The Liberty Theater once housed musical epics like ''The Houseboat on the Styx,'' with its all-star historical cast of more than 70, including representations of such figures as Helen of Troy, Cleopatra, all the wives of Henry VIII, Washington, Napoleon, Sherlock Holmes, Columbus and Shakespeare. Today the Liberty is the most dilapidated of the theaters, with the orchestra almost entirely reduced to rubble. Still hanging is a stage curtain, with a panorama of majestic sailing ships that could have been led by Columbus himself.
A ghostly reminder of theater in its heyday, West 42d Street is a Broadway in exile.

HEADLINE: Getting the Most Out of Byproducts

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 22

 BODY:
General Mills Inc. took Benefit cereal off the market last December when it did not catch on with consumers, leaving the company with 50 tons of unwanted flakes.
But recently General Mills found a more receptive audience for the cereal, made with the grain called psyllium that rated high in fiber, but low in taste. Benefit is being used to fatten up cows and pigs on several South Dakota farms.
The slop trough may seem an ignoble end for a food that had been labored over by product developers and marketers and that cost the company millions to put on supermarket shelves. But General Mills' disposition of the leftover cereal highlights an important, but near invisible, link in the food chain. Food producers' waste and byproducts play a vital role in feeding the nation's livestock. 
No exact figures are available on the size of the highly fragmented byproducts industry. Based on the per-ton price of the individual byproducts, industry experts place annual sales at $5 billion. ''There can be some fairly significant dollars attached,'' said Philip J. Lindau, president of the Pillsbury Company's flour milling and special commodities division.
In 1989, 142 million metric tons of grain were fed to livestock, the Agriculture Department said. Byproducts, or leftovers from milling wheat, crushing soybeans and slaughtering animals, provided another 39 million metric tons of feed.
James E. Cole, an economist with the Agriculture Department, said this was a way for companies to ''minimize their losses, and the farmer to maximize his profits.''
But increasingly, companies, through food alchemy, are trying to salvage their waste, instead of throwing it to the hogs, by converting it into higher-margin products for human consumption. Oat bran and rice bran were used as feeds before the discovery that the grain byproducts could help reduce cholesterol.
''People are much more concerned about human cholesterol than bovine cholesterol,'' said Peter Acly, a spokesman for the Miller Brewing Company.
Miller is one company that is working on converting byproducts into ingredients fit for human consumption. ''What you want to do is upgrade the products to their most beneficial use,'' said Frank Weber, Miller's manager of byproducts. ''In our research efforts we have attempted to look for higher-grade uses.''
The company, for instance, is trying to capitalize on the hundreds of millions of pounds of barley byproduct produced during the brewing process. For years, Miller has been generating millions of dollars of revenue selling its used barley as animal feed. But after years of research, the company has come up with Miller's Barley's Best Bran Flour.
This year, the company plans to sell one million pounds of the flour, which is being used in a bread recently introduced by the Continental Baking Company and in a high-fiber tablet and a high-protein beverage.
But these are exceptions. More typically, remnants of the food-processing operations are shipped off to the nation's feedlots. Little is wasted; bones, blood and feathers are all processed into high-protein meals. There are now experiments under way to use processed poultry litter as a feedstuff.
 
'Not a Pleasant Dinner Topic'
''It's not a terribly pleasant dinner topic,'' said a grain executive knowledgeable about the aftermarket.
Outdated and damaged bakery and dairy products are also processed and recycled as feed.
''John Q. Public doesn't care what happens to stale doughnuts, but among the animal feeders and the bakeries, it is very important,'' said Rolf Peters of the We Toast Bread Company, in Chicago, which converts unusable bakery products into animal feed.
 
A Fairly Routine Path
While it is unusual for an untainted consumer product to be sold as feed, the path General Mills' Benefit followed into the so-called aftermarket was otherwise fairly routine.
John K. McDowell, a grain merchant and cattleman in Lyons, S.D., routinely talks with General Mills officials about grains and byproducts that the big cereal company has for sale. Earlier this year, Mr. McDowell's contact at General Mills mentioned the discontinued Benefit. ''He just kind of brought it up in a conversation,'' Mr. McDowell recalled. ''He said, 'We are taking it off the market for human consumption and we need to do something with it.' ''
Mr. McDowell bought the entire remaining allotment for approximately 3 cents a pound, compared with the 5 cents a pounds for the No. 2 yellow corn that the Benefit is temporarily replacing.
Mr. McDowell's neighbor, a hog farmer, is using a Benefit-laced concoction to wean baby pigs from sow's milk.
Those higher on the food chain, however, never became accustomed to the taste of the Benefit laced with psyllium, which is also a key ingredient in some laxatives. Even R. Craig Shulstad, a General Mills spokesman, acknowledged that ''taste was not a strong selling point'' for Benefit.
In the past, byproducts were simply discarded. The aftermarket gradually developed over the years and took on added importance during the drought of 1988, when normal feed was less available.
 
Monitoring the Aftermarket
In some cases, close monitoring of the aftermarket can provide a clue to the fate of consumer products. Since last summer, the Kellogg Company has been marketing its own psyllium-fortified cereal, called Heartwise. The cereal is selling poorly and there is speculation in the industry that it will soon be withdrawn.
Nancy Roach, a Kellogg spokeswoman, concedes the cereal is not meeting sales expectations, but said that the company remains strongly committed to Heartwise. ''We feel that psyllium will play a very large role in making a contribution to the diet,'' she said.
Nonetheless, Max Busetti, editor of the Food Industry Newsletter in Alexandria, Va., is convinced that Heartwise is doomed. ''I'm just about positive that Heartwise will be shipped to the same hogs,'' he said. ''There are going to be a lot of happy hogs up there.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Frank Weber, right, manager of byproducts at the Miller Brewing Company in Milwaukee, and Vino Chaudhary, principal food technologist, filling bags with Barley's Best Bran Flour. The high-fiber flour is made from barley left over from the brewing process and was once sold only as animal feed. (Jonathan Kirn for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
War Is No Way To Start a Career

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WAR, as everyone knows, is not good for children and other living things. What is more debatable, however, is war's long-term effect on adults who make it back to civilian life.
Studies after World War II showed that soldiers had served themselves by serving Uncle Sam: on average, male veterans have outearned non-veterans by 10 to 20 percent. But soldiers of the Vietnam years have earned 10 to 20 percent less in the civilian job market. 
One often-cited explanation for the contrast is job discrimination. Employers, goes the argument, want nothing to do with those who were exposed to the demoralizing effects of drugs and defeat. Others think the difference in veterans' work experience says more about recruitment than about life in the military. World War II veterans, they argue, were the best and the brightest; in Vietnam the Army was forced to draw disproportionately from the poor and untrained.
Now, two economists, Joshua Angrist of Harvard and Alan Krueger of Princeton, have hit upon an ingenious way to untangle the puzzle. In both wars, they discovered, draft procedures created an arbitrary link between birth dates and the probability of serving in the armed forces. And in both, men with no distinguishing characteristic other than being born on the wrong date earned substantially less in civilian life than men who lucked out.
The Angrist-Krueger analysis of World War II veterans, published as a working paper by the National Bureau of Economic Research, makes use of the fact that draft boards drew on the pool of men in simple chronological order of their birth. Roughly 75 percent of the men born in the first six months of 1926 ended up in the military. Thereafter, the probability declined quarter by quarter: Just 22 percent of those born near the end of 1928 ever served.
It seems unlikely that youth alone was, in itself, a key to success in the postwar labor market. But strikingly, younger workers earned more, strongly suggesting that military service was a handicap. The authors calculate that adjusted for other factors, World War II veterans have earned about 5 percent less over the decades.
Mr. Angrist's study of Vietnam experience, to be published in June in the American Economic Review, exploits an even sharper statistical distinction. During the Vietnam War, birth-date lotteries were used to set draft priorities within each group coming of draft age. In 1971, for example, 20-year-olds born on the first 125 dates chosen like the numbers in Lotto were eligible; the rest were exempt.
Most draft-eligibles never served. Still, draft status made a big difference: Two eligibles in seven ended up in uniform, compared with just one exempt in seven. By matching birth dates with earnings data, Mr. Angrist figures that military service during Vietnam reduced average earnings for white males by about 15 percent. The earnings of non-whites did not seem to be affected.
The enduring psychological damage from combat may play a role for the relatively small percentage of veterans who were ever under fire. But Mr. Angrist's interpretation of the earnings deficit is more straightforward: Skills acquired in the military do not make up for the lost years of civilian experience. Nor, apparently, does that modest privilege of veteran status, G.I. Bill education subsidies.
The trade-off is closer for non-whites, Mr. Angrist speculates, because they entered the Army with fewer skills and left fewer opportunities behind.
The numbers offer a new perspective on an old issue. Americans have long rationalized tight limits on assistance to war veterans on the ground that the time spent in uniform was an advantage in later life. In fact, it appears to be quite costly, at least for men who were not already victims of poverty or discrimination.
The results might also lead to second thoughts about the use of national service as a means of giving the underclass a second chance to gain the discipline needed to succeed in a middle-class world.
Mr. Angrist's numbers suggest no net benefits for recruits who met the Army's minimum standards. Nor does a recently published analysis of the post-military earnings of low-aptitude recruits, admitted to the Army under a special dispensation during the 1960's and 1970's. Indeed, according to the Human Resources Research Organization in Alexandria, Va., veterans of ''Project 100,000'' did less well in the civilian job market than comparably skilled non-veterans.
War may make men out of boys. It does not seem to make them better breadwinners.

HEADLINE: U.S. Investigating Iraq's Purchases of Farm Commodities

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22

 BODY:
The United States Government has found ''possible irregularities,'' which may include kickbacks, in the Iraqi Government's purchases of American agricultural commodities, jeopardizing a $500 million payment guarantee that Iraq has requested from the Commodity Credit Corporation.
The Agriculture Department said on Monday that a team of investigators had returned from Baghdad and reported that Iraq had substantially overpaid American suppliers for sugar, rice and corn. One of the issues is whether the excess funds were used as kickbacks. 
The department asked its Inspector General to investigate the Iraqi Government's requests for ''after sales services'' from American exporters in 1987-89. These services included requests for additional products, the use of designated Iraqi shipping companies and ''cash rebates or discounts.''
''You're dealing with the Middle East, and that's standard operating procedure in some of those countries,'' said an Agriculture Department aide, who asked not to be identified.
Both Administration and Congressional sources said that the Administration had suspended action on Iraq's latest request for a $500 million payment guarantee from the Commodity Credit Corporation, which guarantees loan payments, enabling foreign purchasers of American products to obtain bank financing.
Representative Dan Glickman, a Kansas Democrat who heads the agriculture subcommittee on wheat, soybeans and feed grains, said that ''we have to make sure that the monies were actually used for their intended purpose and not to guarantee the financing of extra services.''
''Members of this committee would be quite upset if the Agriculture Department went ahead with further guarantees until this matter is resolved,'' he added.
Others who have expressed concern are Representative Charles Rose, a North Carolina Democrat who is the chairman of the agriculture subcommittee on tobacco and peanuts, and Representative George E. Brown Jr., a California Democrat who heads the agriculture subcommittee on foreign agriculture.
The Agriculture Department said that the Iraqi Government had instructed all of its state enterprises not to request or accept ''after sales services'' in connection with any future guarantees from the commodity credit agency.
The Bush Administration has thus far refrained from economic action against the Government of Saddam Hussein, despite a growing Congressional effort to impose economic sanctions on Iraq. Bills to impose sanctions are pending in both the House and Senate.
The Agriculture Department's investigation, which was begun last October, was prompted by a Justice Department investigation of the Atlanta branch of Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, which was said to have conducted a clandestine loan operation and had booked more than $2 billion in unauthorized and unreported loans to Iraq. Indictments in the case are expected next month, a Justice Department aide said.
 
Assignment of Proceeds
The Agriculture Department became involved in the Justice Department investigation when Federal investigators and banking officials found that about $750 million of the loans resulted from assignments of letter of credit proceeds for agricultural sales in conjunction with guarantees by the commodity agency.
Iraq has purchased more than $4.5 billion in American agricultural product since 1983, with the aid of payment guarantees from the credit agency, which has lost no money because of its guarantees, since Iraq has repaid all its loans.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Rise in Busy Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose in active trading yesterday, as retail accounts purchased securities after fairly large price declines in recent days.
Buying was touched off early in the session by a report in The Chicago Tribune that $50 billion in unspent funds accumulated by several Federal agencies could be used to reduce the budget deficit.
According to the article, 13 Government agencies, mainly in the defense area, are holding funds in two accounts known as the ''M'' and ''merged surplus'' accounts. The funds have been growing since 1980 and by last year amounted to more than $50 billion, the article said. 
The impact of the report was first seen in the futures trading pits in Chicago, where bond-futures prices moved up strongly. Prices in the cash market for Treasury securities quickly followed.
 
Importance Is Played Down
The importance of the article was played down by Wall Street analysts and by Bush Administration officials. Nevertheless, securities prices remained strong throughout the session.
''The $50 billion the market was focusing on was unspent budget authority,'' said Louis v.B. Crandall, chief economist at R.H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm. ''That is not really cash, but money not spent.''
Analysts at MMS International, an economic information and forecasting firm, noted in their daily market commentary that ''claims in the article that the unspent funds could be used to reduce the deficit were simply untrue.''
''The mystery 'M' and merged-surplus accounts did not represent funds actually spent by the Treasury, only spending which had been authorized,'' they said. ''The Government departments do not have $50 billion in funds which can be transferred to the Treasury to reduce the deficit.''
 
Bargain-Hunting Cited
Traders said that bargain-hunting investors had more to do with the rise in prices than the news report.
''The mood got kind of ugly last Thursday and Friday,'' one government-bond trader said, ''and all of a sudden we were back at levels that we haven't seen since before the producer price numbers were released on May 11. That brought in business.''
Yesterday's price run-up came a day before the Treasury was expected to auction a record $10.8 billion worth of new two-year notes. The notes were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 8.54 percent, down from 8.59 percent late Monday.
Price gains were recorded in all maturities in the secondary market for Treasury securities. By late in the day, the 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at 101 1/2, up 22/32, to yield 8.60 percent. Late Monday, the benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 8.67 percent.
 
Note Issues Rise
Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 17/ 32, up 19/32, to yield 8.64 percent. And the 8 5/8 percent three-year notes were offered at 100 5/32, up 6/32, to yield 8.56 percent.
Treasury bill rates were unchanged to down slightly.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.72 percent, unchanged on the day. Six-month bill rates fell by three basis points, or hundredths of a point, to a late offered rate of 7.74 percent.
In the corporate bond market, the New York State Electric and Gas Company priced a $100 million issue of first-mortgage bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.
The 9 7/8 percent bonds, which mature May 1, 2020, were priced at $98.475 to yield 10.035, 1.43 percentage points higher than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 at the time of pricing.
The issue, which is noncallable for 10 years, is rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by Standard & Poor's.
 
Florida School Bonds
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, Florida School Boards Association Inc. offered $205.84 million of insured lease-revenue bonds through an underwriting group led by Paine Webber.
The bonds, which are insured by Ambac Inc., are rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
The issue consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1991 to 2001, and a term bonds maturing in 2004 and 2005.
Coupons on the serial bonds range from 6.10 percent in 1991 to 7 percent in 2001. The 7 percent term bond maturing in 2004 was priced at $98, to yield 7.22 percent. The 6 1/4 percent bonds maturing in 2005 were priced at $91.50, to yield 7.18 percent.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues rose by between 1/8 point and 3/8 point.
Meanwhile, actively quoted issues in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal securities rose by about 3/8 point, traders said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Mark Trading But Falls Against the Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar gained ground yesterday against most other currencies, particularly the West German mark, which remained under pressure as a result of growing political discord over that country's plans to reunite with East Germany.
While the dollar rose more than a pfennig against the West German mark in New York trading, however, it fell almost two and a half yen against the Japanese currency. Dealers attributed the dollar's drop against the yen largely to comments from Treasury Under Secretary David C. Mulford indicating that a further weakening of the dollar would be acceptable, although not necessarily a remedy to the United States trade deficit. 
Currency dealers said the dollar otherwise benefited from continued weakness in the West German mark amid growing concern about the future of the reunification plan.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government yesterday turned down the opposition Social Democrats' demand for alterations in a newly signed treaty on economic unity with East Germany. The Social Democrats maintain that the new treaty fails to provide enough protection for East German workers and businesses.
The dollar rose in Europe to 1.6685 West German marks, from 1.6630 marks Monday, and to 1.67315 marks in New York from 1.66245.
In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar closed at 152.40 yen, down from 153.25 yen Monday. It traded lower at 151.55 yen in London, and at 151.25 yen in New York, down from 153.73 yen.
The dollar was mixed against the British pound compared with Monday. Sterling bought $1.6915 in London, down from $1.6917, and $1.6930 in New York, up from $1.6875.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.41765 Swiss francs, down from 1.4217; 5.6300 French francs, up from 5.6020; 1,228.00 Italian lire, up from 1,222.50, and 1.18735 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17715.
Gold prices ended higher in New York and in Europe after falling in Asia. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $375.60 a troy ounce, up $2.30 from late Monday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $374.50 an ounce, up $2.15.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $375 an ounce, from $373.25 late Monday. In Zurich, gold rose to $375.35 an ounce from $373.50.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $373.58 an ounce, down from $374.08.
Silver prices increased. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.283 a troy ounce, up from $5.131 Monday. Silver rose in London to $5.19 an ounce, from $5.14 Monday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Cocoa Prices Rise on Fears Of Trouble in Ivory Coast

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Cocoa futures prices rose to 14-month highs yesterday on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York amid fears of supply disruptions from the Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer.
On other commodity markets, copper futures advanced; grains and soybeans were mostly lower; energy futures were mixed, and livestock and meat futures were mixed.
Cocoa futures settled $39 to $45 higher, with the contract for delivery in July at $1,491 a ton, the highest settlement of a near-month cocoa contract since March 15, 1989. 
Prices surged late in the session after a day of erratic price movements that followed a drop of $31 in the July contract on Monday.
Cocoa futures have soared more than $250 a ton in the last two weeks as Government workers in the Ivory Coast have protested wages and living conditions in the West African nation, whose economy has been crippled by last year's collapse in cocoa and coffee prices.
Energy futures ended mixed on the New York Merc ahead of the American Petroleum Institute's weekly stocks report, which showed a sharp rise in American crude oil supplies.
The institute reported crude stocks up 4.4 million barrels in the latest week compared with trade estimates of an increase of no more than 4 million barrels. Gasoline and distillate stocks were within expectations, as was an eight-tenths of a percent increase in refinery activity.
West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 12 cents lower to 10 cents higher, with July at $18.92 a barrel; heating oil futures finished 0.15 cent lower to 0.12 cent higher, with June at 51.40 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.31 cent lower to 0.65 cent higher, with June at 63.04 cents a gallon.
Grain and soybean futures settled mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade, with some corn and soybean contracts up slightly amid fears that planting will be further delayed by rains expected next week in the Midwest.
Cattle and hog futures slipped on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting perceptions that those markets have peaked after strong rallies in recent weeks. Pork bellies advanced amid speculation that a weekly exchange report would show a continued decline in bellies stored in commercial freezers outside Chicago.
