HEADLINE: New Yorkers Trying to Outwit Shrub Rustlers

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
It is that time of year for the community gardeners in Greenwich Village: time to plant, mulch, prune and adjust the chains around the shrubs. Growing things sometimes need a little extra slack. But not too much.
''The Cytisus still seems to have enough room,'' said Mary Emma Harris, eying the steel links entwined in the stems of a Scotch broom shrub in the Sheridan Square Viewing Garden. Next to it was the spot from which an identical shrub, naively left unchained because it was five feet high and five feet wide, was stolen last August.
''It's a shame about the chains,'' she said, ''but the alternative was to give up and plant ivy, and I hate to surrender. At least they seem to be working. A couple of nights this spring the thieves went after a rhododendron and some azaleas, but the chains held.'' 
Casual theft has always been a problem for gardeners - Mother's Day and Easter are traditionally the bleakest times of the year - but the last several years have brought a new wave of larceny. Gardeners and landscapers believe there are professional rustlers out there, fully equipped for large shrubs and small trees. The result has been the new science of floral bondage, which is still in the freewheeling experimental stage.
 
Wearing Barbed Wire
On the Upper East Side, landscapers are planting root balls under wire lattices and are cabling six-foot trees to underground cinder blocks and devices called duckbill anchors. Along Riverside Drive some irate visionaries fantasize about installing alarms, surveillance cameras or radio beepers. On the Lower East Side, the shrubs are wearing barbed wire this spring.
''You can cover the barbed wire with hay or something, or leave it exposed around the stem as a deterrent,'' said Kim Mulcahy, who invented the technique and has been teaching it to community gardeners around the city. ''I show them how to anchor the wire beneath the root ball. I'd rather not talk about the specifics - I don't want the thieves to read about it. Let's just say I advise people on the need to restrain their plants.''
What happens to unrestrained plants when they vanish? Small ones have been spotted for sale on the street, and gardeners suspect that crack addicts are responsible. Small trees and large shrubs are another matter, though. Gardeners have been on the lookout, and the police have conducted overnight stakeouts in Central Park's Conservatory Garden, but so far there are only theories.
Given the inherent difficulties of fencing hot trees and shrubs - they are awkward to store or to break up for parts - gardeners doubt that there is an extensive black market. The best guess is that small-time, economy-minded landscapers are carrying out the thefts before dawn and planting the goods immediately in clients' yards.
 
'Smacks of Professionals'
''It smacks of professionals,'' said Margaret Ternes, executive director of the Park Avenue Malls Planting Project. ''We used to lose a half-dozen plants a summer that ended up on people's window sills, but the past few years it's been different. They took 50 to 60 plants at a time, they knew to go only for the best specimens and -this was the real giveaway - they left wheelbarrow tracks near the median strip.''
Riverside Drive residents reached a similar conclusion when three dozen plants disappeared last summer from the Against All Odds community garden at 101st Street. ''He could spot the expensive stuff no matter how inconspicuous we tried to keep it,'' said Karen Hoodes, referring to the person who stole plants from their gardens, ''and he had a predilection for whites and blues and purples, which leads us to conclude that he was doing it for a specific landscaping project.''
The telltale clue in Central Park was the uprooting technique used last summer, when more than 100 shrubs and plants were taken from the fenced Conservatory Garden at 105th Street.
''We lost a variegated ornamental grass that was huge - five feet tall with a root ball that probably weighed 30 pounds,'' said Lynden B. Miller, the garden's director. ''They removed it without leaving any mess at all, and that's a sign of professionals. It raises my ire no end. If I could get my hands on those people, I'd shake them till their teeth rattle and fall out.''
It is tempting, when confronted with a rhododendron in chains, to conclude that something has gone wrong in New Yorkers' relationship with nature. But maybe it is actually a sign of increased devotion. Charitably minded horticulturists suggest that New Yorkers' increasing fondness for greenery is stimulating the thieves by creating more demand as well as more supply.
''There are more places to steal from,'' Mrs. Miller said, ''because the city is getting more and more beautiful, thanks to the community gardens and the restorations in the parks and the sidewalk plantings. People have more appreciation for plants today, and it's important to remember that in general the public has been wonderful at respecting public gardens.''
 
Perilous Times
Except, of course, at those certain times of the year. ''I have four sons,'' Mrs. Miller said, ''but no one in our home is ever allowed to mention Mother's Day.'' Other gardeners have been known to anticipate that day by pinning a note to a rosebush announcing, ''If you steal these flowers, your mother will die.''
Last summer, when large shrubs kept disappearing throughout the summer at the Conservatory Garden, the curator, Sarah Price, turned to the police. Their first response, she recalled, was, ''Hey, lady, it's a plant.'' Then the police agreed to spend several nights inside the six-acre garden waiting for thieves.
''They didn't catch anyone,'' Ms. Price said, ''but their presence seemed to be a deterrent because the rash of thefts stopped. It was very nice of the police. I can understand why these crimes don't have high priority, but I do think it's a quality-of-life issue. We can't let the thieves take over the jewel of Central Park.''
Commercial landscapers say their work gets stolen all over the city as well as in the suburbs. Dimitri Gravanis, who runs Dimitri's Garden Ltd. at 1572 Second Avenue, near 82d Street, lost a $4,000 tree last year from his own yard in Teaneck, N.J. It was a dwarf maple, six feet high with a six-foot spread, that he had not bothered to anchor.
''I've started advising all our customers to anchor trees and shrubs in exposed places,'' said Mr. Gravanis's son, Basil. ''We use a duckbill anchor that snaps open after you bury it five feet deep. Usually we keep the cable or the chain beneath the surface. You have to consider the esthetics.'' Esthetics or Security? But occasionally esthetics must be sacrificed, even on the Upper East Side. Patricia Taylor Buckley, the wife of the writer and editor William F. Buckley Jr., has been fighting a long battle to keep a pair of small fir trees flanking their front door off Park Avenue.
''First we put the trees in big stone Grecian urns, and the thieves just came along and took them,'' she said. ''After we lost four of them, I tried cementing the urns to the sidewalk. So they just sawed off the urns at the base. They'd come in the middle of the night - I got so paranoid that I'd hear something and run down the staircase at 4 in the morning and turn on the searchlight, but I could never catch them.''
Next, Mrs. Buckley switched from Grecian urns to three-foot-square wooden tubs. ''I cemented the tubs to the sidewalk, so they just dug up the trees and left the tubs behind,'' she said. ''But now I think I've finally beaten them. I found some trees that nobody would ever want to steal. They're terribly scraggly things surrounded by rather dreadful looking ivy, but at least they're mine.''

HEADLINE: SAVINGS FAILURES EXPECTED TO SOAR, THE TREASURY SAYS

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
The Administration told Congress today that more than 1,000 savings and loan associations - 40 percent of the industry - might eventually have to be seized by the Government, twice the number it had initially projected.
Blaming rising interest rates and sizable areas of weakness in the nation's real estate markets, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told the Senate Banking Committee that based on the new projection the $73 billion that Congress appropriated for the bailout last year would have to be raised at least to $89 billion, and perhaps to as high as $130 billion.
''It is now clear that the amounts projected and authorized will fall short of what is required,'' Mr. Brady said.
 
A Shift in Position
Mr. Brady's testimony represented an extraordinary admission by the Administration, which for more than a year has insisted that there was no compelling reason to change its estimates of the cost of the biggest financial debacle in the nation's history, even though private analysts were warning that the Treasury's original numbers were woefully inadequate.
''Reality has arrived and we should be thankful for it,'' said Bert Ely, a financial consultant based in Alexandria, Va. ''The Treasury has put realistic numbers on the table.'' 
But the figures Mr. Brady gave today represent only a portion of the overall cost of the cleanup. They do not include the cost of the deals struck in 1988 for the sale of more than 200 institutions before the bailout law was passed. And, citing the same economic factors, a top regulator admitted today that those costs are also rising. [Page D20.] The new estimates also do not include the huge amounts of interest the taxpayers will have to pay to finance the bailout.
When those are added in, the total cost of the bailout to the taxpayer and the industry could easily exceed $250 billion over the next 10 years, and approach $500 billion over 30 years. Last month, the General Accounting Office said the cost of the bailout including interest would range from $325 billion to $500 billion.
Mr. Brady said his agency did not include the interest costs because such costs are not included in accounting for Government programs. ''It would be like saying that the $30 billion Kennedy space program actually cost $92 billion,'' he said.
Today's estimates were arrived at differently from the $61 billion that Administration officials estimated on Tuesday would be added to next fiscal year's budget deficit because of the bailout.
 
Getting the Bad News Out
Some experts were surprised that the Treasury was willing to paint such a grim picture. ''I think the word must have come down that Brady get the bad news out once and for all and not run the risk that as 1992 approaches they have to change their numbers again,'' said one industry expert who asked not to be identified.
The clear message from Mr. Brady and the Administration was that Congress would need to appropriate large sums of additional money to guarantee that insured depositors not lose any money. Mr. Brady said he would support either an open-ended appropriation or a set figure, whichever the Congress wanted. But he warned that since the cost of the bailout is a moving target, a specific figure might prove to be inadequate and Congress might find it would have to take up the issue again.
The savings and loan industry ran into deep troubles in the mid-1980's as the result of slack regulation at the Federal and state levels and highly speculative investments in real estate by savings and loan entrepreneurs whose lending practices bordered on the fraudulent.
The debacle created billions of dollars of losses for depositors. The Government, which is obligated to cover losses on insured deposits, is now making good on those guarantees. Mr. Brady stressed today that management and stockholders were not being bailed out but that depositors were being rescued.
 
Bailout Officials Attend
Mr. Brady testified as chairman of the Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created last year to oversee the bailout. He appeared with the four other board members: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman; Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and two members from the private sector, Robert C. Larson, a real estate specialist, and Philip C. Jackson, a former Federal Reserve official.
The new estimates also come at a time of delicate budget negotiations between the White House and Congress. The Administration has said that the soaring cost of the bailout has been a driving force behind its desire to get a budget agreement.
Mr. Brady said the biggest contributors to the rise in costs have been higher interest rates and the weak real estate markets. Both factors are sending more savings units into insolvency and making it harder to find buyers for either their assets or their branch offices.
''Thrifts are just not as attractive a franchise relative to banks as they once were,'' Mr. Brady said.
 
Accounting for the Deficit
One issue that Mr. Brady and others will have to solve is how, on a budgetary basis, the Government should treat the high costs of the cleanup, as well as the large volumes of interim financing, often referred to as working capital, the trust corporation needs. The issue is what portion of the costs to count as part of the Federal deficit.
Mr. Brady said he would support keeping the working capital off budget, and thus not counted in the deficit, since it is used to pay off depositors after an institution is seized. Once the Government liquidates the assets of an institution, often in a later fiscal period, it recovers large amounts of the money that it borrowed to pay the depositors. Such transactions produce swings that tend to skew the budget picture.
Mr. Brady did say that the Government should count as part of the deficit any payments to depositors that are not ultimately covered by the sale of assets. But he said he would leave to the budget negotiators the issue of whether the bailout costs should be used in calculating whether the deficit is meeting the budget targets of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law.
The latest numbers are likely to confuse the public, since industry experts, academics, regulators, members of Congress and the General Accounting Office have issued sharply varying projections.
 
Projections by Category
The projections have basically fallen into three categories.
One measures the problem in terms of what it would cost today to cover the losses of depositors' money, ''As if you could write a check and solve the entire problem right now,'' a senior Treasury official said.
Last year, the Treasury said that $50 billion would be enough for the Resolution Trust Corporation to handle failures between August 1989 and August 1992, and another $23 billion would cover failures after that. It has now expanded that estimate so that in the most optimistic case the cost would be $89 billion, and in the worst case, if real estate prices continue to be depressed, it would cost $130 billion.
Other projections, including those of the Office of Management and Budget, have calculated how much the bailout would cost, including interest on borrowings over the next 10 and 30 years. Last year, the 10-year cost was put at $159 billion, while the 30-year cost was estimated to be more than $250 billion.
But Mr. Greenspan said today that the numbers projected by the Treasury implied even higher overall costs than the $320 billion to $500 billion in the G.A.O.'s most recent projections.
Perhaps the most graphic illustration of the huge upward adjustment by the Treasury was its projection that in the worst case as many as 1,037 savings and loan institutions with $530 billion in assets might have to be seized before the Resolution Trust Corporation completes its work in August 1996.
But Mr. Greenspan did not seem overly concerned about the higher figures. He said he did not expect that the extra borrowing implied by the higher cost estimates would have much of an effect on credit markets.
''In and of itself, it should not affect interest rates,'' he said.
 
Survivors and Casualties
A new calculation by the Office of Thrift Supervision divides the savings industry into four categories of comparative health.
One group covers 1,267 well-capitalized and profitable institutions, with assets of $399 billion. A second group comprises 621 institutions, with $327 billion in assets, that are expected to meet the new capital requirements. Few if any of these are expected to fail.
A third group comprises 315 savings associations, with assets of $152 billion that are troubled by poor earnings and low capital levels. The fourth group covers 299 institutions, with $193 billion in assets, and they are expected to fail.
In the worse-case projection, all the institutions in the last two groups would fail.

HEADLINE: Pierre Rinfret, Economist, Chosen By G.O.P. to Run Against Cuomo

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
After months of searching, New York State Republican leaders last night selected an economist who has never run for public office to be their party's candidate for governor.
The candidate, Pierre Rinfret, is almost certain to be ratified at the Republican state nominating convention in Rye next week.
Republican leaders described the 66-year-old Mr. Rinfret as an enthusiastic, articulate, wealthy, knowledgeable economist who can make an issue of the state's fiscal problems and raise enough money to wage a credible, if uphill, campaign against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
The Manhattan resident, who was an unpaid economic adviser to three Presidents, John F. Kennedy, Lyndon B. Johnson and Richard M. Nixon, heads Rinfret Associates, an economic consulting firm in Manhattan. ''He is as clean as a whistle,'' a Republican leader said. 
Party leaders were repeatedly rebuffed by potential candidates in awe of the $8 million Cuomo campaign treasury and the Democratic Governor's high standing in polls, at least earlier this year.
Also considered was Mr. Cuomo's reputation as one of the best public speakers in the country and as someone whose supporters do not hesitate to bloody an opponent and his image. Four years ago, Mr. Cuomo's supporters tore into Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican candidate, over his income tax returns.
In addition, the reluctant Republicans were skeptical of the impoverished New York Republican Party, which has repeatedly left its statewide candidates in the fiscal lurch in the last 10 years.
Republican leaders had scrambled to put together a state ticket before the Memorial Day weekend. Mr. Rinfret and another wealthy Republican, John L. Loeb Jr., a former ambassador to Denmark, were recruited as prospects in the last 36 hours by the Manhattan Republican chairman, State Senator Roy M. Goodman. But Mr. Rinfret (pronounced rin-FRAY) won out.
They were, by one count, the 16th and 17th Republicans to be considered as challengers of Governor Cuomo.
The urgency was dictated by the scheduled start of the Republican state nominating convention next Tuesday. Veteran politicians could not remember state party leaders, Democratic or Republican, taking so long to select a favored gubernatorial candidate before a convention.
A spokeswoman for Mr. Rinfret, Deborah Ishlon, said early yesterday afternoon that ''he has expressed interest in the idea but there are a number of questions and issues to be resolved.'' Although Mr. Rinfret agreed to be photographed at his Fifth Avenue home last night, he gave no further response to requests for comment.
 
Born in Montreal
Mr. Rinfret was born in Montreal and raised in New York City, earning degrees from City College and New York University and a doctorate in political economics from the University of Dijon in France. In World War II, he was awarded a Bronze Star and Purple Heart during service with the Third Army in Europe. He and his wife, Aida, have been married for 41 years and have two grown children.
Mr. Rinfret heads a firm that specializes in economic and business information and trading of government bonds, gold, silver and futures. ''He is personally very affluent and comes well connected,'' said one Republican leader.
His political experience has been at the national level as an economic adviser to the Nixon campaigns in 1968 and 1972. He has not been identified with the New York Republican Party except as a contributor.
 
A Feverish Day
His selection ended a feverish day in which Mr. Goodman and J. Patrick Barrett, the Republican state chairman, met with both Mr. Rinfret and Mr. Loeb and conferred by telephone with various Republican leaders.
Both Mr. Goodman and Mr. Barrett had strong reservations about the statewide stature and fund-raising capability of another possible candidate, Herbert London, a dean at New York University who ran briefly for mayor of New York City last year. He was a rare Republican willing to run and has the support of the Conservative Party.
Mr. Rinfret was described by another Republican leader as favoring abortion rights, a position that could be a problem for the anti-abortion Conservatives. Michael Long, the Conservative Party leader, could not be reached for comment at his home last night.
The two Republican leaders, Mr. Barrett and Mr. Goodman, were serving as representatives of four other Republican county chairmen who joined the recruiting effort when Mr. Barrett failed to enlist a candidate.
The other Republican leaders involved are Assemblyman John C. Cochrane of Suffolk County; Anthony J. Colavita of Westchester County, who was Mr. Barrett's predecessor in the party post; Presiding Supervisor Joseph N. Mondello of Nassau County and Thomas Reynolds, the new Erie County Republican chairman. The 300-member Republican State Committee will actually nominate the state ticket at the convention.
 
Candidates for Other Jobs
The party leaders hope to find candidates for lieutenant governor and state attorney general today or tomorrow. There is only one Republican state incumbent, Comptroller Edward V. Regan, who is seeking re-election.
The party leaders are likely to encounter reluctant candidates for these posts, too. Several have suggested that a woman be nominated for lieutenant governor.
One of those mentioned, Diane McGrath-McKechnie, who was defeated for New York City mayor in 1985, said she would prefer to seek the state chairmanship if Mr. Barrett stepped aside. He has been blamed by some party leaders for what they freely admit has become a public-relations and political debacle.
Robert R. McMillan of Nassau County, who was defeated in a race for the United States Senate in 1988, has been frequently mentioned as an attorney general prospect, but he too said he would rather seek the state chairmanship if Mr. Barrett resigns.

HEADLINE: House, 401-21, Votes to Widen Clean Air Curbs

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
The House of Representatives late tonight overwhelmingly approved the first major overhaul of environmental laws in 13 years, rebuffing warnings from the White House that some provisions were ''unnecessarily costly.''
Before the 401-to-21 vote, lawmakers resolved several lingering items, passing provisions for a program to assist workers whose jobs would be affected by the measure, a pilot program requiring the sales of alternative-fuel cars in Southern California, and expanded warranties for emission-control equipment.
Representative John D. Dingell, the chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, whose decision to compromise on many elements of the legislation cleared the way for passage, said after the vote that the bill was ''a good piece of legislation'' but that it would take a toll on the public.
''Everybody is going to find out that clean air is not free,'' said the Michigan Democrat. ''There are enormous costs in terms of jobs.'' 
 
Estimates of $20 Billion a Year
The bill, which by some estimates would cost industry $20 billion a year, would greatly strengthen the Clean Air Act of 1970, with broad new air quality standards, curbs on automobile emissions, requirements for the sale of cleaner-burning fuels and a program to cut emissions that cause acid rain. Representatives from industry and environmental groups say neither the House nor the Senate version of the legislation is particularly stronger than the other, although there are some differences in specific provisions. The Senate version was approved last month.
Despite earlier warnings that he would recommend a veto of amendments that the House approved today, John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, said he would urge Mr. Bush to support the package.
 
'A Lot of Fine Tuning'
Mr. Sununu said that while he preferred elements of the version passed by the Senate, he was optimistic that provisions opposed by the Administration would be deleted when the measure goes to a House-Senate conference.
''There's a lot of fine-tuning that has to be done,'' Mr. Sununu said in an interview. ''On the principles of the bill, most of what is coming out is consistent with the President's approach. Our recommendation is to proceed to the Senate and House conference.''
Mr. Dingell, commenting on the bill's prospects in negotiations between the chambers, said: ''You're going to see a very interesting conference where the results are difficult to predict.''
 
Environmentalists Welcome Bill
Environmental groups welcomed passage of the bill tonight, but they were restrained in their comments.
''If the conferees choose the best parts of the two bills, they can fashion a good law and the nation will benefit,'' said Richard E. Ayres, chairman of the National Clean Air Coalition, which represents several organizations supporting stronger environmental laws. ''If, on the other hand, they choose the weakest portions of the two bills, the result will delay unacceptably the pollution control needed to protect public health.''
Industry groups said they would press for many changes when the legislation goes to conference.
Thomas R. Kuhn, president of the Edison Electric Institute, which represents electric companies, said tonight, ''Although specific compromises were reached which address some of our concerns, issues are still pending which could increase the five to seven billion-dollar price tag for electric consumers.''
While it took six weeks of floor fights in the Senate to pass the bill, the House acted quickly, resolving most of the disputes in private negotiations. The measure was not introduced in the House until Monday.
 
Debate Was Heated
After a heated debate that focused not on the environment but on economics, the House rebuffed pressure from the White House and from industry, passing a measure that would provide $250 million in unemployment and retraining benefits for workers who lose their jobs because of the law.
The amendment, sponsored by Representative Bob Wise, Democrat of West Virginia, was approved in a vote of 274 to 146, although a broader assistance program proposed by Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, failed by one vote in the Senate. The measure was intended to help an estimated 5,000 coal miners who could lose their jobs because of the tougher acid rain provisions in the House bill.
''We've taken care of industry's interests, we've taken care of the environmental interests,'' Mr. Wise said. ''And it's time to take care of the people's interests.''
The workers' compensation amendment was of particular concern to Administration officials. In a letter Tuesday to House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Mr. Sununu and William K. Reilly, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, warned that the provision ''would open a multibillion-dollar deficit-increasing door that may never be closed.'' The two men raised their concerns in a meeting this morning with House Republicans.
But in the interview later in the day, Mr. Sununu backed off from suggestions that the amendment would prompt a Presidential veto.
 
Approval on Warranties
The House also approved an amendment that would lengthen the warranties that parts and vehicle manufacturers must provide for emission-control equipment. Under the provision, the manufacturer, rather than the car buyer, is liable for many of the repairs of pollution-control equipment. A similar provision is contained in the Senate bill.
''This amendment insures that neither consumers nor the environment gets stuck with the bill for faulty equipment and that independent garages get a fair break,'' said Representative Gerry Sikorski, a Minnesota Democrat and a chief sponsor of the amendment.
A potentially serious jurisdictional dispute was averted when the House rejected an amendment by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois and chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, that would have deleted user fees and tariffs from many of the bill's provisions. Mr. Rostenkowski had contended that the provisions were taxes and should have come under his committee's authority.
Another point of contention that was resolved earlier today and passed by a wide margin was an amendment that would reduce production of chlorofluorocarbons and other chemicals that destroy the ozone layer.
 
Final Point of Contention
It was not until late tonight, in a deal brokered by Speaker Foley, that an agreement was reached on the last point of contention that was the subject of vigorous negotiations throughout the day: The deal diluted a requirement co-authored by Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, that automobile manufacturers each year produce a million vehicles that burn a cleaner fuel, beginning in the middle 1990's in the nation's most polluted cities.
The Waxman plan was opposed by Representative Dingell, who is a staunch ally of the automobile industry. And, although a clean-fuel vehicle provision was contained in the Administration's original clean air proposal, Mr. Sununu said the House plan went too far in dictating certain types of fuels that would have to be used by the cars.
Specifically, in the agreement reached tonight, the amendment would strike the requirement that a million clean-fuel vehicles be produced each year and instead establish a pilot program under which 150,000 cars that use alternative fuel would have to be sold in Southern California in 1994. The number would increase to 300,000 new cars a year beginning in 1997.
After the vote tonight, Mr. Waxman cited the clean-vehicle measure as perhaps the most significant in the legislation. ''It is a foot in the door,'' he said. ''California will lead the way. I think the rest of the country will be following our example.''
Despite Mr. Waxman's optimism, the Clean Air Working Group, a coalition of business and trade associations, expressed serious reservations about the overall legislation. ''The air quality debate in Congress is ignoring the simple guideline that new legislation be both effective and affordable,'' said William D. Fay, administrator of the organization.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Moscow Favors Speedy Talks

DATELINE: GENEVA, May 23

 BODY:
The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said today that Moscow favors speeding up work at the conventional arms reduction talks in Vienna.
The Soviet official's remarks appeared at least partly aimed at American and NATO officials who have been complaining in recent days of Soviet foot-dragging in Vienna. 
Mr. Shevardnadze spoke to reporters after meeting with the West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, at the large Soviet diplomatic mission here. The two officials said they had touched on a wide range of issues between the two countries, including Soviet security concerns about a reunited Germany, economic relations and scientific and technical exchanges.
The Kremlin insists that a unified Germany not be part of NATO, a demand rejected by the West German Government and the other NATO allies.
The two Foreign Ministers did not report any progress on that issue, but they did agree on the conventional arms talks.
''We advocated an acceleration of the Vienna negotiations''
Mr. Shevardnadze said. ''We don't have much time.''
The aim of the Vienna talks is a treaty substantially shrinking the armies in Europe, along with the tanks, airplanes and other non-nuclear gear. Both the United States and the Soviet Union have indicated that the treaty should be completed in time for a meeting of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe tentatively scheduled for December in Paris.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Talks on Broader U.S.-Soviet Airline Service Stall on Currency

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
Negotiations on expanded airline service between the United States and the Soviet Union have stalled over economic issues, dashing hopes that an agreement could be signed at the summit meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, American officials say.
Serious disagreements surfaced in April over what currency American airlines would use when selling their tickets and paying their costs in the Soviet Union, said officials involved in the discussions, which began last December and initially made rapid headway.
The Soviet negotiators are demanding economic conditions that would gain them valuable dollars but would restrict American airlines' ability to profit from the growing demand for travel by Soviet citizens to the United States, the officials said.
The aviation agreement was discussed again last week during the trip to Moscow by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. But Bush Administration officials and airline representatives said that the Soviet negotiators remain intractable and that the agreement cannot be concluded before the summit, which begins when President Gorbachev arrives in Washington on May 30. 
 
'A Tremendous Opening'
''It would be a tremendous opening in the market if it happened,'' an American official said of the proposed expansion of air service. ''But the point is, you can have all this authority to fly, but if U.S. carriers can't make a profit in the Soviet Union it isn't worth anything.''
The officials said that they continued to hope that an agreement can be reached eventually, but that it is already too late for a pact to make much difference in this year's tourist trade.
An agreement would open new Pacific service and expand Atlantic routes between the two nations, whose bilateral air traffic is limited to a few flights each week by Pan Am and Aeroflot, serving only Moscow, Leningrad, New York and Washington.
The new agreement would allow up to six American passenger and freight lines to fly to the Soviet Union, and would let Moscow expand Aeroflot's schedule or establish new airlines to compete with Aeroflot on American routes.
 
Politically Sensitive Route
An agreement would bring new service to several cities: Anchorage, San Francisco, Chicago and Miami, along with the Ukrainian city of Kiev, Magadan and Khabarovsk in the Soviet Far East, Tbilisi in Soviet Georgia and Riga in Latvia.
Selecting the cities caused little dispute between the two sides, and like other broad terms of the agreement that provision was settled on in February.
Only lately have some American officials wondered whether the Riga route might be politically sensitive, because of the implications of reaching a trade agreement with Moscow involving a Baltic republic during the debate over Baltic independence.
The officials said they did not expect Riga to be an obstacle to an eventual agreement. Like other bilateral international aviation agreements, that one would not require approval by the Senate.
 
Dollar-Ruble Dispute
American officials had been very optimistic about the talks, especially when they heard Soviet officials speaking about building a new airline to compete with Aeroflot, a prospect that was taken as a sign of movement toward market economics.
But the dispute over currency suggests that the Soviet side continues to view the airline business as a way of obtaining hard currency under tight economic controls.
The currency issue is paramount to the American airlines that would seek to fly on the new routes. American Airlines, Northwest Airlines, Delta Air Lines, United Airlines, Pan Am and Alaska Airlines, along with charter airlines and freight companies, have been closely watching the talks, which are handled by the State Department with advice from an industry representative.
The Soviets want the American airlines to sell tickets only for dollars, which severely restricts their access to the biggest and fastest growing segment of the aviation market between the two nations: Soviet citizens, who possess only rubles.
 
Competition With Aeroflot
With the relaxation of emigration and travel rights for Soviet citizens, there are now twice as many Soviet citizens flying between the two countries as there are Americans, although American business and tourist travel to the Soviet Union is also growing. According to estimates, 140,000 people flew between the two countries on Pan Am and Aeroflot in 1989; other travelers went through third countries en route to and from the Soviet Union.
The Soviets also want the American airlines to pay in dollars for all their expenses in the Soviet Union, like food services, fuel, rent and labor. Because of the inflated official exchange rate, that is costly to the American companies.
The Americans want permission to sell tickets directly to Soviet citizens, who would pay in rubles. The airlines then would spend the rubles in the Soviet Union to pay their operating expenses, bypassing the costly artificial exchange rate. That would also put the airlines in direct competition with the inefficient state-owned airline, Aeroflot.

HEADLINE: DIPLOMATIC BATTLE WAGED ON KASHMIR

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, May 23

 BODY:
On the day this week that the spiritual leader of thousands of Kashmiri Muslims was shot dead by unknown assassins, India's special minister for Kashmir, George Fernandes, was on his way to Cairo to deliver a letter to President Hosni Mubarak.
Mr. Fernandes arrived on the heels of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, who has just completed an eight-nation tour of the Islamic Middle East. She was asking for Islamic solidarity against India.
An Indian-Pakistani diplomatic war, fought by envoys from Washington to Beijing, has been gaining intensity over several months. But so far it has been a war of accusations rather than a debate over objectives. What each side wants, and why, is not always clear to governments outside this region, diplomats say. A Campaign of Repression? Islamic Pakistan asserts that India has unleashed a military campaign of repression against the Muslim majority in the Kashmir Valley, where alienation from New Delhi has been growing for three years and where many people want to exercise the right, denied them for 40 years, to choose whether they want to be part of India. 
This week those charges were intensified as Indian paramilitary forces fired into a crowd of mourners carrying the body of the slain Muslim cleric, Maulvi Mohammed Farooq, from the hosptial to his religious headquarters in Srinigar, the capital of Kashmir, on Monday. Dozens of people died.
In Srinagar today, witnesses told reporters that there had been no exchange of fire between troops and militants, as Indian authorities have insisted in describing the troops' action as self-defense.
In New Delhi, officials regard the question of Kashmir's future a matter over which there can be no debate. The problem, they say, has become simply one of Pakistani support for armed militants. They say that until Islamabad stops that support, there can be no hope of negotiations inside Kashmir or with Pakistan.
 
Three Border Wars
But beneath the surface, politicians on both sides of the border say, there are other motivations and other reasons for the standoff between two countries that have fought three wars along the Kashmir border.
In Pakistan, resentment has festered for nearly 20 years over India's support for a Bengali Muslim independence movement that in 1971 - with the help of the invading Indian Army -created Bangladesh out of what had been East Pakistan.
Over the last decade, not only Pakistan, but also Bangladesh, Nepal and Sri Lanka have watched as India backed other guerrilla armies in the region, most prominently the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam in the Sri Lankan Northeast. Indian intelligence agencies have also supported guerrilla groups in the Chittagong Hills in Bangladesh. Pakistan fears Indian influence in its already troubled province of Sind.
 
A Chance for Revenge
''So here in Kashmir, Pakistan has the perfect opportunity to pay us back,'' an Indian politician said. ''They have only to give enough support to keep an insurgency running for a long time.''
For India, the Kashmir situation is fraught with so much potential danger that the Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh seems unwilling or unable to gamble on bold political moves - including opening the border between Indian Kashmir and the Pakistani part of the region or talking with Islamabad about how to build a new political entity in Kashmir that would satisfy both countries. India seems intent on crushing the revolt by force before looking for the roots of the problem.
The Singh Government is supported by a Hindu-based party that includes people willing to press a case against Muslims anywhere.
The Kashmir Valley is only about a third of India's Jammu and Kashmir state, and the only Islamic area -Jammu is largely Hindu and Ladakh is Buddhist. But Kashmir's population is large enough to make Jammu and Kashmir the only Indian state with a Muslim majority. It is important to India's image as a secular nation with religious freedom to have a predominantly Muslim state.
Furthermore, in India, religion is an explosive subject even in normal times. There is always the danger that the crisis in Kashmir will set off conflagrations elsewhere. Several thousand people died at the hands of Hindu mobs last fall in several Indian states because of a dispute over a mosque in Ayodhya over which Hindus wanted to construct a temple.
 
Economic and Political Issues
Kashmiris argue, however, that their problems with India are not religious, but economic and political. They and their supporters in Pakistan accuse India of emphasizing their religion in order to undermine their cause in the West, where Asian Muslims often believe there is a prejudice against them.
The Kashmir Valley, which India had been developing as one of its prime tourist areas, suffered from a low investment level in industry, gorwing unemployment, poor communications, limited air services and inadequate roads connect it with to the rest of India. People here have come to believe that the produce of their orchards and farms might move more quickly through Pakistan.
Buddhists Ladakhis have similar complaints. Apricots not available anywhere in Indian cities ripen and rot on Ladakhi hillsides for lack of refrigerated airfreight services.
Under Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and her son and successor, Rajiv, New Delhi began interfering with Kashmir's internal politics, ultimately dominating the National Conference, the last Kashmiri party with any claim to Kashmiri nationalism. As a result, many Kashmiris were pushed outside mainstream politics. A 1987 state election, which more or less everyone admits was rigged in favor of Mr. Gandhi's Congress Party and its National Conference allies, provided recruits for new militant groups.
An Indian attack on Pakistan will not solve these problems, say citizens groups here and in Islamabad who are beginning to fear an accidental war that neither side wants. Both sides accuse each other of massing troops. Both fear the coming of summer, when snows melt in the border mountain ranges and a season conducive to both military maneuvers and guerrilla infiltration begins.

PUB-DATE: May 24, 1990,

SECTION: Section A; Page 11, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 680 words

HEADLINE: House Moves to Free Nicaragua and Panama Aid

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
The House of Representatives took steps today to make sure the United States could soon provide economic aid to Nicaragua and Panama, despite uncertainty over the future of military aid to El Salvador.
On Tuesday night, the House voted down a bill authorizing funds for all three countries. But the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, said today that Congress would use another vehicle, an ''emergency supplemental appropriations'' bill, to send money to the new Governments led by President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro in Nicaragua and President Guillermo Endara in Panama.
The House and the Senate have passed different versions of the appropriations bill. Negotiators from the two chambers have drafted a compromise version scheduled to come up for final approval in the House on Thursday. 
House Democrats said they did not want to expose themselves to further criticism from President Bush, who has repeatedly complained that the Democrats were delaying assistance for Nicaragua and Panama.
Ordinarily a money bill requires a separate prior authorization bill, to provide legal authority to spend the money. But senior Congressional Democrats said they were willing to waive the requirement so they could send the money bill to Mr. Bush before the Memorial Day recess.
The bill includes the full $300 million requested by Mr. Bush for Nicaragua and $420 million of the $500 million he sought for Panama.
On Tuesday, acting on a separate authorization bill, the House voted 250 to 163 in favor of an amendment that would halve United States military aid to El Salvador. But minutes later, in a surprise move, the House voted down the overall bill, 244 to 171. The defeat was insured by Republicans and moderate Democrats who dislike the restriction in military aid to El Salvador; liberals who wanted even more severe restictions, and people from both parties unenthusiastic about foreign aid in general.
Efforts to cut miliary aid to El Salvador have gained momentum because of Congressional doubts about whether the Government of President Alfredo Cristiani will identify and prosecute all the people responsible for the killings of six Jesuit priests in San Salvador in November. Military aid to El Salvador totals $85 million this year.
The fight over Salvadoran aid will soon resume as Congress drafts foreign aid legislation for the fiscal year 1991, which begins Oct. 1.
Mr. Foley said today that the vote on El Salvador was ''a watershed'' in the evolution of United States policy toward that country. ''Almost certainly,'' he said, ''military aid will be curtailed in some form in the future.''
Democrats say that such restrictions would provide new incentives to President Cristiani and the guerrillas to negotiate an end to the decade-long war. The vote Tuesday suggests that a solid majority of House members now favor such restrictions. Indeed, many Republicans in Congress and the Bush Administration said they too would accept some new restrictions on aid, linking it to the behavior of the guerrillas and the Salvadoran armed forces.
The vote on Salvadoran aid highlighted a split between liberals and moderates in the Democratic Party. Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma organized a group of moderate House Democrats who voted against final passage of the foreign aid bill on the ground that Congress should work with the Administration in a bipartisan manner to forge a new policy toward El Salvador.
Mr. McCurdy said, ''Our assistance to El Salvador should contain conditions.'' But now is an ''inopportune moment'' to withhold 50 percent of the military aid funds, just as the Salvadoran Government and the rebels are trying to negotiate a cease-fire, he said.
Moderate Democrats from Georgia, Louisiana, Texas, North Carolina and other states joined Mr. McCurdy in voting against the overall foreign aid bill.
Several House committee chairmen, including Les Aspin of Wisconsin, Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois and G. V. (Sonny) Montgomery of Mississippi, disregarded the leadership of their party and voted against the overall bill.

HEADLINE: Europeans Come to Aid of English Cathedral

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LICHFIELD, England

 BODY:
John Lang, Dean of Lichfield, tells visitors that his red sandstone Cathedral of St. Mary and St. Chad crumbles so easily after seven centuries that tiny pieces of it flake off in every downpour.
''In a heavy rain,'' he said recently, ''you can actually see it going down the drain.''
But in 1988 the European Community came to the rescue, contributing 1,045,000, the equivalent of $1,776,500, to the cathedral's restoration fund. 
As a result, the scaffolding around the buttresses on the south transept bears the blue European Community flag, rimmed with a circle of 12 stars for each member country, which is more usually seen at highway construction sites and industrial parks.
''We got every penny we asked for, on the most extraordinary ground that if the cathedral were to fall into disrepair, tourism would fall off, and therefore employment would decrease,'' Dean Lang said. ''We went over and got a tremendous grilling from a senior official of the European Commission in charge of the European Regional Fund, but what we got nearly doubled the amount we planned to raise.''
Egon Schoneweg, a spokesman for the European Community's Regional Policy directorate in Brussels, said that helping keep Lichfield Cathedral's spires, buttresses and window tracery from collapsing was an unusual activity of the fund, but confirmed Dean Lang's account of the logic behind it.
''It's not a cultural activity on our part,'' he said. ''It's an encouragement of tourism, which makes a contribution to economic development.''
Part of the money is for a visitors' center the church will build on the spacious grounds of the cathedral close. ''We think we get well over 200,000 visitors a year,'' the Dean said.
The sandstone with which Lichfield and Hereford, near the Welsh border, were built is more susceptible to deterioration than the stone of much older cathedral buildings such as Durham, but most of the 30 surviving English medieval cathedrals have had to undertake fund drives to survive.
Most dioceses, like Lichfield, have found their domestic resources inadequate to the task, and many have sought contributions from Anglophile donors in the United States.
Hereford ambitiously contemplated the idea of selling off its 13th-century map of the world at Sotheby's auction house in London, before a national uproar over the potential loss of an important part of the British heritage forced the Dean and Chapter to reconsider. The map went on display again in the cathedral grounds there on May 21, saved by a $3.2 million British Government grant and a $1.6 million gift from an American-born millionaire, John Paul Getty Jr. But most of the other cathedrals are not, like Lichfield, in a region qualifying for special assistance on economic grounds. Coventry Cathedral, in the industrial zone to the south of Lichfield, is, and it received 87,000, nearly $148,000, from the European Community for maintenance and repairs.
Assistance to Britain from the European Community for restructuring its steel and shipbuilding industries from 1989 to 1991 will total $1.6 billion, Mr. Schoneweg said, more than any other member country has received for industrial restructuring. The Community is also providing $991,250,000 for roads, bridges and the like in Northern Ireland over the five years beginning with 1989, he said.

HEADLINE: After the Quake, Older Chinese Fear Crumbling Lives, Not Falling Bricks

BYLINE: By KATHERINE BISHOP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 23

 BODY:
For thousands of Chinatown residents, the violent shaking of their old brick buildings during the earthquake last October was so terrifying that three days afterward, many remained in shock or immobilized by fear.
But now, as planners move to strengthen those same unreinforced masonry buildings - brick structures lacking steel frameworks and held together only by mortar - they find that the area has an even greater fear than earthquakes: Many elderly Chinatown residents would rather live with the possibility that their buildings may fall down in future quakes than move from their tightly knit community, even temporarily, for repairs.
The fear of being displaced that is held by many of the 30,000 residents 60 and older who live in the 10-block core of Chinatown is only one of the complex problems facing this city as it tries to shape an ordinance mandating repair of the unreconstructed masonry buildings. For decades, despite the belief by seismic experts that such buildings are potential deathtraps in a strong earthquake, San Francisco has had what a city report called ''a do-nothing policy.'' But now the city is moving to act, both because it is under pressure from the state to do so and because the quake last year intensified fears about what would happen when the ''Big One'' hits. 
''No politician wants to stand up and put a dollar value on a life, and anything we do in adopting an ordinance has to do that,'' said Mary C. Comerio, an associate professor of architecture at the University of California at Berkeley and a San Francisco architect. She is advising the city on the economic and social impact of an ordinance affecting the buildings.
And experience has shown that landlords are unlikely to act before they are required to do so.
''People who own the buildings don't want to admit the problem because it costs money to retrofit,'' said Tom Hsieh, the only member of the Board of Supervisors who is of Chinese descent. ''The landlords' feeling is very simple. They don't know when the next quake will come, and they got through this one.''
 
Built for Something Else
The precarious situation of the buildings, and of the people who live there, was evident on a recent visit to a typical brick structure in Chinatown. Rickety staircases and long hallways covered in worn carpeting led to rows of 8-by-10-foot rooms that are the entire private living quarters of each resident. A communal kitchen on each floor consisted of a sink and four electric burners; other tiny rooms had toilets and bathtubs.
''Most of these units were designed for transient workers, seamen and other single men,'' said Forrest M. Gok, a spokesman for Self-Help for the Elderly, a nonprofit social service agency serving Chinatown. ''They were like dormitories - not designed for cooking, for families and certainly not for elderly ladies.''
But in fact this brick building, like others in the neighborhood, is home to elderly Chinese immigrants, about 75 percent of whom are women over 60 who do not speak English.
The tenants, speaking through a translator, were anxious to point out the large pieces of plaster lost from the ceilings in the October quake. The women, who pointed out other safety and health violations and did not give their names because of fear of retaliation from the landlord, described how they were thrown to the floor or had to hold on to the wall to keep from falling when the quake struck.
''I was afraid to run out because the stairs were shaking back and forth so hard,'' one elderly Chinese woman said.
 
Tourists Stay Away
The idea of a repair program has prompted not only concern about displacing the elderly tenants but also worries about what it would do to merchants in Chinatown who depend on tourism.
Before the quake, more than 50,000 visitors a day wandered through Chinatown in peak summer months to shop, nibble on dim sum and take pictures at the elaborate gate marking its entrance on Grant Avenue. But many businesses have been suffering since October, when tourism dropped sharply.
''There is no doubt that stopping business for just a few weeks could make them go under,'' said Rose Pak, a consultant for the Chinese Chamber of Commerce. ''Their margin of profit is very, very small. They aren't corporations that have a financial cushion that can weather it.''
 
Banned for Four Decades
There are about 2,100 privately owned unreinforced masonry buildings here - almost 10 percent of the city's total housing stock. Most were constructed before 1924, and all of them before 1952, when the city banned new ones. In the past, owners have been required to reinforce these structures only when increasing the size or changing the use of the buildings.
According to a study from the office of the city's Chief Administrative Officer, Rudolf Nothenberg, who is charged with developing recommendations regarding the ordinance, most are in danger of some degree of life-threatening collapse in a strong earthquake. The problem is not that the buildings were weakened by the last quake, but that the nature of their construction means they would be in danger in a quake that is centered here. That was not the case in October. In 1986, the state passed the Unreinforced Masonry Building Law requiring cities in areas of maximum seismic activity to make an inventory of such buildings, develop a plan for reducing the threat to life they represent and report progress to the State Seismic Safety Commission by Jan. 1, 1990. By that date, less than half the cities, including San Francisco, had complied, according to the commission.
Moreover, Edward Hensley, a spokesman for the commission, said San Francisco was lobbying hard against proposed amendments to the 1986 law. The amendments seek to impose deadlines on cities for beginning work on the buildings and requiring a level of reinforcement adopted by the City of Los Angeles nearly 10 years ago, a higher level of reinforcement than San Francisco has in mind.
''We're looking for a standard that works best for us - that controls costs and avoids displacement of tenants in Chinatown,'' said David Prowler, assistant to Mr. Nothenberg. ''We want to have the flexibility to say this is all the safety we can afford.''
 
Projecting the Bloodshed
A report by Rutherford and Chekene, a structural engineering firm commissioned by the city to study unreinforced masonry buildings says that in any 10-year period, the statistically expected earthquake losses in unreinforced masonry buildings if no strengthening is done would total 126 fatalities, 507 injuries requiring hospitalization and half a billion dollars in property loss. The minimum repair being considered for San Francisco would cut the fatalities and injuries in half. Adopting the Los Angeles plan would reduce them even further, to 22 fatalities and 88 injured.
While several proposals are under consideration, the alternative most likely to be recommended ''gives the least disruption with the least cost and the least safety,'' said William Holmes of Rutherford and Chekene.
It would involve removing sections of flooring beside the walls and driving bolts into the walls to connect them to the floor joists, preventing the floors from collapsing away from the walls in a strong quake. Mr. Holmes said the repairs could be done while tenants stay in the building. Such repairs would also be less expensive than installing structural steel and plywood shear walls, as required under the Los Angeles ordinance.
But even if the work is done in the least disruptive manner, it may take San Francisco up to 30 years to complete the task, Mr. Prowler said.
''If we don't do anything, we're looking at potential rubble,'' Mr. Gok said. ''It's impossible to do it all at once. And if we do it a little at a time, we won't have time to finish by the next quake.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Elderly residents of San Francisco's Chinatown fear being forced to move, even temporarily, while the neighborhood's earthquake-damaged buildings are repaired. A boarded-up building on Kearney Street shows a crack, right, in its masonry facade. 9Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Discussion on Reducing Deficit, Bush Hears Many Voices

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
President Bush's top economic and political advisers are divided over how hard the President should press for a reduction in the budget deficit and whether he should agree to higher taxes.
Many of their views were batted around at a meeting in Vice President Dan Quayle's office last Thursday, and the discussions have continued in smaller groups almost daily.
''It's a continuum,'' said one adviser who was at the meeting, ''with Darman at one end and Ed Rollins at the other and the rest of us at different points in between.''
 
Top Advisers' Views
Richard G. Darman, the budget director, takes the position that Mr. Bush should strike a dramatic deal with Congress, even if it includes new taxes. Otherwise, in his view, the deficit will either remain so high that it will lead to higher interest rates and much less economic growth, or it will be reduced with automatic across-the-board spending cuts so large that the Government cannot function and the economy might be driven into recession. 
Edward J. Rollins, co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, says that with anti-communism and military strength no longer good political issues and with many Republicans on the defensive on abortion and the environment, a strong stand against higher taxes is the only big issue Republican candidates have in their favor going into this year's election.
John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, is said to be closer to the Rollins end of the spectrum. Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, is near the Darman end.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has reserved his views for his private meetings with President Bush, but he is reported to have counseled the President on the effect various measures might have on the financial markets.
The open question is where President Bush stands. His advisers, if they know, are not saying.
 
The Participants
Among the White House officials at the meeting last Thursday, in addition to Mr. Quayle, were Mr. Darman, Mr. Sununu, Andrew H. Card Jr., who is Mr. Sununu's deputy, and William Kristol, who is Mr. Quayle's chief of staff.
The outside political advisers included Mr. Rollins; Robert Teeter, the President's poll taker; Craig L. Fuller, Mr. Bush's chief of staff when he was Vice President; Mary Matalin, chief of staff of the Republican National Committee; Richard N. Bond, political director of Mr. Bush's 1988 Presidential campaign, and Kenneth M. Duberstein, a top official in the Reagan White House.
Some of those attending the meeting would not talk about it. But others, and some officials who were not present, discussed the range of views that President Bush is hearing as long as they were not quoted by name.
They said a consensus had developed on three points:
* The White House has handled the budget issue more clumsily than it has any other political issue since Mr. Bush took office.
* The political damage is not permanent, and if the President handles the situation deftly, he can turn whatever decision he makes on taxes into his political advantage.
* The President must either agree to a sweeping deal with Congress that will resolve the deficit problem at least until after the 1992 election or accept no deal at all. A halfway measure that puts off the problem until next year would be the worst of all approaches.
Many political advisers complained that Mr. Bush had not prepared the country for a budget crisis.
In his State of the Union Message on Jan. 31, the last time Mr. Bush addressed the country on prime-time television, he said of the budget that he had just submitted to Congress: ''That budget brings Federal spending under control. It meets the Gramm-Rudman target, brings that deficit down further and balances the budget by 1993 - with no new taxes.''
 
'Sense of Urgency'
Since then, the economy has, by most measures, performed better than expected. Mr. Bush has never explained the ''sense of urgency'' that he said last week in his news conference had led him to enter budget negotiations with Congress.
Even so, the advisers said, Mr. Bush could be well-placed politically. If he decides to break his pledge of ''no new taxes,'' he can portray it as a courageous move to put the economic interest of the country ahead of political interests. If, on the other hand, he decides against a tax increase, he can depict it as standing fast on principle against pressure from his staff.
At the meeting in Mr. Quayle's office, Mr. Darman painted the same picture that he has been presenting to Congressional leaders at the negotiating sessions over the last two weeks.
It is basically this: A combination of the reluctance of Congress to act on the Bush budget proposals, poor economic forecasting and the mushrooming cost of the savings and loan mess means that the $64 billion deficit limit set by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget balancing law could be missed by as much as $135 billion.
The Government could not function if an across-the-board spending cut of that size went into effect in October as required by the law. President Bush cannot afford to allow the country to slide into recession. Therefore, budget negotiations with Congress are essential.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 455 words

HEADLINE: Fix the Budget, Once

 BODY:
Congress would have to whack more than $100 billion off next year's deficit to meet the target under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget law. That would be three times larger than recent budget cuts and would come when the economy is limp, possibly verging on recession.
Congress doesn't have the stomach for cutting programs and raising taxes by anything like $100 billion. So instead, it will amend the budget law to make next year's cut easier. Fortunately, here's where political expediency makes economic sense. Deficits need to be reduced steadily, not in a rush, and certainly not by risking cruel increases in unemployment. The important point is for Congress to fix the budget law permanently. That requires three principal reforms:
Remove the S & L bailout from Gramm-Rudman. The 1985 budget law was intended to keep huge Federal deficits from siphoning capital away from corporate investment. But Federal borrowing to pay off depositors at failed thrifts poses no such threat. These depositors are no more likely to spend the money they receive from the Government than they were to spend their original deposit. So the money will stay put in the capital market. The S & L bailout never belonged in the Gramm-Rudman calculation and can be safely removed. 
Revise the accounting period. Congress has evaded the full impact of the budget targets by shifting nominal expenditures and revenues back and forth between accounting periods. There are many ways to stop this deception. There is a related need to extend the budget-cutting horizon beyond one year. That way Congress can legislate long-term program reductions, which may produce only minor savings now. This is especially important for military hardware.
Revise the budget target. Because the economy has enjoyed steady growth since the 1985 budget law was passed, a fatal flaw has not surfaced until now. During economic slowdowns, taxes fall and the deficit rises. As currently written, the Gramm-Rudman law could, at the worst moment, force a round of tax hikes and spending cuts that could accelerate a downturn into a disaster.
The remedy is to redefine the target in terms of a hypothetical deficit: the deficit that spending and tax programs would cause if the economy were operating near full employment. Written in this way, an economic slowdown would not affect the redefined target and Congress would not be forced to stifle an already sluggish economy.
The country needs a long-term commitment to steady deficit reduction. That requires manageable hits of, say, $30 billion a year. More deficit reduction in order to fit a poorly conceived budgetary straitjacket is a suicidal formula. Gramm-Rudman needs to be changed. Once, and for all.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Folly to Scrap Plan to Improve J.F.K. Airport

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To this layman's mind, it seems a bit bizarre to scratch the central features of the Port Authority's improvements at Kennedy Airport (news article, May 11), rather akin to ceasing construction of the Second Avenue subway during the economic crunch of the mid-70's.
If 30 million passengers used the facility this year, how much more congestion will be in evidence in a decade with antiquated services dating from 1952, before the age of jet travel? Air travel is here to stay; this week we read, for example, two articles on the new generation of projected supersonic transport planes. Will their clients suffer J.F.K.?
Stephen Berger, executive director of the Port Authority, is correct in assessing the shortsightedness of the airlines. Already traffic is shifting to Newark, with S.A.S., Lufthansa, Air France, Continental and others offering many nonstop international destinations. The need of travelers to escape the delays at J.F.K. is already making peripheral airports like Long Island's MacArthur and Westchester - to say nothing of far-flung Philadelphia and Hartford - boom.
Far lesser cities than New York have financed airports with good design, comfort and access to mass transit: Cleveland, Toronto, Miami, Dallas, Washington, Atlanta, to name a few; and Amsterdam and London, notably, and many others abroad. In a city that sees itself as the center of the universe, J.F.K. is an embarrassment. Why talk of an airport more than 60 miles upstate at Stewart when New York City itself is the market?
 
EDWIN J. BLESCH JR.
New York, May 11, 1990

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
The High-Tech Future

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
Early in April, the Pentagon quietly diverted to other purposes $20 million of $30 million allocated by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency to high-definition television.
About two weeks later, not so quietly, the Defense Department assigned Dr. Craig Fields, the director of Darpa, to another defense position.
Still later, Michael Sekora, the physicist who had directed the Defense Intelligence Agency's ''Project Socrates'' - which monitors the advanced technologies of U.S. economic competitors - announced that he had resigned.
He quit to protest reductions in the Bush Administration's support for compiling an accurate data base on foreign technologies, with the aim of aiding U.S. high-technology efforts -those of the military and the private sector. 
Dr. Fields's reassignment was labeled routine by the Pentagon, but in fact resulted from his efforts to direct Government funds into research aiding the competitive position of the nation's commerce and industry, as well as improving its military strength.
That approach, called ''industrial policy,'' was symbolized by the commitment of Darpa funds to the development of high-definition television (HDTV). But ''industrial policy'' is opposed by Richard Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, Michael Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and John Sununu, President Bush's chief of staff - hence by the Bush Administration. Last year Mr. Sununu rebuked Robert Mosbacher, the Secretary of Commerce, for trying to promote HDTV research.
Dr. Fields's ouster may have been precipitated by a $4 million Darpa investment in a radiation-resistant substitute for silicon called gallium arsenide, on terms allowing Darpa a share of the financial return. But the controversy over HDTV, which has many highly placed supporters in industry and Congress, is more typical of the continuing dispute over ''industrial policy.''
HDTV would replace the 525 horizontal lines of current television receivers with 1,000 to 1,250 lines, resulting in a sharper visual image. Apart from its commercial potential for home TV sets, supporters claim important military applications - for example, flat-panel screens for improved information displays in tanks and aircraft. A Pentagon advisory board recently urged that HDTV research funds be increased to $100 million yearly for the next five years; the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment is preparing a report citing HDTV as vital to the U.S. position in the world electronics market.
Critics, however, contend that pressures for Government support of HDTV come mainly from the American Electronics Association. They question the importance of HDTV's military uses, and claim that its widespread commercial use would require new TV sets in every home, new television broadcast and transmission equipment, therefore huge new investments by consumers and broadcasters for a relatively minor improvement in clarity and reception.
HDTV research, moreover, already is far advanced in Japan, where more than $700 million has been spent on development. Critics insist it's too late and would cost too much for the U.S. to match that effort. Darpa's $30 million would have been wasted, in this view, which holds that U.S. military needs for HDTV are not important enough to justify a catch-up investment.
Even if accurate as to the specific importance of HDTV, this misses the point that the research Craig Fields wanted to sponsor, for which the Administration fired him, may be important to the survival of the U.S. electronics industry - which is vital to American military strength, even if HDTV may not be. By one estimate, half the total cost of new Army weapons by the year 2000 will be for electronics.
Perhaps even more important, high-technology industries will bear the main burden of future American economic competitiveness - on which national prosperity largely depends. For that reason, the M.I.T. Commission on Industrial Productivity concluded, the Government ''should launch new R&D programs directed toward improving manufacturing, product development, and process engineering'' - particularly those ''that can be anticipated to have benefits both for the military and the commercial sector.''
The Administration seems instead to be limiting research support ''solely to technologies with military applications,'' as a recent Congressional statement charged. That suggests a second article.

HEADLINE: 80 Held in Fight At Building Site In Hunts Point

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
Eighty people were arrested yesterday afternoon after two groups seeking construction jobs fought at the site of a new police station house in the Bronx and turned on the police when officers arrived, the authorities said.
More than 100 members of the groups, the Black and Latino Economic Survival and the United Hispanic Coalition, fought with construction materials like steel reinforcing rods, chunks of concrete and two-by-fours.
They turned on about 60 officers from the 41st Precinct and nearby precincts who responded to the dispute at Bruckner Boulevard and Longwood Avenue in the Hunts Point section, a police spokesman, Sgt. Nicholas Vreeland, said. 
Two officers suffered minor injuries from thrown debris, he said. ''It was basically a battle over turf,'' Sergeant Vreeland said.
 
'Or There'll Be Trouble'
The major-case squad of the Police Department is investigating the groups for possible extortion.
Sergeant Vreeland said the groups had gone to construction sites in recent years threatening contractors who did not provide jobs to their members.
''What they do is tell them, 'We want X number of jobs for our people at this site or there'll be trouble,' '' Sergeant Vreeland said. ''In this particular case, both of these groups were at the same location looking for jobs and a fight broke out between them.''
Efforts to reach members of both groups for comment last night were unsuccessful.
Two patrol cars responded first to the site, where the new 41st Precinct station house is being built. On seeing the number of people fighting, the officers called for assistance.
 
Two Officers Hit
''As cops arrived at the scene, the two groups began throwing things at the officers, the things they had been fighting each other with,'' Sergeant Vreeland said.
A brick hit a sergeant's leg, and an officer was hit ''with some type of debris,'' Sergeant Vreeland said, Neither officer was identified.
The 80 people linked to Black and Latino Economic Survival were arrested as they tried to flee on two school buses that had taken them to the scene, the sergeant added. Members of the other group fled.
The suspects were charged last night with first-degree riot and assault.

HEADLINE: Camden School District Accepts Uniform Option

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J., May 23

 BODY:
Students in seven Camden public schools may be trading in their sneakers and jeans next year for blue-and-white uniforms in an effort to relieve fashion pressure in the economically depressed district.
The Camden Board of Education unanimously voted on Monday to give parents and students the option to decide whether the students should wear uniforms. The program will begin with the new school year in September at two middle schools and five elementary schools. 
Because the district is not paying for the uniforms, which cost about $50, the district cannot institute a mandatory uniform dress code, school board officials said.
A Woodrow Wilson High School student, one of two students on the board, was skeptical about the program.
''I believe that most of the students in high school and middle school will be against the idea,'' said Richard Horton, who is 16 years old. ''They want freedom to wear their Adidas and their Troop jackets, their $120 sneaks and their $60 sweatshirts.''
Edward Taylor, a school psychologist for the district, said the optional program would help ''take away the competition for dress among students and allow them to concentrate more on their work.''
Olive Smith, district director of Special Services, said the uniform option would decrease attacks in which students have been robbed of their sneakers and jackets. Such attacks have occurred in several American cities, and a number of school districts have adopted programs under which students can wear uniforms if they choose.
Mary Arnold Frazier, assistant superintendent, said more than 90 percent of parents responding to a district survey were in favor of uniforms.
Girls in elementary schools will wear navy blue jumpers, knee socks and white blouses. Girls in middle schools will wear a similar uniform, but the jumper will be replaced with a navy blue pleated skirt and vest.
Boys at both levels will wear white shirts and navy blue socks, cardigan sweaters and pants. All of the children will wear dark shoes and bow ties in their school colors.
