HEADLINE: Screen Writer Turns to the Novel To Tell of Race and Class in London

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
''The real problem when I was growing up was that racism just wasn't a topic of understanding in England,'' Hanif Kureishi was saying on a recent afternoon. ''If I'd been a black growing up in Detroit, say, there would have been a structure for me to comprehend: the institution of slavery and the history of segregation. But in England, there was no wider understanding of racism. You felt it was your own personal psychological problem.''
Mr. Kureishi, who lives in London, is best known in America as the screenwriter of the Stephen Frears-directed films ''My Beautiful Laundrette'' and ''Sammy and Rosie Get Laid,'' vivid servings of British Asian life that opened the surprising, and hitherto obscure, world of London's Indian and Pakistani immigrant cultures to public scrutiny. The films seemed to offend not only those in England who dislike immigrants, but also some members of England's Asian communities.
Now Mr. Kureishi has returned to the themes of race and class in contemporary London in his first novel, ''The Buddha of Suburbia'' (Viking, $18.95), which has been on best-seller lists in England since it was published there six weeks ago. Since its American debut this month, the book has been critically praised in many newspapers and magazines. 
The writer has skewered practically every target in sight in ''Buddha,'' including suburban social climbers, artistic poseurs, upper-class intellectual twits, Rolls-Royce liberals, scabrous working-class heroes and, once again, England's Asian and black immigrants.
 
A Proto-Punk Romp
''Buddha'' is the oft-raunchy tale of Karim Amir, child of an Indian father and an English mother, who comes of age in Orpington, a London suburb, during the cultural aftershocks of the seismic 60's. Karim moves to London to romp through the proto-punk scene of the 70's - and, not insignificantly, through many a bedroom - until he makes his fortune as an actor.
Mr. Kureishi's screenplays brought him attention, and bought him enough time to work on ''Buddha,'' but ''writing a novel, you really expose yourself,'' Mr. Kureishi said.
''You can't hang back,'' he said. ''It's all there to see. A novel is much more internal, and certainly, writing a first-person novel -it's an act of exposure.''
The 35-year-old Mr. Kureishi was passing through New York on his two-week book tour, traveling light, wearing jeans, black shirt, and a vest emblazoned with a cheerfully lurid icon of Elvis Presley. Lithe and laid-back, Mr. Kureishi spoke quietly and was slow to smile. When he did, his enigmatic eyes and long dark hair gave his expression a startling Mona Lisa quality.
Mr. Kureishi has something of a reputation in London as a scene-maker and dedicated hanger-outer, but, he said, ''you need to live a boring life to be a writer.''
''An idea takes a long time to grow and develop,'' he added. ''You need such discipline and concentration to do a book.'' It took him nearly two years to complete ''Buddha.''
 
'Autobiographical in Some Ways'
Like his fictional protagonist, Mr. Kureishi is the child of an Indian father and an English mother - he grew up in suburban Bromley - and began his own assault on cultural London in the 1970's. In consequence, he is spending much of his time these days fielding questions about just how much of his life is in ''Buddha.''
''Certainly the book is autobiographical in some ways,'' he said. ''That's so obvious. But the relationship between your own life and your writing is very complex. It's hard to realize, yourself, how you've transformed part of yourself into the characters you create.''
His book has occasioned something of a guessing game back home: pin-the-Londoner on the fictional ''Buddha'' character. ''There are two basic reactions,'' Mr. Kureishi said. ''There are those who hate you because they think you put them in the book, and there are those who hate you because they think you didn't put them in the book.''
At least one character has a real-life counterpart: one of Mr. Kureishi's grade-school mates, Bill Broad, became the punk-rocker Billy Idol. A character in ''Buddha,'' Charlie Hero, is partly based on the rocker, ''although I haven't seen him since I was 16,'' Mr. Kureishi said. ''But with all these characters, you create them by taking one person's nose and adding it to another person's hands and another one's feet, and you mix them all up.''
The book's portrait of English racism is autobiographical enough. Young Hanif was the only Asian in his school at the time when ''Paki bashing'' became a vicious pastime for some alienated punks and skinheads.
 
Target of Spitting and Kicking
''One teacher called me 'Pakistani Pete,' something that no teacher would get away with today,'' Mr. Kureishi said. ''Kids I'd known since the age of 5 began spitting at me and kicking me around.''
Unlike his schoolmates, most of whom grew up to be mechanics or laborers, Mr. Kureishi attended King's College in London, began an apprenticeship in London theaters and became a playwright. He won acceptance in theatrical England ''because they liked me,'' Mr. Kureishi said. ''They liked me because I was Indian, and lower-middle-class. That was chic. And I was pretty - then.''
Although he feels that racism is less virulent in England these days, Mr. Kureishi maintained that ''Britain doesn't yet have a vision of itself as a mixed place.'' He explained: ''The feeling is that blacks and Asians were invited to Britain to work, but maybe they'll somehow go back again. Britain still hasn't re-cast itself as a multi-racial, multi-cultural society.''
These days, does Mr. Kureishi think of himself as Indian, English or neither? ''I think of myself as a British writer,'' he said, adding that this is not, perhaps, the way Britain thinks of him.
''Literature there is still in the hand of the old boys,'' he said. ''There are all of these new immigrant experiences in Britain that haven't been touched yet.''
After ''Laundrette'' and ''Sammy and Rosie'' appeared, he received hate mail and threats from Asians in England who objected to his characterizations of immigrant culture.
 
Anger Over Sexual Content
The motivation for some of this anger involved the sexual content of his work, Mr. Kureishi said. In ''Laundrette'' the central characters, Omar and Johnny, were gay. Two of Mr. Kureishi's characters in ''Sammy and Rosie'' had an open marriage, and in ''Buddha,'' the protagonist, Karim Amir, is happily, even energetically, bisexual.
Mr. Kureishi said the biggest protests against ''Laundrette'' occurred not in England but in New York City, in 1986, when the film was picketed by the Pakistan Action Committee. ''People think you're supposed to show them exclusively as strong, truthful and beautiful,'' he said. ''It's just exactly what Philip Roth went through.''
''Looking back on it, I can see in it the seeds of the Rushdie situation,'' he said. Mr. Kureishi was one of the first English writers to speak in support of Salman Rushdie after Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran denounced his novel ''The Satanic Verses'' as blasphemous and called for the author's death. Mr. Kureishi said he had known Mr. Rushdie ''for a very long time, since his family was an old friend of our family in India.''
''It was devastating for him, for all of us,'' said Mr. Kureishi. ''We thought that the community would be proud of Rushdie as someone who has used his position as a famous writer to talk about racism, colonialism and unemployment. But to see them turn round on him, to see 16-year-olds say they want to murder him with their own hands - it was appalling.''
Mr. Kureishi said that Mr. Rushdie had come to terms with his situation, and was ''writing quite a lot.'' Has he seen him recently? ''I can't answer that question,'' he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hanif Kureishi, whose first novel is ''The Buddha of Suburbia.'' (Neal Boenzi/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: One Goal Unmet as Clausen Retires From BankAmerica

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 23

 BODY:
Sometime Thursday afternoon at the BankAmerica Corporation's annual meeting here, A. W. Clausen, the chairman and chief executive, will hand over the gavel of leadership to Richard M. Rosenberg, ending an era - or more correctly two eras - at the nation's third-largest banking company.
Mr. Clausen, who is 67 years old, ran BankAmerica in the 1970's before leaving in 1981, then came back to rescue the bank from near failure in the late 1980's.
But even as he retires with BankAmerica restored to health, Mr. Clausen seems to harbor one more aim - making the San Francisco banking company a global power, as it was when he left the first time.
''I see the bank continuing to be an international player, in contrast to some other banks that are circling their wagons and pulling out of the international scene,'' Mr. Clausen said in an interview on Tuesday. 
To recover from the huge loan problems of the 1980's, BankAmerica had to sell off many businesses, including its bank in Italy and other foreign operations, and to narrow its focus to retail banking in California. Indeed, the new chief executive, Mr. Rosenberg, has spent most of his career as a California retail banker at the Wells Fargo Bank.
But Mr. Clausen's retirement is less than total. He will be chairman of the executive committee of BankAmerica's board and will head a new committee of outside experts that will advise the company on international matters.
Mr. Clausen, who is called Tom after a role in a high school play, said he was eager to increase BankAmerica's European participation, in the West and East, where he visited in March. Although he does not see BankAmerica or other American banks lending directly to Eastern European nations, he said, ''as good commercial banks, we will follow our customers,'' and finance projects by American and other Western companies in Eastern Europe.
Such an international focus is not surprising. In 1981, when he left BankAmerica, Mr. Clausen became the head of the World Bank until he retired in 1986. He has favored maintaining loans to developing countries, while some banks are getting out of that area.
BankAmerica's reserves total 54 percent of its loans to developing nations. Raising the reserves would substantially cut into the company's profits, and Mr. Clausen said he did not think that would be needed. ''I don't see us having to go to 75 or 80 percent,'' he said. ''Neither do the regulators.''
Mr. Clausen was drafted to return to BankAmerica in October 1986, replacing his chosen successor, Samuel H. Armacost. At that time the banking company was the subject of a hostile takeover bid from First Interstate Bancorp and was drowning in loan losses. Mr. Clausen fought off First Interstate and nurtured BankAmerica back to health by cutting jobs, selling off businesses to raise cash and revamping management.
Often described as autocratic, Mr. Clausen, who calls himself ''a workaholic,'' said he never lost hope that BankAmerica could be turned around. ''I was pretty discouraged to begin with,'' he added. ''Things appeared to me to be a lot worse than I had hoped for.''
BankAmerica, which recorded more than $1 billion in profits last year, is ''within shouting distance of being an excellent bank,'' he said, with profits, expense contols and capital levels adequate.
''There's still a little bit to fix around here,'' he cautioned. In particular, he said, he would like to see BankAmerica's credit ratings raised and the level of nonperforming assets lowered.
Mr. Clausen said BankAmerica was interested in expanding into more states. Many analysts think the company would be interested in buying its old foe, First Interstate, which is now considered a takeover candidate and has banks in most Western states. When asked about this, however, he replied, ''No, we have no plans, no discussions and no intentions.''
Although the bank prospered under Mr. Clausen in the 1970's, some critics have said that aggressive lending in that decade and the failure to invest adequately in new electronic technology planted the seeds for the problems that arose after Mr. Clausen left. Similarly, it has been said, some of the elements for the recovery had already been started by the time Mr. Clausen returned.
 
Stands on Record
Mr. Clausen angrily denounced such criticisms as ''catcalls one gets along the way from all those ignoramuses.'' He said he would stand on his record of having presided over the bank twice when it performed well.
Besides his continued association with BankAmerica, Mr. Clausen plans to spend time working on Bay Area regional planning issues and for the United Way, but he does not see taking another full-time job.
''I'm a seasoned hand at retiring,'' Mr. Clausen quipped. ''This will be the third time I'm retiring as a C.E.O.'' He added, ''There won't be a fourth time.''

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Fell by 17.5% In Mid-May

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 23

 BODY:
Despite fairly aggressive incentives, sales of American-made cars and light trucks fell by 17.5 percent in mid-May, disappointing analysts and dealers who expect higher sales in the spring.
The 10 domestic manufacturers today reported car sales totaling 162,018 for the middle of the month, an 18.6 percent decline from the comparable period a year ago.
Cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6 million during the period, one of the lowest selling rates so far this year. That compares with an annual rate of 7.2 million for the period last year, and with 6.7 million for the last 30 days. 
 
Eight Selling Days
Eight selling days were in this period, compared with nine in last year's period.
The sales of light trucks and mini-vans, which normally account for about a third of all new-vehicle sales, fell by 15.7 percent, to 98,092.
''This is the spring selling season, and we expected some good numbers by now,'' said Edward A. Sullivan, a vice president of the WEFA Group, an economic forecasting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. ''The only way to read the continuing slump is that the underlying market for new cars has eroded.''
The spring sales season, usually from April to mid-June, is historically the most important selling period for American auto makers.
All of the large American auto makers reported declines of more than 20 percent in car sales, with the Ford Motor Company reporting a drop of nearly 30 percent.
As a group, car sales by the Big Three fell by 25.6 percent, while those by Japanese companies with factories in the United States - transplants - rose by 61.5 percent in the period, compared with last year.
Several automobile dealers said today that they believed the underlying economy was sound, and attributed a shortage of new-car buyers to the recent trend of lenders offering longer payback periods on loans.
''There are a lot of people out there who still owe too much money on their cars to consider trading it in,'' said Mark Brobeck, general manager of Ricart Ford in Columbus, Ohio. ''The trading cycle is getting longer with customers than it used to be.''
Other analysts said lower sales were tied to worsening consumer confidence and concerns that inflation, in particular, might increase.
''People are are more concerned about the next 12 months or so as far as their economic situation goes than they were this time last year,'' said Michael M. Luckey, the president of the Luckey Consulting Group Inc. in Cresskill, N.J.
''Nobody here has a simple explanation'' for the low sales rates, said Joel H. Pitcoff, a market analyst for Ford. ''My best guess is that a combination of factors are at work, including widespread speculation that interest rates will come down soon,'' causing some potential buyers to postpone purchases.
Ford experienced the biggest sales decline in mid-May, as its car sales plunged by 29.9 percent, to 42,703. The sales of Ford's light trucks fell by 12 percent, to 34,864.
 
G.M. Sales Off 23.7%
The General Motors Corporation's car sales declined by 23.7 percent, to 72,566. G.M.'s light-truck sales were off by 17.6 percent, to 39,359.
The Chrysler Corporation posted a 22.1 percent drop in its car sales, to 21,047. The sales of Chrysler's light trucks and mini-vans fell by 21 percent, to 21,325.
Responding to the sharp decline in sales of its mini-vans, Chrysler this week gave dealers a $500 incentive on them. While the incentive is designed to spur new orders, the discount could get passed on to customers.
The Honda Motor Company reported a 22.4 percent gain in the sales of its American-made cars, to 11,076. The Mazda Motor Corporation's car sales rose by 45.9 percent, to 1,272.
The sales of cars made by the Toyota Motor Corporation more than doubled, to 8,820, while the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation posted a gain of 51.8 percent in its car sales, to 1,154. Both companies have added substantial new production capacity to their American plants.
Isuzu Motors Ltd. reported sales of 100 cars in mid-May, from the plant is operates with Fuji Heavy Industries in West Lafayette, Ind. Subaru of America Inc., the distributor of Fuji-built cars in the United States, reported that it sold 373 cars produced at the same plant.
The Nissan Motor Company posted a 63 percent increase in its car sales, to 1,907, and those of its light trucks rose by 30.3 percent, to 2,544.

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
After Long Fight, Pepsi Enters India

BYLINE: By Barbara Crossette

DATELINE: NEW DELHI

 BODY:
IT took half a decade of negotiating, 20 debates in Parliament and a monumental public relations campaign. But last night, in the silver wine coolers of a luxury hotel, Pepsi-Cola came to India.
Well, not exactly Pepsi-Cola. It is called Lehar Pepsi here, a concession to the anti-foreign lobby. And it will not appear in all of India at first: just Jaipur, Kanpur, Bangalore and Punjab state. Plans are to have Pepsi in the larger cities, like Delhi, Bombay and Calcutta, later this year. 
Nevertheless, Pepsico Inc. and its Indian joint-venture partners are jubilant. No major American soft drink has been allowed in the Indian market since Coca-Cola was forced out in a fit of nationalism in 1977 after it refused to divulge its ingredients and reduce its ownership in its Indian venture.
Christopher Sinclair, the president of Pepsi-Cola International, who was on hand last night when the first lids popped at a news conference, called his company's venture in India ''an historic agreement.''
Because of the agreement, the company called on the Bush Administration not to impose trade sanctions on India under the ''super 301'' provisions of American trade law. The company sent a letter to Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, saying, ''Given the progress of the Pepsi project, and what we believe it portends for future U.S.-India business initiatives, we hope that our Government will not have to take any actions under the super 301 process.''
Pepsico's move into the Indian market, in which three billion bottles of brand-name soft drinks are sold annually, was made possible by the company's willingness to take a 39.9 percent share in a conglomerate called Pepsi Foods Private Limited. Its co-owners are Punjab Agro Industries, a Punjab state company, and the Voltas subsidiary of the giant Tata Group.
Pepsico and its partners, hoping to sell not only Pepsi but also 7-Up and Miranda orange drink in India, agreed to set up fruit and vegetable processing plants, agriculture research stations, franchised bottling operations and snack-food factories using local potatoes and other ingredients. Pepsico said it plans to invest more than $1 billion in India in the next 10 years. The company's first plants have been built in northern Punjab state, where unemployment among well-educated youths has helped fuel a separatist movement.
Pepsico snack foods - potato chips and Cheetoswith Indian seasonings - were introduced earlier this year, but soft-drink production was delayed, partly because of the time it took to bring bottling operations up to international standards and partly because at the last minute the name of the soft drinks had to be changed.
Pepsi Foods Private had planned to call its flagship drink Pepsi Era, but opponents challenged the name under a law, mostly honored in the breach, that forbids foreign names for Indian products. Lehar Pepsi, which means Pepsi Wave, was the compromise. But by then, permanently labeled bottles had to be scrapped and new ones made at a cost exceeding $1 million.
The battle may not be over. Local soft-drink manufacturers are threatening to make Lehar Pepsi disappear from the shelves. Company officials say they are not worried and are confident that there can be no successful campaign of sabotage against the drinks through the illegal use of Pepsi bottles.
Although Pepsico has more than 700 bottling operations overseas, including successful plants in China and the Soviet Union, the psychological barriers in India have been unique.
In a country fiercely protective of local industry, Indian soft-drink manufacturers have built strong political lobbies to fend off foreign challenges. Since a new Government came to power in India in December, the local bottlers have waged a campaign for the reversal of the Pepsico agreement, which was finally approved in 1988.
But the Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh resisted, apparently deciding that it would be a bad precedent to upset a contract that took so long to negotiate.
A new application from Coca-Cola, however, was rejected in March. The only other soft drink here that might be considered American is Double Cola, which is selling in limited areas of India and is owned by Indians who live in the United States.
Lehar Pepsi and its related brands, Lehar 7-Up and Lehar Miranda, got an unexpected assist when the Government decided in April to begin enforcing a two-year-old ban on the use of brominated vegetable oil. The substance, which is used to prevent the separation of ingredients in fruit-flavored drinks, is reported to be carcinogenic.
Indian consumer groups say that more than 120 countries have banned the oil, and the groups are pressing the Government to impose a ban here. Brominated vegetable oils have never been used in Pepsico drinks, Mr. Sinclair said at a news conference last evening.

HEADLINE: Boeing and McDonnell Joining Concorde Study

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 23

 BODY:
The nation's two major commercial aircraft manufacturers, the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, said today that they would join with the major European plane makers to study the feasibility of developing a new generation of supersonic airliners.
Boeing and McDonnell Douglas, which have researched supersonic planes on their own for decades, said they would participate in a ''study group'' formed by British Aerospace P.L.C. and Societe Nationale Industrielle Aerospatiale of France.
The British and French companies, which manufactured the supersonic airliner Concorde, announced plans earlier this month for a faster, more fuel-efficient ''Son of Concorde'' that could travel greater distances - Europe to Japan, for example - and invited participation by other nations. The study group will also include Deutsche Airbus, West Germany's leading builder of airliners and a subsidiary of Daimler-Benz. $10 Billion to Develop the Plane British Aerospace and Aerospatiale have estimated that it could cost $10 billion to develop the plane. The willingness of the major European and American commercial aircraft manufacturers to participate in the study underscores the high risks involved with assuming such huge costs. 
''Any program would be of a significant size, certainly beyond our means to go it alone,'' said Donald Graf, who heads McDonnell Douglas's research into supersonic aircraft.
The group said in a statement that it would look into a variety of issues over the next year, ''including global environmental concerns and expected high program investment and risk levels.''
The group said it would examine the probable level of demand for a new supersonic plane from airlines and would assess the compatability of its members in working together.
 
Environmental Concerns
McDonnell Douglas and Boeing have long expressed interest in building a supersonic airliner. Boeing even started building a prototype during the late 1960's, but abandoned it, largely because of concern about the noise it would make on takeoff and the sonic boom that would reverberate to earth when the plane passed overhead at speeds greater than the speed of sound, roughly 750 miles an hour.
Analysts say it remains unclear whether any supersonic airliner can be commercially viable. The Concorde cost $2 billion to develop and required heavy subsidies from the British and French governments. The manufacturers hoped to sell hundreds of the plane, but ended up selling only 14, seven to British Airways and seven to Air France.
Commercial supersonic flight has always been hampered by a variety of environmental and economic concerns. Because of the sonic boom, the Concorde's routes have been largely limited to those that take it primarily over the Atlantic Ocean. Environmentalists say the release of combustion gases from supersonic engines can harm the ozone layer. The current Concorde cannot carry enough fuel to fly from Europe or North America to the Far East, one of the most rapidly expanding airline markets.

HEADLINE: Loan Plan Set Up for McDonald's

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The hamburger may seem like an unlikely subject for high finance, but the business of selling America's favorite sandwich is the heart of a new financing arrangement announced yesterday by the Chemical Banking Corporation.
The new program offers a way for buyers or owners of McDonald's Corporation franchises to borrow at lower interest rates than they customarily pay for a bank loan. Chemical, and its subsidiary Texas Commerce Bank, will earn fees by handling the finances of a new company whose sole purpose is to make the lower-cost loans. 
The new company, known as Golden Mac, can afford to lend money at a lower interest rate than banks because it borrows money at a low cost in the commercial paper market. Borrowers of Golden Mac rely on sales of hamburgers and other fast food to repay their Golden Mac loans.
 
'A Better Offer'
''We will continue to make bank loans to franchisees who want something special, but for the plain, straight-forward situations, this is a better offer,'' said Lee E. Osborne, senior vice president at Texas Commerce.
Golden Mac, whose full name is Golden Managers Acceptance Corporation, expects to sell commercial paper through Chemcial Securities Inc. at very close to the rate paid by top-quality companies, or about 8.20 percent currently. After adding 1.5 percentage points or 1.75 percentage points to cover various costs, its loan rate to franchisees in the current market would be 9.70 percent or 9.95 percent, depending on the quality of the borrower. Good-quality franchisees typically pay a bank loan rate of the prime rate plus half a percentage point, or 10.50 percent currently.
Franchisees will borrow for seven years at a floating interest rate, which is guaranteed not to rise more than 2.5 percentage points above the initial loan rate for the first three years.
If franchisees default on their loans, investors in the commercial paper would be paid from a letter of credit issued by Credit Lyonnais, which is good for up to 7.5 percent of the commercial paper outstanding.
The initial $125 million limit on Golden Mac's financing will account for less than 10 percent of the $1.5 billion outstanding loans of McDonald's 8,500 American franchisees. Bankers said franchisees borrow over $100 million annually.
 
Similar Programs
Peter A. Sterling, vice president at the Bank of Boston, one of the leading bank lenders to McDonald's and its franchisees for more than 25 years, noted that in early May, the bank began offering McDonald's franchisees a new bank loan program with interest rates ''very competitive'' with rates offered by Golden Mac.
The Golden Mac financing is similar to other bank-sponsored programs that offer lower-rate financing to bank customers who in an earlier era might have borrowed directly from the bank.
Earlier this month, Mellon Bank of Pittsburgh announced the creation of the Three Rivers Funding Corporation, which will buy various kinds of receivables from Mellon's corporate customers. Three Rivers will pay for its purchases with funds raised by selling commercial paper through Merrill Lynch Money Markets Inc.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
$224 Million Bond Offering Priced by Battery Park City

 BODY:
The Battery Park City Authority yesterday priced a $224 million offering of revenue bonds.
The issue raised hackles earlier this year because $150 million of the proceeds are to be used to help close New York City's budget gap in the current fiscal year. Previous borrowings by the authority, a state agency that oversees development on landfill in lower Manhattan, had been used to finance projects in the Battery Park City area.
Special legislation was passed in Albany earlier this year that enabled the proceeds of yesterday's bond sale to pass directly to New York City.
The bond offering, which is a one-time event, prompted former Mayor Edward I. Koch in March to criticize Felix G. Rohatyn, one of Mayor David N. Dinkins's economic advisers, for not attacking the offering.
Battery Park City revenues are usually split between the city and the state, with the city receiving the bulk.
Yesterday's issue consists of serial and term bonds. Maturities on the serial bonds range from 1998 to 2001. Coupons on the bonds, which were priced at 100, range from 7.10 percent on bonds maturing in 1998 to 7.35 percent on bonds that mature in 2001.
About 40 percent of the issue - $92 million - consists of term bonds that will mature in 2015. Those bonds, which carry a coupon of 7.70 percent, were priced to yield 7.80 percent.
Morgan Stanley & Company acted as lead managers for the negotiated deal, which is rated A by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: Seidman Sees Higher Cost For Earlier Savings Bailouts

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
Even as the Government was acknowledging the escalating estimates for future savings and loan failures, the cost of past failures was seen to be rising as well.
L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, told Congress today that falling real estate values and rising interest rates have increased by $12 billion the cost of Government assistance to the more than 200 savings and loan associations that failed before the savings industry bailout was approved by Congress last year. He put the figure now at $65 billion over 10 years.
Among the institutions are those sold by Federal regulators in the waning days of 1988 - the ''December deals'' criticized in Congress as giveaways because of their generous tax benefits and financial assistance agreements. 
The group also includes some 87 Texas savings institutions that were sold as part of the Government's Southwest plan.
 
'Far Larger Problem'
Though the costs of the 202 assistance agreements are not counted in the cost of the bailout, they are a precursor of the increased costs that the Government may face as it begins to liquidate or sell hundreds of failed savings units in the years ahead.
''What we've discoverd is that this is a far larger problem than anyone thought at the time,'' Mr. Seidman said. ''We thought we were looking at a golf ball and it was a basketball instead.''
He pointed specificially to rising interest rates, which have increased the Government guarantees to buyers of troubled loan portfolios, and to a depressed real estate market that has further weakened the value of the savings institutions' assets.
The deals before 1989, which were made by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, were intended to protect depositors of insolvent savings institutions by transferring their ownership to new buyers. At that time, the savings industry's insurer lacked the money to close down insolvent savings units and pay off depositors.
To entice buyers to put new capital into the failed institutions and protect deposit obligations, Federal regulators provided a number of financial benefits.
The deals differed greatly, but among the benefits were tax breaks, direct infusions of cash or debt securities, and ''yield maintenance'' agreements, in which the Government protected new buyers from losses on loan portfolios. The theory behind this arrangement was that buyers could be induced to assume some of the Government's obligations if they were given some protections against financial risk.
 
Some Well-Known Buyers
Buyers of these deals included such well-known financiers as Ronald O. Perelman, chief executive of Revlon Inc., and the Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass.
The 1990 cost of the deals was initially expected to be about $1.8 billion, but that has jumped to $5.2 billion. The total cost of the assistance arrangements, which will run for 10 years, is now expected to be about $12 billion higher than initial estimates.
But a spokesman for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation noted today that the $65 billion in anticipated Government payments will be offset by some $10 billion that has come to the Government from asset sales from these deals.
In his testimony before the Senate Appropriations Committee, Mr. Seidman requested $5.2 billion in 1990 and an additional $4 billion in 1991.
The escalating costs of the program led Senator Barbara A. Mikulski to question Mr. Seidman's request for an indefinite appropriation to cover these costs. ''This is a whopper of an underestimate,'' the Maryland Democrat said of the request for additional money. ''I'm concerned about writing a blank check. We will meet our obligations, but we also want fiscal responsibility.''
Mr. Seidman said he favored an indefinite appropriation because the Government was obligated to protect depositors' money.

LENGTH: 1606 words

HEADLINE: DINKINS PROPOSES INCREASES IN TAXES IN HIS FIRST BUDGET

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Striving to put his stamp on New York City's spending in tough times, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday proposed a restrained budget calling for nearly $1 billion in new taxes, deep cuts in services from street cleaning to school aides and a few modest new social and health programs.
In the face of a regional economic slowdown, huge revenue shortfalls and unexpected increases in fixed costs, Mr. Dinkins conceded that his $28 billion budget for the fiscal year that starts July 1 - his first as Mayor -was ''sure to cause more grimaces than grins.''
But even as he proposed to delay hiring 2,177 police officers, cut 417 parks workers, close three fire companies, reduce educational bureaucracy and double the fare on the Staten Island ferry to 50 cents, he added about $40 million worth of small programs for AIDS care, prenatal care, mental health and the homeless.
 
Quality-of-Life Issues
''Some say quality of life is best defined by spotless parks and litter-free roadways,'' Mr. Dinkins said at a crowded news conference in the Blue Room at City Hall. ''But for me it is best exemplified by a happy, healthy baby or by a teen-ager with a diploma in hand and a sparkle in the eye.'' 
As expected, the biggest chunks of Mr. Dinkins's tax proposals called for a $180 million property tax increase, which would cost the typical homeowner $33 and require approval by the City Council, and a $300 million personal income tax surcharge, which would cost the average resident $80 and require approval by the State Legislature.
Other proposals that would require state approval include tripling the automobile use tax to $45, imposing an 8-cent-a-gallon city gasoline tax, increasing the hotel tax to 6 percent from 5 percent and extending the mortgage recording tax to cooperative apartment transactions and increasing it by one-half of 1 percentage point to raise $70 million.
After months of speculation that he might propose layoffs, Mr. Dinkins avoided that drastic step, and he plans to have nearly 8,000 more workers on the payroll by June 1991 than were working last March. He did propose more than $200 million in service cuts and $267 million in ''productivity increases'' that range from slowing city hospitals' payments to vendors to increasing audits to collect unpaid taxes.
 
Delicately Balanced
But fiscal experts said the Mayor's plan, which was higher than the $26.6 billion budget adopted last June, was more a starting point than a finished product. It is delicately balanced on a range of taxes that may not all be approved and productivity measures that may not be achieved and it assumes a 1.5 percent annual wage-increase settlement for municipal workers whose contracts begin to expire this summer and who are demanding more.
Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the City Council, which must act on the budget, said Mr. Dinkins had done ''a very commendable job of trying to share the pain.'' But he said the Council would work to restore trims in sanitation and the police, the so-called ''hard services'' for which it traditionally fights.
Mr. Vallone said he accepted Mr. Dinkins's call for $859 million in new or higher taxes over all. But he said the Council had not yet determined how that figure should be distributed among the various tax measures the Mayor was seeking.
 
Must Go to Legislature
More than $500 million of the Mayor's proposed tax package would require action by the Legislature. Those taxes would come on top of other increases recently passed by the state to balance its own budget, and their approval is by no means certain.
Besides the real-estate tax, Mr. Dinkins has asked the Council to delay promised energy tax cuts to save $130 million and to impose a new 4 percent sales tax on dry cleaning, tailoring and shoe repairs to raise $12 million.
Mr. Vallone said he hoped to reach agreement with the Mayor on what taxes to press for in Albany within 10 days and then to lobby jointly for them. Mr. Dinkins made clear that if Albany failed to approve all the tax measures he seeks, the difference would have to be made up through even higher property taxes by the Council, or even deeper service cuts.
Barry Feinstein, the president of teamsters Local 237, which represents many city workers, said he was ''speechless, stunned and all the bad things I can say'' over the proposed budget. Mr. Feinstein, who has been one of Mr. Dinkins's biggest political supporters, said that the budget plan put too big a tax burden on individuals and not enough on business and that it called for workers in his union to accept wage increases below the rate of inflation.
''It's so unacceptable, so damaging, that we are going to do whatever we have to do to change this budget,'' he said.
Mr. Dinkins has long said he would not support taxes that he believed could drive away business.
 
'Always Painful'
Ronald K. Shelp, the president of the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the New York City Partnership, said that ''while taxes are always painful, particularly here - with the largest state and local tax burden in the nation - we're happy the Mayor's budget does not unfairly target the industries that are creating jobs in New York City'' in the service sector of the economy.
Mr. Dinkins, when asked if his budget had been hard on the middle class while adding programs for the poor, said that if the city failed to address the problems of ''the least among us,'' it would only have to spend more money on social needs later.
Raymond D. Horton, the president of the Citizens Bugdet Commission, a nonprofit group that monitors city finances, said Mr. Dinkins ''deserves credit for realistically stating the problem.'' But he said the Mayor's proposed solution depended on too many variables like the tax proposals and labor settlement to assure now that it would work.
''I think we can anticipate major revisions,'' he said. ''So in that sense, it's precariously balanced.'' Noting that the Council invariably seeks to restore programs the Mayor has cut, he said it would face a special test this year, the first in which it has not shared power on the budget with the Board of Estimate, which was abolished by changes in the City Charter last year.
''They're really going to have the spotlight on them,'' Mr. Horton said. ''And they're going to have to take the heat one way or the other.''
Mr. Vallone took jocular note of that predicament yesterday when he was asked what he would do in response to the myriad citizens' groups that will be supplicants at the Council's doorstep between now and the end of June. ''We're going to introduce legislation to bring back the Board of Estimate,'' he said, adding that ''we'll do the best we can to try to reflect their concerns.
 
'Very, Very Important'
Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the State Financial Control Board, praised what he called the Mayor's cautious economic predictions and plans for raising an additional $384 million from tougher tax enforcement efforts next year.
But he added: ''It's too soon to say if it's realistically balanced. Obviously to have a plan for an almost $900 million tax program means that the next six weeks are very, very important.''
Mr. Dinkins's plan would cut about 1,300 nonclassroom workers from the Board of Education through attrition, part of about $42 million he had proposed to cut from education programs. Late Wednesday, the city agreed to restore about $22 million of that money for classroom and after-school programs in an agreement with the State Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller.
Mr. Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat, had insisted that the money go to education in exchange for supporting legislation that would pave the way for the transfer to the city of $1.5 billion in surplus funds from the Municipal Assistance Corporation, a state-created fiscal agency, over the next eight years. The city had been counting on $290 million of the surplus to help balance its budget for the coming year.
But the city's Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, said even the lesser cuts ''cannot be taken without hurting our classroom services,'' and he said he would press to restore them.
The State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, has yet to approve the M.A.C. proposal, and Mr. Vallone said the Council believed the measure could not be acted on by the Legislature without a home-rule message from the Council.
 
Delays for Police
Mr. Dinkins would also again delay hiring police officers, planning only two classes of recruits totaling 2,734 officers for the city's three police departments - transit, housing and the main force - over the coming year, instead of the three classes totaling 4,889 recruits that he announced in February. That would increase the overall head count by about 500 officers, to 32,000 officers, for the combined forces.
Seeking to put the best face on this news, city officials said redeployment of officers within the main city department and the transfer of some duties to civilians would mean that the number of officers estimated to be actually available for street duty there would rise slightly, to 9,475 from 9,379.
But senior police officials have long said such enforcement-strength numbers were only rough estimates.
In the mayoral campaign, Mr. Dinkins criticized former Mayor Edward I. Koch for creating ''phantom cops'' by taking credit for proposed hirings in his budgets and then failing to follow through.
''We're going to deliver that which is in the budget,'' Mr. Dinkins said.
''Or I'm dead,'' added his Budget Director, Philip R. Michael.
''At least,'' Mr. Dinkins said.

HEADLINE: Revised Figures Shows Economy Is Still Sluggish

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Deflating a recent impression that the economy was chugging along quite nicely, the Commerce Department reported yesterday that the sluggish economic growth that had set in last September had continued through the first quarter.
In its second estimate of the quarter's economic growth, the Commerce Department said the gross national product, measuring the value of all the nation's goods and services, had expanded at an annual rate of only 1.3 percent from January through March and not, as estimated last month, at a healthy 2.1 percent.
The sharp downward revision came mostly because the automobile industry devoted its energies more to selling off a huge stockpile of vehicles than to manufacturing new cars and trucks. In April, the Commerce Department greatly overestimated actual auto production in the quarter. 
 
Trouble Spots Keep Shifting
Economists described the January-to-March performance as another example of the economy's being dragged down each quarter by a different crisis - the Boeing Company strike in the fourth quarter, the backlog of unsold vehicles in the first quarter and a decline in housing construction that is developing in the current quarter.
''The areas of concern rotate, but there is always another one around the corner to drag down the economy,'' said Albert T. Sommers, a senior fellow at the Conference Board, a business organization. ''That's indicative of the fact that there is no central driving force - strong consumer spending or strong capital spending, for example -to make the economy boom, despite these incidents.''
There were some strong points, however. Exports increased more than the Commerce Department originally estimated, responding to the demands of robust European and Asian economies. Capital spending also rose, mostly because many service-sector companies bought computers and other electronic gear. And despite budgetary problems at the Federal, state and local levels, government purchases remained strong.
But the stock and bond markets were not impressed by the report. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,855.55, essentially unchanged, and bond prices fell slightly.
''The market already had in mind, before the numbers came out, that the economy is weak,'' said Robert Giordano, co-director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company, the Wall Street investment house.
The latest Commerce Department reading means that the American economy has been growing sluggishly for six months. The fourth-quarter G.N.P. growth was only 1.1 percent, at an annual rate, partly because of the 45-day strike at Boeing that halted the manufacture of multimillion-dollar commercial airliners.
Now that the inventory of automobiles has been cut to below a 60 days' supply, from more than 90 days, most economists expect the auto and truck industry to function more or less normally. They say production should move up to an annual rate of 9.5 million units, from the 8.5 million in the first quarter, with sales roughly matching production.
Had the 9.5 million production ratebeen in effect in the first quarter, it might have meant an extra $18 billion for the economy, enough to add more than a percentage point to G.N.P. growth, said Roger Brinner, chief economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill.
As it was, the 1.3 percent rise represented a minuscule $11.2 billion increase in the value of the nation's goods and services. That brought the G.N.P. to a total of $4.188 trillion, after adjustment for inflation.
With the automobile industry apparently rebounding, the big second-quarter concern is new-home construction, a huge sector of the economy involving not only home building but also the industries that supply furniture, appliances, plumbing and the like.
Construction had jumped to nearly 1.6 million homes at an annual rate in the unseasonably warm January and February weather, but by April the figure had plunged to 1.2 million.
''A lot of the construction activity that would have begun in the spring was initiated early - in effect, borrowed from the second quarter,'' said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
 
Tight Rein on Inventories
The G.N.P. report noted, in effect, that businesses had kept their inventories at relatively low levels. That raised the possibility that the economy will get a lift from new stockpiling as factories step up production. Consumer spending, in fact, rose at a 2.4 percent annual rate, reflecting stronger demand than in the fourth quarter, but far below the robust spending of the boom years in the mid-1980's.
''There might be some stimulus to the economy from inventory rebuilding, but not much,'' said Mr. Giordano, expressing a commonly held view.
Inflation, as measured by the fixed-weight G.N.P. price index, rose at an annual rate of 6.7 percent, its largest gain since the fourth quarter of 1981, when it ran at a 7 percent rate, the report said. But the department pointed out that half the gain reflected a sharp run-up in food and energy costs as a result of unusually cold weather last December. Consumer prices fell sharply in April, and this decline should be reflected in a lower inflation rate in the second-quarter G.N.P. reports, economists said.
Corporate profits remained anemic, rising only two-tenths of 1 percent, on an after-tax basis, to $157 billion. A more important measure -the profits earned only from actual production - was up seven-tenths of 1 percent. It had fallen for three consecutive quarters.
Economists took the upturn to mean that business was having an easier time increasing prices to offset, in particular, rising labor costs. ''Now that inflation abroad is pushing up the prices of foreign goods, American producers have more leverage to pass through their own costs,'' Mr. Roach said.
Mr. Sommers agreed that profits might have turned the corner, but he noted that at their current level, they were only 5.2 percent of the total value of G.N.P., the lowest ratio since 1982, a recession year. In the mid-1980's the ratio was regularly 6.5 percent to 7 percent.

LENGTH: 551 words

HEADLINE: LATIN AID PACKAGE VOTED BY CONGRESS

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Friday, May 25

 BODY:
The Congress, eager to leave town for a Memorial Day recess, today gave final approval to a long-delayed emergency spending bill that includes $720 million in aid President Bush requested for the fledgling democracies in Panama and Nicaragua.
The House approved the measure on a 308-to-108 vote on Thursday night and the Senate followed suit with a voice vote shortly after midnight.
The $4 billion spending bill, which also includes $400 million in housing loan guarantees to help Israel resettle Soviet Jews and money for scores of domestic programs, now goes to the President, who is expected to sign it quickly. 
Mr. Bush, who requested the Central American aid months ago, has repeatedly upbraided Congress for delaying the funds to bolster the new Government of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro in Nicaragua and to help Panama recover from a United States trade embargo and the American invasion last December.
Under the bill, Nicaragua would receive $300 million, including $30 million to help resettle the United States-backed Nicaraguan rebels. Last week, Mr. Bush was forced to turn down a request from Mrs. Chamorro for an emergency loan to help her struggling government stay financially afloat.
 
Panama to Get $420 Million
Panama, which has seen its economy devasted by American trade sanctions imposed during the rule of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, would receive $420 million. General Noriega was forced out by the United States in the invasion and is awaiting trial on drug trafficking charges in Miami.
His successor, President Guillermo Endara, has told the Bush Administration that the country will need considerably more assistance to regain its economic footing and to stem rising unemployment that could jeopardize his government, which was installed by the United States after the invasion.
Other foreign assistance money in the bill includes $30 million for African nations, $20 million for the Caribbean, with $3 million of that sum earmarked for Haiti and $8.7 million earmarked for Jamaica. The Soviet republic of Armenia would get $5 million to aid victims of the 1988 earthquake, and $4 million was allotted for development aid to Romania.
A provision sought by the Senate to set aside $10 million for the establishment of a United States Embassy in Lithuania should the United States establish formal diplomatic ties, was dropped from the legislation after strong objections from the Administration. The State Department said such language would limit the President's flexibility in dealing with the sensitive subject of Lithuania's declaration of independence from the Soviet Union.
 
Quarrels Over Domestic Spending
Although legislators have supported the proposal for assistance to Panama and Nicaragua, their quarrels over domestic spending, particularly projects in their home states or districts, repeatedly delayed final action on the spending bill.
The measure includes $1.2 billion to make up for a shortfall in financing for the food stamp program, $545 million for veterans medical benefits, $110 million to help the Census Bureau complete the 1990 census, and $216 million in disaster relief aid, primarily for Southern states hit by hurricanes and flooding.
About half of the new spending would be paid for by reductions in the Pentagon's budget.

HEADLINE: JAPANESE EXPRESS REMORSE TO KOREA

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 24

 BODY:
Emperor Akihito apologized tonight for Japan's brutal subjugation of Korea nearly a half century ago. It was the first time that unambiguous acceptance of responsibility for Japanese wartime aggression had ever been expressed at such a high level.
''I think of the sufferings your people underwent during this unfortunate period, which was brought about by my country, and cannot but feel the deepest regret,'' the 56-year-old Emperor told the visiting South Korean President, Roh Tae Woo, at a state banquet. His remarks were directed pointedly to the people of the Korean peninsula, which is now divided into North and South Korea. 
The phrasing was a departure from the more circumscribed locutions used by the Emperor's father, Hirohito, who in remarks addressed to the United States and China referred to the war years as a ''regrettable'' or ''unfortunate'' period but stopped short of acknowledging any specific Japanese responsibility. Akihito succeeded Hirohito upon his death early last year.
But illustrating the continuing sensitivity toward Japan among its neighbors, it is not clear whether Korean citizens will accept Emperor Akihito's declaration as sufficiently contrite. [On Friday, President Roh opened the second day of his visit with an appeal that Japan and Korea ''break off the shackles of the past.'' [He avoided any specific reference to Japanese colonization of Korea, referring only to the ''past period of darkness'' and recalling the case of a Korean child beaten for insisting on using his own name rather than a Japanese name. Mr. Roh said earlier that he thought Emperor Akihito's apology was significant.] Koreans Protest Visit Japanese occupation of Korea from 1910 to the end of World War II was especially brutal, involving the forced removal of Koreans to do hard labor in Japanese labor camps in Japan and elsewhere in Asia, expropriation of property, destruction of Korean cultural artifacts and even the requirement that Koreans adopt Japanese names. Many South Koreans, nursing centuries of resentment against the Japanese in spite of the improved relationship of the last two decades, have been marching, protesting and even rioting in recent weeks in opposition to President Roh's visit to Tokyo this week.
The visit is the first by a Korean chief of state to Japan since 1984. At that time, Hirohito, who died after ruling for 62 years, made comments that were far more ambiguous than Emperor Akihito's today.
Emperor Akihito's remarks, delivered at the banquet after Mr. Roh arrived in the morning, were the product of weeks of tough and anxious negotiations between Seoul and Tokyo after Korean demands that Japan do more to apologize for its past.
At one point, Mr. Roh's aides were understood to have told Japan that Emperor Akihito would not be welcome to visit South Korea if the apology came not from him but from Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu.
The impasse on the statement had cast a shadow over the state visit, demonstrating that the two most important economic powers of northeast Asia were unable to overcome old hostilities to cooperate on matters of vital concern to their future, such as sharing technology and economic projects. Indeed, although the Emperor's statement may well be accepted, the talks and threats leading up to it have embarrassed Tokyo, underscoring the extent to which Japan still has problems coming to terms with its militaristic past.
 
An Embarrassment for Tokyo
At first, Japan told South Korea it would be improper for the Emperor to issue a strong apology, since Japan's Constitution - written by the occupying Americans after the war - reduced the Emperor's status to that of a mere ''symbol'' of the state, without any political powers. This contention was dismissed by Koreans as an excuse for reluctance to apologize among traditionalists in the ruling Liberal Democratic Party.
Japan then agreed to have the Emperor issue an apology written by government officials. But various versions were disclosed to the press, prompting reports that Koreans found them inadequate. Each disclosure forced the Government to revise its statement, Japanese officials said.
Emperor Akihito's comments were not the first expression of regret from Japan, but past comments on the topic were seen as ambiguous. For example, in 1984, when President Chun Doo Hwan became the first Korean leader to visit Japan, Emperor Hirohito said ''it is indeed regrettable that there was an unfortunate past between us for a period in this century and I believe that it should not be repeated again.''
Many took this statement as an evasion, as if the Emperor were talking about a freak storm instead of troops marching in his name. Japanese responded by saying that the ambiguous comments were simply a reflection of the late Emperor's elliptical speaking style. Mr. Roh replied that even if that was true, Koreans could not understand the statement.
As promised, Mr. Kaifu echoed the Emperor's statement today with his own strongly worded apology, expressing ''my sincere remorse and honest apologies'' for Japanese actions, which he said ''inflicted unbearable suffering and sorrow on the people of the Korean peninsula.'' Japanese officials said that, too, was the strongest apology for Japanese wartime actions ever issued by a Japanese Prime Minister.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Bush's News Session on China's Trade Status With U.S.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's White House news conference today, as recorded by the Federal News Service:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
Well, today, after long and thorough deliberation, I have determined that M.F.N. status, trade status for China, should be extended for a year.
M.F.N. is not a special favor. It's not a concession. It's the basis of everyday trade. And taking M.F.N. away is one thing I said I would not do, that is, in doing that take steps that would hurt the Chinese people themselves. I do not want to do that. 
To express America's outrage at the tragedy of Tiananmen, the Congress and my Administration promptly enacted sanctions against China. These sanctions remain basically unchanged today. And while implementing those sanctions I have repeatedly made clear that I did not want to hurt the Chinese people. And this was a difficult decision, weighing our impulse to lash out in outrage that we all feel against a sober assessment -weighing that against a sober assessment of our nation's long-term interests.
I concluded that it is in our best interest and the interest of the Chinese people to continue China's trade status. Not to do so would hurt the United States.
Trade would drop, dramatically hurting exporters, consumers and investors. China buys about $6 billion a year of American aircraft and wheat and chemicals, lumber and other products. Lose this market and we lose American jobs - aircraft workers in the West, farmers in the Great Plains, high tech employees in the Northeast. Our economic competition will not join us in denying M.F.N. Without M.F.N. an average of 40 percent higher costs for Chinese imports will turn into higher prices for American consumers.
Hong Kong weighed on my mind. Hong Kong would be an innocent victim of our dispute with Beijing - 20,000 jobs and $10 billion could be lost in a colony that is a model of free enterprise spirit. The United Kingdom and China's neighbors have urged me to continue M.F.N. Korea, Japan, Thailand, Singapore, even Taiwan made clear that M.F.N. should be retained.
In recent weeks China has taken modest steps that appear intended to show responsiveness to our concerns. Beijing lifted martial law in Tibet, restored consular access there, giving us a chance to judge the situation for ourselves. Two-hundred and eleven detainees were recently released and then their names provided for the first time.
While we welcome these and earlier steps, they are, let's face it, far from adequate, and I am not basing my decision on the steps that the Chinese have taken so far. Most important of all, as we mark the anniversary of Tiananmen, we must realize that by maintaining our involvement with China we will continue to promote the reforms for which the victims of Tiananmen gave their lives.
The people in China who trade with us are the engine of reform opening to the outside world. During the past 10 years we've seen our engagement in China contribute to the forces for justice and reason that were peacefully protested in Beijing, and our responsibility to them is best met not by isolating those forces from contact with us or by strengthening the hand of reaction, but by keeping open the channels of commerce and communication.
Our Ambassador came to see me here in the Oval Office the other day and told me that not only the people that he is in contact with, but the students there, the intellectuals there, all favor - there in China, favor the continuation of M.F.N.
So, this is why I made the decision I have made . . .
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 
Human Rights Issue
 
Q. Mr. President, it's been a year now since the world has watched China mow its own people down in Tiananmen Square. How can we expect the pro-democracy movement causes around the world to have faith in the United States when they see a reward to Beijing such as the M.F.N?
 
A. . . . I don't think this is a reward to Beijing. I think it is very important we keep these commercial contacts. I think it is in the interest of the United States that we keep these contacts. M.F.N. is based on emigration, and emigration has continued from China at respectable levels. And so, that is why I am making this decision.
And what irks me is when some of the people up on the Hill accuse me of being less interested than they are in human rights. I think I - I think we're on the right track here. . . . It is not a favor we're doing.
 
Cambodia Policy
 
Q. Is it time now, sir, for a review of our policy toward Cambodia in light of the expressed willingness of the Government there to permit internationally supervised elections, and in light of the fact that our policy has drawn widespread condemnation for helping directly or indirectly the Khmer Rouge, the --
 
A. . . . Anytime we can get free and fair, certifiably fair elections, we should - we should be encouraged by that. I am troubled by it, because it isn't clear in Cambodia at all.
 
Q. Well, are you made particularly uncomfortable, sir, by the fact that our support for the non-Communist resistance has the effect, at least, since they are fighting alongside the Khmer Rouge, of helping the notorious Khmer Rouge?
 
A. To the degree it has any effect to help them, yes, I am uncomfortable about it. But when we have this kind of compromise that has been worked out at - it - at this juncture, I think we're on the right track. But there's a discomfort level for it because of the brutality of the Khmer Rouge. And if anybody even perceives that we're trying to help those people, why, then it does cause discomfort. But I think we're on the right track. We are reviewing the whole policy now.
 
Gorbachev and Lithuania
 
Q. About a month or so ago you said that you thought Mr. Gorbachev was showing willingness to compromise and the Lithuanians only showing some willingness to compromise. Is that still your assessment, or have you reviewed the balance on that?
 
A. Well, I - you're presenting me with some - some semantic difference that I did not intend to make. But I - I'm not here to assess blame. What I'm here to do is to assess the - you know, to try to encourage a dialogue on this important question.
 
Contact With China
 
Q. Mr. President, critics of this decision on China believe it is based too heavily on a blind faith that you have in those leaders based on your experience as envoy over there. What message does this send to the younger generation of Chinese leaders who are going to come along and replace those in power now?
 
A. It says that economic contacts are the best way to keep the economic reforms going forward. It says that the more economic contacts we have with China, the more they are going to see the fruits of free market economies. I have told you that the students in China, according to our Ambassador, want to see this M.F.N. continue. And so, it should send no message other than that isolation is bad and economic involvement is good.
 
Taxes for Americans
 
Q. Several polls, including one broadcast last night, are showing that most Americans think that there will be taxes, and about half - in fact, they think you'll go along with taxes - and about half say they're willing to go along with taxes themselves if the case can be proven that taxes are needed. Does this give you more leeway as you make your decision?
 
A. Look, I have stated right here at this podium that I'm not going to go into the details of these - what might be discussed up there. I've said that there's no preconditions. I'm satisfied with the way the process is going. Indeed, I should give credit to Mr. Gephardt for the conduct of these initial meetings. Our people - Dick Darman, Nick Brady, John Sununu up there - all working in good faith.
And I've seen those surveys, but it is way too early to start talking about remedies here. I want to let that process go forward and then, when I get agreement, I will go out and say to the American people, Here's what we recommend. And I'm not going to prejudge it.
 
Q. Some of the Democrats up on the Hill say that you're ducking the tough issue by saying what you just said, that you're not going to tell the American people --
 
A. Yes, I've heard that criticism.
 
Q. They want you to outline the problem and explain to the American people that it's going to take sacrifice. Are you ready to do at least that?
 
A. I'm going to outline the problem when we get agreement so we can go forward with the solution. If I outlined the problem now, I'd go rely on some of the fact that the Congress appropriates all the money and raises all the revenues. That's their obligation. And I'm not one to dwell on surveys recently, but I will point out that people understand that the Congress bears a greater responsibility for this.
But I'm not trying to assign blame; that's why I'm not doing it right now. That's why I'm not doing it. That's why I'm saying we're going to sit and talk. Because if I go out now and say what I think without dealing in, you know, keeping in mind the need to get some progress, I might say something like I just said, and I don't want to do that.
 
Q. But they're going to come back at you today up on the Hill, and they're going to say, See, he's not showing leadership. What's your answer to that?
 
A. My answer is I am. We've gotten these people together. I've said there's no preconditions. Let's talk. And I think it's making progress.
 
Arms Control Talks
 
Q. The Soviets have slowed down the negotiations on conventional arms control. You are not going to be signing a Start treaty, which we'd been led to believe was going to be the centerpiece of this summit. It looks like there won't be any kind of trade treaty signed. Has the summit changed from one of consolidating gains and moving ahead to just trying to get the relationship back on track?
 
A. I wouldn't phrase it exactly that way. . . . We've got a lot to talk about. I don't want to . . . indicate I don't think there will be significant progress on Start. I hope we can move things forward on C.F.E. . . . I hope I've expressed with great enthusiasm and passion my desire to do something about chemical weapons. And it looks to me like we are very, very close there. So we've got a lot of things that I think will be seen properly as progress, but there's enormous problems that just need to be talked about where I can't say there will be an answer.
 
Israel and Arabs
 
Q. Mr. President, the conflict in Israel between the Israelis and the Palestinians seems to become increasingly violent.
 
A. Yes.
 
Q. Do you think the Israelis at this point are acting appropriately and responsibly?
 
A. Well, I have called on both sides for restraint. I've called on the Israeli forces to show constraint. I'm worried about it. I am troubled about the loss of human life in this area. . . . And the answer is to get these talks going. And I will do everything I can to - to get the talks for peace going. . . .
 
Q. Well, Mr. President, is there anything that the United States can do with its enormous clout with Israel, to push the Israelis to be more open to these peace talks?
 
A. Well, the problem we face right now is this, almost an interregnum. I mean, there's no firm decision-making government in place. So, we're in a bit of a hiatus because of that.
 
Balancing the Budget
 
Q. Mr. President, what happened to your promise to balance the budget without raising taxes? Are we going to make it?
 
A. Are we going to make the promise? Things are complicated out there on this subject and we are trying very hard to get a budget agreement and that's the way it is, and we'll see how we go. And I've reported, I think that we've started off now in a bipartisan nature doing a good job. I wish we could control the spending side better.
 
Meetings in Moscow
 
Q. I'd like to ask about the news report coming out of - in the aftermath of the Moscow meetings between - with Secretary Baker, that you were not as pleased with the outcome of those talks, especially pertaining to Start, as Secretary Baker was.
 
A. There is no light between us on that at all. The Administration has a united - unified position. It is a sound position. There's no point just before you sit down to say, ''They caved. They gave more than we did.'' But I am very satisfied with what - where we stand. All I want to do is be sure we can move forward and get - get these deals finalized, and we may not be able to do that. . . . I'll tell you what troubles me is that we're not -somebody asked the question here - we're not further along on conventional forces. But the strategic arms talks are going very well. . . . To get back to your question, there isn't any daylight between the White House and the State Department or the arms control community or Defense. . . . Now we're going to have some criticism. Any time you make a deal you have editiorials out there telling you exactly how it should be done. But I am confident that we're on the right track. . . .
 
Q. Some people are saying that conventional forces is now the real litmus test of Soviet intentions given the developments in Eastern Europe. If they don't pull those troops back out of Eastern Europe, then that tells you something about their ultimate intentions. How do you --
 
A. I'd say - well, I think that - I think that that's a good point and one that I expect the Soviets would want to dispel through action, because I don't get the feeling that they are opposed to C.F.E. agreements.

HEADLINE: DEMOCRATS IRATE OVER BUSH SILENCE

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
President Bush ignited Democratic tempers in Congress today when he refused once again to address the public on the severity of the deficit problem or to offer proposals to solve it.
Speaking at an impromptu White House news conference, Mr. Bush said Congress bears the primary responsibility for dealing with fiscal matters. He said he would not offer more detailed descriptions of the causes for the swelling deficit or make public any recommendations for a solution until after Administration and Congressional negotiators reached a budget agreement.
Democrats wasted little time attacking the President's statement. ''Sitting at Ronald Reagan's right hand, the President learned how to duck, not how to lead,'' said Representative David R. Obey, a Wisconsin Democrat, whose views were widely echoed by Democrats in the House and Senate. Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Senate Budget Committee, complained, ''The American people have learned more about the Soviet economy over the past two days than they have about their own.'' 
 
Fourth Round of Talks
The jousting came as the budget negotiators entered the fourth round of talks with some signs of progress on defining the size of the deficit-cutting package they want to achieve. The Administration negotiators also presented their latest economic forecast, which included more pessimistic assumptions about interest rates, inflation and economic growth.
Mr. Sasser said Democrats were demanding a package that would slash the deficit by $600 billion over five years, with $60 billion of the cut coming in the 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1. Republicans are talking about a $500 billion deficit cut over five years, with about $50 billion in cuts for 1991.
Congressional negotiators in both parties said discussions of more specific proposals for spending cuts or tax increases would come after lawmakers return from a two-week Memorial Day recess scheduled to begin on Friday. For the first time since the talks began last week, lawmakers offered a timetable, saying they would aim for resolution, one way or the other, within the next 30 to 40 days.
But the subject uppermost in the minds of Democrats today was the President's news conference, and many of them joked bitterly that Mr. Bush was the first President in modern memory apparently willing to cede power to Congress. Mr. Bush told reporters at the news conference that if pressed to outline his thoughts now on the deficit crunch, he would say: ''Congress appropriates all the money and raises all the revenues. That's their obligation.''
Insisting that he was not trying to assign blame or sour the budget talks, Mr. Bush added that ''people understand that the Congress bears a greater responsibility for this.''
 
Democrats Angered by Bush
Angry Democrats on and off the budget negotiating team responded in kind. ''Harry Truman had a message on his desk; it said, 'The buck stops here,' '' snapped Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. ''The President's the one who called this summit. If the problem is that serious, the American people are entitled to hear how serious it is.''
Mr. Obey, a House Approporiations subcommittee chairman, said the President was abdicating responsiblity and jeopardizing any chances of an agreement in the budget talks. ''When you run for President, you are supposed to do something, not just be somebody,'' he said, adding that any governor who adopted the posture Mr. Bush has taken would be ''laughed out of the state capital.''
Some Democrats said their patience for protracted talks was wearing thin. ''If they don't get progress in the next three or four weeks, then we ought to walk away from the table,'' said Representative Marty Russo of Illinois, a member of the House Budget Committee but not a participant in the talks.
 
'Golden Opportunity' Seen
''This is a joke, we know what the paramaters are and we know that we want a bold approach that locks the deficit reduction in for five years,'' he said. ''They have a golden opportunity,'' he said of the Administration team. ''If they screw this up now, they deserve the wrath of the American people.''
Administration forecasters are now assuming that interest rates on three-month Treasury bills will average 7.7 percent in 1990, up from the 6.7 percent rate that Administration officials had assumed in January. Longer-term interest rates will average 8.6 percent in 1990, compared with the 7.7 percent level assumed in January.
The Administration forecast economic growth of only 2.4 percent this year and 2.9 percent in 1991, compared with January assumptions of 2.6 percent for 1990 and 3.3 percent for 1991. Inflation, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, will rise by 4.8 percent in 1990 and 4.2 percent in 1991, according to the new estimates.
