SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 461 words

HEADLINE: Power, of a Sort, to the People

 BODY:
A referendum to put policy to a popular test? It's a familiar idea in this country, especially California, but in the Soviet Union? Not for centuries, in czarist or Communist times, have the people been consulted about fundamental issues of government. But now, in another remarkable departure, that's exactly what Mikhail Gorbachev proposes.
No theorist can tell him how to shift from a state-strangled command economy to freer competitive markets. He has to feel his way, improvising as he goes along. A referendum is his latest idea. It's not exactly power to the people, but it's sure a long way from all power to the Soviets. 
Promoting a sense of popular empowerment might just be the only way to implement the desperately needed economic reform - reform that Americans want to see succeed for practical, as well as philosophical reasons.
How can a society accustomed to state paternalism and job security introduce free markets? Poland has chosen the abrupt way, the cold bath. Its Government is not exactly an elected one. But Solidarity, which helped form it and pushed radical economic reform, enjoys broad popular support.
No such social contract exists between the unelected President of the Soviet Union and the peoples of its various republics. And there is little backing for the regime of Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, whose slow-moving reforms won out over the more radical measures proposed by Gorbachev advisers.
The referendum Mr. Gorbachev now proposes could help him either way. If he wins, he wins. A vote of confidence would legitimate the tough measures to follow. Strong support would permit him to push for a market system even faster. And if he loses, he could still win, blaming the Ryzhkov regime and replacing it with new managers.
There's no turning back, Mr. Gorbachev insists, and he's surely right. The apparatus of state controls has been partly dismantled. But until it is replaced by markets, Soviet goods and services will not improve. And it takes the people, not just leaders, to make markets work.
Even so, a plebiscite is no panacea. There's a real risk that voters, spurred on by radical and conservative critics alike, may seize the chance to register resounding disgust with Moscow's economic mismanagement by rejecting the move to markets. The populace is experiencing rising inflation and fears massive unemployment. It still looks upon entrepreneurs as profiteers - which they will be unless truly competitive enterprises spring up to drive prices down.
But Mr. Gorbachev's purpose is not economic; it's profoundly political. If he's to succeed in transforming the economy, he will need wide public support, and that means transforming politics. Let the Soviet people speak: what an extraordinary idea!

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUB-DATE: May 25, 1990,

LENGTH: 503 words

HEADLINE: Offshore Oil Drilling: A Mistake

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Troubled Oil, or Troubled Waters?'' (editorial, May 8) raises some good points regarding our national energy needs and the offshore oil dilemma. However, it is important to point out that oil on the face of the earth runs out in about 100 years. If we do not begin to wean ourselves from oil, we will not only continue the fossil-fuel pollution crisis, smog and the greenhouse effect, we will be bestowing on our grandchildren a chaotic economy frantically attempting to institute conservation and renewable fuel programs. 
Coastal oil development is not the answer to this dilemma.
The idea that we should pursue coastal oil development as an essential aspect of our national energy policy is part of the illusion that we can endlessly spend our and the world's finite resources with impunity. We cannot. Nor can we afford to suffer the environmental degradation of an oil spill like the Santa Barbara well blowout of 1969 or tanker accidents like the Exxon Valdez.
Oil is a potent toxin. At 100 parts per million, oil is classified as hazardous waste. Oil at 5 parts per billion impairs the ability of fish to hunt by affecting their sense of smell. Oil at 1 microgram per liter kills fish and shellfish larvae. Oil destroys both the phytoplankton and the zooplankton, the source of both the food chain and most of the world's oxygen. And as witnessed so tragically with the Exxon Valdez spill, oil killed sea mammals and sea birds in large numbers through hypothermia, poisoning and respiratory disease.
Oil passes into the food chain. Studies show that 13 years after an oil spill, oil at 100 parts per million can still be measured in sediments and being released from sediments.
Offshore oil drilling causes severe air pollution. One exploratory drill ship produces the smog equivalent of 7,000 cars driven 50 miles per day. As shown in both the Valdez spill and the recent Huntington Beach, Calif., spill, coastal tourism and commercial fishing suffer irreparable harm.
It is important to place the offshore oil energy debate in a proper context. We can have energy and a healthy unpolluted environment: they are not mutually exclusive.
Sixty-three percent of our oil needs go toward transportation. In the United States, we are now at the 1985 standard of 27.5 fleet miles per gallon for automobiles. Modern technology, however, can produce cars capable of achieving 107 miles per gallon; and there are cars on today's market that achieve 58 miles per gallon.
If we raised fleet miles per gallon to 40 by the year 2000, we could save four times all of the oil that exists off both the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of the United States. Indeed, if we were to institute a winterization program for the United States, we could save more than two times the oil that exists off both our coastlines. We don't have to settle for a future of disastrous oil spills that ruin our marine environment.
 
TED DANSON
Pres., American Oceans Campaign
 Santa Monica, Calif., May 11, 1990

HEADLINE: New York Loses Badly With New Hotel Tax

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''The Budget: Late and Ugly'' (editorial, May 17) aptly characterizes the New York State budget, but in listing the new taxes to be imposed, omits the occupancy tax on hotel rooms of $100 or more. Tourism is New York State's second largest revenue producer and New York City's third. This multibillion-dollar industry brings revenue and jobs to millions of people. The tax represents fiscal suicide for a healthy industry.
Most of the hotels affected are in New York City and Long Island. Yet our downstate legislators refused to recognize this fact. As a result, the tax on New York City's hotel rooms will skyrocket to nearly 21 percent, possibly the highest in the world. The occupancy tax, coupled with the decimation of funding for the New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau, sets the city's tourism industry for fiscal disaster.
The imposition of the hotel occupancy tax is an economic boon for New Jersey. Its tourism industry will be the real beneficiary of this tax. And the real losers will be New York State and the millions of people who are employed in the hospitality industry.
 
JOSEPH E. SPINNATO
President
Hotel Assn. of New York City
 New York, May 18, 1990

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
People or Monsters?

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
As we approach the first anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre, China tugs at our understanding and our conscience. In a world of spreading democracy, how can so vast and talented a nation remain under authoritarian rule? Is there reason to hope for change? What should we on the outside do to help?
There are profound insights into such questions in a new book, ''A Higher Kind of Loyalty,'' by Liu Binyan. It is a memoir of life in contemporary China, a gripping memoir. It is also an exploration of how people come, and remain, under the sway of tyranny. 
Liu Binyan is China's most important and most courageous journalist. In the brief periods when it was possible to publish honest accounts of life in the People's Republic, he traveled around the country reporting on corruption and injustice. Millions read him and put their hopes in him after his devastating 1979 article on Communist Party cadres' abuse of power, ''People or Monsters?''
In a sense Liu Binyan's greatest story is his own life. For 22 years, between 1957 and 1979, he was in disgrace as a ''rightist.'' For 13 of those years he had to live apart from his wife and children, working as a farm laborer.
Yet it was a long time before he lost his faith in Mao Zedong and the party. He kept thinking that the leaders would correct the horrors he saw and reported. But the book chronicles how waves of ''reform'' always petered out, leaving the corrupt untouched. He came to see that the real issue at the top was not ''right'' or ''left'' but personal power.
''The Chinese people . . . will not tolerate this state any longer,'' he wrote at the end of the book. ''The handful of octogenarians and the privileged bureaucratic clique whom they represent will neither change their ways nor hand over power. Thus they are doomed to destruction.''
In 1987 Liu Binyan was expelled from the party along with Fang Lizhi, the great scientist who is now living in asylum in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing. Mr. Liu was allowed to go to the United States in 1988.
Mr. Liu and his equally courageous wife, Zhu Hong, were in Boston the other day, and we talked about the current situation. I asked whether China could insulate itself from the surge of democracy elsewhere in the world. Both shook their heads no.
''The China of 20 years ago could,'' Mr. Liu said. But control from the center is much weaker now, after the turmoil of the Cultural Revolution and then a decade of economic change.
That loss of control is clear despite the massacre, Mr. Liu said. ''Before the massacre we didn't have underground organizations; now we do, in many provinces. We didn't have underground publications, but now we do.''
Leaders of the democracy movement have escaped from China after months in hiding, Mr. Liu pointed out, although their pictures were posted everywhere as wanted. They got out, he said, because they had help from many, ''including even security officials.''
But Mr. Liu noted that China's Communist Party is much more deep-rooted than those in Eastern Europe. It was not installed by the Soviet Union but won power on its own. And few of the Chinese people, he said, ''know about the terrible things that happened in these 40 years.
''The great famine in the early 1960's, for instance. I myself only learned in the 1980's that 20 to 30 million people died, so ordinary people do not know.
''When they think of the party, they still have illusions. They say, 'Maybe the party itself was good, but there were corrupted officials who did bad things.' They think of the party as something abstract.''
Mr. Liu said there are important forces of change inside the party, ''officials at all levels who oppose the massacre, who oppose corruption. Potentially we have people like Gorbachev. But they don't show themselves, because the time is not right.''
What should the United States do? I asked. Mr. Liu did not disagree with President Bush's decision to extend most-favored-nation trading status to China, but said Mr. Bush should ''exert more pressure on the issue of human rights.''
So far, he said, the President has little to show for all his friendly gestures toward Deng Xiaoping. ''In China we would say, 'Deng Xiaoping never gave Bush any face.'
''It seems to us that Mr. Bush overestimates Deng's control and the stability of his rule - just as the United States did with the nationalist government more than 40 years ago. You helped that government when it was going to be toppled. You lost the government, and at the same time you lost the people - the people's feeling for America.''

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Shopping Siren Sings This Song: IKEA! IKEA!

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

DATELINE: ELIZABETH, N.J.

 BODY:
People worry that America doesn't produce anything useful. Trade deficits persist, savings and loans fail, junk-bond wizards can afford $600 million fines. Yet there's a bright spot: The economy still churns out world-class shoppers.
IKEA, the Swedish home-furnishings chain, held a grand opening of a store the size of seven football fields here on Wednesday, and New York-area shoppers did themselves proud - 3,000 surged in during the first 15 minutes, 25,000 that day. Some had waited in line days to qualify for prizes. At 6 A.M., with three hours to go, a bad rumor about door-prize practices spread, and Karen Battle chanted, ''False advertising! Consumer unity!'' (That brought results: Store officials rushed out, vowing an equitable-prize policy.) They came to shop in a big way. Beata Schmid brought a U-Haul, Ed Kensinger and Bill Kochi rented a van. Something in Swedish furniture sucks yuppies out of the woodwork, even from Bayonne. ''Yeah, there are yuppies in Bayonne,'' said Robin LaScala. ''My husband's a lawyer. I have my Visa ready, my Mastercard, my American Express.'' Anthony Pengue and his fiancee, Elizabeth Jacobson, planned to furnish a condo. ''All we have so far is a mattress and food processor,'' he said. 
Instead of cutting a ribbon, they sawed a board in half (apparently a Swedish custom), and people poured in. It was inspiring. There were shoppers in wheelchairs, shoppers with canes, all exercising their shopping rights.
Minutes after the opening, Anne Dickson turned to Catherine Burke and said, ''Buy anything yet?'' ''I'm about to,'' said Ms. Burke, who found a sofa named Klippan for $95. (Apparently a Swedish marketing custom is to give each item a name.) There was so much to buy and so many shoppers that it took Margaret Calabro and Fran Messina an hour to travel 50 feet. ''Oh my God, Fran, we're going to be here all day,'' said Ms. Calabro. ''I'll have to find someone to pick up my son at school,'' said Mrs. Messina. ''They're giving out candy,'' said Ms. Calabro. ''Candy, Fran?'' Mothers used IKEA day care so they'd have two hands free to shop. Halina Kazmierczak stuck in 3-year-old Arthur and rushed off. ''You're allowed a half hour,'' she said. Debra Queen checked her twins, Tariq and Tarif.
They wanted to do it all right away. By 9:50, Mabel Chung was eating lunch (swedish meatballs and new potatoes) in the IKEA cafe.
Trouble-shooters circulated, unclogging aisles. ''Excuse me, we've been going in circles 10 minutes,'' said Pete Medell. Bill Wiltraut, on emergency duty from another IKEA store, took many by the hand. Melvin Schneider needed lamps and Mr. Wiltraut said, ''Stand here, I'll be right back. Don't move.'' He walked a couple to the other end of the store, then rushed back.
''I'm here, I'm still here,'' said a relieved Mr. Schneider. Mr. Wiltraut showed him a lamp named Korus 36. Mr. Schneider said, ''I need a coffee table, too.'' Upstairs, Mr. Schneider looked nervous. ''I don't want to abandon my cart,'' he said. ''Can I check out my items I just purchased, so I'll have something?''
They spun swivel chairs, punched couches, bounced on beds, took numbers to wait for help at information. Mr. Wiltraut opened a catalogue atop an ironing board named Mellby, looking for a bathroom item for Margit Smith. ''Yes, that's it!'' she said. It was a shelf named Lagen. ''Was I explaining it right?'' she asked, checking shopping technique.
''Sir, sir, are you busy?'' someone yelled in desperation. Mr. Wiltraut found her a rack named Knut 4. A woman needed a lamp named Dolerit in mauve, and Mr. Wiltraut dispatched an aide to the storeroom. ''Two to five minutes?'' said Mr. Wiltraut. ''That's very optimistic,'' said the aide.
Adele Eines was having trouble finding things, so Mr. Wiltraut escorted her. She was so stunned she'd found something that she said, ''I just take it from you? Like this?''
Felice Dodson panicked and couldn't say, office supplies. ''I need office . . . office . . . .'' ''Supplies!'' said Mr. Wiltraut. ''Wait here two minutes. I'll be right back.'' When he returned, four others had joined Mrs. Dodson, and, deciding there was safety in numbers, caravaned to office supplies.
There were lines for carts, the women's room, the bank machine. It was a 40-minute wait for meatballs. (In retrospect, Mrs. Chung was wise to eat lunch at 9:45.) Yet no one seemed to mind much. Wasn't this affirmation that they were on the shopping forefront?
Mr. Pengue and Ms. Jacobson had filled a cart, checked out through one of 28 registers and were back filling a second. ''I'd like to shop three more hours,'' she said. ''I could do three more, easy.'' ''Be realistic,'' he said. It was time to go home and eat some cheese and fruit.

HEADLINE: Rinfret Portrayed as a Fiery Foe for Cuomo

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
Pierre Andre Rinfret, the almost certain Republican candidate for governor of New York, has little state governmental and political experience but could be an oratorical match for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo on the stump, many economists and business executives agreed yesterday.
The 66-year-old Mr. Rinfret (pronounced rin-FRAY) was consistently portrayed as an aggressive, outspoken economist, well-versed in public speaking, writing and television appearances and well-equipped to make a major issue of the state's fiscal problems.
As an economist, he was described as a moderate conservative who had criticized at various times the economic policies of two Republican Presidents, Richard M. Nixon and Ronald Reagan, and also the policies of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d when he was Treasury Secretary in the Reagan Administration. He called for Mr. Baker's resignation in 1987 because of the Baker policy of depreciating the dollar in the world money market. 
 
'He Has Great Courage'
''He has angered many politicians,'' said William E. Simon, the former Secretary of the Treasury in the Ford Administration. ''He has great courage.'' Despite three decades in public life, Mr. Rinfret was viewed as so apolitical, at least in New York State, that questions arose yesterday as to whether he was an enrolled Republican. Daniel De Francisco, executive director of the Board of Elections and a Democrat, said election records indicated that Mr. Rinfret was not enrolled in a party, but he said that pending a further check today, there was a strong possibility that current board records were incorrect.
Mr. Rinfret, who could be the Republican nominee even if he were an independent, declined any interviews yesterday and instead spent the day talking with Republican leaders, potential contributors and consultants. In one of his few ventures out of his economic consulting concern, Rinfret Associates Inc. at 641 Lexington Avenue, near 54th Street, he rode down three floors to pay a courtesy call on Jonathan Bush, President Bush's brother, whose investment management office is in the same building.
Mr. Bush said he had played no role in putting together the Republican state ticket. Indeed, there has been no evidence of any White House involvement as the state Republicans have scrambled to find a candidate to face the popular and well-financed incumbent.
Republican leaders also spent the day trying to select running mates for Mr. Rinfret - for lieutenant governor and attorney general. They are working against a deadline of this Memorial Day weekend. The Republican state nominating convention will begin on Tuesday.
In telephone interviews with economists from San Francisco to New York, descriptions of Mr. Rinfret jarred against the common image of the pipe-smoking, tweedy, contemplative economist. Instead he came across as more of a cigar-smoking salesman and prognosticator.
The descriptions used words like clear, simple, loud, outspoken and outrageous and said Mr. Rinfret was ''one of the few economists you can listen to without falling asleep.''
''He's probably smarter than Cuomo and just as tough,'' said Martin Anderson, a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University and President Reagan's first economic policy adviser. ''I'd love to see the two of them go at each other.''
 
'Good, Clean Fun' Expected
Murray Weidenbaum, Mr. Reagan's first chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, predicted that Renfret-Cuomo encounters would be ''good, clean fun - they'll do it in a way that won't put the electorate to sleep.'' Mr. Weidenbaum, now director of the Center for the Study of American Business at Washington University in St. Louis, added that ''p.r. puffery aside, he does have an analytical mind.''
But if conventional political wisdom and the 1986 Cuomo campaign are any guides, the Governor will very likely avoid giving his Republican challenger any forums until the final days of the campaign. Mr. Cuomo will do his talking in paid television commercials financed by a campaign treasury of at least $8 million. Mr. Rinfret starts out at ground zero in campaign funds.
But two assets he brings to the campaign are his personal wealth, which could provide seed money for his campaign, and his links to potential contributors in the financial community. His financial background also makes him qualified to make issues of Mr. Cuomo's budget and tax increases.
The Republican leaders who selected Mr. Rinfret after he met Wednesday with the Republican state chairman, J. Patrick Barrett, and the Manhattan Republican leader, State Senator Roy M. Goodman, did not know him. But he is well-known in Washington, where he was an unofficial economic adviser to Mr. Nixon during his Presidential campaigns and in the White House and also, to a lesser extent, in the John F. Kennedy, Lyndon B. Johnson and Reagan Administrations.
 
'Understandable' Economics
One former Nixon aide said Mr. Rinfret appealed to Mr. Nixon because ''he talks economics in understandable words.''
State Senator Goodman had put Mr. Rinfret's name forward on the recommendation of a mutual friend. Yesterday Mr. Goodman said Mr. Rinfret was ''enormously energetic, has a great zest for this campaign and has fire in his belly.''
One of the prospective candidate's immediate jobs is to meet with various Republican leaders who are expected to nominate him next week, as well as with Conservative Party leaders who have favored Herbert London, a dean at New York University.
Mr. London, who ran briefly for mayor last year, is being considered as a possible lieutenant governor candidate, although some Republican leaders favor the nomination of a woman.
The Rinfret-London combination would have at least two political problems, Republicans acknowledged. Mr. Rinfret favors a woman's right to an abortion, while Mr. London opposes abortion with few exceptions.

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
The Man Who Has His Own

BYLINE: By William C. Rhoden

 BODY:
For several weeks now Drew Pearson has monitored with some amusement the current debate involving inner-city violence, brand-name sneakers and suggestions that highly visible black athletes should curb their endorsements of overpriced sneakers.
Pearson is a former All-Pro wide receiver who played for the Dallas Cowboys from 1973 through 1983. Today he owns Drew Pearson Enterprises, which was listed among the 100 most successful black industrial and service companies in the latest issue of Black Enterprise magazine. The three-year-old company, based in Addison, Tex., is a sports licensing and sportswear manufacturing concern, which did $10 million in business last year.
What Pearson found amusing about the sneaker controversy was (a) that so much attention has been given to a simple-minded argument that points at sneakers, not the absence of an economic infrastructure, as a major cause of inner-city violence, and (b) that the most substantial recommendation to emerge from the debate was that black athletes, who have broken into the lucrative endorsement market, were somehow to blame. 
What troubles Pearson is that in the course of this wild goose chase a significant point is being missed. The issue is not whether Michael Jordan or Magic Johnson should promote high-priced gym shoes, but whether they should manufacture their own shoes, produce their own lines of sportswear and compete in a multibillion-dollar market.
''Why can't a Michael Jordan and Dominique Wilkins or somebody get together,'' said Pearson, ''and start their own shoe company to compete against Nike or Converse and those people?
''They sell the shoes; it's not the name Nike. It's the name Michael Jordan and the name Dominique Wilkins that sells. I don't know if they realize that they can do it.''
The narrow focus on sneakers is endemic to the sort of tunnel vision that often affects athletes in general and black athletes in particular.
In the past, black athletes were primed to catch passes, not to throw them; now they are encouraged to wear elaborate equipment, but not to make it, to play in stadiums, not to own them.
''We're all shaped and molded a certain way, especially black athletes, from Little League to high school, college and pro sports,'' Pearson said. ''All you see yourself as is an athlete. You don't really see yourself as a coach, or as someone running these concession stands that generate money. Power people see us as being participants, not the ones that set up these leagues, not the ones making any decison concerning the welfare of the league.
''We're just too caught up in being the athlete, and being the reason why there is a league.''
For all the focus on black athletes' selling shoes for Nike, the company, which had $1.2 billion in wholesale sneaker sales last year, bears a once-over.
Like other major companies, Nike manufactures its shoes overseas. It has factories in seven cities in the Far East and three warehouses in this country.
While inner-city youths supposedly kill over shoes they cannot afford, companies that could create jobs and generate money in communities that desperately need it open factories in Taiwan.
And one would think that a company with Jordan and Bo Jackson featured so prominently in its ads might also have significant numbers of blacks in key corporate management levels. No one on Nike's board of directors or any of its 10 vice presidents is black.
The company supplies shoes and apparel for 17 sports; each sport has a four-member management team.
There are two black managers: Harold White heads professional basketball promotion; Don Coleman heads track and field promotion. Those are two of Nike's most prestigious divisions.
''The black kids are buying these shoes but they're not really benefiting from high-volume sales,'' Pearson noted. ''The companies really have no input from that market, yet they seem to know what it takes to get these kids excited to want a pair of shoes.''
It is conceivable that in the next decade black athletes and black businessmen, two groups that have largely ignored each other, will launch the sort of undertakings that could begin to tackle the awesome task of ending economic devastation in the inner city. ''I can see that happening in the sports industry, such as manufacturing your own shoe line, your own clothing line,'' Pearson said.
''When I was coming through in the 1970's and the early 1980's, athletes weren't thinking in those terms,'' he said. ''Because they're making so much money now, athletes are thinking in terms of using their resources, their name recognition, to make something happen for themselves instead of helping somebody else to become profitable, then getting a small percentage of it through a fee.''
The issue, as it turns out, is not who wears the gym shoe but who owns the gymnasium.

HEADLINE: Review/Blues;
Making the Piano Jump and Wail

BYLINE: By JON PARELES

 BODY:
Two pianists who were in on the birth of rock-and-roll headlined the first two nights of the Piano Blues Who's Who, a three-part series presented at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights.
The opening concert on May 17 featured Johnnie Johnson, who hired a guitarist named Chuck Berry in the early 1950's and stayed with him to make rock cornerstones like ''Johnny B. Goode''; the 81-year-old pianist Sammy Price shared the bill. And the May 18 concert brought the return of Harry Vann Walls, who was the studio pianist for Atlantic Records' rhythm-and-blues sessions with Ruth Brown, the Clovers and Joe Turner (''Shake, Rattle and Roll'' and ''Chains of Love''). Opening for him was his student and fan the New Orleans pianist Mac (Dr. John) Rebennack. 
All four pianists carry history in their left hands, which pump out the bouncing chords and boogie-woogie bass lines that made the piano a blues orchestra. Unfortunately, they all chose to work with bands, burying part of their two-fisted playing under drums in the church's tricky acoustics.
The 71-year-old Mr. Vann Walls was a worthy rediscovery. Working with John Dooley on bass fiddle and with Walter Perkins, the quietest of the four bands' drummers, Mr. Vann Walls revealed a clean-lined approach that made barrelhouse blues sound as calmly economical as a solo by Teddy Wilson. His left hand carried rock-ribbed unswerving chords; his right strolled above it with leisurely syncopated chords or shimmering tremolos.
In a gruff, hearty voice, Mr. Vann Walls sang a few blues songs, including one that promised, ''I may play slow, but I play for a long time.'' His trio was joined by Byrdie Green, who has been singing around New York since the 1950's. She has a clear, forthright voice that can turn sly and cutting a la Dinah Washington, and as she flexed the melodies of songs like ''Goin' to Chicago'' and ''Stormy Monday'' the trio cut loose; Mr. Vann Walls made the piano talk back to her with fancy filigree. Mr. Rebennack also sat in on guitar, singing about death in a blues full of sage humor.
Mr. Rebennack's superb set was a survey of New Orleans music, from the prison song ''Junco Partner'' to the Mardi Gras chant ''Iko Iko'' to Professor Longhair's ''Tipitina'' along with his own ''Walk on Gilded Splinters'' and his recent hit, ''Makin' Whoopee.'' While Mr. Rebennack learned about the blues from Mr. Vann Walls, he proudly carries on the extravagant syncopations and joyful floridity of Professor Longhair. He lavishes two-fisted counterpoint on a tune, with splashing, glittering, trickling handfuls of notes that never obscure the steady rolling beat; his approach recalls the architecture of the French quarter in New Orleans, where stately buildings support wildly rococo wrought-iron balconies.
The concert on May 17 was frustrating. Mr. Price worked with a drummer and saxophonist who didn't follow his beat, and he could be heard only in snatches. And the 66-year-old Mr. Johnson was held back by a generic blues-bar band, which gave its guitarist far too much time for facile solos and strained vocals. When Mr. Johnson's solos came through, he clearly still had the steely touch and splashy upper-register syncopations he brought to Mr. Berry's records. But his band made waiting for those solos a trial.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
The Good Teacher: Accumulating Small Victories

BYLINE: By RICHARD RODRIGUEZ: Richard Rodriguez is the author of ''Hunger of Memory,'' the story of his education. His new book, ''Mexico's Children,'' is to be published by Viking in 1991.

 BODY:

Small Victories
The Real World of a Teacher, Her Students, and Their High School
By Samuel G. Freedman
431 pages. Harper & Row. $22.95
As national confidence in public education erodes, there has been a search on television and in films and books for the good teacher - Marva Collins on ''60 Minutes''; Jaime Escalante in ''Stand and Deliver.'' Last year, Tracy Kidder's ''Among School Children'' described a year in the life of a grammar school teacher. Now we have Samuel G. Freedman's ''Small Victories,'' an account of a year in the life of a high school teacher. 
Mr. Freedman's good teacher is Jessica Siegel, a woman in her 30's, single, childless, an English teacher possessed of no discernible sentimentality about her mission and yet much passion. Mr. Freedman, a former reporter for The New York Times, follows her through a single academic year (1987-88) at Seward Park High School on the Lower East Side of Manhattan - ''perhaps the most famous immigrant neighborhood in the world.''
For 150 years, the neighborhood around Seward Park has been a first home to foreigners, and it still is. Today's neighborhood signs are apt to be in Spanish or Chinese. ''Small Victories'' does not tell us very much about the special needs of immigrant children. Despite the fact that 90 percent of Seward Park students come from homes where parents do not speak English, Mr. Freedman does not evaluate debatable innovations like bilingual education. Partly this is because Ms. Siegel's students are seniors - most have been in America for several years and know their way through American English.
Here, windows are broken, classrooms are overcrowded. In 1985, an education task force, noting Seward Park's low test scores, ranked the school with the lowest 10 percent in the state of New York.
''Looking down the aisles and across the rows, Jessica sees the usual Seward Park stew, all the confusion an immigrant society can offer - an American-born black alongside a Panamanian who has the same pigment but speaks Spanish at home; a Chinese in pleated trousers and aviator glasses in front of a compatriot with crudely hacked hair and a second-hand sweatshirt; a Wilberto next to a Wilfredo; three Robertos . . .''
Mr. Freedman tells the stories of two immigrant students - both success stories - one Chinese, the other Dominican. What are we to take from such narratives beyond an admiration for particular achievement? American public schools have never treated the immigrant child particularly well - or any better than now -according to Mr. Freedman. Though some immigrants were culturally more able to make schools work for them, there was no golden age of public education, he asserts, echoing Diane Ravitch, the educational historian.
Seward Park is nothing in the public appraisal. Nothing but an educational Calcutta. Nothing but a big city neighborhood school, ''the catchbasin for poor black, Hispanic and Asian children.'' Seward Park receives proportionately less money from the Board of Education than selective magnet schools or special public schools like Stuyvesant High.
Why, then, do we seek out the story of Jessica Siegel and her ''small victories''?
At a time when college professors shy away from the notion of a common American canon, Ms. Siegel teaches her students the 17th-century Puritan poetry of Anne Bradstreet. Ms. Siegel succeeds because she will not condescend to the ''social disadvantages'' or ''cultural diversity'' of her students.
The most remarkable scene in this book comes when Ms. Siegel explicates with her class the nuances of a paragraph in ''The Great Gatsby.''
I've never read a rendition of the classroom as exciting as this. Ms. Siegel assaults her students with questions amounting to a reveille. Slowly students are awakened to what may be fine and accessible and useful in literature, and even pleasurable. High drama, indeed. Is Ms. Siegel typical of the faculty members at Seward Park? In a way, I think, Mr. Freedman wants us to believe she is. There is a sympathetic portrait of the school principal and another of a truant officer. One chapter describes the weekend job a history teacher must take - dressed in black tie as a maitre d'hotel at wedding receptions - to earn money enough to remain a public school teacher.
Of the students graduating from Seward Park, over 90 percent go on to college or trade school or into the military. So while one never gets a very clear sense of what goes on in classrooms down the hall, Ms. Siegel cannot be the only hero of Seward Park.
What her story does make clear is that teaching, good teaching, is a vocation, not a job.
There she goes with three students in a borrowed car, defying rush hour traffic to get to the State University campus at New Paltz, N.Y. Ms. Siegel has arranged interviews for her students with a counselor for economically disadvantaged students. She gets lost on the way; she gets stuck in traffic; the students arrive too late. (The university bureaucrat is poised to depart his office at exactly 5 o'clock.) And we care about Ms. Siegel's frustration. We care about her disappointment.
A book like ''Small Victories'' encourages optimism. Here is a portrayal of a selfless life in a selfish time. But Jessica Siegel's story should not bring easy consolation. Ms. Siegel has left teaching.
''I'm tired of working this way. . . . All I do is work. I have no life,'' she tells a fellow teacher. She cries when she tells her students she is leaving.
She writes a letter to her own high school teacher - beloved Gloryia Lenzi Okulski - who ransomed Jessica's adolescence a generation before. ''Sometimes I step back from the kids I have developed relationships with and think about how you performed that role for me 20 years ago in New Milford, N.J. I'd love to get back in touch . . .''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Samuel G. Freedman (Harper & Row)

HEADLINE: A Savings Rescue Falls Short

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
Lone Star Technologies had grand plans for turning around the American Federal Bank of Dallas after it bought the savings institution from the Government in late 1988.
Under the Southwest Plan, one of the Government's first attempts to address the nation's growing savings and loan crisis, the Dallas-based steelmaker received Federal support totaling $1.3 billion and expected to strengthen the institution's loan portfolio and quickly turn its attention to expansion.
But American Federal has fallen far short of those original goals, raising questions about whether the Southwest Plan, with all its Government financial support, will be the bonanza for investors that many first thought.
 
No Windfalls Likely
''Not many of these deals look like windfalls,'' said William Ferguson of W. C. Ferguson & Company, a financial consulting firm in Irving, Tex. ''I believe that history will treat the Southwest Plan deals with more charity than they have been treated to date.'' 
Although American Federal is modestly profitable, it is furiously trying to raise capital to meet new Government requirements, , and even top management says the institution is not yet a viable concern. Its experience illustrates the risks and overwhelming difficulty of turning around the nation's ailing savings and loans. Even though it provides generous financial support, the Government's bailout program cannot guarantee success.
In the case of American Federal, a string of unforeseen and unlucky events delayed its return to financial health: when a sluggish Texas economy led to the bankruptcy of Lone Star's steel unit, the parent was left unable to offer the savings unit much financial support. And when illness sidelined Lone Star's 42-year-old chief executive, the new management forced the resignation of American Federal's top executive and chief architect of the acquisition.
But the savings unit was also a victim of changes in Government regulations. Since the Federal capital requirements for savings and loans were increased, some of the 16 savings institutions that were consolidated under the Southwest Plan from 86 insolvent units are struggling.
With such dismal results, critics are saying that the Southwest Plan amounted to nothing more than a Government giveaway. Congress, for one, is objecting to the $11 billion in tax benefits and cash incentives that were given under the plan to entice buyers, and some legislators are urging that the terms of some of the deals be revised.
Indeed, L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, told Congress this week that rising interest costs and falling real estate values have increased by $12 billion the cost to the Government of the Southwest Plan, which covered institutions that failed before a larger bailout was approved by Congress last year.
 
A Different Approach
The Southwest Plan differs somewhat from the one the Government will follow in the months ahead. Under the Southwest Plan, buyers were required to take all the assets of an insolvent institution, both good and bad. In return, many received lucrative tax benefits and promises of Government protection against some of the future losses from bad loans. Federal regulators chose this course because they lacked the cash to simply close the 86 insolvent units and pay off depositors.
But the deals came under such criticism as examples of Government largess that regulators changed their approach when they devised the latest bailout. Now, they are allowing buyers to bid for whatever they want from the insolvent institutions - generally, the most attractive assets are deposit franchises and performing loans. The Government is selling the unwanted assets, generally troubled real estate projects and loans.
But buyers in the Southwest Plan were not only stuck with having to sell portfolios of suspect real estate, they were also devastated by the savings industry bailout legislation enacted by Congress in 1989. By requiring savings unit operators to put up more capital in reserve, the laws undid the economic assumptions behind many of the Southwest Plan deals, forcing investors to reserve money that otherwise could have been used in rebuilding.
 
Many Tax Benefits
As a result, many buyers have enjoyed more in the way of tax benefits than in operating returns.
For instance, the Guaranty Federal Savings Bank in Dallas had a return in 1989 of only 1.07 percent on the $128 million investment from its parent, Temple-Inland Inc., a maker of paper products based in Austin, Tex. ''Our returns from our investment are mediocre, but the tax benefits are pretty good,'' explained Wayne McDonald, chief financial officer at Temple-Inland.
Of course, there have been exceptions. The First Gibraltar Bank, which was sold to Ronald O. Perelman, chief executive of Revlon Inc., earned a 44.52 percent return on capital last year, not counting its $900 million in tax benefits over the next 10 years.
But much lower returns are more typical, with many in the single-digit range and others showing losses, according to W. C. Ferguson.
 
Deal With Lone Star
The deal to buy American Federal was put together by William E. Gibson, a 45-year-old bank economist and former staff member with the Council of Economic Advisers. In late 1988, when the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States got cold feet about financing American Federal, Mr. Gibson turned to an old acquaintance, William Howard Beasley 3d, chief executive of Lone Star.
Lone Star agreed to put up $48 million for 80 percent of American Federal, with the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation taking the remaining 20 percent stake. Lone Star paid Mr. Gibson a finder's fee and put him in charge of the unit.
By selling bad assets, streamlining the 64-branch operation and attracting new deposits, the savings unit thought it would take in new cash, make new investments and grow. But American Federal had more problems than anticipated: its records were a mess, its portfolio of unprofitable assets not only included failing real estate properties, but a winery and a film-distribution company with rights to the ''Texas Chainsaw Massacre.''
 
Illness at the Top
Shortly after the buyout, Mr. Beasley was stricken with cancer and, last May, a board member, John Harbin, a former chairman of the Halliburton Company, a Dallas oil and gas service company, stepped into his position.
Mr. Harbin and Mr. Gibson are said to have clashed over how to raise additional capital. One company official, who declined to be identified, said that Mr. Gibson wanted to bring in outside capital and perhaps even do a leveraged buyout of the savings unit to raise the money, while Mr. Harbin preferred to have American Federal grow from within.
As a result of these and other disagreements, Mr. Gibson resigned last January. Mr. Harbin explained his departure this way: ''He's an economist and the bank needed to be run by an operating type.'' Mr. Gibson did not return phone calls.
Today, the mood is cautiously optimistic. To meet the new capital requirement, American Federal reduced its assets; the fewer the assets, the less capital required. In the past months, nearly $500 million in assets have been sold, primarly single-family homes, small apartment buildings, office buidings and raw land, reducing American Federal's loan portfolio to about $2.8 billion.
American Federal also cut operating costs by about $20 million by closing branches, eliminating overlapping bookkeeping systems and streamlining computer operations.
 
A Place for Profits
The institution is now profitable, although every penny of the $13 million it earned last year and the $7 million earned so far this year is going toward the savings unit's capital account, which must reach $75 million - $20 million more than originally assumed - by June to comply with Government regulations.
''We're not sitting here with our heads hanging down,'' said Allan D. Nichols, who was hired last month as American Financial's new chief executive. ''We are not now in the position to be a top-quality viable financial institution. But our current state of affairs is temporary.
''I feel like Vince Lombardi,'' continued Mr. Nichols, a 30-year veteran of commercial banking in Seattle and Atlanta. ''I feel that our game plan is good and we will win - if the game lasts long enough.'' Mr. Nichols now expects that American Federal will have the needed $75 million in core capital by June.
 
Transformation Planned
Eventually, Mr. Nichols said he hopes to transform American Federal into a bank-like institution that does more than traditional mortgage lending. He envisions that American Federal will make small-business loans, manage financial assets and offer such fee-based services as mortgage origination, insurance sales or mutual fund products.
''We're positive and enthusiastic about the future,'' Mr. Nichols said, in his office in a gleaming North Dallas office tower. ''We've got to finish up consolidating first and then move on to phase two, which is replacing our depleted assets with new assets and getting new income and building new relationships with new customers.''
He said he does not expect American Federal to reach phase two for another six months to a year.
 
Problems Remain
While Mr. Nichols is enthusiastic about American's ability to rebound with the Texas economy, he acknowledges that problems remain. Intense competition, particularly from remaining insolvent savings units that have not been closed or sold, has pushed up the rates needed to attract depositors. And many banking experts say the state still has too many banks and that Texas's economic recovery has been stubbornly slow.
And there is the larger question: How much will the Government ultimately spend to protect American Federal's depositors? Much of that depends on how well Mr. Nichols and other executives manage the business.
When the deal closed, Federal regulators gave American Federal $48 million and a note valued at $499 million. At that time, regulators estimated they would spend up to $800 million more - in agreements that provide cash payments to American Federal to recover losses on asset sales and to bring underperforming loans up to market yields. These payments are on a sliding scale that tapers off over time - and, as American Federal sells its troubled assets and replaces them with market-rate loans, this Federal income stream diminishes.
American Federal will not say how much it has received in Federal payments to date, but they came to about $40 million in the first quarter of 1990, and ran at about the same level in the 1989 fourth quarter, making the Government the biggest source of its revenues, according to filings with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. Whether it continues at this pace and for how long is unclear.
''As we build our value from the marketplace, we continually lower our dependence on Government income,'' Mr. Nichols said. ''That's the premise we are built on.''

HEADLINE: New G.M. Concept: Thinking Small

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LANSING, Mich.

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation did not grow into the world's No. 1 auto maker by thinking small or bucking the economies of assembly-line manufacturing. But G.M. has been trying to do both at the factory that assembles the Buick Reatta coupe, and G.M. executives now seem pleased enough with the result to consider using the system for other models.
Instead of being equipped to build 200,000 Reattas a year, the number long thought by American auto makers to be optimal for maximizing the return on capital investment, G.M.'s Reatta plant can produce only 25,000 cars.
And instead of installing the usual moving assembly line, along which each worker repeatedly performs one or two tasks, G.M. organized its work force into small teams. Workers perform dozens of tasks on the cars at various locations in the plant; the cars are carried between locations by computer-guided carts. 
Because a regular assembly line requires much more space and equipment than the Reatta process, the Reatta plant's capital costs are far lower.
The experiment, begun three years ago, was one of the most innovative among the Big Three auto makers in production on a small scale. Such production has become more important as the marketplace has grown more crowded with competing models tailored to smaller groups of drivers.
While the two-seater Reatta luxury car has not sold well, G.M. is generally satisfied that its manufacturing process is not only more cost-effective for building small numbers of cars but can also match larger plants in the quality of the cars and the performance of the workers building them.
''Most of the industry consists of mega-plants, but we could be seeing the beginning of a whole new concept - manufacturing modules of 30,000 to 50,000 units each,'' said David Cole, head of automotive studies at the University of Michigan.
Indeed, the Chrysler Corporation recently announced that it would produce a two-seat sports coupe, the Dodge Viper, to be sold in limited numbers.
If G.M. and other manufacturers can lower the costs of producing smaller lots, ''this could be an important way to remedy the collapse in volume of various domestic car lines,'' Mr. Cole said.
 
A Shortened Chassis
The $30,000 Reatta was designed to attract drivers who wanted a sporty car, like G.M.'s Corvette, but with more luxury, room and comfort. Rather than spend millions on a new chassis, G.M. engineers shortened the chassis design used on the Buick Riviera, Oldsmobile Toronado and Cadillac Eldorado.
Japanese auto makers have grown adept at building several car or truck models on one assembly line - some can produce cars and trucks - as a way to lower their break-even points by saving money on plants and tools. The Big Three auto makers, to a lesser extent, are also learning to operate assembly lines that produce more than one model. But adding models to one line also adds complexity for line workers and makes high quality tougher to maintain.
Mr. Cole said G.M.'s decision to build the Reatta itself ''was unusual, because any car built in so small a number normally would be given to an outside company.'' G.M., he pointed out, hired Pininfarina, the Italian coach-building company, to build the body for the Cadillac Allante, another two-seater automobile.
But there is a drawback to that idea. ''You allow some other company - not your own - to improve vital auto making skills,'' said Peter Van Hull of Arthur Andersen & Company's consulting subsidiary.
 
First Tried by Volvo
The idea for G.M.'s Reatta plant, which the company calls the Reatta Craft Center, was first tried by Volvo, which used worker teams to build cars at stations mainly as a way to make its employees' jobs more stimulating.
G.M. had another motive: recapturing a sliver of its huge loss of market share in North America during the last decade. G.M. is selling about 1.5 million fewer cars a year than it was a decade ago. Getting back even 25,000 of that number would be worthwhile. But because G.M. still wanted to increase profits, it looked for ways to avoid huge capital outlays.
Rather than build a new plant, G.M. decided to use buildings in Lansing that had made axles and other forgings for Oldsmobile until 1985. Instead of buying new automated machines, which had been done at a string of new G.M. assembly plants, engineers used older tools. Hand-held welders are used instead of new robotic welders, for example.
In all, the plant cost about $250 million, about half of what the cheapest version of a conventional assembly plant would cost.
 
Higher Labor Costs
The plant's labor costs, on the other hand, are higher than normal. Some Japanese assembly plants can build a vehicle in less than 20 worker hours, while some American plants require as much as 40 worker hours. The number of worker hours required to build a Reatta tops 40. ''It's horrendous,'' said James Rucker, the plant manager. ''I won't even tell you.''
One reason is that it takes far more worker hours to build a car when each worker must perform a variety of tasks than when each worker performs only a single task. G.M. knew that labor costs would be higher but that they would be balanced by lower capital costs for machines and tools.
One bonus is that workers have found their jobs more interesting. ''How many kids today want to drive three screws and walk to the next car?'' Mr. Rucker said.
Most auto workers on the usual assembly lines have one or two tasks that they perform hundreds of times daily as cars pass in front of them. As a way to fight boredom they sometimes trade jobs with other workers.
 
Nine 'Craft Stations'
At the Reatta plant, workers at the nine ''craft stations,'' each of which can hold three or four painted car bodies, perform several jobs during the 26 to 28 minutes the car is in each station. Craft Center 1, for example, installs electrical wires, heaters, air-conditioners, the emergency brake and the accelerator pedal; Craft Center 9, near the end of the assembly process, puts on bumpers and exterior body molding.
To as great an extent as possible, workers receive training on a variety of assembly jobs, which allows them to switch when they choose or to substitute for someone who is absent.
''There's a greater sense of ownership here for the workers,'' Mr. Rucker said. ''Ownership'' has become a cliche in personnel management to describe a worker's sense of responsibility and connection to the product.
Darryl McGaha, a 20-year G.M. worker, agreed. ''The work isn't more or less demanding intellectually,'' he said. ''But we have more authority, such as responsibility for making sure the quality of parts from our vendors is good.''
 
Workers' Good Reputation
G.M. chose the Lansing plant and United Automobile Workers Local 1618 to try ''craft station'' manufacturing because the workers there have a reputation for stability and reliability, as evidenced by the relatively low absentee rate.
''There's so many different things for one worker to do that it's impossible to teach a replacement in five minutes,'' said Ken Barnes, a G.M. worker. Most assembly jobs at regular G.M. plants can be taught to other workers relatively easily.
While G.M. is satisfied with the Reatta manufacturing system, sales of the car have been significantly below the goal of 25,000 a year. Sales totaled 7,905 in 1989. Sales through May 10 were 2,532, down from 2,750 in the corresponding period last year. So far, G.M. said, sales have not justified adding a second work shift.
Mr. Rucker would not say how many cars G.M. had to produce to be profitable. But at the current rate of 8,000 or 9,000 a year, he conceded, ''we're at the ragged edge.''
Many of the car's first owners did not like Reatta's touch-sensitive television-screen panel for controlling the air-conditioning, sound system and other functions, so Buick dropped it. A Buick spokesman said the company hoped that a new convertible version of the car would perk up sales.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A Bad Mixture For Policy Makers

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE Commerce Department's revision of the gross national product data for the first quarter of 1990 heightens the picture of an economy suffering from slugflation, a mixture of sluggish growth and inflation that is a kissing cousin to stagflation.
The annual growth rate in the January-March quarter was revised to 1.3 percent from 2.1 percent, and the inflation rate, as measured by a price index used to adjust G.N.P., was raised to 6.7 percent from 6.5 percent. These figures further complicate the fiscal policy choices facing both the Administration-Congressional budget summit negotiators and the monetary policy makers of the Federal Reserve.
The budget deficit has been worsening as the economy slows, revenues fall short, interest rates stay higher than expected and profits decline. How much can the budget summit meeting cut expenditures or raise taxes without thrusting the weak economy into recession? On the monetary front the question is: Can the Fed ease monetary policy without worsening inflationary pressures? 
The answers to these questions are judgment calls about the relative risks of recession and inflation. In the view of many people in troubled businesses like real estate, banking, autos and airlines, the economy is already in recession.
Public anxiety over the economy has been worsened by the Administration's latest estimate that more than 1,000 savings and loan associations, or about 40 percent of the savings industry, might have to be seized. And some worry that a financial crisis could spread to the commercial banks.
Yet the economy as a whole still has forward momentum. A majority of economists insist the economy is not in a recession now and will not be this year or next. The May consensus forecast of the 50 economists polled by Blue Chip Indicators is for 2 percent growth in 1990 and 2.3 percent growth in 1991. And 63 percent of the members of the National Association of Business Economists predict recession will be avoided in the next three years, thanks to what they foresee as ''effective monetary policy.''
But at present the Fed hesitates to risk increasing the rate of inflation. Some economists outside the Fed fear that the underlying inflation rate, stemming from wage and other cost pressures, is worsening and is being aggravated by inflation abroad. Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley, noting that the nation's trading partners have their own inflation problems, said, ''Global interest rates have risen in response, and so, too, have U.S. import prices.''
In Morgan Stanley's May Economic Perspectives, Mr. Roach argues that if the Fed does not check the buildup of inflationary pressures, for fear of ''wreaking havoc on an increasingly fragile financial system,'' the new cost-price feedback mechanism of a globally interdependent economy ''virtually guarantees a further aggravation of U.S. inflation.''
Yet the financial and commodity markets are behaving as though the inflationary danger is waning. Gold prices have dropped, and bond and stock prices have rallied. Oil prices have sagged. An airline fare war is breaking out. Housing and real estate prices are weakening, and they will be further driven down by the Resolution Trust Corporation's sale of real estate it has taken over. With the economy soft, the Research Center in Quantitative Economics of the University of Michigan expects a lower inflation rate in the next few months, and a ''cautious Fed policy.''
What would make it possible for the Fed to ease and bring down rates now? If the budget conference were to reach a compromise that market participants believed would work toward achieving equilibrium over the next few years, both in the budget and in the relationship of savings to investment, interest rates would come down, inflationary worries would be eased and the Fed would be liberated to help sustain economic expansion.
The reduction of American interest rates would also help ease the dollar down, spurring American exports and curbing demand for imports. The combination of a tighter fiscal and an easier monetary policy would, by reducing the cost of capital, stimulate greater business spending for new plant and equipment and for research and development, thereby raising American competitiveness. This would also give the Government the resources it needs to deal with such pressing problems as education, science and technology, health care, the homeless, urban decay, the environment and aid to Eastern Europe and developing countries.
In his first inaugural address, President Bush said, ''We have more will than wallet.'' But, as a new Brookings study, ''Setting National Priorities: Policies for the Nineties,'' puts it, ''The question is not whether America has enough wallet, but whether it has the will to use its abundant wealth to solve the problems it faces.'' The budget summit will be a crucial test of that will.

HEADLINE: Top Regulators Clash On Stock Index Futures

BYLINE: By GREGORY A. ROBB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
The war of words between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission heated up today as Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the S.E.C., and Wendy L. Gramm, the chairwoman of the futures commission, appeared before the House Energy and Commerce Committee's telecommunications and finance subcommittee.
Though Mr. Breeden stressed that the agencies work closely, he told the panel that the S.E.C. could not adequately investigate intermarket fraud because it does not have the authority to get information from the futures markets.
''How can a fire inspector know whether there are too many people in a crowded restaurant if he or she is allowed to look at only half the room?'' Mr. Breeden asked. 
Mrs. Gramm countered that her agency receives daily trading reports from the futures exchanges and noted that the S.E.C. does not have similar authority in its regulation of the securities markets.
''When chairman Breeden talks about seeing one-half of the market, it's our half of the market he is seeing because of our systems,'' Mrs. Gramm said.
The Bush Administration has said it will ask Congress to switch jurisdiction of stock index futures to the S.E.C. from the futures commission, and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has endorsed the change.
Mrs. Gramm is outnumbered 3 to 1 on the White House's working group on financial markets, which was set up after the October 1987 stock market crash. But she has received support from members of the House and Senate Agriculture Committees, which oversee her agency.
The increasing bitterness between the agencies was also highlighted by the release of an S.E.C. staff report on the October 1989 stock market drop.
Central to the debate over switching the regulatory jurisdiction has been the role trading in stock-index futures had in the 1989 plunge. Though based on the same data as a report last week by the futures commission, the S.E.C. study came to a radically different conclusion.
The S.E.C. study found that index arbitrage and other program-trading strategies significantly accelerated and worsened the market's fall; the futures commission's study found no evidence of intermarket trading activity that would have hastened the stock market drop.
According to the S.E.C., stock-index futures floor traders did not provide needed cash that might have stabilized the market. Rather, the S.E.C. said, when the market began to drop, the traders were active sellers, representing 50.1 percent of the total Standard & Poor's 500 futures sell volume.
But Steve Manaster, the director of the futures commission's division of economic analysis, said that the floor traders also accounted for 42 percent of the buying volume.
Richard Ketchum, the director of the S.E.C.'s market regulation division, told reporters this afternoon that the two regulatory agencies were considering whether to extend the so-called ''circuit breakers'' that require temporary halts in trading after a specified drop.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chilmark Stake In UJB Financial

 BODY:
The Chilmark Management Corporation, an investment management firm in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., said it had bought more than 2.2 million shares, or more than 5 percent, of the UJB Financial Corporation, a banking company in Princeton, N.J. UJB, which owns United Jersey Bank, has been hurt by the slowdown in the New Jersey economy, but has remained profitable. In the first quarter, despite a sharp rise in its reserve for loan losses and troubled loans, UJB earned $24.7 million. A year earlier, the company earned $31.9 million.
After trading as high as $28.75 in the last half of 1989, UJB's stock fell to as low as $13.25 earlier this year. It closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $16.375, up 12.5 cents. Chilmark bought its shares at $13.50 to $19.50 each. UJB has 250 banking offices in New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania.

HEADLINE: Stocks Ease As Dow Dips 0.71 Point

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks weakened a bit yesterday amid signs that inflation is too strong for the Federal Reserve to act to bring down interest rates.
By the close the Dow Jones industrial average stood at 2,855.55, down 0.71 point, breaking a string of three successive new highs that began Monday.
Volume slid to 155.1 million shares, from 172.3 million the day before, with 791 stocks down and 725 ahead.
''It feels like a semi-holiday,'' one trader remarked. ''The market's slow and lethargic.'' 
The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index, which rose on Wednesday to within 0.51 point of breaking the record it set last October, sank 0.88 point, to 358.41, suggesting that many investors remained too skittish to move more cash into stocks.
Traders said that heavy selling of Philip Morris stock contributed to the weakness, after Harvard University and the City University of New York said they would sell their tobacco shares.
Although the Government reported yesterday that the gross national product, or the total value of goods and services, grew only 1.3 percent in the first quarter, weaker than the 2.1 percent initially reported, analysts maintained that the economy still remained fairly robust.
''We've been hearing about inflation going away in the last couple of weeks,'' said Tracy G. Herrick, economist of Jefferies & Company in San Francisco, ''but investors are still sensitive to it.''
He noted that ''the G.N.P. numbers had very little overall affect on the market, and it was doing O.K. when the numbers first came out.'' He went on, ''But when investors looked deeper at the inflation component, which stayed high, the market took a temporary dip.''
By 11 A.M., the Dow had slid 13 points, but by noon, it had bounced back 17 points and then seesawed its way through the rest of the day.
Philip Morris, the food and tobacco giant, which fell as low as 43 during the session, ended at 44 1/8, down a point, with 3.67 million shares changing hands. It was by far the most active stock of the day. Traders said that banks, insurance companies and other big investors lightened up on their portfolios of tobacco stocks.
Other tobacco stocks responding to the report were American Brands, down 1 3/8, to 67 5/8, on 447,200 shares, and UST, formerly the United States Tobacco Company, down a point, to 29, on 285,600 shares.
Early in the day, after the huge selloff, Ronald B. Morrow of Smith Barney, Harris Upham recommended them as a good buy, so some investors bought them back.
In another day of strong gains among the technology stocks, Motorola rose 3 3/4, to 83 3/4, after Rajiv Chaudri of Goldman, Sachs recommended the stock because the company had won $35 million in Japanese contracts.
Novell, reaching a high of 49 1/4, jumped 4 3/4, to 49, on 2.6 million shares, No. 2 among the most-active over-the-counter stocks. The computer company reported higher-than-expected profits in the quarter ended April 28. George Kelly of Morgan, Stanley and Louis Giglio of Bear, Stearns subsequently issued new buy recommendations.
Lotus, the software company, surged 2 3/4, to 36 3/4, on 1.5 million shares after Timothy R. McCollum of Dean Witter Reynolds and Michelle Preston of Cowen & Company issued new buy recommendations.
Quantum, maker of disk drives, rose 1 3/4, to 22 5/8, after reaching a 22 3/4 high, on 2.2 million shares. Douglas van Dorsten of Shearson, Lehman, Hutton raised his recommendation on the stock.
Dell Computer rose 1 7/8, to 12, on 2.2 million shares after reporting stronger-than-expected first-quarter profits. Microsoft, which introduced its new Window 3.0 software earlier this week and lent strength to the technology group, reached a high of 78 3/4 and ended at 76 1/2, up 5/8, on 2.04 million shares.
After reaching a high of 81 3/4, Nike, the athletic shoe company, closed at 81 3/8, up 2 7/8, on 763,000 shares. Josephine Esquivel of Shearson and Heidi Steinberg of Salomon Brothers recommended the stock.
Ms. Steinberg also recommended L.A. Gear, a Nike competitor, which rose 1 5/8, to 50 1/8, also in heavy trading.
Time Warner, the publishing and entertainment company, rose 2 7/8, to 107 1/8, after Mara M. Balsbaugh, leisure analyst for Smith Barney, issued a new buy recommendation. ''Entertainment stocks as a group have really come back to life,'' she told Reuters. Paramount Communications rose a point, to 47 1/2.
In the indexes among the smaller stocks, the Nasdaq composite rose 1.42, to 458.29, while the Amex market-value rose 1.11, to 360.76.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Dip in Price

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped in thin trading yesterday, as dealers sold securities after an unexpectedly poor auction of $8.5 billion worth of new five-year notes.
Bids at the auction produced an average yield of 8.54 percent, virtually unchanged from the average yield of 8.53 percent at the last five-year auction on Feb. 22.
But market participants and analysts said the results were disappointing because demand for the new notes was much less than anticipated.
Just under $22 billion worth of bids were received for the notes. Consequently, the ''coverage'' ratio of bids to notes sold was the lowest since the five-year auction in May 1987, said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J. firm that provides analysis and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets. 
Despite the weaker demand, the auction was not without its positive elements, Mr. Stone said.
To begin with, he said, ''it's the last Treasury auction of coupon securities for a month.'' He continued, ''In addition, it looks like Wall Street firms did not end up owning a big chunk of the issue.''
Performance in the credit markets tends to improve when dealer inventories are not swollen with unwanted securities bought at the Treasury auctions.
The new notes did not trade well after the results were announced.
Late yesterday the notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.57 percent.
''The issue was way overpriced before the auction,'' one trader said.
Market participants focused only briefly on the Commerce Department's downward revision of its estimates for first-quarter growth. Revision of the G.N.P. The G.N.P. revision, to 1.3 percent from 2.1 percent, was slightly larger than Wall Street economists had anticipated. But much of the reduction was a result of a more rapid inventory liquidation than had been estimated previously. As a result, Mr. Stone and other economists said that inventories replenishment should help to push up second-quarter growth somewhat.
''There is only a very small probability of a recession,'' said Francis H. Schott, senior vice president and chief economist at the Equitable Life Assurance Society. ''At the moment, I see no basis for the Federal Reserve Board to ease monetary policy.''
The downward revision caused prices in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds to move up in early trading. But the gains were wiped out following the 1 P.M. note auction.
By late in the day, the 8 7/8 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 101 17/32, down 14/16, to yield 8.60 percent. Late Wednesday the benchmark bond was offered at a price to yield 8.57 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 5/8, down 9/32, to yield 8.62 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent two-year notes auctioned on Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.48 percent.
 
Slight Rise in Bill Rates
Treasury bill rates rose slightly.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.66 percent, up three basis points, or hundreths of a point. Six-month bills rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 7.69 percent.
In the corporate bond market, TRW Inc. offered $100 million worth of 30-year bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
The 9.35 percent bonds, which mature Sept. 15, 2020, are ''putable'' in 2000. They were priced at $99.65, to yield 9.40 percent, 83 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 8 7/8 percent 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, dealers said that prices of most actively quoted issues were unchanged to down 1/8 point.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that prices of most issues slipped by about 1/8 point in very slow trading.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week ended May 14.
The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Session Higher On U.S. Official's Remarks

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most currencies yesterday on remarks by a United States Treasury official that the currency was probably undervalued except against the Japanese yen.
The comment, by the Assistant Secretary for Economic Policy, Sydney Jones, in a speech in Chicago, pumped life into what was otherwise a slow market.
Activity was dampened by the closing of major European centers for the Ascension Day holiday, and the approach of the Memorial Day holiday in the United States. 
The dollar closed in New York at 150.90 Japanese yen, down from 151.25 Wednesday, and at 1.6840 West German marks against Wednesday's 1.6760.
 
U.S. Economy Slowing
Earlier, the dollar eased after a report of weaker-than-expected growth in the United States gross national product during the first quarter. The report helped underpin the belief that the economy is slowing and interest rates will decline.
The 1.3 percent revised gain in first-quarter G.N.P. was below market expectations of 1.7 percent and down from the orginal estimate of 2.1 percent.
Analysts said the West German mark was the focus of further uncertainty over the political and economic impact of monetary union between East and West Germany, which is expected to take place July 2.
''The weak mark is lending the dollar a good deal of support at the moment,'' said Jeremy Hawkins, senior economic adviser at the Bank of America.
Dealers said the pound drew support from expectations of Britain's early entry into the European Monetary System, although many in the market say entry before the end of this year is unlikely. Governments of system members pledge to keep their currencies within certain ranges.
The British pound was at $1.6875, compated with $1.6950.
Although many traders think the British pound will enter the European Monetary System in a wide 6 percent fluctuation band, Commissioner Sir Leon Brittan of the European Community said yesterday that the pound should be subject to a narrow 2.25 percent band.
