HEADLINE: Patients' Grades Help to Set Pay for Health-Plan Doctors

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
A growing number of large health-care plans are asking patients to grade their doctors: How long are they kept waiting in the office? Can the doctor be reached at night and on weekends? Does the doctor listen as patients describe symptoms? How well is a treatment explained?
Some health maintenance organizations use the grades as one criterion in paying the doctors. Not surprisingly, many doctors think this is a bad idea.
At least 34 million Americans are enrolled in H.M.O. plans, and more than 2.9 million are in plans that use patient evaluations to help determine doctors' bonuses. The number of such plans is steadily increasing. 
 
Attempts to Set Standards
Measuring patient satisfaction is one step in a growing effort to set national standards of health care, doctors and health-care executives say. It is also a way for the health plans to persuade clients that their opinions are valued, in the hope of keeping them as customers.
The plans pay doctors a set fee of $10 a month, on average, for each family member enrolled, no matter how much or how little care is required. The system is intended to discourage doctors from ordering expensive tests and procedures that may not be needed.
Critics say a patient's health may sometimes suffer because doctors are rewarded for withholding care to meet budget goals. Indeed, some people enrolled in the plans have complained of the difficulty of persuading their general-care physicians to refer them to specialists.
The H.M.O.'s say the patients' evaluations - the grades are excellent, very good, good, fair, poor - count for 25 to 33 percent of a doctor's overall rating. The doctor's ability to hold down costs provides 33 to 50 percent of the rating.
The balance of the rating reflects other measures of care, including an examination of patients' charts to determine whether the care seems appropriate.
Doctors with poor ratings lose out on bonuses, and some plans reduce the set fees the doctors receive for each member under their care. If the scores do not improve, the plans often stop referring new members to the doctors or simply drop the doctors from their roster.
U.S. Healthcare Inc., one of the first health plans to link patient evaluations to doctors' bonuses, said it drops 1 or 2 percent of its 3,600 primary-care physicians each year because of low ratings. It began the program in September 1987.
Dr. John R. Ball, executive vice president of the American College of Physicians, which represents 69,000 internists, objects to using patient evaluations to determine bonus payments. Improving a patient's health is more important than the patient's feelings of satisfaction, he said, adding, ''The kindly physician may not be treating the patient optimally, but the patient may feel satisfied and rate him highly.''
 
'Hostage' to Standards
Dr. James S. Todd, acting executive vice president of the American Medical Association, commented: ''Physicians should be paid for what they do, and if they do not do it properly they should be re-educated. They should be paying the primary-care physicians a reasonable income and not holding them hostage to some predetermined standards.''
But Maryann O'Sullivan, executive director of Health Access, a consumer advocacy coalition based in San Francisco, welcomed the idea of a report card. ''Anything that bolsters the doctor-patient relationship and educates doctors in establishing those relationships has got to be good for the patient's health,'' she said.
Health-care executives and economists say the health plans have strong business reasons for keeping their members satisfied. The plans rely on keeping a large number of relatively healthy members so that costs are widely spread. ''People who are essentially well are the basis of the whole thing,'' said John E. Ware Jr., a senior scientist at the New England Medical Center in Boston.
Dissatisifed members ''have feet -they'll walk away from you,'' said Leonard Abramson, president and chief executive of U.S. Healthcare. The company, based in Blue Bell, Pa., sent questionnaires to 909,000 adult members last year and received 201,000 responses.
Several of the nation's largest health-coverage plans now offer bonuses in addition to the fixed payments. And Dr. Michael R. Soper, national medical director of the Cigna Corporation's H.M.O.'s, said they had increased the doctors' basic pay under the new system.
The bonus systems are an attempt by health maintenance plans to find a way to replace the widespread practice of withholding part of the doctors' fees and not making full payment unless the plan meets its annual budget goals. If a plan agreed to pay a doctor $1,000 a month to treat 100 patients, for example, it might pay $800 a month and distribute the other $200 a month in a lump sum at the end of the year - but only if the plan stayed within its budget.
 
A Growing Practice
Plans that use the patient report cards as one measure of performance include U.S. Healthcare, Cigna, at least one Blue Cross H.M.O., some units of the Kaiser Foundation Health Plans in Northern California and AV-MED Inc., an H.M.O. based in Miami. The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, which has 1.5 million people enrolled in its health maintenance organizations, is planning a similar program, said Dr. David L. Potash, Aetna's vice president of medical affairs.
U.S. Healthcare also reviews patient charts to determine, for example, if children receive immunizations and if doctors order appropriate periodic tests, like checking patients' blood pressure and cholesterol levels.
The H.M.O.'s also look at such practices with an eye to holding down costs. When family-care physicians, internists and pediatricians are found to send patients to specialists and hospitals more often than average for those participating in a plan, they are often put on notice that they are exceeding the plan's budget goals.
The Kaiser Foundation, whose plans have 6.3 million members, said its medical centers regularly surveyed patients. In some Kaiser centers, including the one in San Rafael, Calif., ''the results become a basis of decisions on merit and bonuses,'' said Dr. David Lawrence, a senior vice president. He said Kaiser patients in Hawaii were surveyed in an ''exit poll'' as they left the waiting room after an appointment.
But not all the Kaiser surveys are directly tied to physicians' pay. ''We want to do better, to give feedback to the staff,'' Dr. Lawrence said. ''The emphasis is not on linking to pay, but on linking to performance.''
Some companies insist that the administrators running their employee health plans make sure their patients are satisfied.
''We don't want to lose sight of how the patient feels,'' said Patricia M. Nazemetz, the benefits director of the Xerox Corporation, which has signed up Kaiser, U.S. Healthcare and four other plans. ''They are required to measure member satisfaction on our behalf.''
She said Xerox plans to make its own survey of employees' feelings about ''the plan, the care, the access, the overall opportunity.''
 
Evaluations May Be Difficult
But evaluating the evaluations is not always easy.
Dr. Arnold S. Relman, editor of The New England Journal of Medicine, said: ''How satisfied patients are with the care they get is one of the important criteria of quality. But there is a lot of work to be done before we can be satisfied that we know how to measure quality.''
And one concern for doctors is that they often cannot control some problems that annoy patients, like delays in obtaining results of laboratory tests, said Dr. Donald M. Berwick, a pediatrics professor at Harvard Medical School and expert on health-care quality.
''The agenda we need in health care is to make the whole process better,'' he said. ''You can't expect doctors to do that alone. It's a joint task, the job of management.''

HEADLINE: Arafat, in Geneva, Calls on U.N. To Send Force to Occupied Areas

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, May 25

 BODY:
Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, urged the United Nations Security Council today to send a new international force to the Israel-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to protect Palestinians and pave the way for eventual Israeli withdrawal.
In a long address to the 15-member Council, which moved here from New York to hear him, the P.L.O. chairman bitterly assailed Israel and outlined an approach for ending the violence in the occupied areas. Most of his ideas are unacceptable to both the United States and Israel, and in any case, no vote on his proposal is expected until after the Council returns to New York next week.
This is the first time that the Security Council, as distinct from the General Assembly, has moved here. The meeting was called by Arab nations to focus attention on the Palestinian cause and the recent wave of violence in the occupied territories, which started when an apparently deranged Israeli man killed seven Palestinian day laborers near Tel Aviv. 
By meeting in Geneva, the Council relieved the Bush Administration of having to decide whether to grant a visa to Mr. Arafat to come to the United States. Allowing him into the country would have provoked criticism from many members of Congress, who accuse the P.L.O. of terrorism, and would have further strained ties with Israel. But blocking him would have led to criticism from Arab countries and raised questions about the continuing American dialogue with the P.L.O.
Israeli officials have complained that holding the special meeting to hear Mr. Arafat is evidence of anti-Israeli bias in the United Nations. The meeting was called after the lone Israeli, a discharged serviceman, killed the seven Palestinians last Sunday, provoking violence in the occupied territories and in Israel itself, and leading to the deaths of about 20 other Palestinians.
The Israelis noted that no Council meeting was called after a leading Islamic cleric was killed this week in Kashmir and 30 other Muslims were slain by Indian troops in the protests that resulted.
Today, Mr. Arafat was unsparing in his condemnation of Israeli policy in the territories. ''The Israeli occupation forces,'' he said, ''have been waging a war of extermination on all fronts.''
The P.L.O. leader insisted that his organization remained committed to a negotiated settlement and that it would cooperate with the Bush Administration's efforts to bring about talks between Israelis and Palestinians looking to elections in the occupied territories.
In his plan for ending the violence in the occupied territories, the P.L.O. leader first asked the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, to appoint a permanent mediator to oversee the peace process.
He then called on the Council to send a new international force into the territories to protect Palestinian lives and property and also ''with the purpose of ending completely the Israeli occupation of our Palestinian lands.''
Mr. Arafat asked the Council to order Israel to halt all new Jewish settlements in the territories. And he urged the Council to enact economic sanctions against Israel in retaliation for what he said was its mistreatment of the Palestinians.
Before he spoke, Israel's Deputy Foreign Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, told a news conference that his country has ''no intention of accepting any kind of United Nations observer force'' to protect the Palestinians.
But he hinted that it might allow a limited United Nations investigation into recent acts of violence in the territories, saying it had done so in the past after similar Arab complaints.
 
A Meeting Without Purpose
Later, he told the Council there was no justification for its meeting at all because the Arab nations had called the session with the aim of ''inflaming passions and inciting violence'' and not to promote a peace settlement.
The P.L.O. leader appeared in the makeshift Council chamber in his usual green military uniform, and kaffiyeh, the Arab headdress.
Both the United States and Israel made it clear today that they oppose any major new United Nations presence in the occupied territories. However, both left the door open to a more limited United Nations investigation.
 
U.S. Seems to Shift Ground
A senior American official said the Bush Administration might agree to let the United Nations conduct a small fact-finding operation in the occupied territories, similar to the mission it sent in 1988 after earlier Palestinian complaints of mistreatment by Israeli security forces. But he said the United States opposes any new permanent international presence there, implying it would use its Security Council veto.
This formulation of the American position appeared to modify the stance taken by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d earlier this week. At a Washington news conference, the Secretary of State raised Arab expectations by saying the Administration was now willing ''to discuss the question of a United Nations observer team'' if the Arabs asked for one at today's Security Council session. This suggested to many that the United States might accept some new and more permanent United Nations presence in the occupied territories, as Mr. Arafat demanded today.
 
'DISTORTIONS,' ISRAELI SAYS
JERUSALEM, May 25 (AP) - A senior aide to Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, said today that Mr. Arafat's speech in Geneva was ''full of lies and distortions.''
''Here again, Arafat has used the United Nations as a platform for a vicious attack on Israel, making accusations that are full of lies and distortion,'' the aide, Avi Pazner, said. He added that Mr. Arafat raised ''proposals that he knows have no chance whatsoever to be accepted by Israel.''

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
A Two-Eyed Summit

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The customary deliberate downbeat so as not to risk bloated expectations from an imminent Soviet-American summit meeting is the current Washington sound. And there almost surely won't be the grand agreements on arms reductions that President Bush optimistically anticipated last year.
But this isn't because the intricate treaties have run into roadblocks. The big difference in the approach to Mikhail Gorbachev's sixth encounter with an American President is that the purpose has been vastly enlarged. 
When the two leaders meet, the central issue will no longer be just reducing tensions, although that is already turning the world around. It is how to move to a whole new basis for superpower relations in an international system leaving the cold war behind.
Aleksandr Bessmertnykh, the new Soviet Ambassador to Washington, has an interesting formula for testing the summit meeting's success. It isn't the number of documents signed, he said in an interview, but whether Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev can part with each ''sincerely convinced that relations are on the right track. That will calm anxieties all around and leave each to focus on his domestic problems. Mr. Bush has some too,'' he said with a laugh.
The couple of years ahead are a historical crossroads, as important to coming generations as the years immediately after World War II were to fixing the scene until now. There is a fluidity that won't last after the critical decisions are made on Germany, on Europe, on international security.
As Mr. Bessmertnykh put it, ''we all have to find our places in a new structure.'' Moscow sees it as a ''stage by stage'' development and worries that the Germans ''are in too much of a hurry.'' He regrets the West took a firm stand on including a united Germany in NATO instead of ''sitting down and talking it over together,'' but he doesn't sound tough on this. The Soviet Union isn't looking for parity in Europe, he said, but for ''stability.''
Obviously, the idea of parity between NATO and the Warsaw Pact has been swept away by the upheaval in Eastern Europe. But the Soviets fear being left out in the cold. Mr. Gorbachev needs to take home to his people a sense that he hasn't given away the ramparts on which they were long told their security depended, but has traded an unsustainable order for new opportunities and a more reliable future.
This deserves American understanding. It is in our interest. The more the Russians relax, the less they menace. The West Europeans see it, arguing that a settlement imposed at a time of Soviet weakness could lead to a German-type syndrome, an aggrieved, resentful nation dreaming of revenge, as after the Versailles Treaty.
The extent of the reversal of perceptions is highlighted in a tiny item in the news. A generation ago, when the West was distraught about a Soviet ''master plan to take over the world,'' the Russians were claiming that ''as is well known,'' they had invented practically everything and were inherently superior. Now, it is reported, they have invited Americans, from Anchorage, to teach them how to make sausages efficiently.
But there's no scheme yet for settling the Russians - and whatever peoples they retain in their Union -into an open world in a way they and everybody else can be comfortable with. Mr. Bessmertnykh complained that by integration the West seems to mean Western integration, perhaps inviting some East Europeans to join.
Moscow is vague on its ideas, and emphasizes ''process.'' The Ambassador said it doesn't want to delay or obstruct German unity, but needs respect for Soviet rights, and that Lithuania is entitled to ''independence and sovereignty'' but through constitutional procedures.
The key is transition. On Germany, the outlines of an accord are emerging. Essentially, it will be economic, not only Bonn paying occupation costs to the Red Army in Germany in hard currency for a few years (mind-boggling, but coming) but also honoring East Germany's trade agreements with Moscow. Demolishing the East bloc's complex trade system overnight would be disastrous, but transformation is expensive and will take time.
The U.S. is right to insist that NATO, embracing Germany, is needed as far ahead as the kaleidoscopic future can be seen. Moscow will have to get used to the idea, but it needs help in the form of guarantees. It would like to institutionalize them in the 35-nation Helsinki framework. The U.S. is opposed to abandoning a successful security system for paper, but it could afford to add some paper on longer term goals.
The differences aren't so great if the need for keeping an eye on the ground and on the horizon is kept in mind. Too much is at stake for one-eyed diplomacy, but the prospects are good.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

HEADLINE: Private Pension System Is Alive and Well

 BODY:
To the Editor:
On May 9, you published an Associated Press article about a Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (P.B.G.C.) press release which identified the 50 companies with the largest underfunded pension plans (''Shortfall in Pension Funds Cited''). Unfortunately, that article gave a distorted view of the overall excellent health of the U.S. private pension fund system.
The aggregate assets in the private pension system were equal to 138 percent of total liabilities as of 1987 (the latest data available), and based on the latest available Department of Labor surveys, over 80 percent of private pension plans have assets that exceed their accumulated benefit obligation (termination liability). 
We believe the P.B.G.C. data are flawed in three major areas. First, the low interest rate of 7.75 percent significantly overstates liabilities and is well below prevailing market rates at the time of valuation. Settlement rates with major and healthy insurers were significantly higher at the time. Second, some companies appear on the list solely because foreign subsidiary and non-qualified plans, for which the P.B.G.C. bears no liability, were included in the study. Third, the article gives the impression that the figures apply to the total pension plans of the listed companies while the data were compiled from underfunded plans only, plans that in many cases represent just a fraction of the company's total plans.
For those company plans that are less than fully funded, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (Erisa) mandates strict minimum funding standards in order to insure that benefits will be fully funded during the remaining working careers of the employees.
While we support efforts by Congress and the P.B.G.C. to insure that workers receive their full pension benefits, we would caution against studies that oversimplify and therefore misrepresent an area that is so critical to current and future retirees of our nation. The greater risk facing the private pension system in the U.S. is the myriad of legislation and regulation that is threatening the viability of defined benefit plans, whose demise, all concede, would be detrimental to U.S. workers.
 
JIM KAITZ
Director of Government Relations
Financial Executives Institute
 Washington, May 17, 1990

HEADLINE: Georgia Judge Rule Klan Is Persecuted

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, May 25

 BODY:
Calling the Ku Klux Klan ''a persecuted group,'' a Georgia state court judge ruled today that a state ban on the wearing of masks illegally restricted the group's free speech.
In a sweeping ruling, the judge, Howard E. Cook of Gwinnett County State Court, ruled that a 1952 Georgia law against wearing masks in public, enacted to curb the Klan's activities, ''violates freedoms of speech, free association and equal protection guarantees, as well as being vague and overbroad, and is therefore unconstitutional.''
Judge Cook ruled that widespread hostility to the Klan meant that members might need the anonymity provided by a mask to exercise their First Amendment rights without fear of reprisal. He also said the law impeded the Klan's ability to attract new members. 
 
Return to Old Ways Feared
The Gwinnett County prosecutor's office immediately filed an appeal with the Georgia Supreme Court. Lawyers with the county and the Georgia Attorney General's office expressed shock at the ruling.
''I take particular exception to the judge's characterization of the Klan as a persecuted group,'' said David M. Fuller, chief assistant prosecutor for the county. ''History has shown time and again the Klan is a persecuting group.''
Mr. Fuller expressed confidence that the judge's ruling would be reversed. But he said that if it is upheld, the ruling could have disastrous consequences.
''When this statute was enacted there were a lot of people being murdered and terrorized,'' he said. ''There was vandalism of property, and this act stopped that. If upheld by the Georgia Supreme Court or the U.S. Supreme Court, this would give the Klan carte blanche to revert to how it operated in the 30's and 40's. The Klan is not deserving of the anonymity the mask would afford it.''
The 1952 law, similar to laws in many other states, bans the wearing of masks in public, with several exceptions, including holiday costumes, sportswear or occupational face gear. It was passed by the Georgia Legislature explicitly to combat the Klan's anonymous terror.
 
A Deliberate Challenge
The case stems from a Feb. 28 challenge to the 1952 law mounted by Shade Miller Jr., an unemployed member of the Invisible Empire Knights of the Ku Klux Klan. After telling the authorities of his intentions a day earlier, Mr. Miller showed up at a courthouse in Lawrenceville northeast of Atlanta in his Klan hood.
He was arrested and charged with a misdemeanor violation of the mask law, a charge that carries a maximum penalty of a $1,000 fine and a year in prison. His lawyer, Michael R. Hauptman, who is president of the Georgia American Civil Liberties Union but is defending Mr. Miller on his own, then filed a motion as part of the criminal case charging that the mask law was unconstitutional.
State officials said they felt the law was potentially vulnerable to complaints that it was overly broad, but they were shocked by the judge's far-ranging attack on it. Judge Cook compared the Klan case to lawsuits involving the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in Alabama during the height of the civil rights movement or Iranians here who wore masks at demonstrations critical of the Shah during his reign. He said both groups of critics were given legal sanction for anonymity so they could exercise their First Amendment rights.
''Persecuted groups and sects from time to time throughout history have been able to criticize oppressive practices and law either anonymously or not at all,'' he ruled. ''The court finds that the Klan is in effect a persecuted group in that its beliefs may be so abhorrent to most members of society that the Klan members and their families may be in the same amount of danger'' as the Iranian students or N.A.A.C.P. members were.
 
Shock at Judge's Comparisons
Mr. Fuller said the Klan provided no testimony that supported its claim of danger to its members. And he said that the issues in this case were not the same as those involving the N.A.A.C.P. and that the judge was making an inappropriate comparison.
Officials with organizations that keep track of hate groups said the ruling and the judge's logic were appalling.
''I sat through that hearing and I don't recall one shred of evidence that any Klansman had been lynched, firebombed or assaulted because of who they were,'' said Eva Sears of the Center for Democratic Renewal in Atlanta. ''A Klansman in a Klan mask does have an organizational history of violence.''

HEADLINE: Scientists Urge Rapid Action on Global Warming

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, May 25

 BODY:
A panel of scientists warned today that unless emissions of carbon dioxide and other harmful gases were immediately cut by more than 60 percent, global temperatures would rise sharply over the next century, with unforeseeable consequences for humanity.
While much of the substance of the report has already been disclosed, the report had immediate political consequences. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, breaking with the Bush Administration's skepticism over the need for immediate action, said today that if other countries did their part, Britain would reduce the projected growth of its carbon dioxide emissions enough to stabilize them at 1990 levels by the year 2005.
West Germany's Environment Minister, Klaus Topfer, has proposed that Europe should go further and cut present emissions by 25 percent by that time, but the United States has said until now that the scientific case for global warming - the so-called greenhouse effect - has not been made and that no action needs to be taken. 
Mrs. Thatcher's action is a blow to the Bush Administration, which was counting on her as its major ally in slowing any international action to reduce the industrial pollution that causes global warming.
The report by a working group of the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change was approved by all but a handful of the 90 delegates from 39 countries, said Dr. John T. Houghton, chairman. The report said that if nothing at all was done, the global mean temperature could rise 5.4 degrees Fahrenheit by the end of the 21st century.
It said that in that case, ocean water would expand and ice stored at the poles could melt, raising the level of the sea by 25.6 inches. That would be enough to submerge the Maldives and inundate the coastal plains of Bangladesh and the Netherlands, oceanographers say.
Mr. Houghton, Britain's chief meteorologist, said that only a handful of the scientists in the panel disagreed with the findings, which he said were dramatic confirmation of how rapidly the carbon dioxide, methane, chlorofluorocarbons and other gases released into the air by industrial processes, the burning of tropical forests and other factors had been changing the earth's atmosphere since the end of the 18th century. A draft of the report was previously disclosed.
 
Britain and U.S. Percentages
Britain, with 1 percent of the world's population, is responsible for about 3 percent of its carbon dioxide emissions, Mrs. Thatcher said. The United States, with 5 percent of the population, is responsible for about 25 percent of the emissions, American scientists say.
Prof. Bert Bolin, the chairman of the intergovernmental panel, described Mrs. Thatcher's action as ''very useful'' but said, ''It is not enough in the long term.'' If all countries did as Britain suggested, Dr. Houghton said, it would still not be enough to stop the enhanced greenhouse effect. ''If you want to stop it, you have to cut by 60 percent immediately,'' he said at a news conference in Englefield Green, where the working group discussed its findings this week.
''She has taken a kind of halfway position between the aggressive moves being considered by the West Germans and the 'What, me worry?' position of the United States,'' said Michael Oppenheimer, an atmospheric physicist of the Environmental Defense Fund of New York City, who was in a group of scientists Mrs. Thatcher invited a year ago to advise her on global warming.
 
Called Too Little Too Late
British environmental groups denounced Mrs. Thatcher's proposal as too little, too late. ''It does not even go as far as the very modest first step that the European Community proposed back in March of stabilizing emissions at the present level by the year 2000,'' said Andrew Dilworth, a spokesman for Friends of the Earth.
Mrs. Thatcher, in her speech at the opening of a center for climate prediction and research in Bracknell, said, ''It is no good setting political targets for action which are just not realistic in practice.'' Mrs. Thatcher, who had been briefed on the working group's findings earlier this week, said today that reducing projected increases in British carbon dioxide emissions by 30 percent in 15 years would mean ''significant adjustments to our economies - more efficient power stations, cars which use less fuel, better insulated houses and better management of energy in general.''
The working group's report is one of three that were commissioned in November 1988 by the United Nations Environment Program and the World Meteorological Organization for a global climate conference in Geneva in November. Another working group headed by the Soviet Union is considering the impact of climate changes on agriculture, forests, fisheries, water resources, and sea barriers, and the third, headed by the United States, is considering strategies for responding to climate change. Professor Bolin said today that he would not discuss the draft reports of either of them.
 
Cut of 60% Recommended
The United Nations group's report today said that just to stabilize atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide and chlorofluorocarbons at today's levels, there would have to be immediate cuts of more than 60 percent in their output. Depending on how much was actually done to cut emissions, it said, global mean temperature would still keep rising between 0.1 degrees centigrade (0.18 degrees Fahrenheit) and 0.2 degrees centigrade (0.36 degrees Fahrenheit) per decade.
Global mean surface air temperature has already increased by 0.3 degrees centigrade (0.54 Fahrenheit) to 0.6 degrees centigrade (1.08 degrees Fahrenheit) over the last 100 years, it said, with the five average warmest years all occurring in the 1980's.
Scientists who study global climate trends concede, however, that the computer models on which they base their predictions are flawed. While the researchers can measure gases in the atmosphere with precision, they have not perfected methods of predicting their effects on particular regions on earth.
So far, there has been only one major step to control greenhouse gases - the major industrialized countries' pledge last year to ban production of chlorofluorocarbons, used as refrigerants and propellants, by the end of this century because they rise to the upper atmosphere and destroy the ozone molecules that block most of the sun's harmful ultraviolet radiation.

HEADLINE: Prices of Long-Term U.S. Bonds Decline

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury bonds tumbled yesterday in a shortened pre-Memorial Day weekend session. The Treasury securities market, which normally does not have fixed trading hours, closed at 2 P.M., Eastern daylight time.
Dealers said the sharp markdowns in prices of long-term Treasury bonds reflected the disappointing results at Thursday's auction of $8.5 billion of five-year notes. The notes, which produced an average yield of 8.54 percent, closed yesterday at a yield of 8.59 percent. 
But as is usually the case in a weak Treasury debt market, the most pronounced declines were posted by the longer maturities. For example, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in 2020, were being offered at 100 29/32 at the close. This represented a drop of 20/32 on the day.
 
Yield Up to 8.66%
 The long bond's yield, meanwhile, rose to 8.66 percent, from 8.60 percent the day before, but was still below the 8.69 percent yield of a week ago. The Treasury's long notes, the 8 7/8's of 2000, declined by 11/32, to 101 9/32, for a yield of 8.68 percent.
But the $10.8 billion of two-year notes auctioned on Wednesday at an average yield of 8.52 percent closed down 3/32, at 99 31/32, for a yield of 8.51 percent.
''The results of the five-year auction began undermining prices late Thursday, but did not really manifest itself until this morning,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''Some of today's selling was probably caused by traders wanting to square their books before leaving for the three-day weekend, but there is growing concern about the market's ability to absorb the flood of Treasury debt. An increasing portion of this debt can be traced to the bailout of the thrift industry.''
 
Dollar's Decline a Factor
 Also unsettling the fixed-income market was the overnight decline in the dollar against the yen. The dollar fell below 150 yen for the first time since March 6. ''With Japanese stock and bond markets rallying, it may limit Japanese interest in our markets,'' Mr. Sullivan said.
Still another concern weighing on the bond market was the Government's release yesterday morning of data showing unexpectedly strong consumer spending in April. The Government said that April personal consumption expenditures were up by six-tenths of 1 percent, ''which was above expectations, given all the bearish economic data we have been getting for April,'' Mr. Sullivan added. Personal income for the month was up by three-tenths of 1 percent, which economists had expected.
At the short end of the Treasury market, the discount rate on 90-day bills rose 7 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.75 percent; six-month bills were up 4 basis points, at 7.75 percent, and one-year bills climbed 8 basis points, to 7.67 percent.
 
Thursday Auction Planned
 The Treasury announced that it planned to auction $10 billion of new one-year bills this Thursday. The sale would raise some $1.4 billion in new cash. The Treasury also said it planned to auction $6 billion each of cash management bills on May 30 and dated June 1 in two segments. Half the bills would mature on June 21 and the other half on Sept. 20. Cash management bills are issued only in denominations of $1 million.
The Federal Reserve, meanwhile, added $1 billion of reserves to the banking system to accommodate holiday weekend needs. The key Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for temporary loans, was trading at 8.25 percent at the time the reserves were added, but later edged up to 8 5/16 percent.

HEADLINE: Home Resales Fell in April

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes fell by 2.1 percent in April, the third drop in four months as mortgage rates remained high, a real estate trade group reported today.
The National Association of Realtors said resales of single-family homes in April totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.33 million units, down from the March rate of 3.4 million. 
Sales of existing homes hit their 1989 peak of 3.56 million units in November and December and then fell in January, February and April. Sales were unchanged in March. According to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, mortgage rates ranged from 10.25 percent to 10.56 percent in April. They had dipped to 10.33 percent by today.
John A. Tuccillo, chief economist of the realtor group, said the high rates were keeping many prospective buyers out of the market in hopes of future rate declines.
But despite the cost of mortgages, the sluggish Northeast market posted the only gain in April. Sales rose 4 percent, to 520,000 units, in what the president of the realtor association, Norman D. Flynn, called a ''buyer's market'' caused by supply exceeding demand.
Sales slipped 1.1 percent, to 900,000 units, in the Midwest and dropped by 3.7 percent, to 1.31 million units, in the South. But they plummeted by 7.9 percent, to 580,000 homes, in the West.
The realtor group said the national median price for an existing home in April was $95,300, down by 1 percent from March but up by 2.6 percent from April 1989. The median price means half of the homes cost more, half less.

HEADLINE: Quarterly Trade Deficit A 6-Year Low

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit shrank to $26.4 billion in the first quarter, the smallest quarterly imbalance in more than six years, the Government said today.
The Commerce Department said the 8.2 percent improvement in the trade balance in the January-to-March period resulted from record-high export sales that offset the highest volume of oil imports in more than 12 years.
The improving trade performance, if it continues, would be good news for the American economy. Over the last three years, rising exports have accounted for more than a third of total domestic growth, as United States manufacturers enjoyed an increase in foreign sales. 
 
The Growth Outlook
 ''We have continued strong export growth, and that is leading to better trade numbers than a lot of people were predicting,'' said Howard Lewis, the vice president for international economic affairs at the National Association of Manufacturers, the industry group based here.
David Jones, an economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a government securities dealer in New York, said export growth should continue to be an important source of strength for the United States economy for some time.
But some analysts cautioned today that it was too soon to tell whether the first-quarter performance would continue for the rest of the year. They said oil imports were surging because the nation's crude production had dropped to 25-year lows and that the strength of the United States dollar in comparison with the Japanese yen could start showing up in rising imports of Japanese products, which are cheaper in dollar terms when the currency strengthens.
 
Exports Up 4.7%
 For the first quarter, United States exports rose by 4.7 percent, to a high of $96.04 billion. Imports were also at a record level, reflecting the surge in oil demand. They climbed by 1.6 percent, to $122.4 billion.
Oil imports surged by 17 percent, to $15.6 billion, with the average number of barrels imported daily climbing to 8.9 million, the highest level since the third quarter of 1977.
The first-quarter trade performance marked the second consecutive quarterly improvement in the deficit. In the fourth quarter, the gap between exports and imports fell by 3.5 percent, to $28.7 billion.
The report today on merchandise trade as calculated on a balance-of-payments basis confirmed trends already noted in the department's monthly merchandise trade reports. They showed a first-quarter deficit of $23.9 billion. The disparity in the figures results from the exclusion of military sales by the Government from today's report, and includes other minor adjustments to the monthly figures.
America's deficits declined with several countries, including Japan, which was down by $1.9 billion, to $10.4 billion for the quarter.

HEADLINE: Rise in April Spending Topped Income Increase

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
Americans spent more last month despite a slump in income gains, the Commerce Department said today, providing a continuing stimulus for the economy at the start of the second quarter.
But personal income rose only by three-tenths of a percent in April, the smallest monthly increase in seven months, after solid gains of eight-tenths of a percent in each of the two preceding months. The last time a smaller increase occurred was September last year, when incomes rose by two-tenths of a percent. 
Spending, however, rose at a pace that was stronger that had been forecast, increasing by six-tenths of a percent last month, after gains of five-tenths of a percent each in February and March. The Government said consumers spent at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.68 trillion, making it the largest gain since a 1.2 percent jump in January.
 
Payrolls Fall $2.3 Billion
 Consumer spending acounts for about two-thirds of total consumption of the nation's output of goods and services and is closely monitored because a downturn can foreshadow a weaker expansion.
Manufacturing payrolls fell by $2.3 billion last month, a sharp reversal from March, when employees in goods-producing industries were paid $4.8 billion more than in February.
By contrast, payrolls in the service industry went up by $11.7 billion last month, after a $5.7 billion rise in March. Government wages and salaries increased by $2.8 billion, after a $3 billion March rise.
The Commerce Department on Thursday scaled back its estimate of growth in the first quarter of this year to an annual rate of 1.3 percent from 2.1 percent, largely because businesses cut production and sold off inventories.
 
Some Expansion Seen
 Analysts said the revised estimate left the economy in a position to continue expanding, albeit at a sluggish pace, while inventories were rebuilt.
Kathryn Kobe, an economist for Joel Popkin & Company, a forecasting firm here, said the rise in April spending was surprisingly large in light of other signs of declining sales.
''It's good news, except that we're already seeing weak May car sales so we're not likely to see a big pickup in durables spending continuing,'' Ms. Kobe said.
The sales of American-made cars and trucks in mid-May were 17.5 percent lower than in the comparable period last year. Total retail sales dropped in April for a second straight month after being flat in February.
 
'Low-Growth Scenario'
 Ms. Kobe said that policy makers at the Federal Reserve Board would probably not mind if sales eased.
''The fact that personal consumption is not real strong is good from the Fed's point of view,'' Ms. Kobe said, ''They want a low-growth scenario to keep inflation down.''
As a result, Americans' savings rate, savings as a percentage of disposable income, slipped to 5.5 percent in April, from 5.8 percent in March. It had been 5.5 percent in February, up from 5.3 percent in January.
Total disposable income, seasonally adjusted at annual rates, was $4.01 trillion in April, compared with $3.99 trillion the previous month. Savings fell to an annual rate of $221 billion last month from $234 billion in March.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Retirees Need Investing Acumen

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
For retirees, making the right investment decisions can be crucial because the income from investments must often replace earned income for living expenses. Consequently, most retirees feel they cannot afford to risk any loss of capital.
That makes it tough to make investment decisions, particularly for people with a substantial amount to invest for the first time in their lives, such as a person who has received a lump sum retirement distribution or a recently widowed person who has received insurance proceeds.
Experts discussed investing for retirees at the annual forum of the New York City chapter of the International Association for Financial Planning last week. Although the forum was intended to meet the continuing education needs of financial professionals, the advice can help individuals. 
''There is really no one way of handling it,'' said Connie S. P. Chen, a financial planner who is a member of the chapter's advisory board, adding that the starting point is to make a cash-flow projection, considering income from all sources, including pension, profit-sharing or 401(k) plans, individual retirement accounts and Social Security.
Then look at expenses. If they exceed those sources of income, calculate how much income from investments is needed to make up the difference. In this way retirees can determine what portion of their money to invest for current income and what portion to invest for capital appreciation.
Many retirees are afraid to invest for appreciation, because that can mean buying stocks that might lose value instead of gaining, so they want to put all their assets into safe havens like Treasury securities or certificates of deposit. What advice can be given to such clients? ''If they are going to achieve their goals in today's economy, they are going to have to take risks,'' replied Donald R. Pitti, president and chief executive of Seligman Marketing Inc. That is because the life expectancy of a 65-year-old man is 20 years, and it is longer for a woman, he said, and few pensions are indexed to inflation.
Thus, as the cost of living rises, people who are several years into retirement may need to increase the value of the assets in their portfolios that they can sell and reinvest for greater current income.
The risk can be limited by buying into a mutual fund with a good track record, Mr. Pitti added. ''There are at least a dozen mutual funds with a history of double-digit performance documentable over 30 years,'' he said. An aggressive growth fund would be inappropriate, he added.
Martin Jaffe, chapter chairman, suggested investing in serial maturity bonds and using any excess income they produce to build up an equity portfolio. ''It's not quick, but it will get you there,'' he said. Mr. Jaffe, who is senior vice president and chief operating officer of Wood, Struthers & Winthrop, the investment management subsidiary of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, elaborated on his approach afterward.
''I use serial bonds to reduce volatility,'' he said. ''I normally suggest allocation to meet income requirements,'' he continued, and bonds provide a predictable source of income. For example, if 70 percent of a person's capital will produce income for current needs, it can be put into Government bonds and the other 30 percent in equities.
But for those who may have been burned once and are afraid of the stock market, all or most of their money can be invested in bonds and the excess income used to build up an equity portfolio gradually. ''I've used it; it works,'' he said.
''Never take more risk than you need to take,'' Mr. Jaffe added. ''The only reason for equities is to have something that will grow in value to produce more income for tomorrow.''
Annuities appeal to many retirees. This is an insurance product in which the investment grows on a tax-deferred basis to produce an annual income. While annuities may fit into a diversified portfolio, care must be exercised in selection.
Jerome S. Golden, chairman of the Golden Financial Group, cited as risks their illiquidity and the lack of an inflation hedge. He recommended that people in their 60's select an annuity for a certain period, not a life annuity.
Another important consideration for retirees, he noted, can be disability. A person who becomes disabled may face burdensome expenses for care. Therefore, he suggested a retiree disability feature, in which the annuity holder accepts an actuarial reduction in normal annual income in return for a double payment in the event of disability.
One key to reducing risk is diversification. ''Build as much flexibility as possible,'' Ms. Chen said. One way is to invest in a family of mutual funds.

HEADLINE: Aid Resumed Too Argentina; Debt Talk Set

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund approved the resumption of aid to Argentina yesterday and, at the same time, Argentina and its commercial bankers said they will start debt negotiations on June 7.
The two announcements are breakthoughs in the long-delayed effort to reduce Argentina's debt under the Bush Administration's debt strategy. With $62 billion in debt to banks, international institutions and governments, Argentina is the third-largest debtor among developing countries after Brazil and Mexico. 
The first discussion between the bankers and Argentina will focus on the country's resumption of interest payments. They have been cut off for about two years, and Argentina is now about $6.1 billion behind in interest payments.
 
Details Left to Negotiators
 Ernesto Feldman, Argentina's representative at the I.M.F., said in an interview last night that the monetary fund's board had given ''reassurances that in the framework of negotiations Argentina would resume regular payments to the banks.'' But he added that the ''sequence and size'' of the payments would be left to the negotiators.
Mr. Feldman said that the board was worried about the interest arrears but that Argentina's commitment to pay interest and the start of negotiations on debt reduction with the bankers ''was very helpful.'' The monetary fund has come under criticism for providing loans to countries that are behind in interest payments to their banks. Many bankers argue that this encourages countries not to pay interest.
The monetary fund's board approved the resumption of aid to Argentina that originally received approval last fall only to be cut off in February after the Government's economic program ran aground.
But in March, in another attempt to tame inflation, stabilize the currency and open its markets, the Argentine Government announced a new, tough program. In a statement, the monetary fund cited ''the forceful program'' being put into effect as the reason for the resumption of aid to Argentina.
The original aid to Argentina totaled $1.44 billion. The Argentines got $240 million of it last fall and will get another $240 million immediately. The $240 million payment due in February will be lost.
The final three installments of $240 million each will be available to be used in any debt agreement to provide incentives, like guarantees on interest rates or principal, to get bankers to reduce the level of debt the country owes. Of the $62 billion in total debt, Argentina owes about $30 billion in medium- and long-term loans to its bankers.
The resumption of the debt negotiations with the 13-member bank advisory committee was announced in a statement from William R. Rhodes, senior executive-international at Citibank, and chairman of the bank negotiating committee.
In a related matter, some bankers said yesterday that the meetings this week with the Brazilian Economics Minister, Zelia Cardoso de Mello, were disappointing. They added that there were no indications when Brazil would begin paying interest to the banks or when the country would try to begin negotiations with its bankers on debt reduction. Brazil is about $5.5 billion behind in interest payments.
But one banker, who asked not to be identified, said that Argentina's move to resume some interest payments could put pressure on Brazil. With reserves of $8 billion, Brazil is in a far better position to pay some interest than Argentina, which has reserves of only $1 billion, the banker said. The banker added that there was also growing concern about problems with the stringent Brazilan economic program, which froze about 80 percent of the country's bank accounts for 18 months.

HEADLINE: Black Unionists Cheer Dinkins in New Orleans

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, May 25

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins was loudly cheered today as he arrived to address the Coalition of Black Trade Unionists meeting here.
More than 1,500 workers from 76 international and national unions were expected to attend the weekend event. 
Mr. Dinkins expressed his gratitude to the coalition for their longstanding support, and then spoke of a new mood of ''mutual respect'' in New York City.
''The voices of the great, vast majority of New Yorkers are rising in a chorus that demands an end to bigotry and bias, injustice and violence,'' he said.
Mr. Dinkins also criticized the Federal Government's urban policies.
''For 10 long, hard years,'' he said, ''our national government has treated cities as if we were from another planet.''
He called for more Federal funds for cities, and said he hoped to address that issue next fall when he convenes a meeting of mayors from throughout the nation for the purpose of creating a national urban agenda.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Suburbs Attack Florio's Plan to Shift Their School Aid

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 25

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio's proposed plan to shift tens of millions of dollars in state education aid from prosperous suburban school systems to poorer urban and rural districts was sharply criticized by surburban school officials today as unfair, divisive and shortsighted.
''He's made a political and economic statement that shows no understanding of what it takes to educate kids for the 21st century,'' said Dr. Vincent Doyle, school business administrator for Teaneck, one of the 63 towns in suburban Bergen County that will begin losing at total of nearly $100 million in state money in the 1992-93 school year.
''All he's saying is this is how much money is in the pie - you 600 districts go fight for it,'' Mr. Doyle said. ''It completely misfocuses on the needs of all the state's kids - Camden's kids, Teaneck's kids and the kids in between.'' 
By mid-1996, Teaneck would loose $5.6 million of its current annual state aid of $9.4 million.
 
'It's Devestating for Education'
Like other critics, Mr. Doyle extolled the part of Mr. Florio's plan that would pump millions of dollars into inner-city schools. But, he said, the money should not be taken from high-achieving suburban systems already buffeted by residents' anger over increasing property taxes and Governor Florio's proposed income tax increases.
Ridgewood, another of Bergen's highly regarded districts, would lose half of its annual $7.8 million in state aid under the plan.
''It's devastating for education in Ridgewood,'' said its superintendent, Frederick J. Stokley. ''We're going to have to make up $3.9 million. Excellent school systems in the state will become mediocre. I don't agree with the theory of tearing down school systems with high commitment to education to solve the problems of the inner cities.''
Statewide, 356 systems, primarily those in inner cities and the sparsely settled outlying reaches of the state, would start receiving more aid in the 1991-92 school year from nearly $1 billion in Mr. Florio's proposed income tax increases.
However, 222 other school districts, predominately middle class and upper income, would receive no new aid for 1991-92, and then lose a total of $227 million over the next four years. The cuts would come in 25 percent reductions each year off the 1991-92 level.
One of the 222 is Hackensack, county seat of hard-hit Bergen County and an urban district where 60 percent of the 3,500 students are black or Hispanic. It would lose $5.8 million of its current $8.6 million in state aid by June 1996.
''I'm stunned,'' said Hackensack's superintendent, Anthony Marseglia. ''For a community like ours, it would absolutely destroy our system and the economy of the community would go awry. We'd be looking at increasing taxes a million and a half dollars a year. Many of our people are blue collar or retired on fixed incomes and they're already up in arms over property taxes.''
While Bergen's schools would face the deepest cuts, other suburban districts across the northern half of the state would be cut as well. Wayne, a rapidly growing middle-class suburb in northern Passaic County, would lose $7.3 million of its $11.4 million in state aid by mid-1996. Princeton, one of the state's premier districts, would lose $3.1 million of $4.2 million.
Money for State-Mandated Programs Like a growing number of suburban school executives, Princeton's business administrator, Dr. Robert Rader, complained about aid cuts and increased costs for what he said are educationally superfluous state-mandated programs, like testing schools for radon and digging up aging oil storage tanks.
''We spend a lot of money complying with state requirements that don't improve the education of our students,'' Dr. Rader said. ''If they're going to take away our aid, then take away some of these requirements.''
Princeton and Wayne are among 151 districts deemed too prosperous to receive money under the Governor's new funding system, called foundation aid. What determines whether a district qualifies is its property value per pupil and its personal income per pupil. The 356 districts that would receive foundation aid generally fall below the state average for property value and income. The 151 that do not qualify and another 71 districts that would receive smaller amounts of foundation aid than what they now receive from the state in other aid generally exceed the state average.
These 222 districts would be guaranteed that their 1991-92 state aid levels would match 1990-91 levels. Then four years of cuts would start in 1992-93, and the money cut would go to increase foundation aid to other districts.
Governor Florio's chief education advisor, Thomas B. Corcoran, today defended the proposed shifts in aid, saying the 356 districts that would get increases have 73.5 percent of the state's 1.1 million school children. The other 222, he said, are best able to endure the cuts.
''These are the districts that are wealthiest, and it's fair they should pay their fair share,'' Mr. Corcoran said. ''Plus, the reductions are going to be phased in over four years, so it shouldn't have that big an impact.''
Of the $969 million in foundation aid to be shared by 356 urban and rural districts, 41.5 percent, or about $402 million, will go to the state's 20 poorest cities, including Newark, Jersey City, Paterson, Elizabeth, Camden, Perth Amboy, Trenton, East Orange, Millville and Vineland.
The only current state spending that would not be included in the foundation aid system would be for transportation and special education. No districts would be cut in these areas.

LENGTH: 2435 words

HEADLINE: TOWARD THE SUMMIT;
Gorbachev's Need: To Still Matter

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 26

 BODY:
What President Mikhail S. Gorbachev seems to need most of all from the Washington summit meeting that begins on Wednesday is not arms control or economic aid, not agreement on Germany or sympathy on Lithuania, but proof that he still matters.
A crowd-pleasing performance in America may no longer be enough to distract the Soviet public from its woeful domestic obsessions, but it is only on the international stage these days that Mr. Gorbachev seems to his own people a commanding figure, a shaper of the world. He has never needed that reminder more.
 
Anxiety at Profound Change
It is not that any particular rival threatens his place, or that any faction is poised to overthrow him. His five-year term as President runs until March 1995. But his authority seems to be dissolving beneath him as his popular support slackens and he struggles to keep pace with events. 
People who once viewed any threat to Mr. Gorbachev with alarm, believing that everything depended on him, have now begun to contemplate life after Gorbachev, or at least a life in which Mr. Gorbachev is an officeholder with no real power.
The Soviet leader's comrades say Mr. Gorbachev is not suffering a crisis of trust, simply the natural anxiety that accompanies profound change.
''Of course, the euphoria dies when the leadership starts doing unpopular things,'' Yevgeny M. Primakov, a member of Mr. Gorbachev's Cabinet, said in an interview. ''But at the same time that does not mean we are weak. We are strong enough to continue this course.''
Yegor Yakovlev, editor of the reformist Moscow News, points to the astonishing transformations that have taken place in the last year alone. New political parties are being born, the Communist autocracy is giving way to a constitutional presidency and the Government talks of building a market economy on the ruins of Communist planning.
''Where you see chaos, I perceive the dismantling of the old system,'' the editor wrote in this week's issue.
Indeed, that has been Mr. Gorbachev's style - to instigate a kind of havoc and trust in his own ability to sort out the disorder.
Yet on all fronts - the unraveling of the Communist political system, the dissolution of the Eastern bloc, the cascade of economic discontents - it seems that the breakdown of the old order is accelerating faster than something stable can be built in its place.
 
A Time of 3 Crises, All Coming Home
 The summit takes Mr. Gorbachev from Moscow at a time when three major political crises are coming home at once.
His Government's new economic plan is already under fire from consumers alarmed by the promise of price rises, and by market advocates who say the five-year transition program takes too long to dismantle central planning.
Lithuania is due to run out of oil any day as a result of a selective economic blockade imposed by Mr. Gorbachev to punish the republic's declaration of independence.
And his political nemesis, Boris N. Yeltsin, has mounted a strong challenge for control of the largest Soviet republic, Russia. Even if Mr. Yeltsin falls short, the new Russian Parliament has shown a strong inclination to lessen the republic's subservience to Soviet economic and political managers.
''Yeltsin is a bigger problem for Gorbachev than Bush, because he's right here,'' said Leonid Gurevich, a journalist and a deputy from Murmansk, aptly summing up the priority list of Mr. Gorbachev's headaches.
 
Holding the Center: Soviet Tug-of-War
 Politically, Mr. Gorbachev has tried to hold a stable center as the country polarizes into rival camps of radical change and resistance.
Mr. Gorbachev has alienated a broad alliance of self-styled democrats who have proven substantial popular support at the ballot box and who now control such important enclaves as the Moscow and Leningrad City Governments.
These groups have pushed for innovations like market economics and a multiparty system long before Mr. Gorbachev publicly endorsed them, and have reaped the rewards in public support.
The Soviet leader and his supporters disparage the democratic opposition as ambitious and irresponsible sniping from the sidelines.
As this group grows in strength and self-confidence, and moves from the sidelines into the city halls, it is more and more inclined to regard Mr. Gorbachev as a slightly passe elder statesman and to resent American fascination with the Soviet leader.
''You are all so infatuated with Gorbachev,'' scolded a middle-aged man marching through Red Square on May Day as part of an unofficial column organized by groups demanding greater democracy.
The man was earnest and clean cut, a little embarrassed by the crowd around him that hooted and yelled at Mr. Gorbachev and the other Soviet leaders assembled atop Lenin's mausoleum. But he was sympathetic to their message.
''It seems to me that Gorbachev has brought us this far, but he is not the leader of the future,'' he said. ''It will not be long before he leaves the political stage.
''People like Popov are the wave of the future,'' he said of Gavriil K. Popov, the market economist named head of the Moscow City Council.
The striking thing was that the man was not a dissident or a Westernized intellectual, but a major in the Ministry of Internal Affairs.
Sergei A. Kovalyov, a close confidant of the late human rights campaigner Andrei D. Sakharov and now a member of the Russian republic's Parliament, contends that the Western reluctance to pressure Mr. Gorbachev on issues like Lithuania is shortsighted.
Without Western pressure, he said, the Soviet leader is freer to appease his hard-liners in the party and military, and in doing so he slips farther behind the public mood.
''Up to a certain point, Gorbachev's evolution inspired us to hope,'' Mr. Kovalyov said. ''But he always acts too late. And I don't know whether he's capable of really learning, or only of adapting.''
On issue after issue, Mr. Gorbachev has slipped behind the changes he once seemed to lead.
 
The Cry of 'Gorby! May Be a Lost Chant
 Just last fall, East German youths were chanting ''Gorby! Gorby!'' and hopeful democrats around the Eastern bloc saw him as their liberator and model. Now Mr. Gorbachev's Soviet Union lags behind its former allies in political and economic daring, and some citizens here are beginning to bemoan the loss of the European order they feel that they won in World War II.
At home, Mr. Gorbachev gave the country the closest thing it has had to free elections, but in assuming a new presidency this year he did not dare stand for election himself.
The result is that he governs without a mandate, and is fearful of using his new presidential powers to push through unpopular measures.
Critics say that he seems more remote from public opinion and that Mr. Gorbachev's hubris sometimes seems to blind him to simple political niceties.
This week, Moscow grocery shoppers snorted with indignation as their leader accepted a pay raise and appeared on television squiring Princess Anne through the Kremlin while his Government was announcing plans to triple bread prices.
''Before he listened,'' said a Soviet journalist. ''Now he only listens to himself.''
 
Out in the Cold On the Economy
 On the economy, Mr. Gorbachev experimented with half-measures for five years until the shortages, plummeting productivity, strikes and technological backwardness had discredited the very idea of a planned economy. But his experiments have squandered the good will necessary to sell the public a more sweeping and more painful transformation.
Mr. Gorbachev has so far kept his distance from the economic plan disclosed this week, letting his Prime Minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, take most of the heat.
The prevailing opinion in Moscow is that if the economic plan is put to a public referendum, as some senior officials promised this week, both the plan and Mr. Ryzhkov would be out in the cold.
''This Government will fall because it is unwilling to introduce a market,'' predicted Igor Gryazin, an Estonian deputy in the Soviet Parliament and a free-market advocate. ''The next government will fall because it will introduce a market. Then we''ll have the third government, and maybe things will start to be normal.''
Whether Mr. Gorbachev will ride out this period of falling prime ministers, Mr. Gryazin added, is of no great consequence, ''because he will in any case be powerless.''
To address the challenge of his assertive ethnic minorities, Mr. Gorbachev now promises to remake the Soviet Union into a loose federation, where each republic would govern itself while delegating matters like defense and communications to the center. Even a year ago, such a proposal might have been hailed as a stroke of genius.
But before he has even produced a draft of this new ''union treaty,'' he has already effectively lost several republics. The three Baltic states have declared they want no part of any union, and others have begun to flout Moscow's will on issues like the military draft.
 
Even a Struggle For Russia Itself
 This week Mr. Gorbachev was struggling for control over Russia itself, the republic containing more than half the Soviet population and three-fourths of its territory, as the Russian Parliament mulled plans to put the republic's laws above Soviet law.
Some scholars look beyond Mr. Gorbachev and foresee the disintegration of the soviet union.
Valery L. Makarov, director of a leading research center, the Central Economics and Mathematics Institute, said Moscow was so incapable of imposing uniform laws across its domain that the Soviet Union would ''inevitably'' dissolve.
''Every republic will introduce its own currency, its own banking system, its own monetary system,'' he said in an interview. ''some countries - that is, some republics - will move to a market economy more quickly, others more slowly.''
Public-opinion polls show the populace to be pessimistic, impatient and mistrustful of authority, especially the authority of the Communist Party.
One of the most potent new documentary films, ''This Is No Way to Live,'' raises the question of whether the Communist Party should be subjected to trial along the lines of Nuremberg.
After a recent preview at the cinematographer's union, the director Stanislav Govorukhin said he did not support a criminal trial because ''the moral trial of the party is already under way.''
The federal authorities resisted releasing Mr. Govorukhin's film, but this week the Moscow City Council overrode the central authorities to let it open. The director was wistful about the impotence of the censors.
''Authorities in this country have become so weak that they cannot even prohibit a movie.'' he said. ''But if authorities are unable to do something simple and bad, it implies they are also incapable of doing something simple and good.
''The institutional structure of authority in this country has weakened dramatically, and it makes me feel more sorrow than happiness.''
 
Who Gets Blamed? The Party, It Seems
 The polling data show that the Communist Party is blamed most of all for the country's crises, but that people are also losing faith in the newer institutions that Mr. Gorbachev has introduced to supplant the party, like the Parliament, and in Mr. Gorbachev himself.
''As far as the leader's personal prestige is concerned, it is impossible not to see that its peak has been left behind, in the time of the cloudless hopes of the 'original' perestroika,'' said Yuri Levada, a poll taker writing in Moscow News.
Those who call for Mr. Gorbachev to step down are a small minority, and those who see an available replacement are even fewer.
The critics' message to the West is not to abandon Mr. Gorbachev but not to let him off so easy.
''Well, all right, focus on Gorbachev,'' said Mr. Kovalyov. ''But then force him to make the right steps. And don't greet everything he does with cries of hurrah. I think the tendency in the West now is to justify every obvious blunder of Gorbachev's by his difficult circumstances, by the fact that he's not free, and to rouse enthusiasm over every little step he makes in the right direction. I think Sakharov was right in saying that the best help for Gorbachev is constructive criticism.''
 
 
 
THE PEOPLE'S PESSIMISM
 Opinion polling in the Soviet Union has been fragmentary over the last few years, but has been gaining in respectability, scope and methodological rigor. Here is a sampler of results of opinion polls of Soviet citizens, based on varying methods of interviewing and covering different parts of the Soviet Union.
May 1988: 73 percent of Muscovites with telephones say they strongly support perestroika, and 23 percent say they support it with reservations; 40 percent say their standard of living in the next five years will improve because of perestroika, and 18 percent say they think things will get worse. - Telephone pollMoscow residents conducted by the Institute for Sociological Research of the Soviet Academy of Sciences for The New York Times and CBS News.
June 1988: 73 percent of poll respondents say that ''instead of real perestroika, we are just having a lot of talk''; 3 percent say they feel there have been ''major achievements'' in the economy, while 35 percent say that ''practically nothing has been achieved'' on the economy. - Poll conducted by the Institute for Sociological Research of the Soviet Academy of Sciences. More than 11,000 people at 120 main industrial plants were interviewed.
March 1989: Tatyana Zaslavskaya, a top Soviet sociologist, says polls show that 80 percent of respondents said they believe that perestroika is proceeding slowly.
October 1989: 90 percent of poll respondents say they consider the nation's economic situation bad or critical, and a majority say Mr. Gorbachev's policies are at least as responsible as the mistakes of his predecessors; 52 percent say the country's economic situation has grown ''significantly worse'' in the last two or three years. - Poll conducted by the National Public Opinion Research Center, Moscow, in 16 large and small Soviet cities.
March 1990: In a poll, 41 percent of respondents in a poll said they favor rapid change, while 35 percent favor a slower pace; 19 percent said the Communist Party always acted in the people's interest, while 18 percent said it never did. Almost 50 percent said they were satisfied with their own lives. - Nationwide poll conducted by the National Public Opinion Research Center in Moscow; Emory University in Atlanta and the University of Pennsylvania.

HEADLINE: TOWARD THE SUMMIT;
RUSSIAN MAVERICK AGAIN FAILS TO WIN TOP REPUBLIC POST

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 26

 BODY:
Boris N. Yeltsin narrowly failed today in a second round of voting for the presidency of Russia, after a day of political passions and intrigues that left the fates of the outspoken candidate and the largest Soviet republic in doubt.
Mr. Yeltsin, whose campaign for Russian sovereignty is a direct challenge to the authority of the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, outpolled a Communist Party hard-liner in a runoff election in the Russian Parliament, but he fell 28 votes short of the majority required for victory.
He said he would try again when the Parliament reconvenes on Monday. If that ballot also proves inconclusive, he said he would invite rival factions in Parliament to begin negotiating a power-sharing arrangement for the Russian government. 
 
Truce With Gorbachev Urged
Some of Mr. Yeltsin's supporters predicted an outpouring of public support that might turn up the needed votes by the end of the weekend. But strategists from the Communist Party apparatus were expected to put forward a more moderate candidate next time, in hopes of stealing votes from Mr. Yeltsin.
''Too many people believe in me, and their confidence cannot be betrayed,'' Mr. Yeltsin told reporters, when asked if he would drop from the race.
''If the Parliament cannot decide, the decision must be made by the people,'' he said later, renewing his call for the presidency to be filled in a general election that he would be strongly favored to win.
Mr. Yeltsin called on Mr. Gorbachev to put aside their bitter rivalry and suggest a compromise on the future of the Russian republic.
 
A Humiliating Sendoff
''He can at least refrain from using the words he directed at me in this hall,'' Mr. Yeltsin said. ''He has lost face in the eyes of the country and the world.''
Mr. Gorbachev is scheduled to leave Moscow on Tuesday for Canada and then travel to the United States, and a Yeltsin victory would be a humiliating sendoff. The two men have been public rivals since the Soviet leader jettisoned Mr. Yeltsin from the Communist Party Politburo in 1988.
Mr. Gorbachev has thrown his personal prestige into the Russian contest, vilifying Mr. Yeltsin in a speech to the Parliament on Wednesday. Throughout the week, scores of Communist Party functionaries, allowed onto the Parliament floor as guests, worked as a whip system to line up votes against the popular renegade.
After an initial vote Friday night narrowed the race to two candidates, the corridors of the Great Kremlin Palace today were a noisy political bazaar.
 
Opponents Assail Yeltsin
Members of the Democratic Russia bloc, supporting Mr. Yeltsin, lobbied frantically to win support of deputies from the military and K.G.B., with little success.
''Yeltsin's program is a program for the disintegration of the union,'' said a three-star general, who declined to give his name after a corridor debate with a Democratic Russia whip. Mr. Yeltsin has argued for Russia's virtually total political and economic independence from central control.
The division of power between the Soviet Government and its republics is now one of the most explosive issues facing Mr. Gorbachev. The Russian government, traditionally a docile body that essentially echoed and carried out policies made at the federal level, has now joined many other republics in asserting its right to govern independently.
An opposing faction of orthodox Marxists, called Communist Russia, produced the Russian nationalist writer Vasily Belov to argue that Mr. Yeltsin's market-oriented economic program would mean the sellout of Russia's natural resources to multinational corporations.
This afternoon, copies of an anonymous flyer appeared in the hallways questioning Mr. Yeltsin's patriotism and credibility. #28 Votes Short of Victory One factor that opponents used against Mr. Yeltsin and the Democratic Russia bloc was the Moscow City Council's decision on Friday to restrict food sales in Moscow shops to city residents.
The action by the City Council, now governed by a Democratic Russia majority, was intended to contain panic buying brought on by the Government's announcement of forthcoming food price increases. Hard-liners contended that that shopping policy showed that liberals like Mr. Yeltsin are indifferent to the provincial population, which flocks to Moscow's stores.
In the secret ballot, Mr. Yeltsin won 503 votes, to 458 for Ivan K. Polozkov, the hard-line party chief from the southern Russian region of Krasnodar. Victory requires 531 votes, a majority of the 1,060 members of the Parliament. Another 71 deputies voted against both candidates.
Mr. Yeltsin and others predicted that on Monday the party would advance a more centrist candidate, probably Yuri A. Manayenkov, a low-profile secretary of the Soviet Communist party.
''If nothing emerges from the next round, then the five largest groups of deputies should confer on how to share the ministerial portfolios'' in a coalition government, Mr. Yeltsin told reporters.
Mr. Yeltsin said he would not compromise on the issue of Russian sovereignty, which in his program includes a separate and convertible Russian currency, an independent Russian K.G.B., and complete control over the republic's oil, timber and other natural riches.
