HEADLINE: THE NEW YORK TIMES/CBS NEWS POLL;
Grudging Public Thinks Tax Rise Now Must Come

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

 BODY:
Americans overwhelmingly expect their Federal taxes to go up to reduce the budget deficit, and they are grudgingly willing to accept some new taxes if the taxes are the right ones, the New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.
The latest poll, conducted last week as President Bush and Congressional leaders embarked on their budget negotiations, found the public much more resistant to cuts in spending for Social Security, the environment or education than to various tax increases.
The survey also included unsettling news for Republican Party strategists, supporting their fears that President Bush, in saying that there are no preconditions for budget talks, may be weakening the party's image as the bulwark against taxes.
 
Neither Party Has Advantage
After at least a decade in which the public viewed Republicans as much stronger than the Democrats in opposing taxes, neither party gained a clear advantage in the latest survey when Americans were asked which party was more likely to raise taxes. About 38 percent said Republicans were, and 42 percent picked the Democrats, a statistically insignificant difference because each figure could vary in either direction by as much as three percentage points. 
Fear that they are losing one of their best issues has drawn cries from many prominent Republicans. That frustration was voiced last week by Jack F. Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, who broke with the White House and declared that even if nobody else in the Administration will argue against higher taxes, ''I will.''
Sixty-eight percent of Americans say they expect President Bush to ask Congress to increase taxes, the survey found.
The survey findings underlined the political problem facing the budget negotiators, who find that the total of spending cuts and tax increases that are both acceptable to the public and achievable in the budget still leaves them short of the $50 billion they need to avoid breaching the deficit ceiling set by law for next year's budget.
 
Taxes on Alcohol and the Rich
If higher taxes are needed, about 8 of 10 people say they would accept increased levies on beer and liquor and on upper-income taxpayers, the poll found in a telephone survey of 1,140 adults conducted nationwide Tuesday through Thursday. But in equally large numbers they say that if spending cuts are needed it is unacceptable to delay Social Security increases or to reduce the sums for education or the environment.
Americans, by 2 to 1, accept cuts in military spending. They still oppose an increase in the Federal gasoline tax, but not as strongly as they did in other polls earlier this year.
Across-the-board cuts in spending, which is what will take effect if the budget negotiators fail to reach an agreement that meets the goals set by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law, were described as acceptable by 41 percent of those polled, while 51 percent said they were unacceptable.
Public concern about the deficit is on the increase, the poll suggests. It found that 76 percent of Americans now regard it as a very serious problem calling for immediate action, while 16 percent say it is serious but does not need to be solved immediately.
Shortly after Mr. Bush's inauguration early last year, 29 percent of the public told a Washington Post/ABC News poll, in response to a slightly differrent question, that the deficit was a very serious problem, while 56 percent said it might become a serious problem in years to come.
Some of the increased concern is no doubt in reaction to increased attention to the budget by President Bush, and thus an increase in news reports, in recent weeks. But the rising concern also coincides with a broader increase of pessimism about the economy and the general direction of the country, trends noted in other recent polling.
 
Skepticism About Progress
In the face of such concerns, Americans are deeply skeptical that anything is being done. Only 29 percent say the White House and Congressional budget negotiators are making a serious effort, the poll found, while 54 percent say they are not.
President Bush has declined to say whether his staunch campaign opposition to tax increases is still in effect, and other Republicans have sought to stress that it is really the Democrats who want to raise taxes.
But the public's reluctance to give an advantage to either party, as measured in the new poll, is a sharp departure from the attitudes early in Ronald Reagan's Presidential years.
In a 1981 survey, for example, 42 percent of Americans said Republicans would do a better job holding down taxes while only 15 percent said that of the Democrats. That poll was conducted by the Opinion Research Corporation in November 1981.
In the latest Times/CBS News Poll, Republicans still hold an advantage on taxes in the views of political independents, the crucial swing voters who often decide elections. But in a note that Republicans may perceive as ominous, the youngest voters, by 50 to 36 percent, say the Republicans are more likely to raise taxes. These 18-to-29-year-olds are also the group that most strongly opposes new taxes.
 
Generation Gap, Yet Again
The poll found several sharp cleavages between the generations on questions of taxes and spending.
Senior citizens are more willing than other groups to cut spending on the environment and education, and they support tax increases more than any other group. Young people are just as firm as senior citizens in opposing delays in Social Security increases, but they are far more strongly opposed to tax increases.
Americans over 65 are more likely than the population as a whole to identify themselves as Democrats, and Americans between 18 and 29 are more likely to say they are Republicans. Yet it is older people, by 47 percent to 23 percent, who say that Democrats are more likely to raise taxes, while younger people say Republicasn are more likely.
In a variety of ways, Americans seem resigned to tax increases.
Four in 10 say they do not believe President Bush ever meant his campaign pledge of ''no new taxes,'' and another 23 percent said he meant it only to apply for a year or two. Another 29 percent say he meant no new taxes of any kind.
About 7 in 10 Americans say they think Mr. Bush will ask Congress to increase taxes. The percentage who think he should do that has risen somewhat, from 31 percent immediately after the 1988 Presidential election to 38 percent in the latest survey.
 
Views That Contradict
Americans' attitudes toward higher taxes remain deeply ambivalent. For example, 55 percent of the people say they believe tax increases will be necessary to substantially reduce the deficit. Yet 57 percent, responding to a different question, say they think President Bush should not ask Congress to increase taxes.
Earlier Times/CBS News polls and other analysts of public opinion have found that at least part of the explanation for such contradictory views is that Americans believe substantial sums are wasted in Washington and they do not trust the Government to spend new taxe revenue properly.
These are precisely the political complications that the White House and the Congressional Democrats are trying to navigate in their budget negotiations, largely an exercise aimed at insuring that neither side is saddled with too much blame for whatever painful solutions emerge.
The political problem becomes clearer when the actions Americans would support are considered in light of the $50 billion in reduced spending or increased revenue, or both, that budget experts say is needed. For example, 8 in 10 people say they approve of cuts in foreign aid, but even if the foriegn aid budget were wiped out, it would save only $16 billion or so. In any case, President Bush is asking for an increase in foreign aid for the next budget year, which begins Oct. 1, so the United States can support the emerging democracies of Central America and Eastern Europe.
 
Acceptable Tax, Limited Effect
One proposal discussed often in Washington is an increase in the Federal excise tax on beer, wine and liquor to 25 cents an ounce of alcohol. While the the poll finds that this would be accepted by the public, it would produce only about $7 billion a year in revenue. An increase in the cigarette tax to 32 cents a package would raise another $2.8 billion.
While there is deep division among Republican officials about raising taxes, among the public there are no clear partisan differences on whether President Bush should seek a tax increase.
Republicans are the most opposed to the idea, with 61 percent saying he should not. But that is not statistically distinguishable from the 58 percent of Democrats who say he should not.
Democrats and independents are far more likely than Republicans to dismiss the current budget negotiations as not a serious effort to curtail the deficit.
 
 
 
HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
The New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from May 22 to May 24 with 1,140 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The telephone exchanges called were selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. The telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus including both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened to limit calls to residential telephones.
To reach a larger number of black respondents and make possible more reliable analysis of blacks' opinions, another sample of numbers was drawn from a survey conducted last month by The Times. Telephone numbers of black respondents from the earlier poll were called again, yielding 51 additional black people, for a total of 151. The results were then weighted to reflect the actual racial composition of the adult population. The results have also been weighted to take account of household size and number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by questioning all American adults.
The percentages reported are the particular results most likely to match what would be obtained by seeking out all adults. Other possible percentages are progressively less likely the more they differ from the reported results.
The potential sampling error for subgroups is larger. For example, for blacks it is plus or minus eight percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

LENGTH: 3153 words

HEADLINE: BIG SCIENCE: IS IT WORTH THE PRICE?
A periodic look at the largest new research projects.;
Heavy Costs of Major Projects Pose a Threat to Basic Science

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
The Federal Government has embarked on the most ambitious array of big science projects ever, with some experts saying they herald a new age of discovery while others are warning that their great cost could cripple vital parts of the nation's scientific effort and eventually the American economy.
The scale of American science has never been greater. Examples are the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope now orbiting high above the Earth, the $3 billion project to map the human genetic structure, the $8 billion Superconducting Supercollider planned for the plains of Texas and the $30 billion space station Freedom taking shape on computer design consoles. $100 Billion Operating Costs All told, new projects now planned for completion in the 1990's will cost more than $60 billion to build. And that is just the start. More than $100 billion will be needed to operate the instruments over their lifetimes, placing a heavy mortgage on the nation's research spending well into the future.
Virtually all the projects have worthy objectives, or at least a plausible rationale. Some, like the supercollider, may be close to indispensable if certain scientific gains are to be made in the search for elementary particles and forces. Backers of the projects generally see them as the key to the nation's future success in pushing back the frontiers of science. 
''Bigness is an inevitable component of the evolution of science and we must learn to live with it,'' said Dr. Leon M. Lederman, a Nobel laureate in physics at the University of Chicago and a former director of Fermi National Laboratory, which runs the nation's largest particle accelerator so far.
 
Critics Cite Big Drain
But critics say big projects drain funds from small-scale research vital to the creation of new products and jobs and often to the advance of science itself.
''Big science has gone berserk,'' said Dr. Rustum Roy, professor of materials science at Pennsylvania State University, who is an adviser to the House Committee on Science. ''Good minds and a lot of money are going into areas that are not relevant to American competitiveness, American technological health, or even the balanced development of American science.''
Dr. George F. Chapline, a physicist at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California, said the trend bodes ill for the nation. ''It is very questionable whether these projects will contribute much to stopping America's industrial decline, and may even exacerbate it,'' he said.
Moreover, the big instruments can take so long to plan and build, sometimes a decade or more, that they are sometimes seen as obsolete when switched on because science now moves so fast. Perhaps most troubling, this same lag is seen as causing bright graduate students to abandon some fields now dominated by giant instruments as they search for timely projects on which to base their Ph.D. research.
 
Science Being Altered
Most experts agree that the big projects are fundamentally altering the nature of American science and that the situation is serious because of the nation's fiscal troubles.
''We have a crisis developing,'' said Representative George E. Brown Jr., a California Democrat who has served on the House science committee for nearly a quarter century. ''We're freezing out a lot of our good work because of the commitment to big science.''
Even Administration officials concede that some big projects may eventually have to be delayed, canceled or undertaken with foreign partners to defray expenses.
''The country needs the supercollider and the space station,'' said Erich Bloch, director of the National Science Foundation, the Government's main agency for the support of general science. ''But somewhere you have to make a decision about priorities when you find you can't do all of them simultaneously.''
 
Real Spending Is Steady
Adjusted for inflation, overall Federal spending for research and development in science and technology, including the military's, is little greater than at the height of the Apollo moon program. In 1967 the Government spent $46 billion, according to the National Science Foundation. For 1990 the figure is $48.2 billion.
But while money has remained roughly constant, the number and size of big projects has grown substantially, taking a growing share of the Federal science budget and enveloping dozens of areas of astronomy, physics, chemistry, molecular biology and space science.
A revealing catalogue of big scientific instruments has been complied by the Congressional Research Service of the Library of Congress. It lists all instruments costing more than $25 million. An analysis of that inventory shows the nation built nine projects in the 1950's for physics, astronomy, materials science and space science. The number rose to 34 in the 1980's. Moreover, the cost of the projects soared, even after discounting for inflation. The 1950's bill came to $260 million. The 1980's bill was $6.7 billion.
 
The History
 
Easy Discoveries Have Been Made
 Behind the push for big instruments is a fact scientists seldom mention. Most of the discoveries that can be made with simple instruments and little labor have already been achieved, so in many cases the scientific tools have to be large and powerful.
''It's unfortunate but inevitable in all fields,'' said Dr. Richard A. Isaacson, a science foundation program manager. ''After you do the easy things, it gets harder and harder. Eventually the next step is very difficult and requires a lot of money and large facilities.''
Dr. Isaacson said that it was important ''to keep a balance'' and make sure that small science projects at universities are adequately financed. ''But it's painful, he said. ''Maybe at some point science will come to an end because we can't afford the big facilities.''
Experts have no formal definition of ''big science,'' but for the purposes of this article it is seen as any civilian research project whose construction costs are $100 million or more. This definition excludes military endeavors like the Strategic Defense Initiative, or Star Wars, on which more than $20 billion has been spent so far, and high-technology development programs like the proposed $5 billion aerospace plane that would fly off a runway into earth orbit. Such programs can have much the same impact in siphoning off money and technical talent from other worthy projects, but they are not usually considered scientific in nature.
 
Others Wait in the Wings
Beyond the big science projects already under way, others are waiting in the wings for Federal approval. These include the Compact Ignition Tokamak, a $480 million device for controlled nuclear fusion; the Advanced Neutron Source, a $500 million reactor for studying materials; and the Space Infrared Telescope Facility, an $800 million orbiting observatory for studying stars.
Compounding the strain on the Federal budget is the fact that project costs often rise from the original estimates, sometimes precipitously. The space station was originally sold to Ronald Reagan's Administration and to Congress on the basis of an estimated cost of $8 billion, but its projected price is now more than $30 billion. Experts say part of the problem is that project officials deliberately underestimate expenses while seeking Federal approval.
''There's willful self-delusion on the part of all the participants.'' said Frederick N. Khedouri, a budget official in the Reagan White House who oversaw most of the nation's big-science projects. ''They know the estimates are understated.''
In dealing with inevitable costs rises, Mr. Khedouri said, managers at Federal agencies often ''sacrifice less visible but probably more important programs.'' The overall effect, he said, ''is a system in which bad science tends to drive out the good.''
 
The Problems
 
Big Projects And Big Politics
 Nowhere is the ascendancy of big science more evident than in the field of particle physics. The $8 billion supercollider is to be a behemoth some 54 miles in circumference, the biggest instrument in the history of science. Housed in a tunnel 150 feet beneath the rolling prairie of northeast Texas, the colossus is to boost proton beams to nearly the speed of light and smash them together, yielding debris expected to provide clues to the building blocks of nature.
Scheduled to be switched on in 1999, the machine will cost $313 million a year just to operate. Over its 30-year lifetime, operations will run to an estimated $9.4 billion, with inflation taken into account.
While many experts say the supercollider is on the forefront of science, some big projects are not viewed so kindly. Pork barrel politics, with the promise of lucrative contracts and jobs, are sometimes seen as a driving factor in their genisis. Another factor is the sheer expansionism on the part of Federal agencies.
 
Assessment Depends on Size
''The rigor with which new projects are assessed varies inversely with their size,'' said Dr. Lewis M. Branscomb, a physicist who held top science posts in the Federal Government and is now director of the Science, Technology and Public Policy Program at Harvard University.
For instances, requests for small Federal science grants have to pass a gantlet of review committees and Government examinations. In contrast, some huge projects, like Star Wars, have their origins largely in high-level politics.
At the same time, smaller projects can sometimes produce better science than the big ones, critics say. As an example they point to the space agency's $17 billion Earth Observing System, a group of six huge satellites now under development to monitor changes in the earth's environment at the turn of the century. Some critics say its size has been largely dictated by political forces and that a series of smaller craft would cost less, operate sooner and have greater flexibility to pursue fast-changing scientific questions.
 
Small Can Mean Quick
''In a timely way they would give the global warming information everybody is eager for,'' said Dr. Robert Jastrow, a space scientist at Dartmouth College. Moreover, he said, a quick return of data would help universities rebuild populations of bright young graduate students who are leaving for lack of challenging projects.
''You can't plan a graduate career on a 10-year wait,'' Dr. Jastrow said. ''The field will dry up on the present timetable.''
Dr. Freeman Dyson, a physicist at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, said in his book, ''Infinite in All Directions,'' that some of the big projects take so long to build that they are virtually obsolete when completed.
''The cutting edge of science moves rapidly,'' he said. ''The bigger and more ambitious the missions become, the more difficult it is to reconcile the time scale of the missions with the time scale of science.''
 
The Results
 
Mad Scramble For a Few Dollars
 As big projects have bloomed, small ones have withered. Critics fear that some of the most fertile areas of science are now falling into neglect. ''Significant advances in science typically result from small projects - not large ones,'' said Dr. Chapline of the Livermore laboratory. For instance, A.T.&T. Bell Labs, with a relatively small budget for physics, has produced seven Nobel laureates in that field.
An oft-cited example of small-science productivity comes from the field of superconducting materials that work at high temperatures and promise to revolutionize electric devices. A key breakthrough was made in 1987 by Dr. Paul Chu, a University of Houston physicist. That year his laboratory ran on $130,000, about half from the science foundation.
Despite its allure, and a sizable amount of subsequent Federal financing, the endeavor has recently been eroded by budget pressure. ''Every worker in the field of the basic science of superconductivity in this country is experiencing repeated and severe funding cuts,'' Dr. Philip W. Anderson, a Nobel laureate at Princeton University, told Congress in March.
 
Squeeze Is Surprising
The squeeze is somewhat surprising since the science foundation, a main Federal patron of small science, has received substantial budget increases in recent years. This fiscal year it is spending $2.08 billion, up from $1.72 billion in 1988. But much of the increase has gone to science education and the establishment of large centers for science and engineering. And now the foundation has embarked on a spate of relatively large-scale science projects as well, including the $110 million High Magnetic Field Laboratory and the $190 million Gravitational Wave Observatory.
The science foundation's budgets for small ventures in mathematics, physics, chemistry, engineering, biology and computer science have generally fallen, after inflation is taken into account, below their 1988 levels, according to John C. Crowley and Patrica Ann Levy, analysts at the Association of American Universities in Washington. ''They are weakening steadily,'' the analysts concluded in a recent paper, noting that two thirds of science foundation's competitive research programs were in budgetary decline.
 
Trials of Individual Researchers
''As projects grow larger, the politics of science change drastically in favor of sustaining the larger commitments,'' Mr. Crowley said in an interview. ''Over time, the individual investigator is being squeezed, both in terms of the real value of the average grant and in terms of the numbers of awards.''
Of particular concern to some experts is the science foundation's physics budget, which supports small-scale research critical to the nation's industrial health but, after inflation is taken into account, has been decling for half a decade.
''Things are out of whack,'' said Dr. Neil W. Ashcroft, a professor of physics at Cornell University. ''Condensed-matter physics is at the heart of modern technology, of computer chips, of all the electronic gadgets behind the new industrial order. Yet relative to the big projects, it's neglected.''
 
The Proposals
 
Strict Goals And More Money
 Remedies to the big-project drain on Federal science funds have been offered with increasing frequency in recent years. They include delays, cancellations, the imposition of cost ceilings and the sharing of expenses with international partners. A radical approach calls for doubling the Federal research budget so all science could be better financed.
In an attempt to stop the upward creep of project costs, Congress last year limited to $1.6 billion two new NASA spacecraft, the Cassini Saturn Probe and the Comet Rendezvous and Asteroid Flyby, with the proviso that one be scrapped if there was a cost overrun. More recently, the House voted to put a $5 billion ceiling on the supercollider, with the remaining $3 billion to come from Texas and foreign partners.
Another tactic, much discussed but seldom used, is to delay projects. The idea was broached most notably in April 1988 by Dr. Frank Press, president of the National Academy of Sciences, the prestigious honorary group for scientists. In a speech, he suggested that the pace of big projects might be slowed to permit the financing of less visible but important endeavors.
 
Priority for AIDS Research
He personally gave his highest priority to grants for individual researchers, to crises such as the AIDS epidemic and to science breakthroughs like high-temperature superconductors. Of secondary importance, he said, were large projects like the supercollider and the human genome.
In an interview, Dr. Press reiterated his support for this approach given ''the current budgetary crisis.'' But over the coming decade, he said, the only real solution would be to double the Federal money spent on science.
''With Reagan we doubled the defense budget without a hiccup,'' Dr. Press said. ''If you look at the competition around the world, science and technology is our sole advantage. Because of the relatively low cost, it's a very good investment.''
Mr. Bloch, the science foundation's director, expressed skepticism over whether so much money would materialize. ''I don't think it's realistic,'' he said, adding that it was more important to make sure existing funds were ''spent wisely'' by instituting priorities and rearranging the budget.
He urged that small-scale research be protected. ''We should not sacrifice the science base in in order to do these projects,'' Mr. Bloch said.
 
Bush Backs Big Projects
The Bush Administration has largely ignored proposals to delay big projects, forging ahead with a number of old and new endeavors. Some of these have yet to be approved by Congress, which might yet reject them. They include the $400 million Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider, $190 million Gravitational Wave Observatory and $140 million Eight-Meter Optical Telescopes.
The Administration is seeking increased funds as the main way of achieving its goals for both big and little science. For the next fiscal year, it has requested a 12 percent rise in Federal funds for civilian research and development, from $23.8 billion to $26.7 billion.
In an interview, Dr. D. Allan Bromley, science adviser to President Bush, praised the large facilities as essential ''tools young people will need in 5 or 10 years.'' But he also conceded the Administration had so far failed to support small science to the extent it wished.
''We're not satisfied,'' he said, adding that in the next budget cycle the Administration would start a special initiative ''to make sure individual investigator projects are not squeezed out.''
 
Foreign Partners Sought
In addition to making new money available, the Administration wants to internationalize some of the nation's big science. It has three foreign partners for the space station and is seeking ones for the supercollider and some other projects.
President Bush told the National Academy of Sciences last month that his Administration was ''exploring new ways to encourage international cooperation on big science,'' adding that the huge machines were of ''unprecedented scope and importance.'' He also pledged to double the sceince foundation's budget by 1993.
Absent a dramatic rise in the financing of small-scale scientiic research or a sudden reversal in the Administration's plans for big projects, many scientists foresee a serious decline in the health of American science, with eventual damage to the nation's economy.
''We've got to make some serious decisions,'' said Dr. Stephen M. Younger, a physicist at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico. ''I'm a fan of the supercollider. I think we should build the space station, too. But unfortunately, there are people sleeping in the streets and the Japanese are running circles around us on projects like high-temperature superconductors. That's going to kill us.''

HEADLINE: New York and 3 New England States Sign Pact on Saving Forests

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
In an unusual example of regional cooperation, the governors of New York and three New England states have agreed to increase land purchases and adopt tax incentives to preserve their sprawling northern forests and to support forest-related industry.
The accord, announced last week, reflects the growing anxiety in the Northeast over increasing development in the 26 million acres of nearly contiguous northern forests in New York, Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine.
That the states were able to overcome their usual doubts about interstate cooperation suggests how great their concern is, conservationists and government officials said.
 
Seeking Federal Grants
The four-state consensus was reached by the Governors' Task Force on Northern Lands, formed two years ago to study changes in the woodlands. In a report, the 12-member group recommended the creation of a Northern Forest Lands Council to carry on the study of the region and to promote land conservation. 
The task force called for Federal grants of $25 million a year for four years for full or partial purchase of threatened lands. To encourage landowners to sell to conservation groups instead of developers, the group recommended that the owners be excused from paying income taxes on the money they make from those sales. The group also proposed giving state tax credits to those who donate land to conservation groups.
''The old, comfortable protection techniques of the past are not enough to insure forest conservation,'' Thomas C. Jorling, New York's Environmental Conservation Commissioner, said in a statement accompanying the release of the report. ''We must look for innovative new approaches to deal with the growing pressures on forest lands.''
A coalition of 17 conservation groups praised the task force's proposals, describing them in a statement as ''a significant positive step toward taking substantive action to protect these vital lands.'' The conservationists also support a longer-term protection strategy using coordinated land-use planning and a bigger Federal role.
The report coincided with one released by the United States Forest Service, which examined ownership and land use in the region. It offered 28 tax and acquisition strategies for use by Congress or the states to conserve environmental, recreational and economic interests in the forest.
 
Uproar Over Land Sale
Congress authorized the report, the Northern Forest Lands Study, in 1988 after a big industrial landowner, Diamond Occidental Forest Inc., put up for sale one million acres of forest land in New York, Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine. The sale created an uproar, prompting fears that cherished lands would be sold to developers for the building of vacation homes. Some of those fears were realized.
''Changes in land ownership and use clearly threaten the long-term integrity and traditional uses of the land in parts of the study area,'' the Forest Service concluded.
''As a result,'' it said, ''open space, forestry, farming and recreational uses of 22 million acres of private land in the northern forest are gradually giving way to residential and recreational development.''
Similar conclusions were reached in a recently released study by the Governor's Commission on the Adirondacks in the 21st Century. The commission, appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, recommended some of the approaches offered by the Forest Services and the governors' task force.
But the New York commission went further than the other groups in proposing proportionately more land acquisition and greater state regulation, including a one-year building moratorium on 90 percent of Adirondack Park's privately held lands.
Indeed, the four-state Governors' Task Force had trouble agreeing on some issues and solutions. In part, the differences reflected the New England states' longtime skepticism of government land ownership and regulation. New York has been more willing to use these conservation approaches.

HEADLINE: Auto Dealer's 'Christian Plan' Is Called Bias

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FAIRFAX, Va., May 26

 BODY:
One night last August the letters C, M, B and P popped into Freddy (Action) Jackson's head. Business at his car dealership has never been the same since.
''I started with the C,'' said Mr. Jackson, whose dealership, Brown Lincoln-Mercury, is the subject of a dispute between a national Christian organization and civil rights and Jewish groups, ''I wrote everything down that began with C that had to do with Christ or Christian. I did the same thing with the letter M. I stayed up all night trying to figure out what those letters meant.'' 
The next morning, he said, he had it: ''Christian Members Buying Plan.'' Christians would buy cars at bargain prices and a percentage of his profit would go to their church.
The American Civil Liberties Union and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith say Brown Lincoln-Mercury discriminates against non-Christians.
A lawyer for the A.C.L.U., Victor Glasberg, told the Federal Trade Commission this month that the policy violated equal-opportunity credit laws. A spokesman declined to say whether the commission was investigating.
A spokesman for Mary Sue Terry, Virginia's Attorney General, said the plan apparently did not violate state or local law.
Mr. Glasberg said that unless Mr. Jackson makes the same sale terms available to all, the A.C.L.U. will sue.
 
Repugnant, A.D.L. Aide Says
''Freddy Jackson figures this is a good way to mix two of the important things in his life: business and religion,'' said David Friedman, Virginia director of the Anti-Defamation League, which is considering a suit. ''He doesn't see that the very idea of doing business with people on the basis of their religion is repugnant.''
A countersuit is threatened by the Christian Coalition, a national organization whose director, Ralph Reed, calls the attitude of the two other groups equally repugnant.
''We are sick and tired of Christians and Christian values being expunged from every area of public life,'' he said. ''This isn't separation of church and state; this is a private merchant.''
Under Mr. Jackson's plan, a Christian who fills out a certificate naming his his church and his pastor gets a set price of $600 over cost on Lincolns and $250 over cost on Mercurys. Pastors get a similar discount.
Depending on the car, 10 percent or more of the amount over cost then goes to the church of the buyer's choice. At the end of the year, the church with the most purchases gets a $2,000 bonus.
Despite its charitable aspect, Mr. Friedman said, the plan is flawed. ''Just the very nature of having people declare their religion to get a deal on a car is obnoxious,'' he said.
Three years ago, the Anti-Defamation League was involved in a similar dispute in Pensacola, Fla., where Jerry Harrison, an Exxon station owner, had put up a sign reading, ''For Christians Only: 10 percent discount on labor.''
 
'There's a Force Here'
The league complained to Exxon, and the company asked Mr. Harrison to take the sign down. An agreement was reached, and Mr. Harrison removed his original sign but replaced it with ''10% discount For Those Whom Jesus Loves.''
Mr. Jackson says he will not drop his Christian buying policy. ''There's a force here,'' he said. ''There's something more here than Freddy Jackson and something more than his managers. We're not trying to play church. We're just trying to do the right thing.'' A spokesman for the National Automobile Dealers Association, Mary Beth Robinson, suggested that economics might have been a greater motivation. Sales in the car industry have been sluggish, she said, and dealers have turned to promotion deals.
Mr. Jackson admits business has improved since he inaugurated the plan. ''We're in business to make a profit,'' he said. ''Your Senator and your Congressman, when they run for election, they go to a church or a Sunday school class because they want the votes of the people there. It's the same principle.''

HEADLINE: Chicago Studies Plan to Spur Industry Revival

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 26

 BODY:
Loft condominiums carved out of aging factory buildings have become hot commodities here, symbols of a growing urban battle between industry and developers of commercial and residential real estate.
At its heart, this battle over land is defined by the shifting economy in Chicago and other aging industrial cities where the booming service industry has largely replaced manufacturing, eliminating thousands of factory jobs.
In the next couple of months, the administration of Mayor Richard M. Daley is expected to announce a new land-use policy to protect a number of low-cost industrial areas in the city from the commercial development.
For manufacturers, competing with commercial developers is often a losing proposition as increased demand pushes land prices well above the $3 to $8 a square foot that most industrialists say is the most they are willing to pay. 
Commercial developers, willing to pay at least $40 a square foot, have bought vacant land and antiquated industrial buildings on the North Side, which has undergone sweeping gentrification in the last 15 years.
According to the brokerage firm Corporate Realty Advisors, which publishes a quarterly newsletter detailing market changes, prices for industrial property rose 77 percent on the city's North Side and 65 percent on the South Side from 1986 to 1989. As a result, shopping centers, shopping malls and housing developments have replaced factories, which have moved to the suburbs, where land costs less.
Like Chicago, other major cities are confronting the problem by restricting commercial development in industrial areas. Last year, Boston cleared the way for the creation of light-manufacturing districts in neighborhoods that want them. New York City has a zoning ordinance that provides financial penalties for commercial developers who convert manufacturing space into office space.
Chicago has hundreds of acres of vacant land, but industrialists say the affordable property is inaccessible to heavy vehicles, is in blighted and dangerous neighborhoods or has obsolete buildings that are costly to raze.
 
Strategy Is Explained
At the center of Chicago's industrial plan is an effort to convert industrial-zoned parcels into areas that could accommodate several industries with similar needs.
''One of the strategies is to make those undesirable areas attractive, looking like suburban sites,'' said Wim Wiebel, an associate professor in the School of Urban Planning and Policy at the University of Illinois in Chicago, who has worked with the city's economic development department.
Responding to charges by advocates for industrial growth that the city's zoning laws have been too easily changed by forces supporting commercial development, Joseph J. James, the city's Commissioner of Economic Development, said the city would try to provide zoning that was ''predictable, not whimsical.''
In a 10-point draft, Mr. James described a policy that could provide support for existing industry. It would, for instance, speed up the city permit process to ease construction costs for expanding companies, provide some improvements in industrial areas and strengthen the city's loan programs.
Mayor Daley has not yet said whether he supports Mr. James's proposal. The City Council would also have to act on it.
Acknowledging fears of real estate developers that the new policy could hinder development, Mr. James said it would make only limited use of a zoning ordinance approved by the City Council two and a half years ago allowing the city to designate areas where land-use changes are prohibited.
 
A Revival Is Perceived
So far, the measure has been applied to 115 acres along a strip of warehouses, factories and vacant land that abuts the affluent Near North Side.
The introduction of the industrial plan comes at a time when new technological businesses are reviving the industrial economy and competing heavily for affordable land.

HEADLINE: Bogota Chief Tells of Drug War's Toll

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, May 26

 BODY:
On the eve of the presidential election here, President Virgilio Barco Vargas said Colombia's cocaine traffickers had widened their goal and were determined to bring down the nation's democracy.
''Their goal now is to destroy our democratic system,'' President Barco said on Friday in an interview at the heavily guarded presidential palace.
In the last two weeks, 10 car bombings in three Colombian cities have killed 40 people and wounded about 320, chiefly passers-by. Mr. Barco said the bombers' intention apparently was to scare voters away from polling booths on Sunday.
 
'Intimidation Campaign'
''To have a 50 percent turnout - and I think it could be higher - is even more significant if you take into account the intimidation campaign in which the narco-terrorists are engaged,'' said the President, who is not a candidate in Sunday's election. 
Nine months after starting a war on the cocaine traffickers, Colombia's 68-year-old leader showed no sign of retreating.
Increasingly, the price of resistance comes closer to home.
On Monday, bodyguards for his grandchildren snuffed out the burning fuse of a bomb composed of 350 sticks of dynamite, which had been placed near gasoline storage tanks at the children's private school here.
''There would have been 500 dead children,'' the President said, leaning forward in anger from his chair during the interview. ''It just shows the perversity of these people.''
 
Visit to the United States
In a rare trip beyond the walls of his Spanish colonial palace, Mr. Barco is to travel next week to meet with President Bush in Washington on June 5. In the United States, Mr. Barco will also deliver the commencement address at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, his alma mater.
Mr. Barco plans to ask Mr. Bush to extend United States assistance by removing barriers and improving prices for coffee, bananas and flowers, Colombia's legitimate exports.
''We are still concerned that economic measures designed to assist this region have been slow in coming,'' he said. ''In fact, in trade and financial matters related to the drug war, there have been more words than results.''
This week, Colombian business leaders learned that they may have to buy ''war bonds'' to help finance the drug war, which currently engages 60 percent of the Colombian Army and 85 percent of its police forces. $1 Billion a Year ''It costs our economy at least $1 billion a year, a figure that is increasing some 20 percent every year,'' said Mr. Barco, an engineer and an economist.
Mr. Barco will also seek further American cooperation on blocking black-market arms sales and mercenary assistance to drug trafficking gangs. Earlier this month, the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested two Colombians in Miami who were believed to have been trying to buy 24 Stinger shoulder-held, ground-to-air rockets.
Colombia has also issued formal protests against illegal arms and mercenary training involving Israelis. This month, for the first time, Colombia imposed visa requirements on Israelis.
''We are tying to obtain extradition of those foreigners involved in illegal activities in Colombia,'' the President said. ''But without real international cooperation, we will never be able to stop completely the dirty trade in weapons and the mercenary activity.''
 
Extradition Angers Traffickers
In Colombia, the extradition of drug suspects to the United States is the issue that most angers the traffickers, who have little to fear from Colombia's intimidated judiciary. Although about 15 suspects are awaiting extradition, none have been sent to the United States for trial in the last two months.
''Extradition, as an instrument to battle drug traffickers, remains in force,'' the President said.
An American diplomat here speculated earlier this month that extraditions were suspended to avoid provoking the traffickers during the last two months of the presidential campaign.
''We will not negotiate with terrorists; no deal can be made with the killers of my people,'' the President said in a written answer to several questions.
Mr. Barco said contacts between members of his Government and representatives of the cocaine traffickers in January were limited to winning the release of kidnapping victims. He said the reduced level of violence that followed these meetings was ''an international public relations ploy'' to win good will during the meeting between President Bush and leaders of the Andean nations in February.
 
Search for Pablo Escobar
Mr. Barco, whose four-year term will end when a new President is inaugurated on Aug. 7, showed no sign of winding down the drug war in his final months and gave no indication that he would ease off the search for the cocaine cartel leader, Pablo Escobar. The leader of the Medellin cartel, Mr. Escobar is believed to have directed the wave of bombings that preceded the elections.
''Pablo Escobar is on the run, in this country, apparently never staying in the same place for more than one day,'' the President said. ''We are following him closely. Sooner or later, we will find him.''

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
As Soviet Union Grows Tense, U.S. Tourists Start to Shy Away

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
American tourists, who flocked to the Soviet Union in record numbers in 1988 and 1989, are thinking twice this year, travel companies and agents specializing in Soviet tours say.
Though Americans are still eager to witness the changes in Soviet society, tour operators say, they are wary of running into perestroika's unlovely offspring - crime and ethnic unrest. Jay Schaffner, president of Anniversary Tours Inc., estimates that about 100,000 American tourists will visit the Soviet Union this year, down from about 120,000 last year.
While tour operators say they have no sure way to measure the decline in the number of tours and the size of tour groups, they think that the travel advisory about street crime issued earlier this year by the State Department, the reports of tension in the independence-minded Baltic states and the violence in the Caucasus have helped depress the market. 
 
Neither Peak Nor Valley
''It's a political market,'' said Caroline Cavalli, president of the Russian Travel Bureau in New York. ''If somebody sneezes on either side, it affects it. For 20 years we've had totally peaks and valleys. This is not really a valley, but it's not a peak either.''
A continued increase in prices, which have nearly doubled over the last five years, has not helped, they say. ''What's happened with this whole perestroika business is that every Soviet company is trying to make more hard currency than ever before,'' said Sidney Reiner, president of Cosmos Travel.
The price increases have been steep, particularly from 1987 to 1989, when there was a 25 percent jump in Soviet-controlled costs, Mr. Schaffner said. And, Ms. Cavalli said delicately, ''there has to be a commensurate increase in service'' - a reference to the often-haphazard and sometimes churlish attention lavished on tourists in Soviet hotels and restaurants.
Mr. Schaffner said the State Department's advisory on crime had caused four high school groups and two student groups from Northern Illinois University to cancel their plans, although one of the university groups recently rebooked for October.
 
Perennial Frustrations
Paradoxically, the falloff in tourism has not shortened the visa lines at the Soviet consulate in Washington, where a three-hour line of business executives, scientists, professors and tourists recently stretched for two blocks.
The perennial frustrations of Soviet travel, from creaky bureaucracies to nonexistent restaurant service, have lessened somewhat over the last few years, but tour operators say Americans' curiosity and willingness to endure frustration may be eroding, particularly when there are new places to be curious about. Ms. Cavalli said the summit meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev may change that.
''Some of this is going to be cyclical, especially if there's something new out there,'' said Deborah Kolt, president of the Washington-based Academic Tours Abroad Inc. ''Berlin is swamped. You can't get a hotel bed in Berlin to save your life. People are going to Hungary and Czechoslovakia.''
A first class twin-bed room in a four-star hotel in Moscow costs about $143 a night, Intourist officials say. A 15-day group tour, which in the mid-1980's could sell for as little as $1,400, now is almost impossible to find under $2,200 - and often costs $2,800 or more.
 
Pressure on Exchanges
The same drive by Soviet organizations to insure their economic future by bringing in as much hard currency as possible is also putting pressure on the academic and cultural exchanges. Most exchanges are based on reciprocal visits, with Americans paying for the Soviets who come here and Soviet organizations hosting American students, writers, artists and musicians there.
But the Soviet airline Aeroflot and some Soviet hotels are insisting that all tickets and rooms for foreigners must be paid for in convertible currency, not the increasingly scorned ruble. Soviet hosts - educational institutions, the Soviet concert agency Goskontsert, the Academy of Science -are reluctant to part with convertible Western currencies, which are in short supply in most Soviet organizations and are often the only way of paying for sophisticated technical equipment.
''The ideas for exchanges are there, the interest is there, but it's increasingly hard to put these things together,'' said Molly Raymond, deputy coordinator of the President's United States-Soviet Exchange Initiative, a United States Information Agency office that handles exchange activities. ''I see a lot of frustration out there.''
In particular, she fears that the new scramble for dollars and the determination of Aeroflot to earn hard currency are raising new complications for the growing array of American-Soviet exchanges. Many are fledgling efforts involving small towns, high schools or community hospitals that may have large resevoirs of good will, but little understanding of the frustrations involved.
 
Aeroflot's Requirement
Aeroflot earlier this year announced the requirement that all foreigners' tickets be paid for in convertible Western currencies, regardless whether they were tourists, who have always paid hard currency, or the guests of Soviet organizations, who have not.
Aeroflot officials could not be reached for comment, despite several telephone calls. But the Soviet airline, like most other Soviet industries and service organizations, is part of the Government-mandated self-financing program, learning how to survive in an quasi-market economy.
''I can understand why they are doing it,'' said Vasily Istratov, a Senior Research Fellow from Moscow based at Middlebury College. ''They are trying to teach themselves how to manage in real business.''
''We have a growing power of individual institutions and a deteriorating power of the center,'' he said. ''The situation is imbalanced in the country as a whole. The thing you can be sure of is hard currency.''
Mr. Istratov works with 65 Soviet students who are studying at 25 schools around the country as part of the undergraduate exchange program of the Intercollegiate Consortium.
Charles Dillingham, president of the Entertainment Corporation U.S.A., said that Aeroflot brought up the issue of ticket prices in connection with the planned Soviet tour of the English National Opera Company later this month, but that Goskontsert, the Soviet sponsor of the tour, defused the problem.
Could the regulation limit future eudcational and cultural exchanges?
''No question.'' Mr. Dillingham said.

HEADLINE: TOWARD THE SUMMIT;
Less Luster for Traveling Gorbachev

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
The Soviet delegation to the Washington summit meeting is hawking a glossy magazine with a smiling couple on the cover and the legend ''The Gorbachevs: Mikhail and Raisa at Home and Abroad.''
Phones are ringing at network news bureaus with offers of analysis and commentary from Soviet officials. And the Washington bureau chief of CBS News is having nightmares in which President Gorbachev pops out of his limousine to visit Bloomingdale's. 
The curtain has gone up for a return engagement of the traveling glasnost and perestroika show. The Kremlin hopes to take Washington by storm with the sort of public-relations push it has refined in recent years to advertise Soviet policies when Mr. Gorbachev travels abroad. But there are some signs that the luster has dimmed a bit.
The Soviet delegation held the first of a series of pre-summit news conferences today. Five officials answered questions for an hour.
 
Impromptu Appearances Likely
A few years ago, the room would have been jammed. But there were only about three dozen people in attendence, most of them Soviet officials and journalists. And the mood was, well, sleepy. At one point, one of the panelists, Aleksandr Bovin, an Izvestia columnist, dozed off, his face dropping to his shirtfront.
It may have been because it was a rainy Memorial Day weekend. Or it may have been that the mere appearance of Soviet officials talking with apparent candor about domestic political problems has lost its edge as a news event. In any case, the Soviet delegation was undeterred.
Over the next week, Mr. Gorbachev will meet with American public figures at the Soviet Embassy. His new spokesman, Arkady A. Maslennikov, is to appear at the international press center beside Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman.
And there are likely to be impromptu appearances on the streets of Washington, Minneapolis or San Francisco by a head of state who demonstrated his showmanship in earlier visits with stops on a Washington street corner and in the middle of Broadway.
 
Sympathetic Look at Gorbachev
While Mr. Gorbachev meets with President Bush, top aides and prominent Soviet academicians and politicians will fan out across town, visiting American research centers, Government organizations and public institutions. They will appear on network news programs as commentators. They will hold news conferences with titles like ''Restructuring of Political System in U.S.S.R.''
Some of that is intended to get across a viewpoint on the summit meeting, an effort that the Americans will conduct just as vigorously. But it also is intended to give an American audience a sympathetic look at the Soviet leader and his political and economic problems.
Hence the magazine Soviet Life, with its cozy photograph of the Gorbachevs on the cover and pictures inside of the couple feeding a squirrel and snuggling with their grandchildren in a garden swing.
Although Mr. Gorbachev has to rely to some extent on surrogates, he likes to handle much of his public relations personally. But not too personally.
Last week, a Soviet official was ruminating about how Mr. Gorbachev might be able to ''talk to students'' when he visits Stanford University on June 4. He shook his head at the suggestion that the Soviet leader might invite 10 or 20 students to a private meeting.
No, he said, the Soviet President was thinking more of a speech. Perhaps at the university football stadium. It seats 80,000.

HEADLINE: TOWARD THE SUMMIT;
Gorbachev Rules Out Leading Role for NATO

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
The Soviet Union will never agree to allow the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to play the leading role in building a new European security order, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev says in an interview to be published by Time magazine on Sunday.
Mr. Gorbachev offered strong opposition to allowing a unified Germany to stay in NATO. He suggested that if the United States were unwilling to discuss the creation of a new European security institution, the Soviet Union would want to link the unification process ''as closely as possible'' to the negotiations on cutting conventional arms in Europe. 
On the eve of his second summit meeting with President Bush, Mr. Gorbachev was asked if he expected to have a major disagreement with Mr. Bush on Germany's continued membership in NATO. ''I wouldn't say I expect a major disagreement,'' he said. ''I'd state for a fact that there will be one.''
But Mr. Gorbachev spoke of great improvements in the relationship between the two superpowers, especially in nuclear arms control and cultural and scientific cooperation.
Mr. Gorbachev dwelt on the economic and political problems gripping the Soviet Union and his own political leadership as he met with reporters and editors from Time. He also provided written answers to questions submitted in advance by the magazine, which named him ''man of the decade'' last December.
Mr. Gorbachev said relations between the United States and Soviet Union had reached a critical juncture. ''The strength of our relationship is being tested and it will be tested again in the future,'' he said.
The Soviet leader repeated his proposal for the creation of a new, Europe-wide security system to replace both the Warsaw Pact and NATO.
''Regardless of what is being said about NATO now, for us it is a symbol of the past, a dangerous and confrontational past,'' he said. ''And we will never agree to assign it the leading role in building a new Europe. I want us to be understood correctly on this.''
Mr. Gorbachev said that as he took the steps to relax Soviet control over Eastern Europe he ''had an idea'' of the dramatic change that might result. But he said, ''When people speak to me about various models and timetables, as though all this had happened according to a train schedule, I can only smile.''
Speaking of his economic plans, Mr. Gorbachev said he thought ''market mechanisms and the infrastructure'' for a new economy could be put in place within one or two years. ''But then,'' he said, ''it will take a long time to develop a real market economy.''
When his questioners said there could be no radical reform of the Soviet economy without large amounts of inflation and unemployment, Mr. Gorbachev said, ''I think both things will happen.''

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Sarah Lawrence;
Debate Persists Over a Professor Accused of Bias

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
The late Joseph Campbell, the teacher and philosopher, continues to make his presence felt at Sarah Lawrence College, where he taught for 38 years. Mr. Campbell was known for his work on mythology.
Under pressure from a small group of students and alumni, concerned that Mr. Campbell had made anti-Semitic and racist remarks, Sarah Lawrence has canceled a videotape presentation honoring Mr. Campbell. The event, scheduled for next Saturday, was to have been part of an alumni fund-raising weekend.
The college's commitment to minorities had been an issue in a debate over a teaching chair named for Mr. Campbell, which some students argued should be reserved for minority scholars. Late last month, the college president, Dr. Alice S. Ilchman, responded to the demands by revising the conditions for the chair, setting it aside for people of ''diverse cultures,'' including African, Asian, Native American, Latin American and Middle Eastern. 
Students have taken the issue a step further, calling for more formal policies outlining the financing of teaching chairs and the conferring of honorary degrees. Mr. Campbell received an honorary degree in 1986, a year before he died at the age of 83.
 
'Questionable Merit'
''We should not confer high honors on someone of questionable merit,'' said Patrick Larvie, a student senator and senior.
Dr. Ilchman said in an interview last week that the controversy was over. The college, she said, has no way to prove the allegations against Mr. Campbell, and the administration knew little about the accusations of anti-Semitism and racism until the $1 million endowment for the Campbell chair was accepted two years ago.
''Joseph Campbell made an impact on the lives of many students who wanted to honor him with an endowment,'' Dr. Ilchman said. She said the accusations against him came from ''a few alumni and students.''
After the Public Broadcasting Service televised a series of interviews with Mr. Campbell in 1988, an alumna and a few faculty members, including two literature professors, Arnold Krupat and Daniel Kaiser, came forward to criticize Mr. Campbell as anti-Semitic and racist. Shortly afterward, Brendan Gill, in The New York Review of Books, questioned Mr. Campbell's philsophy of ''follow your bliss,'' and his use of anti-Semitic and racist remarks.
''Campbell's bigotry had another distressing aspect, which was seemingly ineradicable anti-Semitism,'' Mr. Gill wrote in September. ''By the time I came to know him, he had learned to conceal its gross manifestations. But there can be no doubt that it existed and that it tainted not only the man himself, but the quality of his scholarship.''
 
Graduate Recalls a Tirade
When Sarah Lawrence accepted the endowment from 60 friends and alumni, several students denounced the administration for holding a event honoring Mr. Campbell. The event showcased celebrities like the interviewer in the PBS programs, Bill Moyers; Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, and George Lucas, creator of ''Star Wars.''
When the video presentation of a the series, ''Celebration of Joseph Campbell,'' was announced, a Sarah Lawrence alumna and writer of children's books, Eve Feldman, of New York, was, she said, astonished to receive a flier about it.
In 1988, when the endowment was announced, Ms. Feldman said, she had recounted to the administration an anti-Jewish tirade Mr. Campbell delivered in a private conference session when she was a senior. She said she had been told that the teaching chair was already set up.
''He said that Jews were the cause of all that was bad with Western civilization,'' Ms. Feldman recalled, adding that faculty members had told her at the time that such remarks by Mr. Campbell were common knowledge. She dropped the course.
This semester, students petitioned the college to denounce Mr. Campbell's views.
 
Only Four Teaching Chairs
Dr. Ilchman questioned why there was concern, considering that Sarah Lawrence has few endowments and because few students and alumni have complained. Four teaching chairs and three honorary doctorates have been established since the college opened as a women's school in 1926, she said. It became coeducational in 1968.
Last March, 250 students conducted a sit-in demanding cultural diversity on campus, including the hiring of additional minority professors and recruiting students of diverse ethnic and economic backgrounds.
''Our concern was to increase students and faculty of color and diversify the curriculum,'' Megan Parke, a student senator and senior, said. ''But the Campbell controversy showed that they chose to capitalize on the money regardless of the students' views.''
Dr. Ilchman said the minority population had doubled since 1985, to 14 percent of the 950 students, of whom 5.8 percent are black, 4 percent Hispanic and 4.8 percent Asian. The 20 minority professors include 14 blacks, 4 Asians and 2 Hispanics.
Dr. Ilchman noted that the curriculum had changed to include Indian art history and Asian and black studies.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 10, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Campus Life pages on May 27 about Sarah Lawrence College referred incorrectly to selection standards for the Joseph Campbell professorial chair. Drawn in rotation from several disciplines, scholars appointed to the chair will be specialists in the peoples and cultures of Africa, Asia, Native America, Latin America or the Middle East. The chair is not limited to minority scholars.

HEADLINE: Lifestyle;
Sad Thursday for Magazine Crowd

BYLINE: By GEORGIA DULLEA

 BODY:
Thursday will be the last gathering of the Last Thursday of the Month Club at the Zig Zag Bar and Grill in Manhattan. For the past year or so young magazine editors, writers, art directors and photographers have been flocking to these industry parties where the conversation, like the configuration of the bar at the Zig Zag, has a way of veering off at crazy angles.
This is especially true after midnight when one of the owners, Allen Bernstein, breaks out the Old Weller bourbon. But now the 35-year-old Mr. Bernstein, a founder of the Last Thursday Club, is leaving the bar on West 23d Street to restore vintage Porsches at his shop in Chatham, N.J.
 
Core of Group Is From Esquire
While the monthly party draws names from the mastheads of magazines as diverse as Mirabella, Hot Rod, Spy and The New Republic, most of the organizers work or used to work at Esquire. When the talk turns to how the parties began the young editors laugh and break into broad parodies of young stockbrokers at play. Oh, they say, it's their ''intense, high-pressure jobs,'' their ''need to cut loose,'' and so on. 
Mention networking and the editors look horrified. ''Our parties are a little like those Jerry Rubin things,'' one picture editor acknowledged, ''but don't quote me because I can't stand the way it sounds. We're not Wall Street types, most of us who work in magazines.''
What they are is a generation of ''schmoozers,'' a term that crops up with some frequency at the Zig Zag.
''It's a bunch of magazine people schmoozing around in a low-keyed way,'' said Paul Schneider, a free-lance writer who showed up for a party on crutches once and in a cast another time.
Michael Hirschorn, associate editor at Esquire, said: ''It's encoded in our gene pool, this endless desire to schmooze with other journalists, to navel gaze. Our self-involvement is legendary.''
He was perched on a bar stool, drinking martinis with two of the other co-hosts at the parties, Temple Smith and Kathy McCarver. They and the bar owner are among the few constants at the Last Thursday parties, where the 100 or so faces in the crowd change just as the jobs change in the world of musical magazines. Most guests are in their 20's and 30's, they say, and single, but not necessarily looking for dates.
''No great romances come out of these parties,'' said Ms. Smith, a photo consultant, adding that great gossip does emerge, along with an occasional job offer, free-lance assignment or testy encounter. ''Nobody knows who'll show up, so you may see art directors on adjacent bar stools who've been battling each other for years. It's fun to watch.''
Most Last Thursdays have themes, if only to give Ken Kneitel, the graphic artist who designs the announcements, something to play with. The April party was a bring-your-own resume affair honoring three publications that recently disappeared from the newsstands - 7 Days, Model and Taxi.
There was the usual cash bar, but the invitations noted that food stamps would be accepted and unemployment checks cashed. Among the ''exciting door prizes'' listed were straitjackets, dart boards and Librium. Among the free appetizers was Hartz Mountain birdseed, which is made by a company owned by Leonard Stern, who published 7 Days.
''The party was on the same day we got our National Magazine Award, and everyone was struck by the irony,'' said Diane Cardwell, a former 7 Days staff member who is now features editor of Egg magazine.
 
More Than Paychecks Lost
In the magazine world losing a job may mean more than losing a paycheck. There was talk of this at the penultimate meeting of the Last Thursday of the Month Club. One editor's name was switched to the B list at a fashion show. Others were off the press lists for screenings and parties. Press agents they used to dodge would not return their phone calls. They were out of the gossip hub.
The Last Thursday Club provides ''sort of an outreach and counseling service in their time of trouble,'' Mr. Hirschorn said, adding that the house has been quick to buy drinks on such occasions.
When not schmoozing, young magazine people sometimes indulge in freeloading. ''It's an art form with master practitioners,'' Mr. Hirschorn said. ''But most of us are neophytes.''
As for the last Last Thursday of the Month Club (at least at the Zig Zag), Mr. Bernstein predicted that it would be ''a classic, a real Irish wake.''

LENGTH: 922 words

HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
Appreciating the Choreographer's Palette

BYLINE: By JACK ANDERSON

 BODY:
The inventive choreographer often makes much out of only a few steps.
To illustrate: Peter Martins sent 23 dancers hurtling through space in ''Fearful Symmetries,'' his exciting new work that received its premiere by the New York City Ballet earlier this month. In contrast, Claire Porter scarcely moved at all in ''Fitness Digest,'' the comic modern-dance solo she offered last month; instead, she pretended to watch other, invisible people move. Despite the radically different scales of their creations, both Mr. Martins and Ms. Porter were choreographically accomplishing the same thing. 
Let a third choreographer amplify - and brilliantly exemplify - what they were up to. Several years ago, Paul Taylor remarked in an interview that ''the limitations you set up for yourself are a very important part of choreography,'' adding that it is necessary to know ''how to limit your movement palette. And if you know how to limit your palette for a section, or even for the entirety, of a piece, you'll be able to relate movements, and you can make a whole dance out of a minimum of material.''
His words are worth heeding at a time when, perhaps because young dancers today receive such fine technical training, many choreographers cram works with steps that, though physically demanding and visually astonishing, are ultimately ineffectual because they seem unrelated to one another. Mr. Taylor is a master at limiting and controlling his palette. That was especially evident this spring during the Paul Taylor Dance Company's season at the City Center. One program, for instance, contained two striking items from Mr. Taylor's repertory, each with a distinctive movement palette.
''Brandenburgs,'' to excerpts from Bach's Brandenburg Concertos, ends with a wonderful sequence of leaping and spinning. What helps make this conclusion so effervescent is the way the remainder of the choreography artfully contrasts restlessness with rest. Four soloists -a man and three women - often move simply, while an ensemble of five men dashes in and out like frisky puppies. At other times, when the soloists grow lively, the ensemble poses in solid sculptural groupings. Speaking of ''Brandenburgs'' in terms of Mr. Taylor's image of a movement palette, it could be said that this is a work in sunny yellows and cerulean blues.
There is neither brightness nor serenity in Mr. Taylor's ''Danbury Mix.'' With its relentless seethings and scramblings, this creation to orchestral pieces by Charles Ives equates kinetic unrest with social chaos. The members of the community Mr. Taylor depicts are always ready to tear one another apart. Although, once, they do manage to assemble for a parade, it looks as artificially optimistic as much Fourth of July oratory sounds, and it is followed by fits of trembling. An imposing woman who could be a goddess, a saint or the Statue of Liberty occasionally tries to lead them, only to be attacked by them, and she eventually joins them in a riot. ''Danbury Mix'' may have a varied musical spectrum; choreographically, it is all stormy gray.
Mr. Martins's ''Fearful Symmetries'' is as tumultuous as ''Danbury Mix.'' However, the way its space-devouring steps are confidently performed at breakneck speed makes this a choreographic mural in vibrant reds. The title of ''Fearful Symmetries'' comes from the dance's propulsive score by John Adams, who in turn took that phrase from William Blake's poem about a tiger. Nothing restrains the cast's men and women as they leap, sometimes back and forth from side to side, sometimes in long diagonal lines.
Unrelieved abandon can eventually grow musically and choreographically monotonous. Therefore, Mr. Adams shrewdly includes a section in which the music slows a bit - though it never really calms -and to it Mr. Martins has devised a series of pas de deux filled with twistings and coilings, all of which suggest that the energy that had previously been directed outward is now turned inward. Nonetheless, the basic choreographic power remains undiminished. Encounters with space give way to implicitly erotic encounters between two people. When the musical tempo picks up, steps again become extroverted; when the music eventually subsides, the crowds of dancers dwindle away and ''Fearful Symmetries'' fades to an end.
Ms. Porter did nothing but sit on a stool in ''Fitness Digest,'' the solo she performed as part of a Choreographer's Showcase sponsored by Evolving Arts at Dance Space Inc., in lower Manhattan. Portraying a physical-fitness teacher conducting a class, she gave verbal commands to her imaginary pupils, leaned forward to get a better look at them and gestured energetically to spur them on. As the class progressed, she acted stranger and stranger. She was cloyingly sweet one moment, dictatorial the next. Her commands made increasingly less sense until they degenerated into gibberish. At the same time, her gestures grew ever more manic. Her tension ultimately implied that horrifying passions seethed within her. This fitness guru was obviously a monster and possibly also a fake.
Ms. Porter made her points economically. She could have roamed nervously about, demonstrating outlandish exercises; she could have assigned other dancers the roles of timid or bumbling students. Instead, she kept her sketch a solo and sat on a stool. And by doing little - but by doing everything so that the slightest movement counted - she made ''Fitness Digest'' a satirical cartoon drawn in black ink with the sharpest of strokes.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Members of the New York City Ballet in Peter Martins's ''Fearful Symmetries''-The way the space-devouring steps are confidently performed at breakneck speed makes this a choreographic mural in vibrant reds. (Paul Kolnik)
