LENGTH: 1343 words

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
The Force Of Conviction Stirred by the 80's

BYLINE: By Michael Kimmelman

 BODY:
The decade under scrutiny in ''The Decade Show'' - on view through Aug. 19 at three of New York's most innovative museums - is the one that recently ended. But this exhibition could not be more timely. Among its roughly 200 paintings, sculptures, photographs, installations and works on paper is a large-scale drawing from 1987 by a young artist named Y. David Chung that depicts a Korean grocery store in a predominantly black neighborhood, the sort of establishment now so much in the local headlines. Mr. Chung's subject is racial misunderstanding and economic inequality, which he represents by giving to the image an edgy, uneasy and vertiginous feel.
This work, like many others in ''The Decade Show,'' is a cautionary tale. Precisely when vocal elements in New York are advocating strife, the exhibition calls for breaking down barriers. 
It has been organized by the Museum of Contemporary Hispanic Art and the New Museum of Contemporary Art - both on lower Broadway - and the Studio Museum in Harlem. Their intention was not to provide a complete survey of art during the last 10 years but to focus on six broad and loosely defined topics that were felt by curators at these institutions to have been ignored or ill represented by the major art museums. At the Museum of Contemporary Hispanic Art are objects under the headings biography/autobiography and sexuality/gender; the New Museum focuses on myth/spirituality/nature and discourse/media, and the Studio Museum concentrates on social practices/cultural criticism and history/memory/artifact.
In each of the museums has been installed a slanting wall hung with paintings that does not so much separate topics as provide a metaphor for the ideas of going against the grain and creating a new order, ideas that are so fundamental to the exhibition.
Included among the 94 American artists in ''The Decade Show'' are names as familiar as those of Eric Fischl and Barbara Kruger, and as unfamiliar as that of Ken Chu, a painter whose iconography is the history and identity of the Chinese-American. The exhibition's strength resides partly in its capacity to make the familiar look fresh. If, for example, Jean-Michel Basquiat's splattered and energetic paintings have been described largely in terms of their links with the neo-Expressionist wave of the 1980's, here their connections with social and political art of the 80's, particularly work involving the use of texts and of pop images, emerge strongly. Basquiat's ties to Tim Rollins and K. O. S. and to artists like Raymond Saunders become immediately apparent.
''The Decade Show'' is the latest and in some ways the most important exhibition yet to address certain major shifts that have rocked the art world in recent years. Principal among these changes has been a multisided attack on the art-historical canon as being Eurocentric, sexist and elitist. The attack has come from within the universities, which are now finding themselves pressured by certain faculty members and students to put social art history and feminism high on their agendas, and from artists like the ones in ''The Decade Show.''
These artists, many of them black or Hispanic or Asian-American, have found inspiration in a diversity of cultures. They have questioned the disjunction between a mainstream culture and a marginal culture by asking, ''Who's mainstream?'' They have attacked the media and advertisers for codifying what they believe to be a language of discrimination. And they have sought alternative texts, other ways of describing and giving dignity to their own experiences.
Sometimes the results are as simple and undeniable as Alfredo Jaar's video display for Times Square, which is represented at the New Museum in still photographs. Entitled ''America,'' it depicts first a United States flag, then the words ''This is not America's flag,'' then a map of both North and South America.
There are also many works in the exhibition that do not rise above the level of agitprop. Some of the objects are heavy with slogans and images preaching to the converted or simply haranguing a viewer. The issue of audience and context has not always been as satisfactorily resolved as in Mr. Jaar's case, or even in the case of the AIDS activist organization Gran Fury, which has designed a poster on the occasion of the exhibition to be distributed throughout New York City.
But there are works here that bear witness to an obvious pain and anger, and that succeed through the force of their convictions. And there are many works that persuade in a gentler way, like the deceptively modest assemblage of a Coke bottle and a cane by David Hammons that exploits allusion and wordplay (the idea of cocaine and its crippling effects) and that endows these mundane objects with a certain humanity.
Cecilia Vicuna makes similar use of found objects, including pieces of wood and bone, to create small-scale sculptures that can remind some viewers of Paul Klee's mystical inventions but that have their sources in pre-Columbian and Andean cultures. Ms. Vicuna's works are meditations on the fragility of the environment. The same subject concerns Maren Hassinger, who has transformed steel, rope and concrete into a sculpture resembling a billowing wheat field that is also a subtle commentary on the uneasy relationship between industry and nature.
In fact, for an exhibition so full of protest and accompanied by a thick catalogue heavy with predictable fury and declamation, ''The Decade Show'' includes an unusually large proportion of works that make their points quietly. Beverly Buchanan's tiny and meticulously constructed shacks pay homage to the experiences of the blacks in the South who have lived in this sort of ramshackle house.
Tomie Arai constructs beautiful mixed-media works that seem to derive partly from Japanese painted screens and that deal eloquently with the experiences of Asian immigrants in the United States. Martin Puryear is represented by a sensually curved construction in red cedar and pine that can bring to mind an ancient tool or an object of ritual significance.
That is to say, there are a good number of works that demand to be judged not simply on polemical grounds but also on formal terms, although the roots of their formalism are not necessarily European. Abstraction - in the form of violent and energetic paintings like Carlos Alfonzo's ''Gulfstream,'' or elegant and seemingly Japanese-inspired works on paper like Ismael Frigerio's ''Disruption of the Body (The Others' Great Utopia Series)'' - has been included in the exhibition.
But abstract works seem, in this context, to refer to particular places and events. Mel Edwards's welded steel ''Gate of Ogun,'' for example, which is inspired by a gate that the artist saw in Africa, cannot fail to raise the issue of passage - passage from one culture to another, perhaps, or from freedom to slavery.
''The Decade Show,'' in other words, embraces many ways of looking at things, many sources, many voices. What binds this large and diverse show together is indicated by its subtitle, ''Frameworks of Identity in the 1980's.'' This identity may be defined as Asian-American or Hispanic, black or Native American, gay or lesbian. It may be defined as someone who has been diagnosed as having the human immunodeficiency virus. It may not be defined along racial, sexual, economic or physical terms at all, but according to spirituality or psychology.
In any case, it is expressed in myriad ways that the exhibition seems to argue are all valid. High among the show's goals is the promotion of a cultural pluralism that will anger those who regard this philosophy as an assault on inalienable artistic values and standards. But to see the exhibition simply as an assault on tradition is to overlook the conciliatory tone that is also an essential aspect of the display. This ultimately is what makes ''The Decade Show'' so timely. In a city that seems increasingly divided along racial and ethnic lines, it speaks about inclusion and accommodation.

HEADLINE: ON G.E. AND EATING OUR SEED CORN

 BODY:
An article May 13 (''Are We Eating Our Seed Corn?'') discussed the extent to which many large American corporations, and the General Electric Company in particular, are buying back their stock and thus spending less on research and development and missing opportunities to develop innovative products. Business executives, members of Congress, academics and other experts on American industrial policy said in the article that such financial engineering often reflects short-term thinking and is sapping American competitiveness. G.E. officials defended the plan to buy back $10 billion of its stock over the next five years, pointing out that the company is a world leader in those fields in which it has chosen to compete and that its research and development is adequately funded.
Some of the letters received in response to the article follow. 
 
Deregulation of Bank Interest Is the Key
 
To the Editor:
 You quote the critics of the corporations that spend billions to buy back their own stock instead of using the capital to develop new products. The buybacks presumably reflect ''short-term thinking and a lack of confidence'' and damage American competitiveness. Your report overlooks what may be the most important underlying factors.
It is widely known by now that firms buy their own stock to drive up share price, thereby heading off corporate raiders about to attempt hostile takeovers. The managers have little choice but to make share values increase at a faster rate than shareholders could obtain from insured bank accounts. Because the firms often must borrow money to buy back the shares, the ironic result is that share values increase as the firms become more burdened with debt. Meanwhile, the managers are widely applauded for having increased share values.
The basic cause of the foolishness is largely ignored. The deregulation of depositor interest rates has caused financial turmoil everywhere, this example being only one of many. Companies cannot be bothered with research and development when they must offer shareholders higher rates than the government guarantees.
Depositor rates will be re-regulated one day, although we may have to experience another Great Depression before common sense returns. Obviously, buybacks artificially drive up share values to dangerously inflated levels.
 
FREDERICK C. THAYER
Los Angeles, May 13
The writer is professor emeritus at the University of Pittsburgh.

HEADLINE: ON G.E. AND EATING OUR SEED CORN

 BODY:
An article May 13 (''Are We Eating Our Seed Corn?'') discussed the extent to which many large American corporations, and the General Electric Company in particular, are buying back their stock and thus spending less on research and development and missing opportunities to develop innovative products. Business executives, members of Congress, academics and other experts on American industrial policy said in the article that such financial engineering often reflects short-term thinking and is sapping American competitiveness. G.E. officials defended the plan to buy back $10 billion of its stock over the next five years, pointing out that the company is a world leader in those fields in which it has chosen to compete and that its research and development is adequately funded.
Some of the letters received in response to the article follow. 
 
 Where Are the Leaders?
 
To the Editor:
 Where are this country's industrialists? While the United States has a rich supply of entrepreneurs and an ample coterie of industrial policy advocates, where are the individual business leaders capable of mobilizing the capital and human resources needed to capture global dominance in emerging industries - particularly new electronics industries?
As the era of data processing comes to a close and a new era of social computing is born, computer technology will move from the corporate back office into our schools, our cars and our living rooms. Bold new products - representing the merger between today's consumer electronics and computer businesses - will generate hundreds of billions of dollars in worldwide sales. What if the American leadership in data processing becomes a handicap instead of a strength as growth shifts to these new markets?
If American corporations rely on financial managers, bureaucrats and dealmakers to establish industrial priorities, as a nation we will miss the boat. Taking long-term risks and supporting innovation in pursuit of growth is the responsibility of individual leaders who think of themselves as creating new industries and contributing to enduring cultural values. The significant difference between the United States and Japan in this regard isn't the cost of capital - it is the capacity to mobilize sufficient quantities of risk capital. Indeed, as suggested in your article, it would be interesting to know how Mr. Welch's goals compare with those of Mr. Morita.
 
MARK STAHLMAN
New York, May 24
The writer is a securities analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons, Inc.

LENGTH: 1539 words

HEADLINE: ALL ABOUT;
AFTER A DECADE OF CONSOLIDATION, HARD TIMES AWAIT CARPET MAKERS

BYLINE: By JOSH KURTZ

 BODY:
For the American carpet companies that survived waves of consolidation during the 1980's, the real challenge is just beginning. Now they face an era of slack demand from their customers in real estate and the automobile industry. New products are at best a distant promise. And the growth of Shaw Industries Inc. threatens its rivals.
Analysts say the industry will become still more concentrated. A report to be issued by Carpet and Rug Industry magazine counts 170 domestic carpet makers in 1990, down from 350 in 1980. The leading and third-ranked producers from 1980 are gone. Thirteen North American mills have been sold in the last 16 months, with nine independent carpet makers absorbed into other companies.
 
From Luxury to Necessity
Three Decades Of Strong Growth 
Before the late 1950's, carpeting was a luxury. Now, the mills turn out so many millions of yards, so rapidly and inexpensively, that carpeting is usually far cheaper than hardwood floors. ''Now we almost take it for granted,'' said Ronald E. VanGelderen, president of the Carpet and Rug Institute in Dalton, Ga. Almost three-quarters of the nation's carpet mills are in the Dalton area, where labor and water remain plentiful and relatively cheap.
Carpet production set a record in 1989 of almost 1.4 billion square yards, or, as Mr. VanGelderen is fond of saying, ''an amount equal to a nine-lane interstate highway, fully carpeted, around the Equator.'' But the age of strongly increasing sales appears to be over. Production rose 224 percent in the 1960's and 76 percent in the 1970's. But output rose only 13 percent during the 1980's, and that gain was largely due to the introduction of stain-resistant carpeting.
Now that roughly 80 percent of all residential carpeting made in the United States has some form of stain blocker, even the industry's optimists admit that the rush to buy carpeting has subsided. Still, Mr. VanGelderen sees some profits even in economic adversity. Housing starts are down, but people who are moving, or updating their current homes, often call for new carpeting, he says. Fifty-five percent of all residential carpeting sales are replacements, with the other 45 percent for new homes. Five years ago, those numbers were reversed. As for commercial buildings, Mr. VanGelderen said: ''If there are office-building gluts, the realtor will want to spruce up the place, and that will include new carpeting.''
It's tough enough to double and redouble sales in a high-tech, high-growth industry like computer software. But Shaw Industries, also of Dalton, has expanded rapidly in a slower business where soft ware means shag carpeting.
In 1980, Carpet and Rug Industry magazine listed West-Point Pepperell, with $402 million in annual sales, as the nation's leading carpet maker. Armstrong World Industries was third, with $240 million, and Shaw sixth, with $213 million. A decade later, with sales up 656 percent, Shaw heads the list. Sales of almost $1.2 billion for the year ending last July 31, before a recent acquisition, gave Shaw almost three times the volume of its nearest competitor, Burlington Industries. West-Point and Armstrong? They are both owned by Shaw.
Analysts attribute the company's success to its president and chief executive, Robert E. Shaw. He saved money but sustained employee motivation by hiring a young, aggressive sales staff and paying straight salaries with no commissions. He signed relatively short, flexible agreements with retailers, keeping prices down by being one of the first manufacturers to eliminate distributors.
 
The Rise of Shaw
A Fast, Flexible Style Pays Off
In an industry that is now thoroughly modernized, Mr. Shaw was one of the first to automate. He maintained strong cash flow, so that when other mills came up for sale, he was able to buy. ''Bob Shaw is one of the great mavericks of the carpet industry,'' said Frank O'Neill, editor of the Carpet and Rug Industry magazine.
Most analysts predict that the company's market share, now 22 percent, will continue to grow. Mr. O'Neill believes Shaw could pass 40 percent in the 1990's through more acquisitions. Mr. Shaw says his company can dominate the carpet business the way the General Motors Corporation once dominated the market for cars.
''It's not unusual in a maturing industry for the industry leader to have that kind of market share,'' he said.
Not that Shaw's path will be easy. On May 9, John Baugh, an analyst with Wheat First Butcher & Singer Securities, said that the weak economy was the reason for cutting his earnings estimates for Shaw - by eight cents a share, to $2.15, for the year that ended March 31, and 12 cents a share, to $2.85, for the current fiscal year.
The day Mr. Baugh revised his figures, Shaw stock plunged 2 7/8 points, to 30 1/4, and lost an additional 1 1/2 points the next day. It has recently recovered somewhat to hover at about 31. Mr. Baugh said he was shocked by the stock's jumpiness. ''A company usually doesn't fall on such minor changes,'' he said. When it comes to carpet companies, ''I think it tells you how skittish the market is.''
More and more carpet makers, frustrated with the industry's weak growth, are ready to give up. Armstrong World Industries Inc., a home furnishings manufacturer, had a carpet division that was one of the industry's leaders, with 1988 sales of $368 million. Last fall, after sales and earnings had been slipping for eight months, Armstrong sold its carpet operations to Shaw.
 
The Rise of Shaw
A Fast, Flexible Style Pays Off
With many other smaller companies leaving the business, Mr. O'Neill doubts that consolidation will abate or that another company will rival Shaw's size. If anyone can challenge Shaw, Mr. O'Neill picks Beaulieu of America, also based in Dalton. Although ranked 31st in the United States, with estimated sales of $68 million last year, it is owned by the Beaulieu Group of Belgium, with worldwide sales of about $970 million.
Mr. Shaw said that Beaulieu could hinder him if he tries to expand overseas. Carpeting is seldom exported, because shipping it is so expensive. American carpet mills have been largely free from the foreign competition that has afflicted other textile industries. But Beaulieu has opened a mill in the United States. ''They are obviously intent on establishing a presence in this industry on a worldwide basis,'' said Mr. O'Neill.
If Shaw can't be surpassed in volume, smaller, nimble companies might rely on creative marketing or imaginative design. A few small companies are successfully making higher-priced designer carpets. Karastan-Bigelow has reached about $320 million in sales, fifth in the nation, by producing decorative area rugs and reproducing American designs from the 19th century. Other less resourceful companies face a struggle. ''Right now, I'm really pessimistic about the rest of the industry'' Mr. O'Neill said. ''If companies don't establish themselves to try to find a niche, like fashion, they're going to have a hard time competing with Shaw.''
 
 
 
CAN CARPETS MAKE YOU ILL?
In a Washington office building, the brown tweed carpeting installed in 1987 seemed like nothing more than standard government decor. But within days, employees complained of dizziness, sore throats and flu symptoms, with one rushed to a hospital in respiratory shock. It was one of the carpeting industry's worst moments: Everyone who became ill worked for the Environmental Protection Agency.
No one at the E.P.A. has proved what caused the illnesses, but most point to the carpeting. Ronald E. VanGelderen, president of the Carpet and Rug Institute, says that the carpeting might have deteriorated while stored in a warehouse for more than a year.
The incident prompted the industry to work with the E.P.A. and the Consumer Product Safety Commission to develop carpets that give off fewer vapors and are less prone to chemically react with fluids like animal urine or medication. In the last three years the safety commission has received more than 130 complaints about carpeting, mostly about eye and throat irritation.
Mr. VanGelderen said tests will show there is no danger from properly stored carpeting installed in adequately ventilated buildings (the E.P.A.'s windows did not open). Dr. Mark Van Ert, director of the University of Arizona occupational safety and health program, says that a suspect chemical in carpeting has been cleared in testing so far. ''That doesn't mean we're ready to give it a clean bill of health yet,'' he said. ''But at least it suggests that it's not highly toxic.'' He says that the adhesives used to secure carpeting might be the culprits. Many scientists believe that indoor pollutants have contributed to the symptoms of illness as much as the carpets.And Mr. VanGelderen contends the problem may be one of perception, because, he says, new carpeting often gives off strong, though harmless, odors.
Even as the industry seeks to debunk the odor theory, some might try to profit from it. Just as stain-resistant carpeting increased revenues during the 1980's, Mr. VanGeldern hopes that the introduction of fume-free carpets - in a few years, maybe - will aid the industry in the 90's.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
FOREIGN INVESTORS, LOCAL POLITICS

BYLINE: By JOHN CAHILL: John Cahill is the managing director and chief executive of BTR P.L.C.

 BODY:
In the first contested takeover of the 1990's, the company I manage, BTR P.L.C., announced its desire to purchase the Norton Company in what securities analysts viewed as a model tender offer. BTR raised its cash through traditional bank loans, not ''junk bonds,'' and pledged that it had absolutely no plans to sell off parts of the company, close plants or even move Norton's headquarters from its hometown of Worcester, Mass.
While I had hoped to work out an agreement with Norton on amicable terms, the reaction to our offer was as negative as it was instantaneous and astonishing. Encouraged by Norton's management, workers who had never heard of BTR - or BTR's long history of helping its subsidiaries operate and prosper on a semi-autonomous basis - declared that the British industrial manufacturer was a ''corporate raider.'' On the day I visited Worcester to explain BTR's intentions to local constituencies, Norton employees demonstrated without hearing what I had to say. They shouted ''U.S.A., U.S.A.'' and burned the Union Jack. 
This reaction was quickly echoed by state politicians. Local leaders boasted in the press that they had immediately begun work on ''emergency'' legislation to ''save'' Norton. The legislation was quickly passed by a sparsely attended, informal session of the Legislature. It took two hours for a handful of lawmakers to change radically corporate law in the commonwealth.
Not to be outdone, Gov.Michael Dukakis signed the bill the next morning in a Norton plant. Before cheering Norton workers, Mr. Dukakis compared BTR's tender offer to the British invasion of America during the Revolutionary War, explaining that it was ''another attempt by a foreign power to interfere with our ability to shape our own destiny.''
Meanwhile, Norton management continually claimed that a foreign company would be an unfit parent because of Norton's highly sensitive ceramics work for the American defense industry. Norton's defense claims were pressed upon Congress despite Britain's close ties to the United States and BTR's own work for the Defense Department. These efforts culminated in a letter to President Bush, signed by 120 congressmen, warning that a foreign acquisition of Norton would jeopardize national security.
So where did all the talk of foreign powers and national security take us? Weeks later, Norton announced that it had signed a merger agreement with a French company, Compagnie de Saint-Gobain, under terms similar to what BTR offered but for substantially more money than BTR was willing to pay. Furthermore, despite all the anti-foreigner hysteria generated by Norton, Norton management knew for much of the time after our bid that it could merge with the French company on terms amenable to senior management.
In the end it can be said that the free market worked, in spite of politics. Norton stock is now worth almost twice as much as it would have been without BTR's initiative. But the attempt by Norton management and its political allies to interfere with that system is most concerning, both for the integrity of state government and for America's ability to preach the virtues of free and fair markets to Japan and the world.
I would suggest that there are at least two lessons to be learned from the battle over Norton. The first is that responsible business mergers should not be confused with the junk bond-financed takeovers of the 1980's. Globalization and market consolidation in Europe, the United States and elsewhere promise more international business combinations in the years ahead. If economics drives politics, then this trend - promoted by the United States for decades - will surely create the sort of global economic interdependence that insures world peace and stability.
The second lesson is that state governments are clearly setting a precedent to become the unquestioning defenders of local management. And as the Norton case demonstrates, entrenched managements will not shy away from manipulation, even when they know those manipulations will become obvious. Company employees and local politicians have every right to be skeptical of proposed takeovers. But if they do not apply the same skepticism to their own management, they are likely to be left with executives who are much more adept at playing politics than they are at managing competitive companies that generate jobs and prosperity over the long haul.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
THE PYRAMID AND THE WEB

BYLINE: By SALLY HELGESEN; Sally Helgesen is author of ''The Female Advantage: Women's Ways of Leadership.''

 BODY:
Over lunch one day with Frances Hesselbein, the national executive director of the Girl Scouts, I listened as she described the ''circular management system'' she had devised. ''Here's me, in the center,'' she explained, setting her glass of iced tea in the middle of the table, then surrounding it with a circle of cups, more glasses, a pepper mill, ''and this is my first management team.'' She constructed more circles, building outward concentrically, then began linking them, using knives and forks as radials. ''The great thing about the circle is it does not box you in. You can connect with any other point. As the circles extend outward, the fabric becomes more interwoven.''
I watched fascinated, for the woman who Peter Drucker says ''could manage any company in America'' had created the perfect image of a spider's web, that delicate tracery whose purpose is to draw other creatures into it. 
It is not unusual that women, setting up their own companies or running divisions of larger corporations over which they have relative autonomy, would create organizational structures different from those developed by men during the long years when they defined and managed the public world of work. The women in business whom I have studied have tended to disdain that most traditional of business structures - the hierarchical ladder. When they described their place or role in their companies, they, like Ms. Hesselbein, spoke of a desire to be in the center of things, rather than at the top, which they perceived as a lonely and disconnected position. Inseparable from this notion of being in the center was the women's desire to be connected to all those around them as if by invisible strands or threads constructed around the central point.
These images - the hierarchy and the web - are in a way mirror opposites, since the most desirable place in the one is the worst spot in the other. Hierarchy values position, individual achievement won by competition, while the web puts a premium on affiliation, on staying close.
Until recently, the hierarchical pyramid was considered the very model of organizational efficiency, and for heavy industry this may have been true. But as today's companies attempt to restructure in response to the very different needs of the information age, the value of the old pyramid is being questioned: Didn't hierarchy give birth to slow-moving bureaucracy? The old military model chain-of-command increasingly is seen as too lumbering and muscle-bound for a fast-changing global economy - and far too expensive as well. Progressive companies are trying out new structures. And it is in this restructuring that the web of inclusion - that product of the female psyche - has a contribution to make.
The advantages of a web structure are many. For one thing, because it is not primarily concerned with where people stand or how they are ranked, it permits flexibility without lowering morale. A person can serve on various teams without worrying about whether the assignment is appropriate to his or her status, thus taking full advantage of the person's talents and skills. As Ms. Hesselbein explained to me as she constructed her circles, ''When someone gets shifted, it doesn't feel like a demotion, because there is no up or down.''
Another advantage of the web structure is that it permits a greater flow of information, because there are more points of connection or contact. In a hierarchy the information flow is strictly up or down, along appropriate channels. And because information is power, there can be a tendency to hoard it.
The web's more direct, free-flowing, multiconnected mode mimics the workings of the microchip or circuit board. This feminine method of management is more appropriate to today's environment than a model first developed to serve the needs of Caesar's army.

HEADLINE: 'Junk Bond' Anxiety Shakes the G.I.C.

BYLINE: By DEBORAH RANKIN

 BODY:
The collapse of the ''junk bond'' market and the well-publicized troubles of the First Executive Corporation, whose California insurance unit has the largest investment portfolio of the high-risk, high-yield bonds, have prompted employers and employees to stop and take a closer look at what has been a popular vehicle for retirement plans.
At issue are the billions of dollars that have been placed in Guaranteed Investment Contracts, or G.I.C.'s, the investment option chosen by most employees who participate in 401(k) plans. Under these plans, employees salt away pre-tax rather than after-tax dollars by agreeing to defer part of their salary and invest it in one of several types of options offered by their companies. Even though a stock mutual fund is typically one of the choices offered, roughly two out of three employees - wary of placing their retirement savings in equities in the wake of the two October stock-market crashes - select a fixed-income option.
While it might go by some unrevealing label, like Fixed Income or Capital Preservation Fund, the underpinning for this option is a G.I.C. For large employers, participants' money is more likely invested in a handful of G.I.C.'s issued by several insurance companies, with maturities ranging from one to five years. 
Until recently, G.I.C.'s were almost a no-brainer, widely considered to be the safest choice (even though stocks significantly outperform bonds over the long term), because the insurance companies guaranteed the interest rate on the money.
''Participants got a good rate of interest, guaranteed to be competitive, without the risk of losing principal,'' said Murray L. Becker, president of Becker & Rooney in Teaneck, N.J., a leading G.I.C. consulting firm that serves large employers. For example, top rates on three-year G.I.C.'s, which are typically compared with Treasury securities of the same maturity, are about 9.3 percent, or half a point or so above Treasuries.
Most large employers have always known, however, that the guarantee behind a G.I.C. was only as good as the creditworthiness of the insurance company that issued it. And when the junk-bond market began to unravel - and First Executive's troubles began to surface - plan sponsors were deluged with questions from employees about the safety of G.I.C.'s.
First Executive announced an $859 million charge against earnings in 1989 to reflect the declining value of the junk bonds held by its subsidiaries, including the California-based Executive Life Insurance Company and, to a lesser extent, the Executive Life Insurance Company of New York. The bonds constituted nearly 45 percent of the assets of First Executive's operating units.
First Executive'S chairman, Fred Carr, says that people are focusing on a safety problem that does not exist. ''We have a very, very strong capital position and a very, very strong cash position and high liquidity,'' he said.
Moreover, industry experts are quick to point out that Executive Life of California accounts for less than 2 percent of all G.I.C. contracts and that only a small percentage of retirement money overall is in junk bonds. And they note that no G.I.C. participant has ever lost a dime.
Nonetheless, ''employers are now getting bombarded with inquiries, if not from rank-and-file employees, then from senior managers,'' Mr. Becker said. ''Plan sponsors have become more sensitive to the employee-relations aspect of G.I.C.'s.''
Indeed, large employers who sponsor 401(k) plans are getting fussier about which insurance companies to use. ''Everybody's very nervous, and plan sponsors, because of their fiduciary responsibility, are leaning toward safety,'' said John B. Kleiman, a vice president at Conning & Company, a Hartford investment firm.
The mounting concern is creating opportunities for commercial banks, which already had been making inroads into the 401(k) investment business, to increase their share of the G.I.C. market. The financial stakes are enormous and the battle for turf has already set off a skirmish in Washington.
The G.I.C. market is estimated to total between $150 billion and $160 billion. About $30 billion of new contracts are written annually, including maturing contracts that are reinvested. Although there is no central source of statistics, it is estimated that banks (which call their version of the contracts Bank Investment Contracts, or B.I.C.'s) obtained from one-tenth to one-third of the new contracts written last year, and are expected to do about as well in 1990.
Insurance companies maintain that banks have an unfair advantage because they are able to ''pass through'' Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation coverage.
''Life insurance companies are backed by their own full faith and credit, while banks have a universal guarantee provided at taxpayer expense,'' said Henri Bersoux, a spokesman for the American Council of Life Insurance, an industry trade group based in Washington.
The life insurance industry maintains that the pass-through of deposit insurance will encourage small, weak banks to take unwarranted risks in bidding for G.I.C. business, and could lead to problems for commercial banks that would rival the savings and loan crisis. (An attempt to ban the pass-through of F.D.I.C. coverage was narrowly defeated in Congress last year, but the council plans to begin another effort again this year.) Such protection already has reached its limits, Mr. Bersoux said. ''How much is enough? The F.D.I.C. already insures your savings account and your checking account.'' Eventually, he predicted, banks could become the dominant players in the G.I.C. business.
''That would be nice, but I don't think it's very likely,'' said David J. Salvin, vice president of global funding for the Bankers Trust Company, the leading issuer of B.I.C.'s.
In fact, the three banks that have the lion's share of the B.I.C. business - the others are Citibank and Morgan Guaranty - have said they would be glad to give up the insurance coverage if they could also give up paying the premiums that are tied to B.I.C. contracts, something that is not an option now.
Many consulting firms view the additional competition in the G.I.C. field as a positive development. ''The entry of a new class of issuers - banks - is healthy in a growing market,'' said Marjorie E. Zwick, a principal with William M. Mercer Asset Planning Inc., a New York pension consulting firm. ''It has helped to even out the supply-and-demand equation.''
One likely outcome of the continuing changes in the G.I.C. business is that plan sponsors will seek even more diversification, Mr. Salvin of Bankers Trust said. Companies that are neither banks nor insurers could enter the market, floating G.I.C.'s of their own, he said.
In a separate development, a group of state regulators, the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, proposed new guidelines earlier this month that may have the effect of limiting insurance company ownership of junk bonds. The guidelines, which would be phased in over a period of five years, are expected to be approved by regulators in June.
For now, experts say that a large-scale insurance industry default involving household names is almost unthinkable and that even if an insurer as big as Executive Life of California were to default, it would still have valuable assets that could be sold, enabling participants to recover most of their investment.
To show how minimal the effect would be, Mr. Becker of Becker & Rooney provided a worst-case scenario should Executive Life become insolvent. A 401(k) plan might have 10 percent of its assets invested with that insurance company; and if the company had to write down 25 percent of its assets, a plan participant might see the value of his or her account shrink by 2.5 percent.
''But this would only happen if your plan had placed money with Executive Life,'' Mr. Becker said. ''Since the rest of the insurance industry has not followed down Executive Life's path, the vast majority of G.I.C.'s are not at risk.''
Other insurance experts say that junk bonds are not the only problem facing insurance companies. ''You've got to look at the entire portfolio of a G.I.C. issuer,'' said Bill Morris of the Laughlin Group, a Beaverton, Ore., G.I.C. consulting firm. ''Some companies that have invested heavily in the oil patch areas of the Southwest and in parts of New England have a much greater exposure to real estate problems than they do to junk bonds.''
Still other factors can impair an insurer's creditworthiness, Mr. Morris added. His firm has recommended, for example, against awarding G.I.C. contracts to several insurance companies with healthy investment portfolios because they either had a lack of reserves to cover a risky new line of underwriting business or because their profits were being ''diverted and upstreamed'' by the insurer's corporate parent.
All of these concerns are causing employers to start setting credit targets for their G.I.C. holdings, often aiming for portfolios with an overall credit rating of at least AA. (See box.) ''We are seeing more clients who are adopting minimum credit requirements for the purchase of future G.I.C.'s and B.I.C.'s,'' said Ms. Zwick of Mercer Asset Planning. ''Some may have had informal minimums before, but we certainly think it is prudent for them to adopt a formal investment policy now.''
 
 
 
INSIST ON THE DETAILS
Should you be worried if your 401(k) plan is in a Guaranteed Investment Contract? Probably not. But to sleep well at night, you might want to find out exactly where that money is invested. The goal is ''not to have all your G.I.C. eggs in one basket,'' said Marjorie E. Zwick, a principal with William M. Mercer Asset Planning Inc., a New York consulting firm.
The place to begin your inquiries is with your plan administrator, typically your company's employee benefits department. Ask which insurance companies and banks are represented in the plan's G.I.C. portfolio, and what portion of the portfolio each issuer accounts for.
In the past, it was not unusual for plans to place all their fixed-income money with one issuer. But now the norm among large companies is to spread that money among several insurers or banks. Smaller plans, however, may still have just one or two G.I.C. issuers. That is probably fine, as long as your plan has not put all of its fixed-income money into G.I.C.'s issued by a company with a big portfolio of troubled ''junk bonds.'' The quality of an issuer's portfolio, as well as other factors, is reflected in its credit rating. The higher the credit rating, the less likely the company (and its G.I.C.'s) will run into trouble.
Ask your plan administrator for the credit rating of each issuer. Top-rated insurance companies will have an AAA rating, while top-rated banks generally have an AA rating. Issuers with ratings below single-A are considered more risky.
If you are troubled by what you learn, it may be time to consider making changes in the way your 401(k) contributions are invested. While participants in a minority of plans are given no say about how their money is invested, most plans allow investment options to be changed, typically two to four times a year. You might want to follow the example of managers of large pension funds, who put about two-thirds of the money they handle into the stock market and the rest into bonds and cash.
But it is doubtful that you would be allowed to pick and choose among G.I.C. issuers and keep, say, the 25 percent of your holdings issued by insurance company A, but liquidate the 75 percent issued by companies B and C. And it is probably not prudent to liquidate all your current holdings in fixed-income investments and convert them to equities. Diversification - among types of investments, as well as among types of issuers - remains a key to both safety and performance.
''So don't throw the baby out with the bath water,'' Ms. Zwick warned.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Will Oil Gush Again? Ask the Saudis

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Do the Saudis know something that American oil traders are only beginning to suspect?
That question arose last week as the Saudis were reported to be dumping gold, which plunged in price in response to the sales. A widespread rumor had it that they sold the gold to pay for American Treasury bonds, of all things. 
The conventional wisdom in the brokerage community this year has been that oil prices are headed up, at least in the long term. The world is again running short of oil, goes the argument, and the oil exporters have learned their lesson and will restrict production enough to push up prices.
As it happens, on the same day that the Saudis sold gold, oil prices fell in reaction to reports that showed rapidly rising inventories of crude. But the prevalent Wall Street view sees that as temporary, which is why crude prices for delivery next year fell only a bit, even as prices for nearby delivery were plunging, with July futures down $1.62 a barrel for the week, to $17.80.
The available evidence now is that if any oil producer is cheating on production limits imposed by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, it is probably Kuwait. ''We know Saudi Arabia is adhering to its new quota,'' said William Randol, an oil analyst at the First Boston Corporation who thinks the long-term bullish case for crude is still intact.
But if the Saudis are loading up on Treasury bonds, one has to suspect that they have an opinion on bond prices - that they will rise as yields fall - that is unlikely to be accurate if oil prices zoom higher. Historically, rising oil prices have usually meant bad news for both the stock and bond markets. And if any country can hold down oil prices, simply by pumping more oil, it is Saudi Arabia.
Falling gold and oil prices helped to restrain inflationary fears, but the small rebound in gold prices after the Saudis stopped selling may indicate that the plunge in gold reflected the illiquidity of that market more than a changing investment outlook. Gold futures for June delivery traded as low as $361 per ounce, but ended the week off just $7.20, at $368.40.
If the rumored market moves by the Saudis turn out to be wise, that would be good news for the stock market. But after struggling upward for most of last week, share prices fell on Friday as the Government reported personal income was a bit higher than expected in April, thus damaging the case that a slowing economy will force the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates. It was the first time since January that consumer spending rose more rapidly than income, a fact that depressed bond prices.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week up 1.01 points, to 2,820.92, after setting a new peak of 2,856.26 on Wednesday. Some chart readers saw significance in the fact that the market rally died just as the Standard & Poor's 500 was making its second unsuccessful attempt at topping the record close of 359.80 it reached last October. It closed at 359.29 on Wednesday, having reached 359.69 in January. For the week, the S&P slipped 0.06 to 354.58.

HEADLINE: What's Big and Hairy And Worries Wall Street Silly?

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The stock market has been hitting new highs in recent weeks, but Wall Street can't get its mind off something else that has gone through the roof: the Federal budget deficit.
With the White House and Congress engaged in yet another highly publicized effort, the fifth in nine years, to pull the United States out of its budgetary morass, many on the Street are saying that time is running out. A failure to achieve a credible budget reduction this time around, they say, will consign the country to years of sub-par growth and, sooner or later, to a recession that might otherwise have been avoided.
''A budget deal is of the utmost urgency,'' contended Rimmer de Vries, chief economist for J. P. Morgan & Company. ''If we are to prevent a recession, we have to have an agreement.'' 
Indeed, with the deficit approaching $200 billion this year, twice as much as the Administration estimated just four months ago, the concern is deep enough that many Wall Streeters say they would accept tax increases, even a hike in the income tax, if this were needed for a budget breakthrough.
''If it takes tax increases, that's the price we have to pay,'' said Darwin L. Beck, an economist at the First Boston Corporation.
''I wish we didn't have to,'' added Carl B. Weinberg of High Frequency Economics Ltd., an advisory firm based in New York, even as he acknowledged that higher taxes are probably inevitable. He noted that most of his overseas clients regard American taxes as ''ridiculously low.''
As it happens, the noble-sounding sentiments about deficit reduction largely coincide with Wall Street's self-interest. A tax increase might well send the stock market up further, at least in the short term, said some on the Street, explaining that almost any serious action on the deficit would be greeted warmly by the markets.
The call for action was heard repeatedly in interviews with people in the securities and financial industries. Fiscal policy was first on nearly every agenda for change involving Washington, handily eclipsing even such emotion-laden subjects as trade policy with Japan or, in some quarters, the transfer of regulatory authority over stock-index futures to the Securities and Exchange Commission. (See box.) If taxes are to go up, the most likely candidates appear to be ''sin'' levies on tobacco and alcohol. Energy taxes have big revenue potential but involve regional rivalries. Raising income taxes seems to be everyone's last resort, but most appear to be willing to bite that bullet, too. The raise most likely would take the form of an across-the-board top rate of 33 percent, instead of the current ''blended'' mix of rates that results in a final bracket of 28 percent for the biggest earners. The increase could be made more palatable by linking it to a restoration of the break for capital gains.
To be sure, not everyone thinks a trade-off like that would be acceptable to most of those who work on the Street.
''They just don't want to give up any more of their paychecks,'' said Lawrence A. Kudlow, the chief economist for Bear, Stearns & Company and a former official in the hard-line anti-tax Reagan Administration.
Nonetheless, various combinations of spending cuts and tax increases would win considerable support, those interviewed generally said, as evidence that the nation's political leaders were finally finding a way to deal with the long-festering problem.
Warnings about the deficit sparking a recession have been sounded before during the budgetary gridlock of the past half decade or so, yet the business expansion of the last seven and a half years, the second-longest on record, remains intact. Now, however, economic growth has slowed substantially because the Federal Reserve has been forced to counter fiscal laxity with persistently high interest rates. So, the risks may have climbed. Wall Street itself has made the consequences of any recession more dire because of its role during the 1980's in increasing corporate America's reliance on borrowed money.
The economy, in fact, is looking fragile enough for some people to question whether it could stand the amount of deficit reduction that would now be required to meet fully the targets specified by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings legislation. Gramm-Rudman, which was adopted in 1985, set deficit-reduction targets originally intended to lead to a balanced budget by 1991.
Senior people on Wall Street are in overwhelming agreement that what is needed most to keep the economy growing is a plan to bring the deficit down in a gradual but steady way.
''Wall Street has gotten pretty skeptical, if not cynical,'' about the political process, said James R. Schlesinger, a long-time Washington hand who serves as a senior adviser to Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. The remedy, he added, is to put the fiscal problem ''on a path toward solution over the intermediate term - the next five years or so.''
The Gramm-Rudman legislation, of course, is one such attempt but American budget discipline has been so poor that there is no longer any realistic hope of meeting the Gramm-Rudman goals. Its standards have already been officially compromised by allowing the law's deficit targets to recede by two years.
Dismayed by Washington's proclivity to respond to Gramm-Rudman with little more than smoke and mirrors, many critics in the financial markets and elsewhere insist that the budget-making process become more transparent and less vulnerable to accounting tricks and unrealistic hopes.
Isn't something very wrong, asked Roger M. Kubarych, a manager at Henry Kaufman & Company, when almost nobody noticed until eight months into the current fiscal year that the budget had gone into a ditch?
''We're not looking for a miracle here, just more clarity, more openness and more honesty,'' Mr. Kubarych said.
While those who, say, trade bonds for a living may revel in such lurches, it is widely accepted that the economy, the markets, investors and society at large would fare better if Washington found the will to put the deficit into a soundly conceived shrinkage.
Such an accord would almost certainly reduce interest rates, even if the economy continued to expand and, as now seems to be the case, even if the nation's shrinking trade deficit puts fewer dollars in the hands of foreigners for reinvestment here.
The Federal Reserve, no longer needing to regard itself as the sole defense against inflation, could relax monetary policy. With the Government's priority claim on the capital market diminished, private savings would increase. Investors could finance more enterprises. Productive capacity could expand, supporting economic growth while keeping a lid on prices.
There are some alternatives if a grand budget compromise cannot be reached. M. Kathryn Eickhoff, president of Eickhoff Economics Inc., a consulting firm in New York and Washington, is one of those who thinks the President should be given authority to veto individual budget items and to rescind previously approved spending.
''Something's got to be done,'' Ms. Eickhoff said, even while acknowledging that these measures remain a political long shot.
But will anything be done? Last week, President Bush angered Democrats in Congress when he said that Congress bears the primary responsibility for solving the fiscal mess. In turn, the Democrats accused Mr. Bush of jeopardizing the budget talks by refusing to offer a plan of his own. Some of the Democrats are already saying that the talks could break down within weeks.
That would only confirm Wall Street's worst fears. The Street's own scandals notwithstanding, many in the securities industry say that Washington has behaved like an irresponsible teen-ager in handling money - and could well continue to do so.
''I'm extremely discouraged about how we make decisions,'' said Donald H. Straszheim, senior economist at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., pondering this year's jump in the deficit. ''This is insanity.''
 
 
 
FEARS FOR TRADE AND THE FED, TOO
There are other things on Wall Street's Washington agenda, of course, besides the deficit. Perhaps the most important is the mechanism for the steady expansion of world trade.
''Wall Streeters would like to see a more open global economy, in terms of both goods and services,'' said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of the Goldman Sachs International Corporation. He said he expected the Bush Administration to press vigorously for American interests in the current round of negotiations to improve the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Another vital interest, though one not seriously threatened, is the continued ability of the Federal Reserve to conduct an independent monetary policy, largely shielded from passing political pressures. Some Congressional proposals would dent the Fed's armor in this respect but they are not expected to be adopted.
A more immediate fear is that Washington would go overboard in responding to the surge of interest in environmental matters and would jettison the cost-benefit analysis and market-based policy that the Administration and others have sought, with a certain amount of success, to achieve.
''There is great concern that actions on the environmental front will be taken with too little consideration of the economic and financial impacts,'' said James R. Schlesinger, who served as Energy Secretary in the Carter Administration and now is a senior adviser to Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. A Senate-House conference is expected to spend much of the summer debating measures to strengthen the Clean Air Act, which cleared the House last week.
Many on Wall Street are eager for additional regulatory action to reduce wild price gyrations in the stock market.
One of the best ways to accomplish this, according to the Securities Industry Association, would be to consolidate authority in the Securities and Exchange Commission. In a crisis, said Marc E. Lackritz, executive vice president of the brokers' trade group, ''you don't want to have three or four people all trying to reach one another.''
The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which now oversees stock futures, is strenuously resisting a transfer of authority to the S.E.C. Support for the idea, however, appears to be growing.

HEADLINE: Currency Psychology and the Yen

 BODY:
It was a milestone of sorts for the Japanese. The dollar fell below 150 to the yen on Friday, a key psychological break for the Japanese currency. Although still weak, the yen has risen 5.9 percent against the dollar in three weeks and is at its strongest point since the beginning of March. If the dollar remains below 150, the yen could gain more momentum as the Japanese switch their hedges, which would mean buying more yen. The Tokyo stock market, as it has on other recent signs of strength in the yen, rallied 482.13 points on Friday, nearing the 33,000 level on the Nikkei 225 index. At the same time, the dollar rose against the West German mark, which has been troubled by the uncertainty and costs surrounding the pending economic union of the two Germanys.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1677 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Putting Ivan Boesky on Trial
 
The Mulheren trial is turning into the Boesky trial. Ivan F. Boesky was forced to testify last week that he kept millions in profits from insider trading, took a tax deduction for half of his $100 million settlement and illegally paid other prisoners to do his laundry. Mr. Boesky, who finished a three-year prison stay last month, is cooperating with the Government in the securities fraud trial of John A. Mulheren Jr., the former head of Jamie Securities. In appearance, the star witness was the Boesky of old, with a dark suit and a gold ring on his pinky. In manner, he was reduced from a braggart to a mouse, afraid to mutter a word without having a document under his nose. Members of Congress demanded another look at his settlement, which now seems less onerous than it had appeared.
 
 
Grab the Prize, But Skip the Drink 
 
For Cracker Jack it works fine. But the Coca-Cola Company can't get the knack of tucking prizes into its product. Special Coke cans - dubbed MagiCans - have prizes that pop up from spring-loaded vials. No plastic trinkets these; the awards are bills from $1 to $500 or coupons for merchandise or travel. The winning cans are weighted with a foul-tasting chlorinated fluid in their bottoms to keep wily customers from picking them out. But with some defective MagiCans, customers might accidentally drink the fluid. Then their wily lawyers might file product liability claims against the company. Coca-Cola has had to take out full-page newspaper advertisements explaining that, unlike Cracker Jack boxes, its cans offer product or prize, but not both.
 
Creeping 'Baby Bellism'
 
The ''baby Bells'' are boasting of an advance in their campaign to enter new lines of business. A Senate committee voted on Tuesday to let the regional Bell operating companies design and manufacture telephone equipment. Not that the Bell companies want to slug it out with all the mass-market, cut-rate electronics companies. ''They don't have any interest in being broad telecommunications manufacturers,'' said Frank Governali, an analyst at First Boston. At most, they would work on software, switching equipment or other products for the telephone companies themselves. The real value of the Senate bill for the companies would be as a precedent for letting them pursue other businesses restricted under the terms of the Bell breakup in 1984. They hunger to offer information services, like databases and electronic banking, that other companies guard as their own domains. But even the measure that cleared the Senate committee is a long way from becoming law.
 
Dumping Tobacco Stocks
 
It might have taken a 29-year-old public health student to help get the nation's largest university endowment to sell its tobacco stocks. Dr. Philip Huang, at Harvard, belongs to a national anti-smoking group, Doctors Ought to Care (DOC) that has produced mock advertisements for ''Emphysema Slims'' and the ''Smoking is Not Kool Jazz Festival.'' At Harvard, he helped create an advertisement broadcast on the school's radio station that derided President Derek Bok for failing to unload the school's tobacco shares. Harvard decided last September to sell its stocks, and the City University of New York followed last week. In the wake of the announcements, tobacco stocks tumbled.
 
Ivan's Exploding Television Set
 
How can you get Soviet viewers to sit still for commercials when they fear that their television sets are about to explode? A study by the D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles agency, released last week, raised this worry as the major obstacle for companies wanting to advertise on Soviet television. Manufacturing defects have caused many televisions there to burst into flames. But the Soviets are trying to sell advertisements, and Western advertising agencies are rushing into the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe as their clients make plans to expand their sales.
 
Bush Son on the Spot
He did what hundreds of other directors at failed savings and loans have done: He sought and approved loans for business associates, failing to disclose his connections. But because Neil Bush is the President's son, he is receiving special attention. Appearing before a House committee last week, he complained about finger-pointing. But he admitted that he won his seat on the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association board in 1985 in part because his father was Vice President. Some of the loans in question have gone bad, contributing to bailout costs for Silverado that are likely to reach $1 billion.
 
In Brief
 
General Motors Corporation stockholders approved a pension plan that will increase the benefits for Roger Smith, the retiring chairman, from $700,000 to $1.2 million a year.
 
*
 
GNP Commodities Inc. and its chairman, Brian Monieson, were each fined $500,000 and expelled from the futures industry on Friday. Both are likely to appeal. Mr. Monieson is a former chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
 
*
 
Adobe Systems Inc. shares fell 15 1/4 to 35 1/4 on Friday after the computer software company predicted lower earnings.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY
 
A Few Signs of Life
 
The economy remains slack, but not as lifeless as the latest estimate of the gross national product implies. The Commerce Department said last week that first-quarter gross national product rose at an annual rate of just 1.3 percent, lower than the initial estimate of 2.1 percent. But much of the revision came from reduced inventories, especially of automobiles. Some economists say that factories will have to maintain or increase production to replenish their stocks. ''You have less of an inventory problem to put a damper on economic growth,'' said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities.
 
 
The Light Touch
 
President Bush has handled trade with China as delicately as a Ming vase. Last week, he announced his decision to renew China's most-favored-nation status for another year. Despite weeks of careful preparation - with lawmakers given statistics on how Chinese trade benefits their districts - Congressional leaders mauled his plans. But they will have trouble gathering two-thirds of each house to deny continued trade privileges. The President said at the same time that he will not ease trade with the Soviet Union as long as the Lithuanian dispute continues.
 
 
In Brief
 
President Bush vetoed a bill on Thursday to continue subsidizing Amtrak, with $700 million in the coming year.
 
*
 
The International Monetary Fund approved the resumption of aid to Argentina as Argentina and its bankers agreed to hold negotiations.
 
 
The Crisis Deepens
 
The Bush Administration acknowledged last week that twice as many savings and loans as expected would collapse. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told the Senate Banking Committee that more than 1,000 insitutions - 40 percent of the total - might eventually be seized. The Administration had insisted for more than a year that its estimates of bailout costs were adequate, even as regulators, Congressional officials and private analysts repeatedly raised their figures. Congress appropriated $73 billion for the bailout last year, but the job will take $89 billion to $130 billion, Mr. Brady said. Other Administration officials warned that increased Government borrowing to clean up the industry will raise interest rates and risk tipping the economy into a recession.

 
F.D.I.C. Fund Fades
 
The fund that insured the nation's savings and loan deposits has long been gone, and the fund for bank deposits is going. With $13.2 billion at the end of the year, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation had just 70 cents for each $100 in bank deposits, down from 80 cents in 1988. Some analysts say that bank failures will continue draining the fund this year. But as banks pay higher insurance premiums, the fund's health is likely to improve over several more years to the $1.25 level considered safe. Only a sharp recession and the collapse of several major banks might deplete it, analysts say. Then the banks, like the savings institutions, would need their own Federal bailout. Congress has pledged to stand behind all insured deposits no matter what happens.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
 
Gorbachev's Bizarre Play
 
Mikhail S. Gorbachev should have hired some slick American political consultants years ago. Run for President while you're popular, promise no higher food prices, win your mandate, they would have said. Then, when the economic crunch comes, blame it on Boris Yeltsin. Instead, Mr. Gorbachev is staking his economic program on a referendum this year. ''Truly bizarre,'' said Michael Mandelbaum, at the Council on Foreign Relations. ''It's the Soviet equivalent of a Hail Mary pass,'' a desperate throw by a losing quarterback. A plan approved last week would triple bread prices on July 1 before the vote, with other price increases to take effect Jan. 1. Mr. Mandelbaum said that the Soviet President's only hope for winning the referendum is to portray himself as an opponent of the status quo. ''If it turns into a referendum on his stewardship of the economy,'' said Mr. Mandelbaum, ''he's not in good shape.''
 
 
Soviet Oil Exports Likely to Rise
 
The Soviet Union is likely to get much more of its oil out of the ground and into world markets. Last week, the Soviet Union signed its first oil production agreement with a Western company, Elf Aquitaine Inc., of France. The Soviet Union is still the world's largest oil producer, but output and exports have been falling, and hard-currency earnings slipping, for years. Soviet extraction methods are primitive and inefficient, leaving a good deal of oil in the ground. As Marshall Goldman, of the Russian Research Center at Harvard, said, ''The Soviet Union is a very rich country in natural resources, but those resources have to be used intelligently.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: May 27, 1990,

SECTION: Section 4; Page 12, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 678 words

HEADLINE: New Taxes Without Fear

 BODY:
Your taxes are going up. President Bush knows that. Congress knows that. And according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, taxpayers know it too. Politicians might not admit that until after the November elections. But there is no other way to control the yawning deficit and still pay for needed Federal programs.
That need not, however, inspire fear and trembling. There are sensible ways to generate revenue without imposing unfair and onerous burdens. 
 
How Much?
Congress will undoubtedly amend the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget law to keep next year's deficit cut under $65 billion. But reducing the deficit that much might push the economy into a recession. Cutting the deficit by $30 billion would keep reductions headed steadily downward relative to the size of the overall economy. That's good enough. And it would be reasonable to raise half that, $15 billion, with tax increases.
 
Which Taxes?
The income tax would be the fairest. Boosting the 15 percent tax rate to 16 and the 28 percent rate to 30 would do the trick.
But there are two barriers. One is President Bush's obdurate refusal to contemplate income-tax hikes. The other is the bargain struck to achieve the 1986 tax reform. The top rate was lowered to 28 percent from 50, in exchange for eliminating most loopholes. That magnificent achievement should be unraveled only for dire necessity.
There's agitation in Congress to undo another part of the 1986 package, an anomaly known as the ''bubble.'' The law is written so that marginal tax rates jump from 28 to 33 percent on family income approximately between $75,000 and $200,000, and then fall back to 28. People make too much of the bubble. Even with it, the rich still pay higher taxes. The bubble, more ungainly than unfair, is not a compelling reason to breach the 1986 pact.
Taking everything into account, the best choice is higher energy taxes. They would raise revenue, conserve energy and fight pollution. They would fall on the rich and the poor alike, but Congress could readily compensate low-income families by, for instance, boosting the Earned Income Tax Credit.
And the best way to raise energy taxes would be to impose a small tax on all energy consumption -not just gasoline or oil. A tax as low as 5 percent would raise about $15 billion and still leave U.S. energy prices below those of Western Europe.
Another good option is to raise $10 billion a year with higher ''sin'' taxes on alcohol and tobacco. Energy and sin taxes, with offsets for the poor, could solve Congress's problem.
 
Index Capital Gains
Well, not quite. There is still the matter of capital gains - the increase in value of assets like stocks and bonds. President Bush insists on a highly ill-advised reduction in the tax rate on capital gains. The principle underlying the 1986 tax reform was to tax capital gains and wages alike.
The President does make a valid point, however. Despite identical tax rates, taxes end up unlike. The reason is inflation. Assets are often sold many years after purchase. Inflation in the interim raises the sale price even though the asset is actually worth less. Despite the loss in real value, the I.R.S. collects a tax.
The answer is to index capital gains: tax only the increase in value adjusted for inflation. But Congress should restrict indexing to new investments. Otherwise it would confer an indefensible windfall gain on individuals who invested with full knowledge of the existing tax laws.
To offset indexing or any other shortfall in collections, Congress can choose other sensible changes, like limiting the tax deductibility of fringe benefits. But even then, it would still have done only half its job. There will still be another $15 billion in deficit reduction that will have to come out of present programs. And those reductions will have to be made after a decade in which non-military programs have been starved.
But first Mr. Bush and Congress have to own up to what they already know. Sizable tax increases need not be forbidding, but they are necessary.
