HEADLINE: Today's NATO - and Tomorrow's

SERIES: Designs For Europe - An Occasional Series

BYLINE: By Stanley Hoffmann; Stanley Hoffmann is chairman of the Center for European Studies at Harvard.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Many American officials and strategic analysts seem to be making the preservation of NATO the principal objective of American policy in Europe. This goal makes sense in the short run. NATO is still the only organization that gives the U.S. a preponderant role in Europe, and it remains critical to preserving stability and balance there. But for the longer run, we need new institutions, and we had better begin thinking about them now.
And for both the long and short run, the West has to pay careful attention to the Soviet Union's humiliation arising from its loss of the cold war.
This blow could be softened if the Western allies made it clear that today's NATO -an integrated military alliance dominated by the U.S. - is entering its final phase and will need to be transformed when the period of European transition is over. 
American policy makers' devotion to NATO is understandable. NATO not only helped to safeguard peace in Europe through the worst years of the cold war, it also successfully managed the initially traumatic issue of West German rearmament.
NATO forces are also still needed to counterbalance Soviet forces. For reasons of policy, prestige and practicality, Soviet troops will not be removed entirely from what is still East Germany for some time. Some Soviet forces may remain in Poland as long as Poland is not fully reassured that Germany intends to abandon its claims on Polish areas that were once German.
Moreover, NATO as well as what is left of the Warsaw Pact will play a useful role in negotiating reductions of conventional forces and tactical nuclear weapons in Europe.
Above all, NATO is still needed as a home for Germany. Nobody has an interest in a neutralized and united Germany, unattached and tempted again to be a freewheeling major player or subject to fits of insecurity because of real or imagined threats from the East or West.
Why do the Soviets still talk about a neutralized Germany? Because a united Germany in NATO - even a Germany that guarantees that NATO forces will not move into the former East Germany - would be psychologically painful: it would symbolize the Soviet Union's loss of the political empire and Eastern European security buffer zone won in the war.
But Moscow has not pushed hard for a neutralized Germany because this goal has no support in Eastern Europe. The Soviet Union is not really convinced that a freewheeling Germany is in its long-term interest. Nor does Moscow have cards strong enough to insist on neutralization.
Neither are the Germans enticed by the idea of neutrality, because they do not want to risk repeating their history. And Moscow's threat to keep Soviet forces in East Germany until the Germans and their Western partners agree on a formula to remove Germany from NATO could boomerang. These forces would find themselves amid a hostile population, far from their homeland and isolated if Germany induced Poland to request the departure of Soviet troops from Polish soil.
In effect, the Soviets have already acknowledged the inevitability of German unity; it is remarkable that they have not tried to use their acceptance of unification to gain Bonn's agreement to certain security arrangements. At the least, they can try to obtain a reward for having made unification possible.
Such arrangements would include limits on German weapons and forces, which Germany and its NATO allies would have no reason to refuse; perhaps an agreement on the removal of U.S. nuclear weapons from German soil and an economic deal for German contributions to the failing Soviet economy.
Beyond these immediate issues, the need is for long-range thinking.
Against what enemy would today's NATO need to be preserved? None of the main hypotheses about the Soviet Union's future - a victory of perestroika, disintegration and civil strife, an authoritarian and repressive reaction against disorder and separatism - entails the likelihood of a Soviet military threat against Europe for many years, if at all.
How long, under these circumstances, would Germany want to remain a subordinate member of a U.S.-dominated alliance and to be the last occupied country in Europe? Not long. This would be especially true if U.S. forces remained in the western parts of Germany well after the Soviet troops left the eastern parts.
How long, indeed, will the American public and Congress want to pay for today's NATO once the Soviet threat has been removed, once the European members ''confront'' only far weaker, entirely friendly and Western-oriented Central and Eastern European nations, and once the only rationale for preserving the old NATO is ''stability''? (That code word means ''distrust of Germany,'' which, ironically, is America's most powerful NATO ally.) Can NATO's present structure be maintained once U.S. conventional and tactical nuclear forces are reduced? West Germany's army, NATO's largest, has been under direct U.S. command. How acceptable will this arrangement be to the Germans and other Europeans once the U.S. military presence has shrunk?
In the long run, a restructured European security order will have to be able to deter any Soviet threat - a concern likely to be especially intense among the now liberated Central and Eastern European countries.It must reassure all of Europe against the possible resurgence of German aggressiveness or militarism.
It must also provide an environment in which an economically and financially very powerful Germany will feel sufficiently secure to continue seeking influence and prestige through wealth - and the political benefits wealth brings - rather than through military might.
Finally, it must set up adequate procedures for peacefully resolving interstate and secessionist conflicts that traditional rivalries and ethnic tensions, especially in Central and Eastern Europe, might well provoke. It should also be prepared to contain and quickly end violence should attempts at peaceful settlement fail.
Given this multiplicity of aims, a diversity of institutions is the only sensible answer. Instead of the present NATO, we would need a system based on the North Atlantic treaty of 1949, which did not set up any integrated military structure but provided an American security guarantee to Western Europe.
The Council of Foreign Ministers of the signatories would be the foreign-policy coordinating body. And as long as some U.S. forces remained in Europe, organs for joint military planning and cooperation should persist.
The European Community ought gradually to take over the dominant security role in the alliance and set up a new Western European defense organization. It is the Community that is destined to insure that the ties between Germany and its partners are so numerous and strong that they cannot be severed. These ties would provide Germany with more influence than it would have if fully sovereign.
The road toward turning a potential single market into a political union -with a central bank, a common currency, coordinated diplomacy and a defense system that intimately links the now independent French and British nuclear deterrents and German conventional forces - is likely to be long.
The results may never resemble the Union that forms the United States. But European unification is by far the best solution for nations that realize that their national objectives can no longer be achieved by purely national means.
The new Western European defense organization ought to have the task of cooperating with the nations of Central and Eastern Europe to provide protection and deter or cope with any renewed Soviet threat.
Finally, the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe could provide the broadest security framework. It would limit the forces of all its members in such a way that Germany would not be singled out as the only country with special restrictions. It might ban the stationing of nuclear weapons in countries that have none of their own.
The conference could insure the participation of the U.S. and the Soviet Union in European security without providing them any possibility for renewed hegemony and could serve as the framework for procedures for settling European disputes.
In this intricate arrangement, separate alliances might well persist - for example, Western European countries and the U.S.; the Soviet Union and Poland. But there would be sufficient security, strong enough economic and political links in the European Community and close enough links between the Community and other European nations to divert Germany from nuclear ambitions. Such ambitions could only recreate the nightmare of anti-German coalitions that past German clumsiness and expansionism fostered.
Obviously, the superpowers' grip on Europe would be enormously loosened. But it is too late to try to preserve a crumbled bipolarity or to revive a Warsaw Pact whose main function was the management of a Soviet hegemony in Eastern Europe. Moreover, it is insulting to suggest that the Europeans, left to themselves, would make the same mess as before the two world wars. As the main victims of their errors, they, too, have learned a lot.
Today, peace and prosperity are the concerns - indeed, in Eastern Europe a desperate need - of all Europeans. The moment to build on their hopes and good dispositions is at hand.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
The League of Terror

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
The Presidential commission on terrorism in the air has turned in a report that is clear, thoughtful, brave and of commanding importance. Therefore the likelihood is that the Administration will try to shove it into oblivion as fast as possible.
That is not intended as cynicism. It is an interpretation of something very much in style these days in Washington - pragmatism. 
The report centers on the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 and the 270 lives lost in that act of mass murder. But its conclusions go to the heart of terrorism and how to fight it - with a policy of retaliation against the ''League of Terror,'' the governments that sponsor the murder gangs.
In the last five years alone, terrorist attacks against planes of a half-dozen countries have killed 1,030 people. Not one nation has taken retaliatory action.
In Washington, Bush Administration ''pragmatism'' on terrorism has meant doing nothing to take action against the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, General Command, the gang that blew up Pan Am 103, or its masters, Syria and Iran.
Nothing - although the Government knew almost from the beginning that Iran paid and dispatched the killers, that Syria gives them safe haven and that Libya supplies the murder gangs of the world with the special plastic explosive that destroyed Pan Am 103.
It is hard to think of anything the Administration has done publicly to fight terrorism stronger than saying thank you, thank you Syria and Iran, for any small bones of mercy they might throw us from time to time.
The report is full of criticism of air security - the Government's and Pan Am's - and has a long list of specific security recommendations. But in its analysis of terrorism and its policy for action, it has special importance going even beyond the tragedy of Pan Am 103.
These are the essentials of the analysis:
The victim world has been lurching from terrorist attack to attack, always caught without response strategy. Terrorism remains a deadly weapon of the weak and cowardly, cheap and effective enough to change the policies of major nations. Once terrorism was the isolated acts of individuals, now it is state-sponsored acts of war and aggression.
These are the essentials of the policy proposals against terrorism:
Zero tolerance. The U.S must take leadership. The American public must show and exercise a national will to fight terrorism and support Government action. Retaliation must be threatened and carried out, retaliation graded upward from political and diplomatic to economic to military attack against terrorist targets in the League of Terror states.
''The commission finds unacceptable the idea of holding ourselves in all cases to a criminal standard of proof before we act . . . The U.S. must be ready to view some terrorist attacks as a matter of security or an act of aggression.''
The President appointed the commission because of the determination of people who would not surrender -the families of the victims of Pan Am 103.
It turned out to be a runaway commission, polite but independent. Its members told the President the truth, knowing it would not appeal to him.
It was headed by Ann McLaughlin, a former Secretary of Labor, a strong leader. Other members were Representatives John P. Hammerschmidt, Republican of Arkansas, and James L. Oberstar, Democrat of Minnesota; former Secretary of the Navy Edward Hidalgo; Gen. Thomas C. Richards, Air Force, retired; and two Senators, Frank Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, and Alfonse D'Amato, the New York Republican who by his commission service earns dehexing for voting to uphold a Presidential veto of a bill protecting Chinese students.
Since the commission's most important recommendation is to make sure the terrorist states know they will pay a price, it carries a never-stated but implicit criticism of the existing do-nothing policy.
So what seems to await the report is a deep file drawer somewhere in the Executive Offices.
But if a policy of retaliation is not announced as a preventive warning and another American passenger plane is blown into scraps of metal and flesh, this report will creep out of that drawer to haunt the Administration.
So it is just possible that given enough public and Congressional courage now, the Administration will have to take account of the report and its plain words on terrorism.
We have that hope, thanks to the McLaughlin commission, which is better than what we have had so far - pragmatically, nothing.

HEADLINE: THE COUNTRY IN THE CITY: A GREAT NOTION LIVES ON IN BROOKLYN'S PROSPECT PARK

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
The weather willing, armies of picnickers, many lugging elaborate barbecuing gear, will descend on Prospect Park in Brooklyn this Memorial Day weekend. Others will come just to sit or sleep or sip in the Long Meadow -six times the size of the Sheep Meadow in Central Park and said to be the longest continuous open space in any American urban park.
The air will be filled with multifarious balls, Frisbees, model planes and the hypnotizing beat of Caribbean drums. ''Coming to the park is like taking a bath,'' said a 60-year-old man who has been a regular for half a century. ''I leave with a refreshed mind.'' 
This essay will stroll through the optimistic origins and triumphant rise of this 526-acre patch of green, pause to consider its decades-long decline, then let out a bit of a hoot over its resurgence.
By any measure, Prospect Park is a great achievement. And great achievements spring from confidence and fear. The park's birth in the middle of the last century reflected a separate municipality, then the nation's third largest, on the make and proud of it.
In the 1860's, the value of Brooklyn's manufactured goods and its population had both burgeoned. But just across the East River, Manhattan was growing faster and richer. Brooklyn was in danger of becoming a dumping ground for Gotham's most obnoxious industries, bone-boiling for one. And as the cost of Manhattan living surged, more poor people arrived on the busy ferries.
The American way is to marry economic need, almost always defined by class interest, with idealistic goals. By building a park arguably superior even to the newly completed Central Park, Brooklyn's city fathers hoped to lure affluent residents and increase the tax base.
So how marvelous that these hard-headed goals perfectly coincided with prevailing progressive ideology. Parks were seen as specks of sanity in sinister, dehumanizing cities. America might have been teeming with new immigrants, torn by new technologies and dominated by robber barons, but this was at heart an agrarian nation. There was also the thought that parks might act as a civilizing influence on the foreign hordes, perhaps making them less prone to riot.
Using designs owing much to the picturesque tradition of English landscape design, they used heavy equipment to contrive bucolic settings in emphatically non-rural areas. Sort of no-charge theme parks for would-be Daniel Boones with 12-hour-a-day factory jobs.
 
The Masters of Design
 Enter the kings of park design. Frederick Law Olmsted, a social philosopher, and Calvert Vaux, an architect, first collaborated on Central Park, begun in 1859. Prospect Park, begun in 1866, was their next achievement, the one Olmsted always deemed greatest. These two visionaries working together, and then Olmsted working alone, would leave their mark on magnificent parks from Buffalo to Chicago to Montreal to Seattle to the Capitol.
The Olmstedian vision has a distinctly anti-urban tinge: cities were hells to escape. His idea was to find ''the greatest possible contrast with the restraining and confining conditions of the town, those conditions which compel us to walk circumspectly, watchfully, jealously, which compel us to look closely upon others without sympathy.''
From the beginning, Prospect Park fulfilled its joyful purpose. Sepia photographs show Sunday-only gentry and a flock of sheep crowded on the Long Meadow. There was a wind-powered carousel on the lake, a penful of deer in the woods. Traditions coalesced: fishing contests, ice carnivals, Maypole dancing.
Then came ornate Italianate buildings like the boathouse, sitting well with popular taste. In the 1930's, Parks Commissioner and master planner Robert Moses brought more pedestrian but utilitarian things - a zoo, bandshell and skating rink with all the charm of a freeway Howard Johnson's. On an obscure hillside, the Quaker cemetery endured.
But after the Korean War, the world and Prospect Park changed. Soldiers bought houses in the suburbs; poor blacks forced from their homes by urban renewal landed in the houses of those who left. By the 1960's, the Dodgers and neighboring Ebbets Field were history and Brooklyn was a sadder place. The Goldman Band, which had played free concerts in the park since 1918, saw attendance drop, particularly at the once popular ''Music of Eastern Europe'' and Italian programs.
By the mid-1970's, the fiscal crisis had dealt more brutal blows. Maintenance grew dreadful; buildings were boarded up. A poll showed 44 percent of New Yorkers thought no one should ever venture into the park.
But as money came back to the city, Brooklyn brownstones started to look good to a housing-hungry city, and people came back to the park, too. Ever more hesitantly, the sun peeked over the horizon.
It rose with the appointment in 1980 of a permanent Prospect Park Administrator, the utterly peripetatic Tupper Thomas. She begins her day walking her labrador, Sheffield, in the park, and is liable to drive trucks, press higher-ups for more funds and personally greet visitors.
A torrent of volunteers has also descended. On Thursdays, adults come; on Saturday, children. On Sundays, the Brooklyn Bird Club works on a wildflower meadow atop Lookout Hill. The city has not been silent, spending almost $50 million on 14 big projects in the park's most recent decade. The long-neglected woods are looking a bit more like Olmsted and Vaux designed them.
 
Helping Hands
 Then there are the 250 auxiliary police to reassure the new waves of visitors, and the Prospect Park Alliance, formed in 1987 by prominent private citizens deeply committed to the park. Though much poorer than the Central Park Conservancy, Ms. Thomas says, the alliance represents a watchdog, a high-powered independent advocate in case City Hall ''drops the ball.''
Today's dangling question mark is whether a financially strapped New York can afford what Robert Moses called ''the immediate jewel of Brooklyn's crown.'' But in the sweep of history, Ms. Thomas sees only a minor interruption in Prospect Park's uphill course. Brooklynites will demand nothing less.
So let us sing the praises of the Long Meadow that somehow seems to rise from both directions. Let us marvel at that superbly unruly Camperdown elm memorialized in Marianne Moore's poem. And let us check out the events that draw people to the park in groups of every size: the Metropolitan Opera and New York Philharmonic, lectures on the history of slavery in Brooklyn, quilting classes.
And let us be surprised, for this is a surprising park. The Haitian artist, Deenps Bazile, who carves stumps into magnificent African visages. Three homeless men living in the Music Pagoda who regularly volunteer for park improvement projects. A restored zoo and carousel, both now happening. Two perfect lovers who the other day sat on a blanket with a bottle of champagne, a single rose in a crystal vase and each other.

HEADLINE: Glasnost Byproduct: Virulent Anti-Semitism

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Some of your readers might think that Irina Ginsburg, the Moscow novelist, was exaggerating when she declared, ''We Russian Jews Fear for Our Lives'' (Op-Ed, May 5). But as non-Jews who have visited Moscow several times over the past few years, most recently in March, we can confirm that anti-Semitism is indeed on the rise in the Soviet Union and presents a serious threat to Soviet Jews.
The paradox of glasnost is that it has opened up the media not simply to calls for freedom and justice but also to the raw anti-Semitism of members of the ultra-rightwing nationalist organization Pamyat and kindred individuals and groups. Prospective members of Pamyat must submit the names and addresses of five Jews; three names and addresses are sufficient if they belong to Jews ''trying to conceal their Jewishness.'' As a Pamyat leader asserted recently, those ''hidden Jews,'' seeking to attack Russian culture from the inside, are the nation's most dangerous enemies. 
There is an obvious parallel between Soviet society today and German society prior to the rise of Hitler. Here again is a weak democracy -really, a democracy in its infancy -where the leadership has no popular support, including Mikhail Gorbachev. Economic collapse seems imminent. Just as Germany went through the hyper-inflation of the 1920's, so Russians find their rubles growing increasingly worthless. (In March, we could not find a single cab driver who would take us anywhere for rubles; packs of American cigarettes are the required currency.) In the midst of the growing corruption, Russians feel frustrated and angry. We listened in Moscow apartments to fears of famine in the countryside within a year, accompanied by street demonstrations and riots in Moscow itself. Such anxieties piled on top of justified exasperation over the denigration of Russian culture during much of the Soviet period makes many Russians give in to the all-too-human desire to find a scapegoat. Inevitably, the old belief in the Jew as the source of the Russians' troubles has re-emerged.
Some Russians do condemn anti-Semitism and call upon their compatriots to accept responsibility for the present crisis, but theirs are voices in the wilderness. All too many want to believe that the Jews are guilty, just as the Germans eagerly accepted Hitler's claim that they were responsible, in some vague manner, for Germany's defeat in World War I. What is particularly distressing about the anti-Semitic wave in Moscow is that it is being led by writers and other intellectuals. While conducting interviews for our book ''Inside the Soviet Writers' Union'' [reviewed April 11], we were treated to the most breathtaking expressions of raw anti-Semitism from privileged members of the organization. Seemingly sophisticated and sensible persons asserted that Jews had been responsible for the terror-famine in the Ukraine, which the Soviet press has now acknowledged starved millions to death. That Lazar Kaganovich, a member of Stalin's Politburo, was a Jew proved the Jews' guilt.
A leading figure in the Russian nationalist, anti-Jewish movement is Igor Shafarevich, a close friend of Alexander Solzhenitsyn and a corresponding member of the Soviet Academy of Sciences. Shafarevich, following Solzhenitsyn's example, has popularized the term ''Russophobe'' as a codeword for Jew.
The Russian Republic branch of the Writers' Union has as members many well-known Soviet writers who have used the pages of journals under the union's jurisdiction for the worst sort of hatred of the Jews. The journal Nash Sovremennik carried the allegation that the Jews themselves were responsible for the murder of Jews at Dachau and Auschwitz. Valentin Rasputin, a respected writer who has just been appointed to Mr. Gorbachev's Presidential Council, stated that the Jews ''killed God'' and were responsible for the October Revolution and the mass terror that followed it (New York Times Magazine, Jan. 28).
The transcripts of meetings of the Russian Republic branch of the Writers' Union read like accounts of speeches at Nazi rallies in the 1930's. Jews who are major figures in Russian literature, such as Babel, Pasternak, Grossman, are said to belong to ''literature in the Russian language,'' not Russian literature proper. Anyone who opposes these views is condemned as a Jew, whether or not he is Jewish. In other words, the very word Jew has become a term of abuse.
Things are falling apart inside the Soviet Union. The center is not holding, and yet another ''blood-dimmed tide'' is gathering strength. Before its fury is loosed upon the world, let us hope that the intended victims are able to escape.
 
JOHN GARRARD
 
CAROL E. GARRARD
 Tucson, Ariz., May 12, 1990
 
The writers are, respectively, professor of Russian literature at the University of Arizona and adjunct professor at the University of Phoenix.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Israel Looks Around, and Finds New Cause to Worry

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
Israelis are casting a wary eye on the summit meeting of Arab leaders that begins Monday in Baghdad, conscious of a resurgent mood of belligerence that Israel has not had to face in more than a decade.
The Israelis have been weaned on fear of the Arab world that surrounds them, and they have always been skeptical about the steadfastness of Western support. Now they see both the Arabs and the West trying to force them into radically changing the policies they have followed in the Arab territories of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which they have occupied since 1967.
Conversations in the last week with Israeli officials, political and military analysts, academics and ordinary citizens showed four major worries: Israelis fear the rise of a new threat from an eastern military coalition led by Iraq, they lament the evident loss of active support by the West, they are perplexed as they watch Egypt return to the Arab fold, and they are appalled at the inability of their politicians to form a government that can put forward a coherent policy to face these challenges. 
Foremost is what the country's military establishment views as a dangerous political alliance being forged between Jordan, the Palestine Liberation Organization and Iraq, whose President, Saddam Hussein, has threatened to scorch half of Israel if it attacks his country.
 
The Hussein Alliance
 For almost 20 years, King Hussein of Jordan was viewed as an Arab ruler with whom Israel had reached a tacit understanding of non-aggression. But now Israelis are watching with astonishment as the King moves into what they believe to be a growing military, political and economic reliance on Iraq.
Alarm bells rang loudly here recently when Jordan allowed Iraqi air force planes to fly along its borders with Israel, and even louder when the King enthusiastically supported the Iraqi President's insistence on Baghdad's right to produce chemical weapons and to seek to match Israel's nuclear capability.
''The entire volume of King Hussein's involvement with Saddam goes far beyond what is considered natural geopolitical considerations,'' commented Yosi Olmert, an expert on Middle East affairs.
Egypt's recent efforts to broker a Syrian-Iraqi reconciliation, thus bringing Syria too back into the Arab fold, could heighten the threat to Israel, said Ehud Ya'ari, a writer and television commentator, by raising ''the specter of a military Arab alliance to our east.''
Israeli politicians are also concerned about the palpable decline of expressions of support that they see coming from Israel's closest ally, the United States. And they worry over the cooling of ties with Western Europe, where pro-Palestinian sentiment is becoming more pronounced.
Others are distressed at the drift of Egypt, the only Arab country that has a peace treaty with Israel, to a not-so-friendly common Arab front.
Many Israelis say the most immediate danger is that the intifada, the 29-month-old uprising of Palestinians against the occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, will spread beyond the occupied lands.
Last week the revolt crossed the ''velvet line'' dividing the occupied territories from Israel, and reached into the towns where the estimated 650,000 to 800,000 Arab citizens of Israel have lived since 1948.
Perhaps more significantly, the revolt shook the refugee camps in neighboring Jordan where hundreds of thousands of Palestinians live. This left King Hussein caught between the threat of an intifada by Palestinians on his own soil and a mounting challenge from Muslim fundamentalists at home, while he also tries to fix a shaky economy.
''The worst thing of all would be if everything falls apart in Jordan, forcing the King to seek Iraqi materiel or military assistance,'' said Mark Heller, a Middle East affairs expert at the Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies in Tel Aviv. ''This would eliminate Jordan as a buffer between us and the Iraqis. Then everyone could lose control.''
Even the issue foremost on the minds of most Israelis - the inability over the last eight weeks of either major political party to form a government after the latest inconclusive elections - may be intractable.
The problem is so difficult, in the view of Zeev Schiff, defense affairs editor of the daily newspaper Haaretz, because it is intimately tied to a similarly intractrable problem -''the outcome of the Palestinian intifada and the Palestinian problem.''
Speaking of the riots this week that followed the slaying on Sunday of seven Palestinians by an Israeli gunman who the authorities said was deranged, a senior Israeli official expressed fear that events are headed for an explosion. ''With the intifada reaching a turning point this week, there is more room for miscalculations all around,'' the official said.
About the only certainty in the view of Israelis and Palestinian analysts here is that the tensions could transform the conflict between Palestinians and Israelis into a regional one. ''Since the peace with Egypt 10 years ago, the conflict has been an introverted conflict between us and the Palestinians,'' Mr. Schiff said. ''Now the Arab world is dragging it back into being an Arab-Israeli conflict.''
Israelis who preferred to believe that their conflict with the Palestinians could be insulated from the wider Arab world are clearly reassessing strategies after this last bloody week, when at least 23 Palestinians died and nearly 900 were injured in the rioting that followed the shooting of the seven Palestinians.
What the Israelis cannot agree on is whether a settlement with Arab nations like Egypt, Syria or Jordan would be enough to eliminate the Palestinian problem, as hard-liners insist, or, as liberals say, that a deal exchanging land for peace with Palestinians under occupation would be enough to end Israel's confrontation with Arab nations.
Either way, Professor Heller asserts, the Arab meeting on Monday will again make it clear that ''the Palestinians are at the center of all Arab politics that concern Israel.''

LENGTH: 957 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Tear Gas Clears, The Tensions Remain

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: KWANGJU, South Korea

 BODY:
When student protests commemorating a massacre of demonstrators here 10 years ago slowly tailed off and then stopped, there was almost a palpable sigh of relief from Koreans. After a decade of persistent violence in the streets, most Koreans seem eager to put the disruptions behind them and breathe in some of the country's air of economic success rather than tear gas.
Few mistake the relief for optimism, however. The streets, for now, may not be the favored venue for airing grievances, but many experts say the kind of frustrations that fed the violence remain, fueled by lopsided government development policies that have left important regions feeling left out of the country's economic miracle. 
As many scholars and some politicians here note, the growing problem of Korean regionalism is particularly surprising for a country that will soon be the last to suffer from the painful and highly emotional effects of a Communist-enforced division. Yet the problem seems to be growing.
Some of the dissatisfaction is felt in the northwest, but nowhere is the anger being expressed more poignantly than in South Cholla province, where Kwangju, a flat, dusty university town of a million residents, is the capital. Cholla takes up most of the southwest tip of the divided Korean peninsula, an emerald mosaic of rice paddies punctuated with craggy mountains. Handsome though that landscape may be, the people here are resentful when they compare it with the neighboring province.
Just a few miles to the east, in Kyong-san province, is an often less attractive but more prosperous landscape that houses Korea's largest auto plants, shipbuilding yards and ports, all constructed within the last few decades under the firm hand of Korea's authoritarian governments. The government decides where to focus that development, and Cholla has received little.
Song In-Sung, a specialist in regional development at Chonnam National University in Kwangju, said the central problem is relatively simple: those in power accumulate most of the wealth, and those in power have traditionally been from Seoul or the eastern provinces. Seoul, he said, has about a third of South Korea's population and about 80 percent of its wealth.
He cited figures laying out the problem even more bluntly: in the last 30 years, the population of South Korea has doubled; in that time, the population of South Cholla has declined slightly as young people fled the hard life on farms for the cities.
That, he said, has only made things worse, because when they move to the cities, these former farmers bring their simple ways and tend to take the lowest level jobs. That has made being from Cholla something of a stigma in the eyes of many Koreans; a businessman here complained that, in Korean movies, petty criminals often have distinctive Cholla accents.
It does not help that the United States is demanding that Korea open its agricultural markets. Farm imports would clearly hurt Cholla province more than other regions, so these demands have fed anti-Americanism among students here.
Yoo Jong-Hae, a professor of public administration at Yonsei University in Seoul, has studied another facet of the problem -the numbers of people from Cholla in key sectors of government and industry.
''They just do not have any means of entry into the government,'' he said, pointing to figures he had collected on the paucity of people from Cholla in the police, customs offices, the military, the civil service, even big corporations and major banks.
Mr. Yoo added, ''all they can do is join the PPD,'' or the Party for Peace and Democracy, the power base of Korea's best known opposition leader, Kim Dae Jung, who is also Cholla's most famous native son. Mr. Kim and his Cholla-based party were conspicuously the only big opposition group left out of a recent merger between the ruling party and two other opposition groups, isolating Cholla even further.
 
Feelings of Frustration
 ''Their grievance is right,'' Mr. Yoo said. ''They feel total frustration.'' The government has proposed a new development program to try to alleviate these imbalances. Under the plan, funds would be poured into better highways, rail lines, airports and industrial plants. The overall goal would be to prepare this region for a burst in trade with China, just off Korea's western shores. The two countries do not have diplomatic relations because China recognizes Communist North Korea, but they have been warming up to each other slowly and expanding trade.
Many are skeptical of the plan. Substantial growth in the China trade still seems a long way off. And the Korean legislature has yet to show much enthusiasm, Mr. Song said, for committing to Cholla large sums that might be spent in the home districts of the new ruling party's members.
''The western development program has been effective - as a slogan,'' said Mr. Yoo.
Kwangju's history of student demonstrations has also hurt Cholla's image in the rest of Korea. It has created an impression that people from Cholla are combative and more prone to violence. Cholla residents complain that the national government is quicker to use force on demonstrators in their region, as evidenced by the brutal killings in Kwangju 10 years ago, when at least 200 pro-democracy demonstrators were slain by troops.
''There is only one answer, which is more government investment in things like infrastructure,'' Mr. Song said in his sunny office last week, high above a gathering of students attending a funeral for a young man killed accidentally during the most recent demonstrations. ''They don't want to take the first step, but I can assure you, there would be an immediate response if they really made the investment.''

The province has been bypassed by the country's prosperity. (Associated Press); map: South Korea indicating South Cholla (The New York Times)

PUB-DATE: May 27, 1990,

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1, Column 2; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1318 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Deficit Reduction, Phase 1: The Staring

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For all the hand-wringing on Capitol Hill and at the White House over how to cut the budget deficit, the truth is that are infinite possibilities.
Want to save a quick $3 billion in 1991? Make the Federal Aviation Administration a private corporation. Looking for bigger savings? Eliminate cost-of-living increases for a year on Social Security and Railroad Retirement benefits and squeeze $7.6 billion out of the 1991 deficit. Or go for the grand slam: impose a 5 percent value-added tax, in effect a national sales tax, to raise $89 billion by 1992 and $532 billion over five years.
If it were really that simple, the mutually suspicious Democrats and Republicans called together by President Bush for a ''budget summit'' would not have spent the last two weeks staring at each other across the conference table waiting to see who blinks first. After four sessions, largely devoted to an Administration tutorial on the deficit, the economy and the rising costs of the savings and loan bailout, about the only thing the participants have agreed to is holding some more meetings when Congress returns from a Memorial Day recess on June 5. 
''These first meetings were a testing of the willingness of each side to participate in good-faith negotiations,'' said Representative Leon Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee. ''We haven't gotten to the hard stuff.''
The hard stuff is deciding what combination of spending cuts and tax increases can be cobbled together to make a credible assault on what now looms as a deficit of somewhere between $138 billion and $199 billion for the 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1. But the really hard stuff is spreading the political pain and blame evenly enough so that neither party can bludgeon the other for what finally emerges.
Senator Wyche Fowler, the Georgia Democrat who is serving as Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell's representative at the talks, says that a genuine concern for all the Congressional negotiators is that even if they painfully come to an agreement among themselves, they will leave the talks only to find that they do not have enough troops waiting to follow. It is one reason that the participants have been so edgy about discussing their discussions.
To the extent that they are talking publicly at all about what they would like to see in the way of deficit reduction, the numbers are extraordinarily ambitious. Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Senate Budget Committee, speaks of a $60 billion deficit cut in 1991 and a cut of $600 billion over five years. Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the senior Republican on the budget panel, says that $45 billion to $50 billion for 1991 and $450 billion to $500 billion over five years is more realistic.
In each instance, the magnitude of deficit reduction is far greater than anything Congress has ever attempted, let alone achieved. Privately, lawmakers in both parties acknowledge that even their own best efforts at this point fall short of the goals they have proclaimed.
''Without using the traditional smoke and mirrors process, you're talking about some very tough political choices that have to be made on defense, entitlements and taxes to make the numbers add up,'' Mr. Panetta said.
Senator Alan K. Simpson, a Wyoming Republican known for not mincing words, put it more bluntly. ''We all know what we have to do, and it's ghastly,'' he said.
If and when the negotiators finally lay their cards on the table, they will be looking at four main ways to cut the deficit: the military budget, which accounts for about one-fourth of total Federal spending; the so-called entitlements, like Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, food stamps, farm subsidies and veterans' benefits, which account for about half; a category of ''discretionary'' programs, which includes everything that is not an entitlement or not part of the military budget; and tax increases.
Over the last decade, the discretionary programs, accounting for roughly 17 percent of Federal spending, have borne the brunt of budget-cutting. House Democrats vowed this year to begin devoting some new dollars to them, earmarking about $5 billion in their 1991 budget for areas like education, housing and basic research.
Republicans, who would also like to see increases in some of these areas, maintain that the additional spending has to be offset by cuts in other discretionary programs. But they have not said where, and privately lawmakers on both sides admit that their estimates of what will be saved or spent on discretionary programs are more wishful thinking than realistic possibilities.
Reducing spending on the entitlement programs, which grow automatically, is politically perilous, especially in an election year. Lawmakers assume that they can eke out several billion dollars in savings by reducing Medicare reimbursement rates for physicians and hospitals. But any significant savings would have to come from actual reductions in benefits. That probably means paring farm subsidies, freezing annual cost-of-living adjustments, or perhaps taxing a larger portion of benefit income for wealthier Social Security recipients. So far, neither party is willing to publicly embrace those options. That leaves the military budget and taxes. ''You've got the classic problem here of Democrats looking at the defense budget as a place where substantial cuts can be made, and you've got Republicans saying let's cut the entitlements,'' Senator Sasser said. ''Neither side is saying let's restore the revenue base because that means raising taxes.''
Enter George Bush, whose views on the subject of tax increases, or for that matter any other aspect of deficit reduction, remain a mystery to the Democrats in the budget summit. They insist that the President will have to be the first to call for tax increases.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said no one wants to claim parentage for such a plan. ''Somewhere along the line, we'll have to find a piece of paper on the table,'' he said, ''and of course nobody will know where it came from.''
In the meantime, the only revenue number any of the negotiators will publicly own up to is the $20 billion in the now-outdated budget that Mr. Bush submitted to Congress in January.
His ''read my lips'' pledges notwithstanding, the President called for $13.9 billion in increased revenue and about $6 billion in assorted ''user fees.''
The President has again proposed cutting the capital gains tax rate, a plan the Democrats say would mainly benefit the wealthiest Americans. In return, they will likely demand an increase in the top income tax rate for upper-income taxpayers. Under the current law, those with the highest incomes pay a top rate of 28 percent, while those just below pay a top rate of 33 percent.
Other tax ideas bandied about - whenever negotiators forget that they are not going to talk about them until Mr. Bush does - are a rise in the gasoline tax and an oil import fee. The two are generally paired on the theory that the combination would neutralize conflicting regional interests of the West and the Northeast.
Increasing excise taxes on beer, wine, spirits and tobacco is a perennial possibility, and a one-year halt in the adjustment of tax brackets for inflation is often mentioned as a quid pro quo for any freeze in retirees' cost-of-living adjustments. Several months ago, the House Ways and Means Committee Chairman, Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, proposed all of these tax increases and a domestic spending freeze as a challenge to the Administration.
Now, as part of the Democratic negotiating team, he figures it's the President's turn to ante up. As he told his colleagues during one recent session, ''I received an invitiation to this garden party, and I'm not bringing the bread and I'm not bringing the wine.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: May 27, 1990,

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1, Column 2; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1956 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
TIME TO DEAL?

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As he meets with President Bush this week, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has an overriding interest in more trade with the United States as the key to restructuring the Soviet economy and integrating it into the world economy.
He is hoping President Bush will end more than a half-century of trade discrimination against Moscow by offering most-favored-nation status, which would allow the lowest possible tariffs on imports from the Soviet Union.
Regardless of whether that happens at this meeting, the Soviet President has little choice but to bank on closer commercial ties with the United States in the long term. For when he talks about trade with this country, he means it in the broadest sense: a flow of investments, technology and finance needed to help invigorate Soviet industry and agriculture and get more goods on the shelves for Soviet consumers.
For the United States, a commitment to sound commercial relations with the Soviet Union would be both a chance to get an early toehold in a potentially lucrative market and a vote of confidence in the Soviet economic reform process - and in Mr. Gorbachev as he struggles to put those reforms in place. 
 
'Trade Relationships Are Pivotal'
 ''It is of central importance to Gorbachev that this agreement be signed during the summit because economic and trade relationships are pivotal to the Soviet Union at this time and supersede the importance of the arms control agenda,'' said Roger W. Robinson Jr., former chief economist at the National Security Council.
But there are obstacles to any agreement to grant favorable trade status, and it is far from certain that a pact will be signed this week. The Jackson-Vanik amendment to the Trade Act of 1974 bars trade concessions to countries that impede free emigration, and President Bush told Mr. Gorbachev at their previous meeting, in Malta, that he would seek a waiver that would give the Soviets the favored trade status once the Soviets codified their emigration law. Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union has now risen dramatically, and the emigration bill is awaiting action in the Supreme Soviet, but the summit meeting is likely to begin before the Supreme Soviet acts.
Now a new test has emerged for offering the tariff concession - the way Moscow deals with the issue of independence. President Bush noted last week that Moscow's sanctions against Lithuania had generated ''a political climate in this country that would make it extraordinarily difficult to grant'' favorable trade status to the Soviets, although it was renewed for a more hard-line Beijing.
''I think he knows that we're not trying to undermine him or make his life complicated for him,'' the President said of Mr. Gorbachev on Thursday. ''But we have certain differences with the Soviet Union, which I'll be perfectly prepared to talk about.''
As seen by the maneuvering over the trade pact, questions arise over how far the United States will actually go in normalizing the economic relationship. Some want Washington to maintain economic pressures to further weaken the Soviet empire and reduce a still existing military threat. Others argue that since the Soviet Union remains the one country with a nuclear arsenal that could destroy the United States, it is far better to pursue peaceful competition and cooperation and slowly work to bring the Soviet Union into the world economic community.
The Bush Administration has already taken a step in this direction by approving Soviet observer status in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which promotes freer trade in the world.
''Establishing an international climate that allows Soviet leaders to focus on domestic reform would be a major U.S. contribution,'' said a Harvard international security specialist, Joseph S. Nye Jr., in a new book, ''Bound to Lead.''
Although a stronger Soviet Union could again threaten the United States, its precipitious decline presents even greater risks.
''Who's the enemy?'' asked President Bush. ''Instability and unpredictability. I would repeat that I don't want to have two ships pass in the night, the Soviet Union and the United States.''
Here is an outline of what the Soviet Union and the United States want from a trade agreement.
 
Commerce
 
So Many People, So Few Goods
 In 1989 the United States and the Soviet Union traded goods worth about $5 billion. Largely because the Soviets are big buyers of American grain, the United States enjoys a huge trade surplus, one of the few countries with which the United States is in such a position. Last year the surplus was $3.5 billion.
Although there could be flourishing long-term trade expansion, no one expects any short-term surges. Other obstacles remain. The Soviet Union's lack of hard currency means American companies would have to continue entering into barter arrangements to sell their wares. Payment is in Soviet goods that they undertake to sell in world markets. Meanwhile, there is little the Soviets now produce that Americans want.
But in such specific sectors as nitrogen fertilzers, ferroalloys, nonferrous metals, furs, textiles, paper, chemicals and structural steel, some import increases are possible with lower tariffs.
Given high-running protectionist feelings, domestic producers of these items, particularly textiles, are likely to complain about intensified price competition, possible worker displacement and financial woes arising from the imports.
Despite the short-term prospects, some American companies express keen interest in the Soviet market of 280 million people, one of the last big markets where there is no real Western competition.
''The economic rationale for expanded trade is overwhelming,'' said Dwayne O. Andreas, president of the Archer Daniels Midland Company, a leading agricultural exporter. ''I estimate we could double our agricultural sales to the Soviet Union if we would simply open our doors and give them the opportunity to sell to us on the same terms and conditions as other countries.''
American companies see their Western European and Japanese competitors rushing into the market, leaving the United States at a competitive disadvantage.
 
Investment
 
'Thanks for Using A.T.&T. Moscow'
Should the United States finally offer the concessions needed to normalize trade relations, investment activity could pick up dramatically.
Latest Soviet figures indicate there are about 1,400 joint ventures between Soviet enterprises and Western companies. Of these a relatively modest 140 are with American companies.
Consultants and law and accounting firms lead the way, but many leading American multinational companies have been studying such operations as well.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has just signed an agreement with the Soviet Ministry of Communications to explore future joint ventures that would include such activities as telecommunications services, research and development and equipment manufacturing. It also participates in a consortium led by U S West to build a trans-Siberian fiber-optic cable telecommunications link between Europe and Asia.
The American Trade Consortium, including Chevron, Eastman Kodak, Johnson & Johnson, Archer Daniels Midland and RJR Nabisco, has a number of joint ventures under negotiation ''in varying stages of completion,'' according to a spokesman.
The Soviets are enthusiastic about making deals with Americans. But American officals complain that the one thing the Soviets don't seem to understand is the reality of what they will have to do on hard currency.
''Their needs for it are desperate,'' said John A. Hinds, president of AT&T International. ''But still they don't seem to understand that Western entities have to get hard currency out at some point, to derive benefits of some kind.'' Another problem is the controls that the United States maintains against the flow of possibly militarily useful high technology to the Soviets.
 
Technology
 
The Password Is Computer
The United States and 16 other Western countries are members of the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, or Cocom, which has been working since the early cold war years to deny the Soviet Union the industrial know-how to make war.
Political changes in Eastern Europe and the virtual disappearance of the Warsaw Pact have led Cocom to revamp its controls policy, aiming at higher walls around fewer products. But some now wonder why it is necessary to have the controls at all. Without strong strategic reasons for doing so, many countries may be unwilling to keep restrictions on their exporters for very long.
''We are entering an era in which small technical adjustments in our export controls are no longer appropriate,'' said Charles E. Hugel, chairman of ASEA Brown Boveri Inc., a big European-based power equipment company.
Under pressure from European allies and the business community, the Bush Administration proposed last month to reduce 25 percent of the categories on Cocom's industrial list. But such action would still keep most advanced telecommunications equipment and computers out of Soviet and Eastern European hands. The proposals also would make it easier for Eastern Europe to get the technology than the Soviet Union, which many West Europeans regard as impractical.
 
Finance
 
Comrade, Can You Spare a Billion?
A trade agreement is expected to be followed by a bilateral investment treaty that would make the Soviet Union eligible for a number of American programs, such as Export-Import Bank credits and insurance from the Overseas Private Insurance Corporation.
Another agreement the Soviets are likely to reach with the United States would be important in terms of financial flows. This is the pact to settle an estimated $1.52 billion of World War II lend-lease and other Soviet debts to the United States. Moscow would then be free to raise money in the American bond market for the first time.
But the Soviet Union is now in arrears in its payments to many of its major suppliers from the West and Japan. The Center for Security Policy, a Washington-based policy research organization, places late payments owed to Western companies in the range of $2 billion to $3 billion.
The Soviet financial troubles have hit at a time when many American banks and investment houses are still holding devalued third world debt and are not anxious to make new foreign commitments.
 
Prospects
 
Other Fish In the Sea
 Should trade curbs and other economic restraints be maintained by the United States, Moscow still has Western Europe and possibly Japan as potential partners.
Continued Soviet occupation of four islands seized in 1945 off Hokkaido has kept a lid on the Japanese relationship, but the islands issue is expected to be resolved by next spring, when Mr. Gorbachev visits Tokyo.
West German aid offers so far are substantial, including bank credits, money for the continued stationing of the Soviet Union's 380,000 troops in East Germany and the pledged assumption of East Germany's supply contracts with the Soviet Union once the two Germanys are united.
One reason the United States is so important to Moscow is that politically the Soviets cannot tolerate a reliance on Western Europe dominated by Germany.
Already the largest bank in Poland is the Deutsche Bank. That it or other German institutions could dominate portions of commerce in the Soviet Union is unacceptable.
From Washington's point of view, the economic changes in the Soviet Union seem to offer a real chance to set the world on a new course. One American businessman weighing a Soviet connection recalled an old Russian proverb: ''Fat people don't dig foxholes.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: May 27, 1990,

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3, Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1255 words

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory

 BODY:

Talks Stumble On Expanding Soviet Flights
WASHINGTON Amid all the talk about nuclear missiles and the realignment of Europe in Soviet-American relations, the United States and Soviet Union have been working on something promising more practical impact on Americans' lives - a new agreement on commercial airline traffic.
Prospects for signing the accord when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev comes to Washington this week seemed to have fallen through last week.
But once the tough issues are resolved, a new agreement should make it easier for American travelers to get a firsthand view of glasnost and perestroika, not to mention Red Square.
Currently, Pan Am is the only American airline that flies directly to the Soviet Union, with four afternoon flights each week to Moscow and Leningrad from Washington and New York.
The proposed agreement would expand the number of United States carriers that can fly to those cities. It also would open four cities in the western part of the Soviet Union - Kiev, Riga, Minsk and Tbilisi - and two cities in the Far Eastern region - Magadan and Khabarovsk, the eastern terminus of the trans-Siberian Railroad - to American carriers. 
With five or six United States airlines expressing interest in the routes, flights could become available from virtually every region of the United States.
For those who would like to travel on the Soviet airline, Aeroflot, which now flies only to New York and Washington, the proposals would allow Aeroflot to fly to Chicago and Miami and to San Francisco, with a stop in Anchorage.
Many details have not been worked out, including precise schedules, a final agreement on the new Soviet destinations and the toughest question of all: whether American companies will be allowed to sell tickets to Russians for rubles. All that may delay the moment when a traveler in Chicago, say, or Atlanta will be able to call a travel agent and ask, ''What's the supersaver fare to Moscow and how much frequent flier mileage will I earn?'' - ANDREW ROSENTHAL
 
Airlines Offer Terror 'Bounty'
United States airlines are teaming up with the Federal Government to deter terrorist attacks as the summer tourist season nears. The Air Transport Association, a Washington-based organization of major commercial carriers, is offering a bounty of up to $1 million for information that either prevents a terrorist attack or leads to the arrest and conviction of terrorists responsible for attacks against United States airlines.
The $1 million will supplement a $2 million reward offered by the State Department, according to Stephen D. Hayes, vice president of the association.
''We think this might be a deterrent,'' he said. ''This reward program is one more element in the way of initiatives government and industry are taking together.''
The reward offer took effect May 1. The association president, Robert Aaronson, said the program would be a ''powerful incentive for people within or close to terrorist organizations to reveal plots before they are hatched.''
The association expects the State Department to take the lead in publicizing the reward in the Middle East and Europe.
 
Lyons Flights
After a year, American Airlines is discontinuing its daily nonstop flights between Kennedy International Airport and Lyons, France. The service is to be dropped at the end of the month. Lyons was to serve as a gateway to the south of France and to the Alps.
American needed the aircraft for Latin American routes it bought from Eastern, which also included Continental's Miami-London service and the Chicago-London service bought from T.W.A., according to John Hotard, a spokesman for American. Business on the New York-Lyons run was ''marginal,'' he said.
 
Cost Watching At Motels
How much did you pay when you last stayed at a motel? If you were looking for lower rates and paid more than $40 for a double room, you are missing something, according to the latest edition of ''The 1990-1991 National Directory of Budget Motels.'' The 80-page booklet says that budget motels offering all the basic amenities - including air-conditioning, television, full bath and swimming pool - generally charge $22 to $33 for a single and $26 to $37 for two. Some major chains, the directory says, charge as little as $23 for a double.
It lists more than 2,000 motels in the United States and a few dozen in Canada and also includes headquarters of 26 of the budget chains, most of which have toll-free 800 numbers.
Rates are not given for individual motels because of ''unpredictable cost factors in the economy,'' but the directory does include umbrella rates along with its listing of motel chains.
Rates at Budget Host Inns, for example, are given as from $18.88, double. Among other starting rates, for two, are: Days Inns, $25; Econo Lodges, $21.99; Hampton Inns, $36; Motel 6, $24.95; Super 8 Motels, $22.50; Susse Chalet, $39.70, and TraveLodge, $28.
Write or telephone the motel and ask for mailed confirmation of a guaranteed price, the directory suggests, particularly during holiday periods.
Request a room rate before checking in and inquire about the lowest rates.
Travelers should also ask about the family, senior citizen and other possible special-group discounts.
Certain areas, including the Northeast, and places with major tourist attractions and resorts offer few budget motels, the directory warns. The booklet is available solely from the publisher, Pilot Books, 103 Cooper Street, Babylon, N.Y. 11702 at $3.95 a copy plus $1 for postage.
 
Spoleto Tickets for Early Risers
It's not too late to attend the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C., which began Friday and runs through June 10. Tickets to the festival's top two draws - Mozart's ''Marriage of Figaro,'' directed by the festival founder, Gian Carlo Menotti, and Oscar Wilde's ''Salome,'' directed by Steven Berkoff - can be obtained with a little sweat and a lot of patience. And tickets for many of the other 118 events being presented this year remain available through normal channels.
Although both ''The Marriage of Figaro'' and ''Salome'' are listed as sold out, people willing to get out of bed early can buy tickets on the day of each performance. The Dock Street Theater, the historic, 463-seat theater where both works are being performed, withholds 40 tickets to every show and sells them to the first 40 people in line. Sales begin at 10 A.M. at the festival's main box office at 14 George Street, and lines form before breakfast. (''The Marriage of Figaro'' is being performed on May 27 to 30 and June 1, 2, 5 and 7; ''Salome'' is being performed May 27 to June 4 and June 7 to 10.) Among other noteworthy performances to which tickets are not as scarce are the world premiere of a Philip Glass opera with text by Allen Ginsberg (May 27 to June 2 at the Sottile Theater), and dance performances by the Martha Graham Dance Company (May 27 and 28, Gaillard Municipal Auditorium), the Joffrey Ballet (June 8 and 9, Gaillard), and the Urban Bush Women (May 30 to June 3, Garden Theater). There is also a variety of chamber music, orchestral and choral concerts, and jazz concerts, among others, by Chick Corea (May 28, Gaillard) and Chet Atkins and Stanley Jordan (June 3, Gaillard).
Ticket prices range from $8 to $150 and can be ordered at 800-868-7228 or from the box office at 14 George Street in Charleston. For a brochure write Spoleto Festival U.S.A., Post Office Box 157, Charleston, S.C. 29402 or call 803-722-2764.

HEADLINE: What's Doing In;
Seattle

BYLINE: By Timothy Egan; TIMOTHY EGAN, the Seattle bureau chief of The Times, is the author of ''The Good Rain'' (Knopf), a nonfiction book about the Northwest to be published next month.

 BODY:
Every city likes to show off after a major remodeling, and Seattle is no exception, despite lingering traits of Scandinavian bashfulness. For the last four years Seattle has been under almost constant construction, but now virtually everything - the new skyscrapers, the pocket-park in the center of town, the underground bus tunnel - is finished, or in the final stages.
The paint is drying just in time. From July 20 to Aug. 5 Seattle will be the site of the Goodwill Games, a sports and arts extravaganza expected to draw upward of 150,000 visitors from out of town.
Not since the World's Fair of 1962 has Seattle thrown open its doors with so much to offer. The games, a creation of Ted Turner, the cable television broadcaster, were originally planned as a cold war antidote, bringing the best Russian and American athletes together between Olympic years. 
The games have been opened up since they were first held in 1986 in Moscow; now more than 2,500 world-class athletes from at least 50 countries are expected to compete.
The accompanying arts festival should be equally grand. From the Bolshoi Ballet, presenting the American premiere of ''Ivan the Terrible,'' to a $2 million Seattle Opera production of ''War and Peace,'' to a rare unveiling of the long-hidden Northwest treasures of the Seattle Art Museum, the bounty of high culture has never been greater.
In recent years Seattle has been through so much change that its native citizens still seem shellshocked. With its souped-up economy and boom times real estate market, the city's pace has quickened and traffic has slowed. Those looking for a quiet and green Northwest experience should cross Puget Sound, to the Olympic Peninsula, or go south of the Columbia River, to slower-paced Oregon.
Nonetheless, this remains a calming and livable city, where ancient cedar forests and bald eagles can be found on the bluff of Discovery Park in West Seattle, 15 minutes from downtown. To sample the new urban treats of Seattle without an afternoon in the wild is to miss what makes this city different from most.
 
The Sights
A walking tour of downtown is the best way to get acquainted with the new face of Seattle. Beginning in Westlake Center, a small plaza at Pine and Fifth Avenue, follow your nose down Pine Street to the Pike Place Market, one of the oldest, best-known and most authentic outdoor fresh food markets in the country.
Then, heading south on First Avenue, boutiques, small bookstores and coffee shops line a street where porno shops and X-rated shows used to proliferate. Turn left on the steep hill of University Street up one block to the Washington Mutual Building, a 55-story tower by Kohn Pederson Fox that many architects have called the best addition to the Seattle skyline since the Space Needle.
Farther up the hill, turn left at Sixth Avenueand follow it to 2 Union Square, which presents a sleek face to the wind, in a design bow to Boeing jetliners. Finally, at Fifth and Pike, is Pacific First Centre Building, heavily ornamented outside with a boisterous retail center inside.
There should be a good run of sockeye salmon making their way back to spawning grounds above Lake Washington this year. The best place to observe a fish obsessed with its journey home to die is at the Hiram M. Chittenden Locks in Ballard, known informally as the Ballard Locks (3015 Northwest 54th Street; 206-783-7059). The salmon can be seen through glass walls. The run should be at its peak in late June through mid-July. It's free.
A Washington State ferry, (206-464-6990 for schedules), leaving about every 45 minutes from the Colman Dock downtown at the foot of Madison Street, will cross Puget Sound to Winslow, on Bainbridge Island. From the west side of the island it's a 10-minute drive to Bloedel Reserve (7571 Northeast Dolphin Drive; 206-842-7631).
The reserve is 150 acres of lush landscaped grounds. Open Wednesday to Sunday, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., the cost is $4 , $2 for seniors, free for children under 5. Reservations required.
 
Arts and Sports
Seats are still available for many of the prime sporting and artistic attractions of the Goodwill Games, although the best seats have generally been sold. Tickets for track, wrestling, diving, ice hockey, rowing and other events can be had by calling 206-292-1990; the prices range from $5 to $25.
The best events - such as the opening ceremonies and races between Olympic-caliber athletes in track and field - will be held in Husky Stadium, on the shores of Lake Washington at the University of Washington campus.
The Bolshoi Ballet will open its 1990 American tour at the Goodwill Arts Festival with the United States premiere of ''Ivan the Terrible,'' July 2 to 8, at the Seattle Center Opera House (Mercer Street, at the Seattle Center; 206-292-1990.) The work is choreographed by Yuri Grigorovich, the Bolshoi's artistic director. Although most tickets had to be ordered by May, some seats may open up in late June. Prices range from $20 to $125. In its most ambitious production in years, the Seattle Opera will present a $2 million production of Prokofiev's ''War and Peace,'' the Tolstoy masterpiece, conducted by Mark Ermler of the Bolshoi Opera produced in Seattle by Speight Jenkins, general director. A cast of 200 will be led by the American Sheri Greenawald and soloists from the Kirov Opera, including Vladimir Chernov. Performances are scheduled for July 22, 25, 27, 29, 31, and Aug. 2 and 4, at the Seattle Center Opera House. Call 206-443-3299 or 206-292-1990 for tickets, which range in price from $32 to $85.
Beginning next Friday and running through the end of September, ''Moscow: Treasures and Traditions,'' more than 250 Russian masterworks from five centuries will be on display at the Washington State Convention and Trade Center, Eighth Avenue and Pike Street. Tickets are $7.50, $6.50 for students and seniors and $4.50 for children 3 to 12(206-292-1990).
During roughly the same period, the Seattle Art Museum (Volunteer Park, 1400 East Prospect Street; 206-625-8901), which has a fine permanent collection of Asian art, will mount its most extensive collection ever of Northwest art spanning the past 100 years - 1,800 pieces from regional artists. Tickets are $2 and $1 for students and seniors.
 
Where to Eat
The most exciting newcomer on the fast-changing local scene is Palomino's (Pacific First Centre Building, corner of Fifth Avenue and Pike Street; 206-623-1300). Situated inside a bejeweled new skyscraper, Palomino's describes itself as as a purveyor of European-Seattle cuisine - traditional Northwest fare done in the latest recipes from the Mediterranean. Palomino's is quite loud and a bit showy. Dinner for two with wine is $60 to $100.
Underground and intimate, at the Pike Place Market, is Il Bistro, (93A Pike Street; 206-682-3049)a candlelighted cavern serving Italian food coupled with the best of fresh local products. The atmosphere alone, with its hint of intrigue and hushed coversations, might be worth the visit, but Il Bistro delivers in almost every way. Its wine list is extensive, with pinot noirs from Oregon and cabernet sauvignon and merlots from the Columbia River Valley to complement Tuscan standbys. Pasta dishes are in the $12 range. Heavier Bistro favorites such as rack of lamb or veal chops run $20 to $30 for entrees. Dinner for two with wine $65 to $100.
Another Pike Place Market favorite, Cafe Sport (a block north of the market on Western Avenue; 206-443-6000) is faster-paced and more prone to experimentation than the Bistro. The food does stimulate, but not without warning. It serves Pacific Rim specialties, blending spicy Asian influences.The choice of fresh fish list is always extensive. Expect to pay $60 to $100 for dinner, with wine, for two.
For a taste of old-salt Seattle charm with a view of the biggest fishing fleet on the American Pacific shore, try Chinook's (Fisherman's Terminal, 1735 West Thurman; 206-283-4665). It is a large, friendly, inexpensive restaurant with a 125-item menu.Chinooks is a good place to sip a Seattle ale and watch the mariners clean their boats. Dinner for two with local brews is about $30. No reservations, so arrive early, late or expect to wait about 30 minutes.
 
Where to Stay
This summer is supposed to be the busiest in decades. But local tourism officials expect that there will be some rooms at the major hotels in the three weeks of the Goodwill Games. In the week of July 4 to 8, it will be virtually impossible to find a room , because of a national convention of Alcoholics Anonymous.
A Seattle landmark for more than 60 years, the Four Seasons Olympic Hotel (Fifth Avenue and University; 206-621-1700) was renovated a few years back to restore some of the luster it lost in the 1970's. In the heart of downtown, the Olympic is one of the few major hotels in Seattle that cannot boast stunning views of the Puget Sound or the mountains. What it does offer are rooms stuffed with fine furniture, superb service and attention at all hours, the right touches of chandeliers and marble in the lobby and grand ballroom, and a staff that is ever knowledgable and helpful. An oyster bar downstairs, called Shuckers, and the main dining room just across from the lobby, the Georgian Room, are both excellentin their way. Room rates run from $190 to $265 for a small suite.
The Seattle Sheraton Hotel and Towers (Sixth Avenue and Pike Street; 206-621-9000) is a high-density high-rise, 840 rooms in all, with a good track record among travlers, and a restaurant, Fuller's, that some consider reason enough for the stay. Close to the Convention Center and the retail section, the Sheraton is bubbling at all hours. Upper floors have goods views of the sound. Double room rates range from $125 to $195.
Less costly, but close to all the attractions in the center of town, is the West Coast Roosevelt Hotel (Seventh Avenue and Pine Street; 206-621-1200). Built in 1929, as an Art Deco showoff, the Roosevelt was completedly renovated two years ago with a new restaurant, Von's. As with the Sheraton, the Roosevelt is within walking distance of the shopping frenzy at the Westlake Center and the Pike Place Market. Standard rooms are a bit small, but prices, $83 to $93 for a double, make the Roosevelt a buy in the high rent district. Budget choice: Meany Tower Hotel (45th Avenue and Brooklyn Avenue N.E.; 206-634-2000), is in the University of Washington district, the area north of Lake Union where most of the athletes at the Goodwill Games will be staying. Views are good from most rooms. On weekend nights the U-District, as its called, can get a bit noisy from exuberant students, but the Meany is well-insulated. Doubles run $88
