HEADLINE: New Rules Tighten Mortgage Process

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
Shaky real estate values and tougher Federal banking rules are causing mortgage lenders to take a much harder look at loan applications than they once did.
In most cases, the tougher standards for writing mortgages will mean nothing more than a few extra days' wait for mortgage approval, or a requirement for a letter confirming employment instead of a pay stub as proof.
But buyers who were counting on low teaser rates on an adjustable-rate mortgage, or mortgages that let borrowers pile part of the interest charges onto the debt, or whose work does not provide a clear earnings record may find that mortgages that used to be easy to get are becoming hard to find.
''The feedback I am getting from my correspondents out there shows that, yes, there is a tightening up,'' said Brian Bragg, editor of U.S. Housing Markets, a research newsletter published in Detroit by Lomas Mortgage USA of Dallas. ''Banks are taking much more time to confirm sources of income, sources of down payment, making it difficult to slip through a poor quality loan.'' 
Paul Havemann, a partner in HSH Associates, mortgage analysts in Butler, N.J., seconded this view.
''The plain vanilla borrowers probably won't notice the difference except that the bank may squint a little harder,'' he said. ''The one who will be affected is the guy who wants to buy that third house using lots of creative financing, who wants to take back a second mortgage and borrow the down payment from grandpa. That's not going to fly anymore.''
The villain in tighter mortgage rules, Mr. Havemann said, is the soft real estate market.
''It's a complete reversal from before,'' he said. ''It used to be that high appreciation would bail out the imprudent borrower. If he got into trouble with one of these new, creative mortgages, he would just unload the property and the worst that could happen was that he broke even. Now it's just the reverse.''
Most of the tightening of lending standards was introduced several years ago by the country's two big secondary mortgage marketers, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, and the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae.
Where the tightening has been perceived more recently, some bankers say, is from portfolio lenders, banks that keep their mortgages as assets instead of selling them, and who are trimming their practices to match the big banks' practices, as well as new capital requirements of Federal banking law. ''A lot of lenders, such as ourselves, go by standards that are pretty much nationwide in scope,'' said Walter Henderson, first vice president of Mechanics and Merchants Bank in Bridgeport, Conn. ''Lenders who have always followed those standards are considered possibly a little harder to deal with because of those standards, and I think that the rest of the market that has not in the past followed those guidelines are now being seen as tightening up.''
Ellen Feldschreiber, president of Manhattan Mortgage Company, a mortgage broker active in the city's expensive co-op market, agreed.
''Lenders are looking very carefully at approvals, particularly in a marketplace where there is a concern about values,'' she said. ''Something that may have had a certain value 12 months ago may not be worth as much now. If you're buying a co-op or a condo, banks are also looking more carefully at the solvency of the project itself, particularly at how many units are unsold or retained by the sponsor.''
The unsettled housing market has sometimes left bankers and borrowers so far apart that they don't even agree on the value of a property, some bankers said, with the result that bankers refuse mortgages on properties they think the buyers had paid too much for.
The problem has abated, they said, as an appreciation of the stagnation and even slump in the real estate market settles in to the public consciousness, with sellers no longer insisting on unrealistically high valuations for their properties, and buyers more inclined to bargain prices down to a level the banks consider safe.
''The market is depreciating, and offering prices are more likely to reflect this than before,'' said Mr. Henderson of Mechanics and Merchants Bank. ''So appraised values and offering prices are both becoming more in sync now than they were six or eight months ago.''
Problems with differing views of appraisals have sometimes extended to relations between banks and the secondary mortgage market. About a year ago Fannie Mae sent a stern warning to all of its lender banks against trying to protect local market values, and therefore the value of the bank's loan portfolio, by pressing appraisers to give higher appraisals on properties that have lost value.
''Recently we have been advised that some lenders have given appraisers the impression that future assignments might not be forthcoming unless the appraiser removed or changed information in the appraisal report that might be considered detrimental to a specific property or its neighborhood,'' the memo said. ''Such attempts to unduly influence the appraiser are clearly unacceptable.''
Besides the long-term problems of the savings and loan bailouts and tightening Federal regulation of the thrift industry, mortgage lenders are contending with a sudden upturn in the overdue mortgage payment rate. After declining steadily for several years during the market boom, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America reported a sudden increase in the number of borrowers who are more than a month behind on their mortgages, from 4.53 percent in the second quarter of last year to 5.05 percent for the third and fourth quarters. This year's first quarter rate has not yet been calculated.
The sharpest increases in delinquency are in the adjustable-rate mortgages, Mr. Havemann said, which comes as no surprise to Richard Peach, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Assocation.
Research shows that the amount of equity an owner has in a property is probably the most important factor in explaining defaults, Mr. Peach said. Defaults are more likely when falling prices leave owners with little or no equity in the house, he said.
One of the little-known features of adjustable rate mortgages, Mr. Havemann said, is the widespread provision that removes all caps on increases in monthly payments if the value of the property falls below a certain point, usually 25 percent less than the mortgage balance.
In Dallas, Denver and Oklahoma City, where depressed energy prices pushed housing values down sharply a few years ago, resale prices of many condominium apartments fell to half or less of their original values. Mortgage holders, seeking to protect their collateral, often demanded payments to cover the lost value, just as a stock broker will demand cash to cover the margin of a stock bought on credit.
''Adjustable-rate mortgages were once hailed as the savior of the thrift industry,'' Mr. Havemann said. By tying interest rates to an index of money costs, they were intended to make it possible for thrifts and other home-mortgage lenders to charge enough for mortgages to remain competitive for deposits.
But what the so-called ARMs gave the banks in flexible income, they took away in safety. ''They are getting harder to get than they used to be,'' Mr. Havemann went on. ''You would be lucky to get one with 15 percent down any more, because their default rate is higher than on fixed rates, and in these days of declining real estate values and rising interest rates, the banks are insisting that you put in more equity.''
Fannie Mae now refuses to buy adjustable rate mortgages whose borrowers were not shown to be financially qualified in the second year of the mortgage, when the teaser rate is phased out and the actual rates begin to apply.
Negative amortization mortgages, in which part of the interest is piled on to the mortgage principal, have also become rare.
The giant mortgage buying agency also takes a hard look at mortgages on property that was sold with builder give-backs and buy-downs, such as a $5,000 rebate on closing or offers to pay mortgage origination fees.
''Instead of reducing sale prices, sellers sometimes like to use gimmicks like buydowns on interest rates or rebates on the house,'' said Robert J. Engelstad, senior vice president for mortgage and lender standards at Fannie Mae.
''It concerns us because we will only put a mortgage on a house that has a loan-to-value ratio that is real, and if a builder is selling a house for $100,000 but putting in $5,000 worth of concessions, we think that house is worth $95,000, not $100,000.''
Freddie Mac, meanwhile, is also serving notice of stiffer standards in its dealings with banks that originate mortgages, beginning last year with a new set of rules for lenders to make sure borrowers can meet their payments, and the mortgaged properties provide sufficient collateral to make the loan safe.
James E. Crum, director of customer administration for the North Central Region, said in a recent report that 17 percent of the mortgages Freddie Mac rejects for the secondary market are on properties where the sale was made with too small a down payment; 15 percent of the rejects failed to establish comparable value of the property; 15 percent involve borrowers having too much debt to safely carry the mortgage and nine percent involve unverifiable borrower assets.
Above all, Mr. Crum wrote, lenders should be able to defend the value of the loans they offer for sale.
''The point is that our ability to understand why the lender believes a loan is good quality is critical to a decision about the investment quality of the loan,'' he said.
Mr. Crum noted that the documentation for a loan takes on special importance these days, and Mr. Engelstad of Fannie Mae said he shares this view.
During the boom years, Mr. Engelstad said, many lenders developed low-documentation loans, no-documentation loans and time-saver loans as marketing tools in a competitive market. A low-documentation loan may mean only that last year's W-2 income report is accepted as proof of employment, instead of the traditional letter from an employer, a request that may take weeks to be filled.
A tightening up on documentation is not the same as a tightening of credit standards, Mr. Engelstad emphasized. The credit standards - down payment requiremnnts, debt limits and so on - are the same, but banks will demand more documentation to prove employment, the source of the down payment, and income, he said.
But bankers and analysts alike come back to the theme that, despite the tougher scrutiny that prospective borrowers may be subjected to, money for mortgages is still readily available.
''I haven't picked up any feeling that the solid-credit people are being turned down,'' said Mr. Bragg of U.S. Housing Markets.
''The money is there as long as the lender is satisfied that the quality of the loan is going to be high. The banks are just making damn sure that the credit worthiness is there.''
Ms. Feldschreiber of Manhattan Mortgage Company added that mortgage banks still have their own priorities, their own personalities and their own marketing agendas, and that customers should not assume that, because one bank makes impossible demands for proof on this or that detail, another bank won't let the mortgage application sail through.
''I think there is a perception out there that the banks have tightened up much more than they really have,'' she said. ''When you talk about the S & L crisis what you're generally talking about are the big construction loans that got into trouble, not the invividual mortgage. So you may find a bank that wants to increase the amount people have to put down on a house, that doesn't mean you couldn't find another bank that will write a mortgage for 95 percent. They're all different.''

HEADLINE: A New Hand at the Tiller for Landmarks

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Although much of her preservation work has been done building by building, Laurie Beckelman hopes to bring a wider perspective - that of whole neighborhoods - to her new job as chairwoman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.
''I want to look at areas that have been ignored in the past,'' said Ms. Beckelman, who came to her civic post from the private New York Landmarks Conservancy. She means areas like Harlem, the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn and Jackson Heights, Queens, which will soon be considered by the commission.
Ms. Beckelman, who is 39 years old and lives on the Upper West Side, was hired by the Municipal Art Society in 1973, not long after graduating from Boston University. 
From 1981 until last month, she was executive director of the conservancy, whose purpose is to protect, preserve and revitalize significant historic properties. Her predecessor in that job, Susan Henshaw Jones, is returning as executive director.
As the seventh person to head the 25-year-old landmarks panel, Ms. Beckelman will preside during a critical period, as designations come under the scrutiny of the City Council for the first time and as a number of religious organizations press their constitutional challenge to the landmarks law.
Another critical development will be the commission's growing regulatory role at a time of shrinking municipal spending. Critics of the commission have long complained about procedures that they see as complicated, time-consuming, arbitrary and hostile to economic concerns.
The commission itself will be undergoing significant change. All the current members are serving beyond the expiration of their terms, as they may do until reappointed or replaced. Some are expected to be retained, said Ms. Beckelman, because ''it's important to keep the continuity and the institutional memory.''
But, she added, Mayor David N. Dinkins ''would like to see a mosaic on the commission'' and will probably have appointed an entirely new majority on the 11-member panel by year's end.
Ms. Beckelman, who is at once soft-spoken but forceful in articulating her views, clearly has her own mission: the city's neighborhoods.
''Harlem is a main priority of mine,'' she said, as ''one of the most lush areas for revitalization.'' Indeed, Ms. Beckelman is currently renovating a brownstone on West 146th Street, to be sold as a condominium.
Although there are small historic districts in Harlem, she said, there are ''rows and rows'' of undesignated homes and other properties that are eligible for landmark status. If designated, they might benefit from low-interest loans, rehabilitation grants or even money from the state's Environmental Quality Bond Act.
Asked whether neighborhood emphasis implied a maintenance of existing scale, as opposed to the greater density at which developers would prefer to build, Ms. Beckelman answered, ''If we are talking about compatibility, we're not talking about out-of-scale design.''
''The Upper West Side, now that it's designated, should have more contextual, compatible zoning,'' she continued. ''I think people have had enough of the extremes in development and that a sense of coherence is really important. You have more and more developers wanting to invest and develop in historic neighborhoods because you have a coherent volume.''
Her call for complementary zoning presumes a link between the landmarks panel and City Planning Commission that has not been much in evidence in recent years, with the exception of the Upper East Side Historic District. She said she is committed to a ''very serious ongoing dialogue'' with city planners.
Besides the sweeping themes, Ms. Beckelman will have to deal with a number of specific issues, among them the fact that this is a time of bare-bones municipal budgets.
There is, for example, only one person on the staff to monitor work that is done on designated buildings without the commission's approval. ''I mean to be extremely tough on people who are creating violations,'' she said. ''But how can I be when I don't have the manpower to enforce the landmarks law?''
The law will face a critical legal test during Ms. Beckelman's term: a constitutional challenge by St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church on Park Avenue, whose effort to replace its Community House with an office tower has been blocked by the city.
A number of religious leaders, organizations and congregations have attacked the landmarks law, saying that it forces them to place the maintenance of physical properties ahead of their mission, diverting scarce dollars from social and spiritual programs.
With the St. Batholomew's case pending in Federal appeals court, Ms. Beckelman declined to comment specifically. Speaking generally, however, she said:
''I don't believe the argument that 'we're being forced to maintain our buildings before we minister to our constituents.' If these buildings had been maintained properly over the years - I'm not putting the blame on anyone - and you started from the beginning, you could phase anything in and meet those goals and not have ongoing disasters.''
Ms. Beckelman is also inheriting the case of the 78-year-old Audubon Theater and Ballroom, between 165th and 166th Streets, across from the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, where Malcolm X was assassinated in 1965.
Columbia University seeks to replace the theater with a biomedical research building, but there is a growing movement to preserve the Audubon as an architectural and cultural landmark, and as a memorial to Malcolm X. Although the commission passed up the chance years ago to designate the theater, Ms. Beckelman said, ''I want to see if there's some way that the Audubon building can be incorporated into the new structure.''
Another pending issue is a personal one, involving Ms. Beckelman's three-story brownstone in Harlem, at 425 West 146th Street, which she has been converting into a condominium. The building is not a landmark.
She said it was almost completed. However, she may have to sell the building earlier than planned, if her continued ownership is deemed to pose an ethical conflict by the city's Conflicts of Interest Board. An opinion is pending.
''I don't want to be an absentee landlord,'' Ms. Beckelman said. ''I've always been interested in preservation development and I thought this would be a wonderful way to sink my teeth into something. I'm really proud of the work that we're doing.''

HEADLINE: The Other Side Of Welfare Debate

 BODY:
It is entirely appropriate that Ruth Brandwein, Suffolk's Commissioner of Social Services, should express her concern for all those receiving welfare benefits on Long Island and to explain the reasons, in her opinion, for their inability to leave the welfare role. (''Freedom From Welfare, the Best Hope Yet,'' Opinion, April 29).
But let's look at the other side of the coin and the case of the alleged ''affluent'' citizens on Long Island. Yes, many were born to affluency and since this is not a socialist country, they are entirely entitled to their plateau in society as a result of their noble birth. 
There are many others, however, who drive beautiful cars, own typically ''middle class'' homes with well-manicured lawns, who vacation, who pay for their children's educations and who have obviously captured a fair share of the American Dream entirely under their own steam with no assistance from any agency whatsover! How did they earn their share? The key word is ''earn.'' Many were born of immigrant parents and grandparents who had high ideals and strict work ethics, who often worked 12 to 16 hours a day to feed their families. But families also supported each other. Child care existed in the form of grandparents and relatives caring for children to enable their parents to earn a living and to live in dignity without financial assistance.
And many migrated to Long Island from the boroughs of New York City, where they had used subways and other forms of public transportation to reach whatever jobs were available. They were familiar with the indignity of being subjected to steamy hours spent on poorly ventilated subways that often broke down for hours in dark, airless, poorly lit tunnels.
But they were undaunted and persisted with their goals, which sometimes required working at two and three jobs. A large number of these emigres still travel back to the city from ''bucolic,'' affluent Long Island, either spending four hours daily on the Long Island Railroad or hours trapped in traffic jams on overcrowded Long Island highways.
Due to the recent downturn in the Long Island economy and increases in taxes, many are facing the loss of homes and jobs. Senior citizens who contributed a wealth of benefits to society are also suffering as a result of increased taxation on homes which they are desperately trying to maintain on fixed incomes.
Should they be subjected to paying taxes for those who are receiving welfare assistance but who look at public transportation as too arduous?
Should these citizens be taxed to provide case management for those who are already receiving public assistance but who cannot or will not look to family members or friends for support in the area of child care, who refuse to travel to provide that care and who need the government to give them direction?
Should those who are earning minimal salaries and paying huge sums in annual health care benefits be taxed additionally to provide these benefits for those who cannot or will not find meaningful employment?
Should we, who are enjoying middle-class affluence, pay taxes to guide others through the ''rough'' times when we have spent a lifetime of coping with these ''rough'' times and building our own self-esteem through hard work and endurance?
And should we be paying taxes to cover the cost of additional case workers in the Department of Social Services when Suffolk County government is looking to lay off workers while encouraging others to retire early to reduce the cost of running the government and decrease the burden of taxes for those who are striving to maintain what they have righfully earned?
The answers to creating a society free from homelessness, poverty and those who would surely perish without financial assistance from the government are not simplistic. In this age of technological miracles and the bounty that many Americans enjoy, it seems quite ironic for severe poverty to co-exist with apparent affluency. But let's not create yet another generation fraught with hopelessness and dependency.
Let's restore spirit and self-esteem. A step in the right direction, might be to supply crash courses (along with temporary assistance) in techniques of coping, how to work hard to succeed despite drawbacks and how to be proud of what is ''earned'' rather than look for what can be gained through government assistance.
We, the people, are the government. And we pay for whatever is granted in financial assistance. Let us try to instill motivation such as that which built our great country, so that each of us is responsible for our own destiny.
 
BARBARA WARSAW
 Bay Shore

HEADLINE: Handling Growth In Somerset County

 BODY:
The fine article ''In Morris County, a Changing Outlook on Development'' (April 15) summarized the impact of growth and increased employment opportunities on one central New Jersey county. Somerset County was noted as having enjoyed the same kind of economic growth and prosperity in recent years.
I am quick to point out, however, that Somerset County and many of the major employers here are aware of the impact that rapid population growth, industrial and business expansion and new housing development can have on the region. And we are proud of the fact that those of us in Somerset County have already taken the initiative to deal with the more obvious problems of traffic congestion, the lack of affordable housing, the need for family care and the importance of economically viable town centers. 
The Somerset Alliance for the Future is a coalition of corporate representatives, municipal and state officials and nonprofit corporation executives who believe in the need for pooling resources and cooperative action to protect, enhance and develop portions of Somerset County. It is the product of a year of research. We have made a $1 million three-year commitment to deal with the key issues at the regional level.
As the impact of growth and business expansion in beautiful central New Jersey is monitored,I want people to know that one county is not standing by while both the physical and economic environment disintegrate from problems associated with growth and development. We believe that the kind of strong partnership that the alliance represents at both the daily working level and the public and private executive level is the key to planning and organizing for an ideal future.
While maintaining the quality of life style we enjoy in Somerset County, we plan to have a solid base of employment, attractive and profitable town centers, accessible open space and a large stock of affordable housing. We may even be able to expand and enhance family care environment and favorably affect traffic congestion. This is what we have to do for the future generations of Somerset County residents and employees.
 
RAYMOND H. BATEMAN
 Chairman
 
 Somerset Alliance for the Future
 Somerville

HEADLINE: HOME CLINIC;
How to Repoint Brickwork

BYLINE: By JOHN WARDE

 BODY:
MORTAR joints in brickwork require yearly inspection. Cracked, loose and crumbling joints should be restored whenever discovered, else moisture can seep between bricks and cause damage.
The process of restoring mortar joints is called repointing or tuck pointing. It consists of chiseling away most of the old mortar from deteriorating joints and replacing it with new material. 
Because mortar is easiest to work with and cures best when the temperature is between 50 and 80, late spring or early summer is a good time for major repointing projects, especially those involving outdoor construction.
Repointing only a few joints usually can be done by using improvised tools: an ordinary cold chisel no wider than the joints, a heavy ball peen or small sledge hammer for striking the chisel, a gardener's trowel for mixing and applying fresh mortar and an old kitchen spoon for smoothing the restored joints.
For large jobs, use plugging and cape chisels instead of a cold chisel, plus proper masonry tools described herein. All are available at hardware and masonry supply stores.
Whether using improvised tools or not, wear goggles for protection against brick and mortar particles and heavy work gloves to ward off errant hammer blows. Never use a carpenter's claw hammer for striking a metal chisel; the head of the hammer may chip or shatter, sending out metal splinters.
Repoint areas of about three to five feet square at a time. Use the plugging chisel, which has a thin blade trimmed at an angle across the end, for loosening the mortar, and the cape chisel, which has a thicker blade that tapers to a point in the center, for digging the loosened mortar out of the joints.
Cut a square-sided groove (not V-shaped) about three-quarters of an inch deep between the bricks, and expose bare brick on at least one side of each joint. After chiseling, either brush the joints free of dust with a whisk broom or a wide, thin brush with coarse bristles, or wash the joints clean with hard spray from a garden hose.
Next, apply new mortar. Dry mortar that requires only adding water is available in bags ranging from 5 to 80 pounds; this is the easiest type to use. An 80-pound bag is sufficent for repointing more than 100 bricks.
For larger jobs, mixing your own mortar from separate ingredients is usually more economical. Conventional proportions for mortar are one part Portland cement, one part hydrated lime and six parts sand, or one part masonry cement and three parts sand. Specify clean masonry sand.
Before repointing brick that is more than 100 years old, consult an experienced mason. Modern mortar mixed in conventional proportions is often harder than old brick and can cause it to crack or flake.
To mix mortar, use a coffee can or marked bucket for measuring the ingredients. Mortar becomes too hard to use after two hours, and so mix only small batches at a time.
Place the dry ingredients in a wheelbarrow. Mix them thoroughly with a large mason's trowel, then add small amounts of clear water and continue mixing until the mortar forms peaks that hold their shape when the mortar is spread upward with the trowel.
Some masons advocate first adding only enough water to make a stiff ball of mortar, then waiting about 20 minutes before adding more. This process, called rehydration, may reduce the tendency of the existing mortar to draw moisture away from the new mortar, which weakens it.
To fill the joints, you sometimes will need a small mason's trowel called a pointing trowel. First, wet the joints with fine spray from a garden hose, dampening them thoroughly but not soaking them. Then scoop up mortar on the back of the large trowel and hold it against the wall as a palette and to catch excess mortar falling from the joints as they are filled.
Use the back of the pointing trowel to pick up mortar from the large trowel and press it tightly into the brickwork's vertical joints. After filling these, use the same technique to fill the horizontal joints.
However, because the horizontal joints are longer, it is often easier to repoint them by using a long, narrow tool called a margin trowel than by using the pointing trowel.
After about an hour, when the mortar has stiffened enough to retain a thumb print, scrape off excess amounts with a mason's trowel and finish the joints by smoothing and compressing them with a tool called a jointer.
Smooth the vertical joints first, then the horizontals. If possible, duplicate the shape of the surrounding joints. But keep in mind that joints with concave surfaces shed water best and are easiest to make. After smoothing, move on to the next section. Keep repointed joints damp by spraying them often until the mortar cures fully, usually in about four days. After 24 hours, excess mortar particles can be swept from the edges of the smoothed joints with a whisk broom. Large pieces should be left to harden completely, then knocked off by striking them with the edge of the large mason's trowel.
Stains left by mortar can sometimes be removed simply by scrubbing the brick with a stiff bristle brush after the mortar has hardened. If that does not work, wash the wall with a mild solution of muriatic acid, which is available at building supply stores and home centers.
Follow the printed precautions on the container for using the acid. Afterward, wash the brick thoroughly with clear water.

HEADLINE: Community Hospitals Adapt to Changes

BYLINE: By JUDY GLASS

 BODY:
ON a stroll through the corridors of any one of Long Island's community hospitals 30 years ago, a visitor might have seen heart attack victims in their third week of recuperation, a new mother taking her first halting steps days after her baby's birth and a few affluent members of the community on a kind of rest and rehabilitation program, compliments of good insurance coverage.
As for the most advanced technology, it might well have been the X-ray equipment.
Not so today. Heart-attack victims usually spend 8 to 10 days in a hospital, mothers and babies about three days, hospital beds have few ''exhausted'' patients and community hospitals own or have ready access to CAT scanners and nuclear-magnetic imaging machines and other advanced equipment.
The changes in Long Island's community hospitals reflect not only the growth and changes in the population, but also the demand for expensive technology and a shift to shorter stays, mandated by state regulations, medical advances and reimbursement policies. 
 
Two Major Impacts
Ambulatory care - one-day outpatient treatment - is often completed in less time than it takes to visit the local beauty salon. It is faster and easier for a wide variety of simple surgeries and outpatient procedures. Pre-admission workups, once done as part of the entire overnight admission, are now done on an outpatient basis as well.
However, hospitals lose the revenue from the ''hotel'' portion of the cost, the room and ancillary services that these patients would have needed in the past, and this puts a strain on the community hospital budgets.
Community hospitals, which years ago cared for almost everyone in the neighborhood, now compete for patients with free-standing clinics, clinics in doctors' offices and teaching hospitals with the most sophisticated care.
Emergency rooms, which are seeing far more gunshot wounds, drug overdoses and traumatic injuries from accidents and violence than a generation ago, often admit patients to beds that were scheduled for elective surgery.
Patients who do not have a physician of their own also use the emergency room for ailments like a virus, a stomach ache or a minor injury. And rather than put off a long-awaited elective procedure, doctors often have their insured patients admitted through the emergency room, one hospital administrator said.
Two other factors - an increase in the number of elderly people and the AIDS epidemic - have also had a major impact on how community hospitals provide care and handle priorities.
 
New Services Introduced
Long Island has the fastest-growing number of aged people in New York State and more people with AIDS than any other suburban area in the country, according to the Nassau-Suffolk Hospital Council, an advocacy and purchasing group for the island's 22 nonprofit hospitals.
On the other hand, to be economically viable and provide modern care, community hospitals have introduced a variety of new services. South Side Hospital now offers an out-patient procedure called Easy Street, a physical rehabilitation center; diet centers, pre-natal clinics and psychological counseling care.
Easy Street is a physical rehabilitation center that trains people to lift and carry properly, and helps people learn how to readjust to the physical demands of everyday living following surgery.
It contains simulated settings of a Waldbaum's supermarket, one of the sponsors, and a bank, as well as an automobile and a separate room of exercise equipment.
''A community hospital is a not-for-profit, voluntary hospital governed by a volunteer board of directors,'' said Ann Marie Brown, vice president of the Hospital Council.
Collectively, she said, Long Island's community hospitals serve 2.7 million people with 6,500 beds.
Community hospitals come in many sizes and architectural designs, and some operate nursing homes as part of their complexes. They include Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip, Central Suffolk Hospital in Riverhead, Franklin Hospital Medical Center in Valley Stream, Long Beach Memorial in Long Beach and North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset.
''Demographics make a big difference in a hospital's ability to operate successfully,'' said Theodore A. Jospe, president of South Side Hospital in Bay Shore, which serves Bay Shore, Brentwood, Central Islip, Brightwaters, Sayville and Oakdale.
This is a catchment area of about 10 miles with some of the ''toughest problems facing hospitals,'' said Ms. Brown. These include an overburdened emergency room, a high number of uninsured patients, and competition from other institutions.
 
Payer Determines Price
''We're expected to operate a hospital like a business,'' Mr. Jospe said, ''but in no other business does the payer determine the price rather than the provider. Prices should reflect cost, just as they do in the automobile business.
''The difference is that if you can't afford increased prices, you can buy a used car, but you can't buy used health care. The cost of doing business in hospitals these days far outstrips revenues.''
He indicated that the hospital stays of the seriously ill, the comatose and premature babies can be prolonged with the use of new but often expensive technology. Hospitals have little control over the use of high-priced drugs and devices, if their doctors want them, he noted.
 
Nursing Home Beds Needed
The elderly often occupy hospital beds when the care they require is custodial, which can be provided in nursing homes. Long Island currently has a shortage of 3,000 nursing home beds, according to the Nassau-Suffolk Health Systems Agency Inc., which approves plans for the Island's hospitals, nursing homes, substance-abuse centers and other health-care facilities.
In years past, patients with insurance subsidized patients with no insurance, Ms. Brown said. Virtually all treatment was delivered to inpatients, and the length of the patient's stay was determined solely by the doctor in charge.
In 1986, largely to combat rising medical costs, the state began using the Diagnostic Related Group method to pay hospitals.
Payment is based on a complicated formula that takes into account the type of procedure, the expected time for recovery, the region in which the care is delivered and a hospital's past financial record.
 
Intent of the System
The system was designed to save money, but there are many costs other than patient care - like malpractice insurance - that community hospitals must meet whether beds are empty or full, Mr. Jospe said.
Eastern Long Island Hospital on the North Fork and Southampton Hospital on the South Fork, for example, may fill up in the summer months. But they accommodate far fewer patients in the winter, and remain costly to run, Ms. Brown said.
In general, Long Island hospitals are more in demand than hospitals in other parts of the state, running about 85 to 90 percent occupancy, with some units unable to handle the demand, said Marvin H. Burton, executive director of the Health Systems Agency.
Occupied beds, however, do not always produce revenue. More than 250,000 Long Islanders have no insurance or are under-insured and too poor to pay medical bills, Mr. Burton said.
There is a medical consensus that people lacking adequate medical insurance do not go to the doctor as frequently as they should; when they are first admitted to the hospital, usually through the emergency room, they are often sicker than they would have been had they received earlier care, Mr. Jospe said.
Paradoxically, the cost of services that a hospital bills an uninsured patient is higher than what it receives for the same service from third-party payers like Blue Cross, which pays according to the Diagnostic Related Group method, Mr. Jospe said.
It takes more employees to run a hospital today, said J. Ronald Gaudreault, president of Huntington Hospital, who has hired 189 people in the last two years. He is not filling positions that are vacated because his budget, which showed a surplus of close to $1 million in 1988, is $2.5 million in the red this year. He cited too many regulations and not enough reimbursements as the cause of the deficit.
As a community hospital, Huntington Hospital has been in the same residential neighborhood since it was established in 1914. It has deep ties to its community and its activities are watched closely by neighbors, some of whom have opposed the hospital's expansion in the past.
 
Volunteers' Group Has Decreased
The hospital relies on Auxilians, a volunteers' group and candy-stripers for assistance but the number of Auxilians has declined from more than 1,000 members a few years ago to 450, as women have opted for paid jobs. However, the Auxilians continue to provide thousands of hours of service and have donated $170,000 from its annual geranium sale and other fund-raisers.
Similar volunteer organizations exist in a number of community hospitals.
In recent years, however, larger, more-sophisticated public relations and fund-raising campaigns have become part of the agendas and budgets of most community hospitals.
For example, donations of $1 million to Huntington's capital campaign last year enabled the hospital to establish not only a 12-bed intensive-care unit but also a separate oncology unit so that cancer patients will not be scattered throughout the hospital.
The hospital, which had 300 beds and 1,000 employees when Mr. Gaudreault joined its administrative staff 25 years ago, now has 398 beds and 1,700 full-time employees.
In 1963, the hospital treated 32,000 patients, compared with 113,000, many of them ambulatory patients, out-patients or emergency room walk-ins, last year. ''But remember,'' Mr. Gaudreault said, ''the population of Huntington has increased from 160,000 to 210,000.''
To save money, hospitals like St. Charles and Mather Memorial, which are a mile apart in Port Jefferson, are sharing some services and keeping only one emergency room open, the one at Mather. Other hospitals have closed their pediatric units, which were once filled with children suffering from communicable diseases now controlled by antibiotics and immunization.
 
AIDS CASES INCREASING
''ALL of Long Island's community hospitals are going to have to become more involved with the AIDS epidemic if projections are correct,'' says Patricia Campagna, social services and housing coordinator for the Long Island Association for AIDS Care, which operates a hot line (516-AIDS) and offers the most-comprehensive agenda of services on the Island.
All of the Island's hospitals are currently handling some AIDS patients, but often with great reluctance, studies show. Whenever possible, some of the hospitals refer the patients to the three designated AIDS centers at Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow, North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset and University Hospital in Stony Brook.
These centers have special sections for the care of AIDS patients, particularly those in the latter stages of the disease. So far, however, these centers have not been overwhelmed, Ms. Campagna said.
At present, there are believed to be 1,300 cases of fully identified AIDS cases on Long Island and at least 20,000 to 25,000 Long Islanders infected with the virus. It is projected that there will be at least 2,700 AIDS cases on the Island by next year.
According to the Federal Centers for Disease Control, Long Island not only has the largest number of AIDS patients of any suburban area in the country, but also the most people with the HIV infection. Nassau County is fifth in the nation in intravenous drug use, ''a prime way for people to get AIDS,'' Ms. Campagna said.
According to Carol Lindquist, a spokeswoman for the AIDS Care Association, ''Shooting steroids and sharing needles, a good-buddy, jock activity among body builders all over Long Island, can lead to AIDS among affluent young men and their female sex partners.''
Many AIDS cases may be unreported, specialists say, sometimes with the cooperation of a family physician, because of the stigma attached to the disease.
In some cases, patients who go to the hospital with AIDS-related illnesses are not aware that they are carrying the virus. In others, a doctor may treat the same patient a number of times without suspecting AIDS, and the patient is finally diagnosed elsewhere.
According to the AIDS Care Association, 70 percent of AIDS patients nationally are gay. On Long Island, it is 35 percent. Of the other 65 percent, 40 percent in each county are intravenous drug users and 2 percent in Nassau County and 4 percent in Suffolk County are children. Heterosexuals constitute 8 percent of the AIDS population in Nassau and 4 percent in Suffolk.
''The designated AIDS centers at present are better prepared to handle AIDS patients,'' Ms. Campagna said.
With extra reimbursement from the state, she said, they have been better able to train their staffs and equip their units.
With better medication and health management, Ms. Campagna said, AIDS patients are living longer and do not require as much hospitalization as they did in the early stages of the epidemic. However, the Nassau-Suffolk Health Systems Agency Inc. estimates that the average AIDS patient will spend 76 days in a hospital and will be admitted 3.4 times.
''Until our attitudes toward the disease become less prejudicial, community hospitals will probably set up separate units, as one has already done,'' Ms. Campagna said. ''But not every community hospital has enough AIDS patients to warrant a unit.''
The results of a study by the State Department of Health are expected to give Long Island hospitals and planners up-to-date information on how many AIDS patients are now in community hospitals.
''Community hospitals don't need special physicians or staffs, but there's a tremendous need to educate,'' said Renee Pekmezaris, Ph.D., Director of Health Care Research and Information Systems for the Nassau-Suffolk Health Systems Agency.
''Staff at the AIDS-designated centers were afraid until they were educated, but there's been a significant change.''

LENGTH: 1552 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in:;
Prospect Heights

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
Although it takes in less than a quarter of a square mile, Prospect Heights in Brooklyn is a microcosm of New York City's housing situation.
It is graced with richly crafted turn-of-the-century brownstones and elegant 1920's apartment buildings. Its population is a rich mixture of all races and income groups. And it is now recovering from the turbulent 70's, when many buildings were either abandoned by landlords or burned out. This is leading to tension between developers and community groups.
Prospect Heights lies between Park Slope and Crown Heights. It is also surrounded by the finest cultural and recreational institutions in Brooklyn - the Brooklyn Museum, the main branch of the Brooklyn Public Library, the Botanic Garden, the Brooklyn Academy of Music and Prospect Park. 
''It's an area where you a have a mix of everything,'' said Lynn R. Yellin, a realtor with the William B. May Company, a Manhattan realty company with offices in Brooklyn. ''But it is not so homogenized that we are losing the cream. Every group expresses itself and you get the best of everything.''
Lincoln Place best reflects what is happening to Prospect Heights. Boarded up, burned-out structures that are defaced with graffiti stand alongside newly renovated apartment complexes with glass elevators and rooftop gardens.
Stephen B. Jacobs, a Manhattan architect who bought three boarded-up buildings on Lincoln Place between Washington and Underhill Avenues for $1.4 million in 1986, has since acquired three more. So far, four of the buildings have been converted to new one-, two- and three-bedroom simplex and duplex co-ops, selling for $84,500 to $225,000.
''I saw in Prospect Heights a development resource unmatched anywhere else in Brooklyn,'' said Mr. Jacobs. ''It is a logical extension of Park Slope. But the properties could be acquired at a much more favorable price.''
His buildings are drawing professionals to the mostly blue-collar neighborhood, leading to resentment from local groups.
''They are pushing up the prices of all of the housing in the area,'' said Haddie Bowers, chairwoman of the Prospect Heights Neighborhood Corporation, formed in 1980 to restore buildings and provide low- and moderate-income housing. ''The new people coming in are yuppies and dinks'' - double income, no kids. ''They are not the people who get involved in the neighborhood.''
She said poorer young families are being forced to double up with parents and grandparents, while housing in their neighborhood is being sold to outsiders.
Using contributions from the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, Ms. Bowers's organization has renovated four city-owned buildings, sold to them for $1 each. One has gone co-op, with apartments selling for up to $5,000 for a three-bedroom unit. A second building is going co-op. The two others are among the last rent-stabilized buildings in the neighborhood, with a total of 16 units, renting for from $226 for a studio to $500 for a three-bedroom.
Alphonso Wright, district manager of Community Board 8, which includes Prospect Heights, said city, state and Federal programs contributed $10.3 million since 1985 toward the renovation of 488 low- and moderate-income co-op and rental units. Private contractors have restored a fourth to a half of the neighborhood's 9,500 housing units, converting most to co-ops.
The most expensive building in Prospect Heights is Turner Towers on Eastern Parkway, just across from the Brooklyn Museum, which earlier this month announced the first phase of a $100 million renovation project. In 1978, Turner Towers was rundown and the landlord in arrears on his mortgage.
A tenants' association bought the building from Lincoln Savings in 1980 and turned it into a co-op. Since then the tenants, 85 percent of whom bought their apartments, have put more than $1 million into the building's renovation and plan to spend four times as much over the next five years.
Ms. Yellin, one of the initial buyers, paid $7,200 for her 1,800-square-foot, three-bedroom apartment and sold it in 1986 for $170,000. Today, 3 1/2-bedroom apartments can go for over $300,000.
One of the most controversial buildings is the old Public School 9, known locally as ''old nine.'' The 1895 structure was renovated last year by the Forest City-Ratner Companies, who turned it into 22 apartments, selling for $92,000 for a small one-bedroom to $504,000 for a 2,300-square-foot, three-bedroom. Although the building needed repairs when the developers took it over, it had been a city-owned community center controlled by the Prospect Heights Neighborhood Corporation.
Ms. Bowers sees the sale as a betrayal. ''We have no place to have those programs we were providing for our children and senior citizens,'' she says.
Borough President Howard Golden acknowledges that some displacement has taken place but maintains that his administration has kept this to a minimum. He said redevelopment was inevitable because the building of several large office complexes nearby is creating new jobs.
Eastern Parkway is now in the throes of a $59 million renovation -including new sewers, repaving, new benches and landscaping - that should drive up the prices of apartments even more.
Records in the Brooklyn Public Library indicate that the name Prospect Heights was in use in 1892. Patrick Smith, spokesman for the Borough President, said the area was part of a Revolutionary War neighborhood known as Crow Hill, because it was inhabited by freed slaves. Most of it is now Crown Heights.
A relative newcomer, Nanette Rainone moved to Prospect Heights from the Upper West Side in 1983. She lives in a condominium apartment house on Grand Army Plaza.
Ms. Rainone, who heads the Fund for the Borough of Brooklyn, an organization operating out of Mr. Golden's office to promote cultural interests, maintains that the neighborhood will never be totally gentrified. ''There is just too much long-term ownership of the brownstones for anyone to ever think that the area could pass from one racial group or one economic group to another,'' she said.
The four commercial streets - Underhill, Flatbush, Vanderbilt and Washington avenues - have few restaurants and many residents shop in neighboring Park Slope. Among places to eat are the New Prospect Cafe and the Garden Cafe, which have American menus, and Tom's Restaurant, a luncheonette, open from 6 A.M. to 4 P.M. The owner, Constantine Vlahavas, dismisses the talk of friction between newcomers and longtime residents.
''Since many of the new people are moving into formerly abandoned buildings, how could this be bad,'' he said.
Many Prospect Heights children attend P.S. 9 on Underhill Avenue and Prospect Heights High School on Classon Avenue at Union Street, neither of which has a good reputation in the community.
Jerry J. Cioffi, the high school principal, noted that a study last year indicated that his school had one one of the the worst dropout rates and reputations for violence in the state.
''The school is receiving a bad rap,'' Mr. Cioffi said. ''Since 1987, the dropout rate has declined from 12.5 to 9.7 percent. We were rated as the fifth most violent, and now we are the 12th.''
He said the school, whose 2,000 students represents 43 different nationalities, has not been renovated since it was built in 1929. ''How can you expect the kids to achieve when they have plaster falling down on their heads?''
He maintains, however, that the school is effective because 75 percent of the entering students are unable to read. By the time they graduate, he noted, 55 percent have passed the Regents examinations.
For intermediate school, students attend I.S. 210, I.S. 390 or I.S. 61K, all in Crown Heights.
One program that is helping the academic situation is the Science Skill Center, a city-financed after-school math and science program, teaching 100 minority students between 7 to 15 years old. According to the program's director, Michael A. Johnson, last year the center produced the youngest group of students ever to take the state Regents examination in biology. All of the 16 9- to 12-year-olds who took the exam passed.

Stage to Sanctuary: When construction began in 1926 for Union Temple commemorating the merger of Reform Jewish congregations from Crown Heights and Williamsburg, the plan was for two 10-story towers at 17 Eastern Parkway connected by a structure half that height housing a stairwell. By 1928, one tower, which was to accommodate a theater and a recreation center, and the stairwell were completed. The sanctuary was to be added later. But the Depression intervened and the Jewish community never met growth projections and plans for the second tower were dropped. So the theater, with its orchestra pit, was converted permanently to a sanctuary.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: May 27, 1990,

SECTION: Section 12LI; Page 1, Column 5; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1515 words

HEADLINE: Summer Outlook: Fewer Jobs, Fewer Youths

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
SEASONAL jobs as lifeguards, park attendants, beachcombers and camp counselors have traditionally been held by Long Island's high school and college students and filled by Memorial Day, the holiday weekend that marks the beginning of summer.
But changing economics and demographics on the Island in recent years have affected the summer job market.
A decade ago, an excess of students looking for summer jobs spurred the use of lotteries to decide how to assign them. In contrast, during the last few summers there was such a shortage of applicants to fill the available positions that many employers were offering bonuses to attract workers.
 
Booming Economy Has Slowed
The outlook for this summer is somewhere in between, said James A. Larocca, president of the Long Island Association. The booming economy of the last few years has slowed, he said, but there remains a declining pool of youngsters to fill the jobs. The gap between jobs and candidates has narrowed, and this should be the trend for the next few summers, Mr. Larocca said. 
The number of students graduating from the Island's high schools continues to decline, said Arthur Kunz, director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. In Nassau County, the population peaked in the late 60's, and for Suffolk it was the early 70's, he said. But while there are fewer youngsters, there are also fewer jobs available, he said.
''The Island's economy is a little gloomier this summer,'' Mr. Kunz said. ''Constraints on county governments will diminish the number of jobs available.
''Last year, we saw a good economy with fewer kids to fill the jobs. This year, there are still fewer kids but an economy that is not as red hot.''
The largest number of seasonal jobs are at Long Island's beaches, parks and other recreational facilitiies.
Nassau County employs about 1,000 seasonal workers - 900 of them in county parks and the other 100 in clerical positions - said George Sinnott, a county spokesman. Budget cuts have caused job cutbacks of about 10 percent since last year, and salaries have remained the same for the last two years, he said.
 
No Problem in Filling Jobs
But in spite of frozen salaries, there has not been a problem filling the county jobs, Mr. Sinnott said, adding:
''Ironically, we had more difficulty recruiting last summer than this year, but we're not sure why.''
Nassau County's Job Development Center provides approximately 1,000 jobs for high school and college students from middle- and low-income families, said James Rice, executive director of the county's Commission of Human Rights.
About 400 are employed to work in various county departments, and another 500 or so are placed in positions in the private sector. Jobs may be available at United Parcel, at one of the New York airports or at a McDonald's or Burger King, Mr. Rice said.
The only significant difficulty in recruiting summer employees has been felt by the county parks on the North Shore, Mr. Sinnott said, explaining:
''They are more well-to-do areas, and there are not as many kids around for the summer because many students travel or are away for the summer.''
Summer positions at South Shore beaches and parks within the Town of Oyster Bay also fill faster than those on the North Shore, said Doris Kirby, a town spokeswoman.
The town hires between 750 and 800 seasonal employees for its Departments of Parks and Public Works.
Jobs within the Parks Department include recreation aides, lifeguards, maintenance workers and positions in children's programs. Openings in the Public Works Department offer higher salaries for highway and sanitation workers and are filled first, Ms. Kirby said.
Jobs at the town parks were not filled last summer, she said, but this year there has been an increase in the number of applicants.
The Suffolk County Parks Department recruits 250 seasonal employees and several hundred more in its Labor Department, most of whom are students, said County Executive Patrick G. Halpin.
 
Competition Enters Picture
But as the county's population has gotten older and fewer high school and college students are available for summer jobs, county positions have had to compete with private companies that also recruit young employees, and starting salaries at county beaches and parks are now $5.50 an hour, Mr. Halpin said.
Over the last three years, there has been a 30 percent cut in seasonal jobs in proportion with budget cuts, said Brad O'Hearn, a Suffolk County spokesman. But even with the reduction in jobs, there still do not seem to be enough students to fill those available, he said.
''Everybody's looking for kids,'' Mr. O'Hearn said. ''There's been a tremendous explosion in service industries - from fast food to health clubs - and many more businesses are chasing far fewer kids.''
To fill in the gaps over the last few years, Suffolk County has also been hiring the elderly to work in the parks during the summers, Mr. Halpin said.
''It's been working out great,'' he said. ''We are able to match people with nearby parks so that they don't have to travel far distances. For many senior citizens, it's an opportunity to get out of the house and keep busy, and the jobs are a labor of love.''
Island-wide, the summer job that is experiencing the most difficulty in recruiting candidates seems to be lifeguard.
 
Lifeguarding Losing Its Appeal
Lifeguarding is not the sought-after glamorous job that it used to be, Mr. Halpin said. There formerly were many more applicants for lifeguard than positions, he said, but demographics have changed. Last year, there were only 40 lifeguards to fill 50 Suffolk County positions; to keep all areas protected, the county had to pay overtime.
To attract more lifeguards, the starting salary for Suffolk County lifeguards is now $6.75 for freshwater areas and $7.25 for saltwater beaches, rising to $10 an hour for a senior lifeguard with five years of experience.
Starting salary for Nassau County lifeguards is $5.75 an hour; according to Mr. Sinnott, most county lifeguard positions for this summer are filled.
But a shortage of lifeguards has also been the complaint of other municipalities. In the Town of Hempstead, most of the 1,500 summer jobs are already filled, except for lifeguards, whose starting salary is $6.25 an hour, said Mike McConnell, a spokesman.
The Town of Southampton also needs lifeguards, said Edith Valentino, a spokeswoman. Starting salary for first-year lifeguards is $7 an hour, and salaries have gone up significantly over the last few years to remain competitive with private industry, she said.
Many seasonal employees return yearly, and the town tries to hire residents first, Ms. Valentino said.
Although the beaches on the East End are not experiencing difficulty filling jobs of attendants, beachcombers and park laborers, private hotels, restaurants and other businesses need summer employees, Mr. Larocca said. Growing numbers of businesses in the Hamptons are hiring Irish students who are spending their summers on Long Island, he said.
 
400 Jobs in Long Beach
In Long Beach are more than 400 summer positions, including lifeguards, beachcombers, cashiers, gate attendants, camp counelors and sports instructors. To induce more students to fill the summer positions, the city has raised the salary to $4.50 an hour, offered flexible hours and provided free breakfast as a bonus, said City Manager Edwin Eaton.
''It may sound minor to provide rolls and soda,'' he said, ''but last year it cost us $5,000.
''A few years ago, we had terrible trouble filling the summer jobs. Only 40 kids applied for more than 100 positions. This year, there are more applicants, but still not enough students to fill the jobs.''
Any student who wants a job can get one, said Pat McCormick, director of the Long Beach Department of Youth and Family Services.
One service of the department is to help place youngsters in jobs, he said, adding that it might be working for the city at the beach; at McDonald's, which pays $6 an hour; at the baggage claim counters at Kennedy International Airport, which pays $9 an hour, or at Jones Beach, cleaning the beaches for $5 to $6 an hour with free transportation provided.
A separate Summer Youth Employment Program, financed by Federal money, also places youngsters from economically disadvantaged families in different positions within the city and private sector, Mr. McCormick said. There are 40 available positions this summer, and the salary is $4 an hour.
''The jobs are available, but many kids are unskilled and don't like the jobs that are available to them,'' Mr. McCormick said. ''They're looking for the easy way out. I hear, 'I don't want to clean beaches' or 'I don't want to work with little kids.'
''If delivering mail is easier than painting yellow lines on streets, they opt for the easy jobs. If there's an opening in Oceanside, the next town over, they say, 'How am I going to get to Oceanside?'
''But if there was a rock concert in Oceanside, they wouldn't think twice about how to get there.''

HEADLINE: MANAGING;
NURTURING THE NEXT WORK FORCE

BYLINE: By SANDRA SALMANS; Sandra Salmans, a former New York Times reporter, writes about business and education from Washington.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Frank Stoler said he is using ''crackerjack'' computer programs written by students at H. D. Woodson High School in Washington. But Mr. Stoler, senior vice president for mortgage operations at the Federal National Home Mortgage Association, said the mentor program at Woodson, sponsored by his employer, provides something even more valuable to him.
''I do a lot of management by walking around,'' among the young people who work for him, he said. Being a mentor has helped him understand them better. ''I'm pushing 40, and this is a way for me to stay in touch,'' he said. 
The $1 million program, which Fannie Mae, the nation's largest home mortgage investor, introduced in 1988, brings personal and financial support to students at Woodson, an inner-city school with many low-income students. It is one of many programs nationwide that industry has initiated in recent years to help improve public schools and their students. Companies say that if they want to draw on a well-educated, highly skilled pool of workers, they will have to create it.
''Every business in Washington is going to need skilled workers,'' said David O. Maxwell, Fannie Mae's chief executive. ''We have to help produce them, and this is one way.''
Although Fannie Mae's program is not the country's largest or best endowed, its focus on smart and ambitious inner-city teen-agers shows how one company is trying to make a difference - and how the program has made a difference to the mentors, too.
''I'm getting a sense of accomplishment,'' said Henry Cooper, who does account reconciliation in Fannie Mae's operations department. ''And I feel my employer cares about the community.'' The program focuses on the most promising of Woodson's 1,200 students. Anyone who earns all A's and B's in a single semester is enrolled in the Futures 500 Club, a membership that brings a mentor, $500 each semester - deposited in an account earmarked for education - and the possibility of getting one of the 20 summer jobs that Fannie Mae opens for Woodson students.
Since the program began, the number of Woodson students qualifying for membership in the Futures 500 club has doubled, to about 130. There may be some grade inflation by teachers eager to help students, Lonnie Edmonson, an educator who runs the program for Fannie Mae, conceded. But, he said, ''if a C-plus becomes a B-minus, so what? It's another student in the pipeline.''
Although the summer jobs offered by Fannie Mae are fairly mundane - filing, inputting computer data - mornings are devoted to training and development courses.
The mentors' involvement ranges from playing basketball with students on Saturday mornings to helping students apply to college, and they typically do it on their own time. For some students, the most surprising thing about the program is the relationship they develop with their mentors.
Doresa McCombs, an 18-year-old senior, said her circle of friends now includes Carolyn Fitzgerald, who manages Fannie Mae's mortgaged-backed securities back office. ''Before I met her, I thought she would be a snob,'' says Doresa. ''But she's just like me.''
Ms. Fitzgerald and Doresa have conversations by telephone two or three times a week, and do things together. Until last year Doresa had never seen a play or been farther from Washington than neighboring Maryland. But since she entered the program, she has seen the Dance Theater of Harlem and has gone to Boston to visit the campus of Northeastern University, where she will enroll this fall to study engineering. Fannie Mae finances trips allowing seniors to scout colleges.
Besides the relationships with their proteges, mentors also develop relationships with each other. At monthly meetings Mr. Edmonson holds for mentors, ''employees come together in a unique way,'' said Lynn Williams, a secretary and a mentor. ''It's not, 'I'm a secretary, he's a vice president.' You're all mentors.''
 
AN OFFICE THAT 'BUMPS'
These are excerpts from the journal of LaShawn Dennis, an 18-year-old Woodson senior who is a member of the Futures 500 Club:
PUB-DATE: June 26, 1989.
The interns went into this very cold training room with a big round table and nice, comfortable chairs. I thought to myself, ''This is heaven.'' Right then and there, I felt like a businessperson.
Later my supervisor . . . introduced me to all the employees who were working in this section. My first reaction was, they don't like me. I was wrong. The people in the office seemed to be more excited that I was there than I was. I started to become less scared and, by the time I left, I was relaxed.
My office is (excuse the English) bumping. I have a desk, supplies and my own telephone. To top it all off, I have my own personal computer. I (excuse the language) was psyched. No one could tell me that I didn't look like a businessperson, because I looked like one in that office and also felt like one.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
GORBACHEV ISSUES APPEAL FOR CALM AMID PANIC BUYING

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 27

 BODY:
Faced with deep popular anxiety over a Government proposal to more than double food prices, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev made a nationally televised appeal to Soviet citizens tonight to stay calm during a ''tense, difficult and frankly speaking, dangerous'' period.
Delivered two days before he leaves for a trip to Canada and the United States, Mr. Gorbachev's somber, unscheduled 45-minute address came after a weekend of panic buying in Moscow and other cities, where consumers reacted with alarm and distrust to the Government's move to what it calls a ''regulated market economy'' that starts July 1 with a tripling of bread prices. Other price increases are due to follow on Jan. 1.
The economic crisis was not the only problem facing Mr. Gorbachev. New violence broke out today in Armenia on the eve of mass celebrations scheduled for Armenian independence day. Six people were killed in a clash between Soviet troops and a crowd at a railroad station in Yerevan, the capital of Armenia. [Page 7.] 'Don't Succumb to Panic' 
On the economic situation, Mr. Gorbachev said: ''I ask you, dear comrades, don't succumb to panic, don't succumb to panic. Let us look at all this realistically and soberly and we will solve the problem.''
The new economic program, still under discussion in the Supreme Soviet, or Parliament, has been under attack from all sides since it was announced on Thursday. Liberal economists have criticized it as timid, while some politicians, including Mr. Gorbachev's rival Boris N. Yeltsin, have attacked its reliance on the highly unpopular price increases. In the Ukraine, miners have reacted by threatening to strike in protest.
The Soviet President tonight cast doubts on plans, announced last week by top Government officials, to hold a referendum on the economic package, which combines price rises with a compensating increase in salaries. He said the program would be open for ''broad discussion at work collectives and in local soviets,'' or councils. The results of such discussion should filter back to the Kremlin, he said.
Mr. Gorbachev, appealing tonight for a ''joint effort and mutual trust,'' said those who tried to make political gains during the country's current difficulties should be ''put in their place.''
''Of course, all types of ultimatums, incitement and irresponsible calls are impermissible,'' he said. ''This could simply ruin everything and cause irreversible harm.''
As Mr. Gorbachev's political and economic problems continue to mount, the summit meeting in Washington, which starts on Thursday, has receded into the background. Mr. Gorbachev made no reference tonight to the meeting with President Bush in his speech, which was devoted entirely to a stern lecture on the need for economic reform.
Until tonight, Mr. Gorbachev had kept his distance from the economic plan, which was presented by Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. Now, the President has put his own authority behind the measures, which he described as inevitable after earlier attempts at economic change failed to produce results.
''Everyone on the Presidential Council agreed that we cannot afford to go slow,'' he said. ''Despite all the difficulties of today's circumstances, we must nevertheless act: in the next few months or year or so, the situation will become more tense, difficult and frankly speaking, dangerous.''
 
Gorbachev Appears Tense
Mr. Gorbachev, who tonight appeared tense and whose speech was at time halting, faces a list of other problems demanding his attention before his departure for North America on Tuesday. Today, Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, a member of the Presidential Council and the Communist Party Politburo, said today on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press'' that he would be staying in Moscow during the summit talks, a departure from past procedure and a sign of the Kremlin's concern about the internal situation.
Politically, the most pressing question facing Mr. Gorbachev is the election of the next President of the Russian republic - a post for which the leading candidate has been Boris N. Yeltsin, a populist backed by a loose liberal coalition who has become Mr. Gorbachev's most visible opponent.
Mr. Yeltsin's chances for election in a third round of voting this week even edged out the food crisis as the leading topic of discussion on street corners and around kitchen tables this weekend. Many Soviet citizens see the coming summit conference as a necessary and welcome event but largely irrevelent to the main issues of the day.
 
Critical Situation at Home
Some Moscow residents suggested today that Mr. Gorbachev should stay home to take charge of the critical situation in the country. ''It is always better when the master is at home,'' said Lydia Ostanin, a 56-year-old construction worker.
But, she added, ''it is also important that he go to the United States, to learn how they do business there.''
Mr. Gorbachev's international stature is now something many people here take for granted. The issue for many people now is his authority at home.
''He should be more presidential,'' said Vladimir, a 50-year-old who declined to give his last name. ''Somebody needs to enforce the laws - not with repression like Stalin, but just make sure they are obeyed.''
''Now, we have everything coming together at once, economic and political,'' he said. ''All the politicians are in their seats all around the place - the Supreme Soviet, the City Council, the Russian Congress - and there is nothing in the shops. That is not right.''
Today, with most stores closed, the sense of anxiety about the food supplies seemed to ebb somewhat in Moscow. In the farmers' market, where the prices are well above the average family budgets, strawberries and cherries, priced at 15 rubles - $2.40 at the tourist exchange rate - for 2 pounds, drew no more customers than usual. Par for the Course? For some people out strolling through the city on a bright, windy day, this week's political and economic tensions are now par for the course. ''The situation is pretty normal,'' said Rushan, a 28-year-old bureaucrat who did not give his last name. ''There are just some problems with the food supply.''
On Monday, the city of Moscow imposes a new rule limiting purchases in most stores to city residents, a measure that has been greeted with relief by Muscovites who hope it will whittle a few hours off the time they stand in line to do their shopping.
But the new rule produced an outcry from officials in outlying regions, who accused Moscow of abusing its privileged position as the capital and the city's newly elected liberal government of going too far.
This new tension, pitting the city against the provinces, was added to the list of bad feelings that broke to the surface this week at the Congress of Deputies of the Russian republic.
As Sergei B. Stankevich, deputy chairman of Moscow's City Council, tried to explain to a restive and hostile group of provincial representatives, the emptying of the stores in recent days was not the city's doing. ''It is not possible to call this an act of provocation,'' he said.
The city has taken emergency measures to provide for some out-of-towners: Stores near train stations and airports will sell goods to nonresidents, and special provisions will be made for the capital's growing population of refugees.
 
Curb on Residents' Purchases
City residents will also find their purchases further limited - to about 2 pounds of meat a person, 1 pound of sausages, 10 1/2 ounces of butter and just over a pound of coffee.
But some people say they sense a quickening crisis, now spreading from the periphery to the center. In a line queueing up at a cashier's counter in downtown store yesterday, Sasha Pavlov, a resident of the textile city of Ivanovo, complained that he had not been allowed to buy anything on a recent trip to the republic of Latvia, while a neighbor, Georgi Dugaryan, said there was little to buy in Armenia because of a disruption of supplies from the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan.
''And now,'' Mr. Pavlov said, ''we can't get anything in Moscow either.''
