HEADLINE: TOWARD THE SUMMIT;
A Summit Without Maps

BYLINE: By R W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
This week's summit conference between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, the first such meeting of the post-cold war era, promises to be different from any other.
Different, first of all, because the shape of the new Europe, not arms control agreements or ideological argument, will be its principal focus. That difference flows from others: for the first time, a Soviet leader approaches the bargaining table from a position of real weakness at home, with some Western analysts doubting his ability to last another year and others, more confident of his survival, doubtful about his long-term ability to lead. For the first time as well, the two superpowers find their status in doubt. 
Though arms control details and discussions have dominated the preliminary negotiations for this second encounter between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev, this is misleading. Broad agreement will no doubt be reached to reduce strategic arms, though by less than the 50 per cent originally sought, and on chemical weapons, two items from the old East-West agenda.
 
The New Realities
But the success of the meeting will better be measured by the degree to which the leaders come to grips with the new power realities forced on them by a year of constant change.
Both sides appear to understand this as they ponder the consequences of a moribund Warsaw Pact, a North Atlantic Treaty Organization that has lost its main mission, a united Germany and a disintegrating Soviet bloc. Making sense, and stability, of it all is a challenge worthy of Metternich.
''The fundamental issues at the summit are not going to be arms control,'' Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, said today on the ABC News program ''This Week.'' ''The fundamental issues are remaking a political map of Germany and also secondarily what's going on in the Soviet Union.''
On the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, a major adviser to Mr. Gorbachev, emphasized the same issues and added, ''We should expect this meeting will be much more significant than the previous ones.''
 
Staving Off Armageddon
Arms control, as a leading European diplomat put it the other day, matters most when there is no chance of basic political change. ''You nibble away at the edges, hoping to reduce the possibilities that the underlying hostilities will lead to Armageddon.'' But now there is basic political change aplenty, notably in the troubled Soviet Union and in Germany, which seems to be re-emerging as Europe's largest, richest and most powerful land, undoing the balance of power that once existed between NATO and the Warsaw Pact.
Indeed, political and economic imperatives may accomplish what arms control has not and perhaps will not. The 380,000 Soviet troops now in East Germany are highly unlikely to stay there very long; they may be bargained out, but if they are not, at least some of them will probably have to leave because the Soviet Union cannot maintain them or does not think the effort worthwhile. The process might already have begun, except that the Kremlin has no housing or jobs to give returning soldiers.
As they approach this week's discussions, Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush still control the bulk of the world's nuclear weapons - more than 95 per cent, by most calculations. But in their different ways, they have lost control over other matters. The Soviet leader will leave a capital gripped by panic buying, with political power dubious and fragmented, with a sullen almost rebellious populace, with part of an old bloc gone and other parts yearning to leave.
Except in the military sphere, the Soviet Union has lost its place at the head of the list of nations.
No such crises confront Mr. Bush, but he is struggling to redefine and to hold together the NATO alliance that has provided the United States its principal entree into Europe since World War II, at a time when Europe seems to stand on the verge of its greatest postwar strength and cohesion. Other longstanding American alliances, facing greatly lessened threats from the Communist world, are losing their muscle tone.
Mr. Bush must deal with economic challenges to American leadership from Japan and from a reinvigorated Europe, anchored by a Germany moving rapidly toward unification.
 
An Unprecedented Weakness
These fresh realities will shape the negotiating positions here. Mr. Gorbachev, who has achieved so much despite a position of weakness, is now trying to avoid allowing a unified Germany to become a full NATO member. From the Soviet viewpoint, that would in effect undo the results of World War II, because Moscow saw the partition of Germany as one of the chief benefits of its hard-won victory.
Mr. Bush, arguing from a much stronger position, must try to persuade the Soviets to accept German membership in NATO, the chosen American vehicle for ''the new architecture of Europe,'' because only NATO, not the European Community or the nascent Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, would allow the United States a significant role in European decision-making.
The President is not without weapons in this endeavor. His West German allies have already offered a wide range of economic inducements to the Soviets, largely involving the direct payment of marks.
If some compromise on Lithuania and the other Baltic states, a ticklish subject that Mr. Bush has promised to raise at the meeting, can be reached in coming weeks, the United States would be in a position to offer trade concessions, such as most favored nation status, and other economic assistance.
 
The President's Blueprint
In an interview last week with the BBC, Mr. Bush set his own agenda for this week. He said he was looking for answers to such questions as these: ''How does post-German-unification Europe look? Who will be calling the shots? What is the role of the United States in terms of stability?'' What he meant, of course, was not that Mr. Gorbachev could supply the answers at this meeting, but that Mr. Gorbachev's attitudes would be a major factor in the direction that American policy ultimately takes.
Much may turn on the answer to a pair of decisions. Mr. Gorbachev said this week that he would never let NATO, with Germany a member, play the leading role in building a new European security order, as Mr. Bush wants it to.
The President will therefore have to decide how deeply committed his counterpart is to that view, and, if he concludes that Mr. Gorbachev will not budge, he will have to decide how far the West, which holds most of the cards, should push the Soviets on the status of Germany at the risk of generating lasting resentment in Moscow that might undermine the Europe everyone is working so hard to construct.

GRAPHIC: Photo: ''The fundamental issues at the summit are not going to be arms control,'' said Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser. (George Tames for The New York Times) (pg. 6)

LENGTH: 1317 words

HEADLINE: Divisive Abortion Politics Bring Iowa Democrats' Primary to a Boil

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DES MOINES, May 26

 BODY:
The rough new politics of abortion has descended on Iowa, straining old alliances, roiling the race for governor and mobilizing both sides of the issue for a battle being waged from church parking lots to the airwaves.
In the last week Iowa's abortion rights supporters have held 200 house parties, from Sioux City to Davenport, to help organize for the June 5 primary here. The National Abortion Rights Action League has jumped into the Iowa governor's race with a vengeance, vowing to defeat Attorney General Tom Miller, one of three major candidates for the Democratic nomination and the only one who opposes abortion.
 
A Battle of Copying Machines
Abortion opponents, long a powerful force in Iowa politics, say they are activating a well-tested network and are ready for any onslaught. Marlys Popma, the head of the Iowa Right to Life Committee, which is preparing a major mailing that describes the candidates' positions on abortion, said: ''We're working harder than we've ever worked. We can't keep our copying machine alive.'' 
But the abortion battle here, like many such struggles around the country in this year's elections, is not as clear-cut as the campaign speeches suggest. In elections for governor in Virginia and New Jersey in 1989, candidates who supported abortion rights defeated candidates who opposed them. Those elections were widely seen as primers for the new political era opened by last year's Supreme Court decision in the Webster case, which gave states new latitude to restrict abortion.
But the Iowa contest shows how complicated the politics of abortion can be. And the outcome of the primary, in which Democrats will choose a nominee to run against Gov. Terry E. Branstad, an abortion opponent, could add some intriguing new chapters to the abortion politics primer.
 
Concern About Dividing Votes
To begin with, there are two major candidates in the Democratic primary who support a woman's right to choose abortion: Don Avenson, the Speaker of the House, and John Chrystal, a banker who has long been active in politics.
As a result, some supporters of abortion rights are concerned that their votes will be divided and that they will unwittingly aid the nomination of Mr. Miller, meaning that Iowans would have a choice in November between two candidates who oppose abortion rights. So the state chapter of the Abortion Rights Action League endorsed Mr. Avenson on Friday, kicking off an advertising campaign that declares, ''If you want to protect the right to choose, Don Avenson is your choice for Governor.''
This prompted an angry statement from Mr. Chrystal blasting ''tin-horn, would-be kingmakers from Washington.'' The text of his statement was delivered to the abortion rights advocates by a worker for Mr. Chrystal who plopped it on the podium just as the abortion rights leaders were beginning their announcement of support for Mr. Avenson - not exactly emblematic of a new unity on the issue.
Kate Michelman, head of the national abortion rights league, acknowledged in a telephone interview that the decision to endorse one ally over another was unusual but added, ''These are unusual times, and the stakes are unusually high.''
While abortion rights supporters said they had prevailed on every abortion-related vote in the State Legislature this year, they are intent on replacing Mr. Branstad with a more sympathetic governor.
There are other crosscurrents here. Many Iowa Democrats pride themselves on civil and sophisticated politics, and some of them are troubled by what they see as a single-issue attack on Mr. Miller, a popular politician who has been Attorney General for 12 years.
 
'Good Man Is Getting Beat Up'
Tom Whitney, a former state Democratic chairman who is supporting Mr. Miller, watched his candidate campaign in an American Legion hall in south Des Moines the other night and described what was happening as nothing short of tragic.
''A very good man is getting beat up,'' Mr. Whitney said.
Bonnie Campbell, another former state Democratic chairman and a candidate for Attorney General, acknowledged that some Democrats feel torn. ''They remember when the same issue bit us and we begged the pro-life people not to be single-issue people,'' Ms. Campbell said. ''On the other hand, they do see this issue as very important in the larger social scheme.''
Mr. Miller was visibly pained as he talked about the issue in an interview. ''I've been a consistent proponent of no single-issue voting,'' he said. ''I've supported a number of pro-choice candidates in my career.''
Moreover, the Attorney General said, he has repeatedly promised that he ''would not advocate or propose any new restrictions with the exception of parental notification for minors with the appropriate safeguards.''
Many Democrats here say Mr. Miller has been clearly slowed by his opposition to abortion. He began the race as the frontrunner, and the most recent public opinion polls showed it to be a fairly close race with a large undecided vote.
The Des Moines Register's latest Iowa Poll, conducted April 16-18, showed Mr. Miller with 21 percent, Mr. Avenson with 18 percent, Mr. Chrystal with 14 percent, and 41 percent undecided. That poll was based on interviews with 431 people considered likely to vote in the Democratic primary, and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4.7 percentage points.
 
Some Move to One Issue
On Sunday, The Register endorsed Mr. Chrystal for the nomination.
Mr. Miller and his aides argue that the real issues are crime, education, the environment and jobs. Mr. Chrystal's campaign emphasizes his international contacts and the way they can assist Iowa's farm economy. Mr. Chrystal has been a frequent visitor to the Soviet Union where he became acquainted with top officials, including Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He has been invited to lead a delegation of Iowans to meet with the Soviet President when he visits Minneapolis next month, just before the primary, aides said.
Mr. Avenson's campaign portrays him as a fighter who can make strides on issues like education and the environment.
Mr. Avenson said he was convinced the abortion issue would be an important factor in the primary balloting. ''It's the one that creates the most emotion among primary voters,'' he said.
Amy Maxey, a retired associate professor of sociology who held one of the abortion rights parties in her Sioux City home last week, said: ''I come awfully close to being willing to vote single issue, although generally I would deplore that. ''I think this is a critical time for us.''
Some Iowa Democrats said the issue may have waned in recent months, although they added that could change as the voting nears and advertising campaigns intensify.
Mrs. Popma of the Iowa Right to Life Committee said her organization was circulating a brochure that sets out the candidates' stands on abortion and ''shows Miller in a positive light in relation to the other two.'' But she said her group chose not to actually endorse Mr. Miller because he failed to return a questionnaire setting out his stands on various abortion-related issues.
Both sides of the abortion debate say the election in the fall will be an even greater test of the issue: the Senate race here pits Tom Harkin, the incumbent Democrat and a supporter of abortion rights, against Representative Tom Tauke, a Republican opponent of abortion.
And in the governor's race this fall, a spokesman for the Iowa Republicans said the party was confident Mr. Branstad could defeat whomever the Democrats nominate, although many Democrats here assert the two-term Republican is vulnerable.
In the meantime, Iowans are struggling to adjust to the new political landscape. ''It's a new world since Webster,'' said Lois Ichelson, an active supporter of abortion rights and family planning causes. ''It's like walking from one room to another.''

HEADLINE: To Call Consumption Taxes Regressive Is Just a Lame Excuse

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Robert S. McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice (''Are the Democrats Really So Stupid?'', Op-Ed, May 14) and the chairman of General Motors, Roger B. Smith (news article, Business Day, same issue) argue against increasing the gasoline tax because the burden of the tax falls disproportionately on the poor.
To dismiss gasoline and other taxes on consumption because they are regressive is a worn-out excuse since consumption taxes can be nested in an overall progressive tax package or they can be progressively structured. Mr. McIntyre's argument against consumption taxes is indicative of a lack of creativity among champions of the poor, and Mr. Smith's argument is a thin veil for a traditional concern of American car makers: higher gasoline taxes mean lower sales of big American cars.
A revenue-increasing tax package could be created with steep consumption taxes and highly progressive income-tax cuts. Tax on the first $7,700 of income (gross annual minimum-wage earnings) could be eliminated. The proposed capital gains tax cut and expanded Individual Retirement Accounts could be replaced by a tax on the first $4,000 of interest income. 
The alcohol tax could be made progressive by linking the tax per ounce of alcohol to the price of the beverage it is in (e.g., the alcohol in a $50 bottle of wine is taxed at a higher rate than the alcohol in a $5 bottle). Progressive sales taxes could also be designed for big-ticket items like automobiles. The first $10,000 of a car's price could be taxed at a standard national sales tax rate, say 5 percent; the next $10,000 at 10 percent; anything more than $20,000 at 20 percent. This principle could be applied to pleasure boats, big-screen televisions, fur coats, etc.
Shifting taxes from income to consumption while cutting the deficit encourages saving and minimizes disincentives to additional earning. Given that decreasing the deficit and increasing the savings rate is at the top of Japan's list of recommendations for the United States economy, levying consumption taxes reassures foreign investors on the economy's future health and could also be used in bargaining to open Japan's markets.
Should consumption taxes be rejected with the lame argument of regressiveness, it will be clear to all that Americans value consumption over thrift even if it drives us into the ground.
 
REY KOSLOWSKI
Philadelphia, May 15, 1990

CORRECTION-DATE: June 13, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Lines were omitted from a letter May 28 by Rey Koslowski on taxes. The sentence affected should have read: ''The proposed capital gains tax cut and expanded individual retirement accounts could be replaced by a more equitable and simpler investment incentive - eliminate the tax on the first $4,000 of interest income (8 percent interest on $50,000 of savings).''

HEADLINE: Immigrants and Welfare

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Recent research refutes Julian L. Simon's claim in ''More Immigration Can Cut the Deficit'' (Op-Ed, May 10) that immigrants receive no more welfare than natives. The immigration studies of George Borjas, based on census data, show immigrants 15 percent more likely to be in poverty, 13.7 percent more likely to be welfare users, and 6 percent more likely to be unemployed. 
Mr. Simon's generalizations about the youth of immigrants don't hold up either. Mr. Borjas finds immigrants twice as likely to be over 65 and 23 percent more likely to be on Social Security than natives. Lief Jensen's 1988 study of census data revealed even higher levels of poverty and welfare use.
The seductive notion that more immigration can lighten the tax burden in general and the Social Security burden in particular collides with some hard actuarial facts: immigrant earnings are down and their social service costs are up; our earned income tax credit rebates much of the Social Security payments of low earners, and with their migratory life style and later entries into the work force, immigrants tend to qualify for benefits with smaller contributions.
 
DAVID SIMCOX
 Dir., Center for Immigration Studies
 Washington, May 10, 1990

HEADLINE: The Smiles and Chills In the Poetry Of Charles Simic

BYLINE: By D. J. R. BRUCKNER

 BODY:
Charles Simic, who won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry this year with a collection of prose poems, ''The World Doesn't End,'' credits the military police with having helped in the formation of his work. Mr. Simic had begun writing verse in his youth, only a couple of years after he acquired English when he came to this country from Yugoslavia. But his early work was largely imitative.
Then, he says, he was drafted and served as an M.P. briefly in West Germany and later in France between 1961 and 1964. ''The Army had a great impact on me,'' he recalled. ''I was far from everything, all by myself. I had my brother in Illinois send me all the poems I had written and I sat there in the barracks at night reading them and ripping them up, saying: 'This is Pound. This is Cummings. This is Eliot.' And when they were all gone, I thought: 'My God, what will I do now? I've got nothing.''
More than 25 years later, Mr. Simic still seems moved by this shredding of his youth. In a telephone interview from his home in Strafford, N.H., he said, ''I stopped doing all the things I had done before and really began anew.'' Perhaps it is natural that his early experience should still arouse powerful emotions; for him poetry is bound up with finding a new life and a new language. 
 
A Nine-Year Separation
He was born in Belgrade. His father, an electrical engineer who worked for a branch of the Western Electric Company during World War II, was in Italy when the war ended and did not return home, but went on to the United States. It took his wife and children almost nine years to get out of Yugoslavia and join him, with a year in France on the way. Charles Simic was 16 years old when he arrived here in 1954.
Mr. Simic gives much credit to the faculty of Oak Park High School in a suburb of Chicago, where he spent his senior year. ''They did remind you all the time this was the high school of Ernest Hemingway, and that made you wonder who you were,'' he recalled. ''But if they found you were interested in reading they just kept handing books to you.
''Then I found some of the students were writing poetry. They would show it to one another, and I started writing in reaction to what they had done. I didn't know English as well as Serbo-Croatian at the time, but a poem of maybe 10 lines was possible. It was a challenge: it was ambitious for me, but I could probably handle it better than I could have handled prose in English.''
 
'An Obsession With Economy'
In his first few years out of high school he toyed with becoming an artist, and attended the University of Chicago at night while working for The Chicago Sun-Times for several years, two of them as a proofreader of classified advertising, a job that could be seen as a natural apprenticeship for a poet who has, he admits, ''an obsession with economy, the effort to say less and less to mean more and more.''
His first two poems to appear in print were in The Chicago Review in the winter 1959 issue. He had moved a year earlier to New York City to get a degree from New York University and pursue a career in poetry, and eventually to do a dozen years of bookkeeping and accounting to support his literary habit (he was once business manager of Aperture magazine). But he dates his real formation as a poet from his return to New York from the Army.
During the subsequent few years, before his first book of poems was published in 1967, he says: ''I went through enormous changes. Before the Army I had become too literary, buttoned down, in tweeds, pipe-smoking, all that. After the Army I had a much humbler view of myself. I started thinking about a remark of the painter Paul Klee, that if a young man is to accomplish something he has to find something truly his own. Well, I had a kind of minimalist urge and so I started writing poems about the simplest things. Household objects: a knife, a fork, a spoon, my shoes.''
 
Profundity of Everyday Life
There is more than a little irony in his saying he was writing about his flatware; only a very foolhardy critic would say what any Simic poem is about. In rich detail they are all filled with ordinary objects, but they tend to leave the impression that the poet has poked a hole into everyday life to reveal a glimpse of something endless.
Often the vision is hilarious, but Mr. Simic can spring a chilling surprise. In a poem called ''Baby Pictures of Famous Dictators'' he creates a sepia-toned world of turn-of-the-century children, ''Lovable little mugs smiling faintly toward/The new century.'' At the very end, after an idyllic holiday, they are ''carried off to bed by their mothers and big sisters,/ While the dogs remained behind:/ Pedigreed bitches pregnant with bloodhounds.''
If he spent his youthful years imitating the Americans he was reading, his mature poetry is clearly more influenced by French writers. ''There was a time when I thought I had to read them all - Apollinaire, Rimbaud, Baudelaire, Robert Desnos, Max Jacob, all the Surrealists,'' Mr. Simic said. ''I adore the sheer sound of French verse. Indeed, he has translated so many of the French Surrealists by now that there may be readers of French verse in translation who mistake the Simic voice for some of the originals. He has also translated a number of modern Yugoslav poets.
Despite the fact that he came to English after Serbo-Croatian and French, he writes only in English. ''I have not even been tempted to try poetry in other languages,'' he said.
 
The Accidental Book
''The World Doesn't End'' (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich), the book that won the Pulitzer, is his most accidental book. ''The idea of getting a Pulitzer for this is so strange,'' he said, ''but everything about this book has been a surprise. Over the years I wrote down quick notations once in a while. I thought of them as maybe ideas for poems, you know, when maybe the impulses for prose and those for poetry collide.'' Among those that read very much like a Simic idea for a Simic poem is a strange meditation on a butterfly collection:
''A much dwindled, starker annotator sitting in a child's prison for butterflies. There's Phoebus. There's Painted Lady, Dog Face, White Admiral, Zebra, Mourning Cloak, Question Mark, Little Wood Satyr. Their colors are very pretty.
''Who told the little kid about sticking pins into us?''
A couple of hundred of these scraps had accumulated - ''I can't even date them'' - when Mr. Simic decided to enter them into his computer several years ago. He winnowed them down to 60 or 70 and began to toy with them.
''I spent more time on these things than I ever have on a poem,'' he said. ''You know, a sentence is difficult. Its rhythm is very different. When you have a line of a poem, you know you have a line. But with a sentence, you change a word and the whole thing changes and then everything around it.''
 
Elusive Connections
He says he is satisfied the little prose pieces in the book are poems: ''What makes them poems is that they are self-contained, and once you read one you have to go back and start reading it again. That's what a poem does.''
In his case one goes back because he is a specialist in elusive connections, as in the prose poem that begins ''Everything's foreseeable'' and sweeps through a brief catalogue of fateful accidents until he reaches a grandmother who ''says there's no god, only an eye here and there that sees clearly. The neighbors are too busy watching TV to burn her as a witch.'' In his enchantments Mr. Simic is like the family in another prose poem that sought its fortune ''manufacturing objects we had seen in dreams that night.''
His next book, the 14th, to be published later this year, is in verse. It is, he said, ''a kind of homage to New York.'' He and his wife left the city 20 years ago. He taught for several years in a California college; he has been teaching American literature at the University of New Hampshire for 17 years. He has won many awards for his writing, including the MacArthur Foundation fellowship in 1984. Still, he insists that New York ''won't relax its grip on me.'' He wants to celebrate the street life and street scenes of the city, especially of the 50's and 60's when he knew it best. The new work is called ''The Book of Gods and Devils.''
 
'Out in Another World'
''It's a kind of pagan book,'' the poet said. ''There are some strange figures in it, like out of Greek mythology.'' For instance? ''Well, in the late 50's, after a late-night poker party on West 45th Street, somewhere between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, I was walking along and suddenly there were two people stark naked on the street. This one guy was all covered with tattoos. They looked like something out of Ovid, some kind of Gorgons. They passed right by me without even noticing me. It left me very shaken, out in another world. There are things like that to be written about New York. I love it.''
As readers of Mr. Simic's other books know, Gorgons and gods and devils and many another creature one would expect to find only in the most extravagant mythology, turn up in many of his poems, sometimes with ordinary modern American names and outfits covering up their startling strangeness. ''But in New York they are natural,'' the poet said.
 
The bird who watches me
sleeping
from the branch of an apple tree
in bloom.
 
A black bird
for whom a strange man
gathers rocks
in the ruts of the road.
 
And among the willow trees:
water
before water made up its mind
to be water.
 
My sister says if I drink
of that water I will die . . .
That's why the heart beats:
to waken the water.
 
- ''Peaceful Kingdom,'' from ''Selected Poems, 1963-1983'' (1985)
 
When a tree falls in a forest
And there's no one around
To hear the sound, the poor owls
Have to do all the thinking.
 
They think so hard they fall off
Their perch and are eaten by ants,
Who, as you already know, all look like
Little Black Riding Hoods.
 
- ''Bedtime Story,'' from ''Selected Poems''
 
We were so poor I had to take the place of the bait in the mousetrap. All alone in the cellar, I could hear them pacing upstairs, tossing and turning in their beds. ''These are dark and evil days,'' the mouse told me as he nibbled my ear. Years passed. My mother wore a cat-fur collar which she stroked until its sparks lit up the cellar.
 
- ''We were so poor,'' from Part I of ''The World Doesn't End'' (1989)
He held the Beast of the Apocalypse by its tail, the stupid kid! Oh beards on fire, our doom appeared sealed. The buildings were tottering; the computer screens were as dark as our grandmother's cupboards. We were too frightened to plead. Another century gone to hell - and for what? Just because some people don't know how to bring their children up!
 
- ''He held the Beast,'' from Part I of ''The World Doesn't End''
The dog went to dancing school. The dog's owner sniffed vials of Viennese air. One day the two heard the new Master of the Universe pass their door with a heavy step. After that, the man exchanged clothes with his dog. It was a dog on two legs, wearing a tuxedo, that they led to the edge of the common grave. As for the man, blind and deaf as he came to be, he still wags his tail at the approach of a stranger.
 
- ''The dog went,'' from Part II of ''The World Doesn't End''

PUB-DATE: May 28, 1990,

SECTION: Section 1; Page 10, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1308 words

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Incumbents Fear That Incumbency May Become a Campaign Liability

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
Representative John P. Murtha is one of the most influential power brokers in Congress, but in a Democratic primary two weeks ago the voters of his Pennsylvania district nearly turned him out of office.
In Washington, Mr. Murtha, head of a House Appropriations subcommittee on defense, is an insider's insider. But back in Johnstown, the eight-term incumbent was pounded by an underfinanced opponent, and by the local newspaper, for supporting the Congressional pay increase and for accepting speaking fees and contributions from political action committees. When the votes were counted, Mr. Murtha had only 51 percent.
This brush with defeat has sent a shudder through Mr. Murtha's colleagues, reinforcing their feeling that voters are in a dark mood toward politicians this year, striking fear in the hearts of officeholders from the county commission to Capitol Hill. 
 
Evidence Mounts
There is not much doubt about the public's sour attitude toward politicians at all levels. And polling results, isolated election returns and reports from town meetings and shopping malls are suggesting to politicians and their consultants that this mood might be influencing elections.
Representative Mike Synar, who faces a primary in August against an opponent who accuses him of losing touch with his Oklahoma district, has been studying this developing mood on behalf of his Democratic colleagues in the House. ''There is a feeling out there that incumbency is not an advantage,'' he said.
That represents a shift in the conventional wisdom in a body where 98 percent of those who sought re-election in the last two elections won it. No one predicts a drastic change, but Charles Cook, who analyzes Congressional races in a monthly newsletter, says the re-election rate in the House seems likely to fall this year.
 
A Distinction Disappears
One reason is that fewer voters, when questioned by poll takers, no longer make the distinction between their disdain for Congress in general and their respect for their own representative.
It used to be that only one voter in ten thought his or her representative was involved in shenanigans on the Hill. Now, one voter in three thinks so, said Celinda Lake, a Democratic poll taker.
Mr. Synar says a number of poll takers are picking up another trend on a question close to a politician's heart: does an officeholder deserve re-election?
''They are saying the re-elect number is down 10 to 15 percent for incumbents,'' Mr. Synar said.
Nobody knows yet how this mood will affect elections this year. In addition to Mr. Murtha's close call, there is other evidence of an anti-incumbent mood. In a number of elections for local offices in recent weeks, in suburban Chicago, in Indiana and outside Los Angeles, members of school boards, city councils and other government bodies have been dumped.
A primary and a few local results do not prove a trend. But there is a suggestion that voters are beginning to express their frustration with officeholders who cannot seem to curb crime or unclog traffic or hold down taxes or generally get things done.
 
'Disappointed So Much'
''People have been disappointed so much,'' said Raymond Strother, a Democratic political consultant. ''Everything they see and hear about government is some sort of failure. They're just sort of fed up.'' Politicians say being an incumbent does not stir enough anger, by itself, to endanger re-election. It is a combination of factors, as in Mr. Murtha's case: hard times back home, combined with a record of supporting a Congressional pay increase or accepting speaking fees while constituents cannot find a job.
Mr. Murtha and his colleagues still have all the advantages that have made House incumbents difficult to unseat: Government-paid mailing privileges, access to the news media and extensive support from political action committees.
 
Incumbents Fear Change in '90
The fear on Capitol Hill is that 1990 could be a year in which these advantages of incumbency are counteracted by a shifting voter pyschology that makes being in office automatically suspect.
What is particularly interesting, says Mr. Cook, the Congressional analyst, is that the anti-politician feeling seems to be emerging without any great national crisis like Watergate, which brought down many Republicans in the mid-1970's, or roaring inflation, which hurt the Democrats in 1980. A number of consultants and poll takers say it may take until the 1992 elections before it can be seen whether the current discontent will bring another storm of vengeance against incumbents.
But the 1990 campaigns are already heavy with anti-politician themes. ''As I move around the state the one thing I hear more than anything else is 'kick butt,' '' said Lowell Weicker of Connecticut, a former Republican Senator who is now running as an independent candidate for governor. ''That's the mood.'' Candidates Adjust Mr. Weicker's effort is a vivid illustration of how the anti-politician mood has gathered strength and forced politicians to adjust. In 1988 he was turned out of the Senate because his Democratic opponent painted him as an out-of-touch politician who took speaking fees from special interests. Now he is running against both parties, saying the public is fed up with Democrats and Republicans alike.
''The public sees a budget summit not as an exercise in solving our budget problem but making sure not too much heat descends on either party at election time,'' Mr. Weicker said. ''The public's not stupid. They see these things for what they are.''
Thomas D'Amore, a former Republican state chairman and ally of Mr. Weicker, says he tried to stop the former Senator from breaking with the Republicans, but is amazed by the response to his outsider campaign.
Anti-politician sentiment is particularly strong toward Washington. When Baron Hill, an Indiana state legislator who is the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, wanted to attack Daniel R. Coats, the Republican appointed to fill Vice President Dan Quayle's Senate seat, he settled on two words guaranteed to grate on voters.
 
A 'Washington Politician'
Mr. Hill called Mr. Coats a ''Washington politician'' in a radio ad, describing how Mr. Coats had used Government mailing privileges to send 13 million pieces of mail to Indianans.
''He's not a Washington politician,'' responded Mr. Coats's spokesman, Curt Smith, ''He's a Hoosier who's representing Hoosier values in Washington.''
In general, members of Congress are trying to distance themselves from Congress and identify more forcefully with their constituents.
Politicians and their consultants report that voters are angry not so much with government itself, but rather with the politicians who do not seem to be able, or willing, to make government do what the voters want.
Francis X. Bellotti, the former Attorney General of Massachusetts who is running for the Democratic nomination for governor, tried sympathy in a campaign advertisement.
 
'Sometimes They Forget'
''You take care of your family, you vote, you pay taxes and government treats you as though you were a number,'' he said. ''Sometimes they forget who built this state.''
''They'' has become a popular word on the stump and in commercials this year. Poll takers and consultants are intent on showing that their candidates are not part of ''them,'' but instead represent something ''new, different and better,'' a phrase that Squier-Eskew Communications is using in an ad to describe John Silber, the Boston University president, who is also seeking the Democratic nomination for governor. (The third candidate is Lieut. Gov. Evelyn Murphy.) The ad shows pictures of his opponents spinning on a merry-go-round; the announcer calls them the same old faces who have gone round and round in state government.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: May 28, 1990,

SECTION: Section 1; Page 6, Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: Toward the Summit;
At Summit Talks, the Great Indoors Is the Only Setting Gorbachev Needs

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., May 27

 BODY:
The news was a bit of a blow to Mr. Bush, who has been trying eagerly to do a little casual bonding with his more reserved Soviet counterpart.
Soviet and American aides agree that chemistry will be an important factor in this week's summit meeting as the leaders jockey to develop a trusting relationship, one that can help them move East-West relations beyond the cold war.
While the Presidents share a belief that they can use their personalities to shape foreign policy, they have fundamental differences in outlook and style, differences that have so far given their encounters a tentative feeling.
Buoyed by his approval rating at home, Mr. Bush is approaching the summit meeting with a sense of optimism and at times playfulness, as he did before the Malta session in December. But Mr. Gorbachev, faced with the intricate task of saving his country from economic ruin, takes a more somber view. 
 
'A Serious Fellow'
''Gorbachev is a serious fellow and his country and view of history are hanging by a thread,'' said Richard N. Perle, an Assistant Secretary of Defense under President Reagan. ''There is an echo here of: 'You may want to tool around in speedboats off Kennebunkport. I'm trying to save my country.' ''
In past summit meetings and in interviews about the Washington session, which begins on Wednesday, Mr. Gorbachev tends to speak in impersonal terms about governments and matters of state. Mr. Bush tries to frame the matchup in a more personal way.
Mr. Bush, who spent the weekend before the summit talks at his family retreat here, said in an interview broadcast on the Soviet television today that he expected to talk frankly with the Soviet President. ''I've got grandchildren and he's got family and we can talk about it as human beings. 'Hey, what are we going to do to make things a little safer?' ''
He said he thought he had a good personal relationship with Mr. Gorbachev, but added: ''Wait until I see him. Then I'll be able to tell you, because he may be mad with me over some things.'' Sandals, Not Shoes?
Emphasizing that he will press Mr. Gorbachev on the fate of the Baltic republics, which are trying peacefully to secede from the Soviet realm, the President told the Soviet people: ''If we argue, we'll do that pleasantly. He's a tough guy. Listen, I've been around him enough to know that he drives his point home. Well, I can do the same.''
Mr. Bush has made friendly diplomacy in sporty settings a hallmark of his Presidency. He is exceedingly proud of the way he loosened up foreign leaders like President Francois Mitterrand of France, who meandered around Kennebunkport with Mr. Bush, and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, who sat through a Baltimore Orioles baseball game with the President.
There is nothing that Mr. Bush likes better before meeting with a world leader in some relaxing spot than to have everyone change into sports clothes. He likes to take leaders around Kennebunkport's bays at demonic speeds in his motor boat.
He loves sports and martinis and getting away for ''boy's weekends'' of golf and fishing. He feels at his best in one-on-one settings, where he can turn on the charm and try to put himself in his counterpart's shoes. The ultimate challenge, and the leader most resistant to Mr. Bush's folksy, feet-up style, is Mr. Gorbachev.
 
Mind Before Matter
The Soviet President is more cerebral, with a taste for classical literature, philosophy and art. Mr. Gorbachev has a diabetic condition, and he takes only a glass of wine on holidays. He also almost never leaves home without his wife.
Mr. Gorbachev's tastes are in striking contrast to those of past Soviet leaders. In June 1973, Leonid I. Brezhnev insisted on staying at President Nixon's home in San Clemente, Calif., to show off their personal relationship. One chronicler wrote that Mr. Brezhnev's eyes filled with tears twice because he was so moved by Mr. Nixon's hospitality, including a ride in the President's golf cart and a poolside party with Hollywood stars and vodka toasts.
Mr. Gorbachev may want to be toasted by America, but he doesn't want to send images of frivolity back to a country in crisis.
''I think Gorbachev would be appalled at the notion of going out on Bush's boat,'' a senior Bush official said. ''Does he look like the type of guy who would wear a sweatshirt and sneakers and have his hair blowing 50 mile per hour as they pounded across the waves?''
 
Chemistry as Destiny
Some in and outside the Administration worry that Mr. Bush's craving for stability and his tendency to personalize his relationships with leaders can backfire.
''It's very easy to get caught up in personal relationships and fail thereby to analyze the situation accurately,'' said Mr. Perle, who said Americans tended to ''cater to Gorbachev like an anxious bride.''
Mr. Bush defended his proclivity for the personal in his Soviet television interview. ''Some of my critics in this country say, 'Hey, you're putting too much emphasis on Mr. Gorbachev.'
 
And I'm saying, 'I know him.' ''
Summit meetings have shown that chemistry may be destiny. After his Vienna meeting in June 1961 with John F. Kennedy, Nikita S. Khrushchev concluded that the American leader would not stand up to a challenge, a view that some Soviet and American historians think led Khrushchev to place Soviet missiles in Cuba. By contrast, Mr. Brezhnev found Mr. Nixon strong and felt he could work with him.
In meetings with President Reagan, Mr. Gorbachev often spoke sharply and slapped the edge of the table as Mr. Reagan listened quietly, preferring the overall symbolism of the summit meetings to the individual moves in the chess game.
 
'Ron' and 'Mikhail'
Although Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev are men with revolutionary visions and magnetic personalities, the Soviet leader maintained his air of reserve.
''Reagan kept calling Gorbachev 'Mikhail,' figuring that he would call him 'Ron' back, but it never worked,'' a former Reagan aide said.
Mr. Gorbachev also calls Mr. Bush ''Mr. President.'' And even though Mr. Bush loves to be on a first-name basis with world leaders, he takes the hint and calls Mr. Gorbachev ''Mr. President'' in return.
At their first exchange at the Malta meeting last December, Bush advisers recall, Mr. Bush was a little nervous, anxious about how the meeting would go and how Mr. Gorbachev would act. They said Mr. Bush made an extended presentation at the first meeting in Malta, outlining a 17-point plan to help the Soviet Union in part to show his mettle.
But by their second Malta meeting, the skittishness between them had dissipated a bit and they found some common ground.
''They're both practical and energetic,'' said Brent Scowcroft, Mr. Bush's national security adviser. ''They both want to do things and get at things.''
 
An Occasional Chuckle
Mr. Bush's aides said that in Malta the President saw his Soviet counterpart as a direct man who liked to speak his mind, and that the American President appreciated the Soviet leader's frankness.
Soviet officials said that Mr. Gorbachev liked the fact that Mr. Bush was in command of his facts and that the two could roam through various issues without opening their briefing books.
The Soviet President reportedly also found Mr. Bush discreet, and he began to feel that his words would not be distorted for political purposes.
''They have begun to develop the kind of relationship that allows them to discuss the most delicate problems,'' said Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, the new Soviet Ambassador in Washington.
The Americans in Malta noted with relief that Mr. Gorbachev could chuckle and tease on occasion, a verbal sparring that Mr. Bush enjoys as well.
When he ran into his spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, chatting with Mr. Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, on the cruise liner Maxim Gorky, Mr. Gorbachev observed: ''I see we have two spokesman together. What I'd do with spokesmen is put you in a bag and dump you over the side of the ship.''

LENGTH: 861 words

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
Tiny Village Welcomes U.S.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAD RAGAZ, Switzerland, May 27

 BODY:
To say that it is quiet around here almost disturbs the calm. Church bells ring at the appropriate times. Horses pulling wagons of tourists neigh now and again. Somewhere off in the distance, a dog barks and a rooster crows.
But that's about it. A village of 4,500 doesn't make much noise, or anything else, for that matter. While the principal industry here is tourism, the majority of visitors, as many as 6,000 during the peak summer months, barely add to whatever commotion there is. 
The tourists come to Bad Ragaz for one reason only: to soak in thermal baths, reputed to work wonders for rheumatism, arthritis and other ailments common to older people.
Indeed, the average age of a tourist is around 60, according to Robert Staub, the 45-year-old Mayor. Younger faces are so rare they provoke staring. ''Sometimes I think I'm working in an old-age home,'' said a woman behind the reception desk of a local hotel. ''When I see a couple in their 50's, I think, 'Oh, young people.' ''
The demographics hardly bother the Mayor, inasmuch as the 105-degree waters, piped down from springs in the nearby central Alps, have been warming villagers and visitors for almost 150 years.
 
Well-Known Soakers
 In his office, the Mayor keeps a book that lists some of the well-known people who have soaked there. They include Victor Hugo, Hans Christian Andersen, James Fenimore Cooper, Freidrich Nietzche, Thomas Mann, Hermann Hesse and Johanna Spyri, whose story, Heidi, was written here and based on the life of a girl who lived in the next village, Maienfeld.
For all the visitors to Bad Ragaz over the years, famous and otherwise, none would seem so unlikely as the group of Americans who arrived today. For one thing, the members of the United States national soccer team have an average age of 23. For another, they may have little time for therapeutic baths, however badly they might need them.
Bound for the World Cup finals next month in Italy, the team has arranged to stay here for a week to take advantage of the quiet setting and first-rate training facilities offered free by the Bad Ragaz Football Club, which has, among its 300 members, a handful of players good enough to hold down third place in a third division league.
The Americans will train daily and play two games, one Wednesday night in Eschen, Liechtenstein, against Liechtenstein's national team; the other Saturday in St. Gallen, against the Swiss national team.
 
To the Mayor's Delight
 Then, the United States team plans to leave by bus for Tirrenia, a small town on Italy's west coast, which will serve as its base for the three games of the first round of the World Cup finals. It would be somewhat redundant to say that Staub is delighted to have the Americans in his midst, even if he had nothing to do with getting them here.
Before he was first elected in 1981, he served as the director of tourism for the canton, or state, in which Bad Ragaz is situated. Before that, he was a banker in London. With the village immersed for some time in a campaign to attract more younger people, he recognizes the public relations value of the team training here.
''We are now trying to make people know that we have more than the baths,'' he said in an interview. ''This is why it is very good to have the soccer team here. We can say that we are not just for old people.''
The idea to bring a World Cup team, any World Cup team, to Bad Ragaz originated with neither the Mayor nor any of the village leaders. In fact, they credit the chef at the Quenellehof Hotel, a five-star establishment adjacent to the famous baths. He had suggested to a friend at the Swiss national soccer federation that the tranquillity of the area and its proximity to Italy would make it ideally suited for a team bound for the World Cup.
Several other Swiss cities had the same idea, including Lausanne, Lugano and Locarno, so the Swiss soccer federation let it be known to World Cup participants that training sites were available. In February, American team officials toured some of them and chose Bad Ragaz over Locarno for its facilities and convenience. The training center is little more than a walk from the four-star Bristol Hotel, which agreed to exclude all other guests during the team's stay.
 
Five Police Officers
 Staub admitted he had no idea what economic benefits, if any, his village might derive from the American team. Little seems to matter but the baths, which cost 11 francs, about $8, for 20 minutes, the recommended soaking time. In the last 10 years, the village population has grown by just 500; three municipal buses and a police department of five is more than adequate.
Yet some villages wonder if more could not be done to improve business. Manfred Bereiter, the manager of the Bristol, used Heidi as the perfect example. While the book brought some attention to the area after it was published in the 19th century, as have several film versions of the novel, nothing has been done since.
''No one has taken advantage of it,'' he said, sitting with the Mayor at an outdoor table at the hotel. ''If this were America, there would already be a Heidiland.''

SECTION: Section 1; Page 33, Column 4; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 950 words

HEADLINE: AUTO RACING;
Luyendyk Wins in Fastest Indianapolis 500 Ever

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, May 27

 BODY:
What was fine weather for Arie Luyendyk and about 350,000 fans who watched him win the Indianapolis 500 today turned out to be miserable conditions for Emerson Fittipaldi, Al Unser Jr. and a bunch of Goodyear tires.
Luyendyk, a 36-year-old racer from the Netherlands, beat Bobby Rahal to the finish line by 10.7 seconds for his first Indy-car victory after more than 6 years and 76 starts.
And despite winning the race at the fastest average speed ever, 185.984 miles per hour, Luyendyk's victory was partly a result of the literally blistering pace set by Fittipaldi and Unser. Luyendyk finished the race 14 minutes sooner and with an average speed more than 15 miles per hour faster than the previous record-holder, Rahal, who won in 1986. 
The weather today, 64 degrees at the start with a high of 75 under mostly sunny skies, was a sharp change from the generally cool, cloudy conditions that had kept the track surface cool, fast and easy on tires throughout the month.
 
Right Rear Tire Suffers
Because the weather was so much hotter today, Fittipaldi, who led 128 of the first 135 laps of the 200-lap race, wound up putting too much strain on his right rear tire, which caused the tire to overheat and blister.
The blistering, which also afflicted Unser as soon as he tried to run hard enough to catch Fittipaldi, made the tires vibrate dangerously and forced both drivers to make extra pit stops to change tires, dropping them to third and fourth at the end.
Back in the team's garage after the race, Doug Shierson, Luyendyk's car owner, was asked what his team had done to avoid the blistering.
''I won't comment on that at all,'' Shierson said with a trace of a grin as he accepted congratulations.
''I don't know what we did,'' Luyendyk said when asked the same question.
The answer might be found in understanding what Fittipaldi, who finished third, did wrong.
''I was very disappointed,'' said Fittipaldi, who won the race last year and started from the pole today. ''The car was handling beautifully.''
It may have handled too beautifully.
Teddy Mayer, the chief engineer for Fittipaldi's Penske-Chevy, said the tires provided by Goodyear, the exclusive supplier here, weren't faulty but were just too soft for today's weather.
''If we'd've had this kind of weather early in the month, we'd've been on the backup compound,'' Mayer said.
He was alluding to a slightly harder tire that Goodyear had available if teams wanted to use it. A harder tire is less likely to blister on a warm day, but it also provides less traction than softer, stickier tires.
Fittipaldi's fast pace put more of a strain on the right rear tire because as it took the four left-hand turns on the two-and-a-half-mile oval, the back end of the car wanted to go out.
 
A Speed/Stress Trade-off
When a car handles like this, it's said to be ''loose.'' It's a faster way to go, but puts more strain on the right rear tire.
Mayer said the problem didn't appear earlier in the race because the first two sets of tires the team used were broken in for 15 to 20 laps each earlier this month. This had cured the rubber, hardening it slightly.
''The later sets had only five or six laps in them,'' Mayer said. ''We didn't expect the tires to be that marginal.''
Leo Mehl, Goodyear's director of worldwide racing, said the faster teams outsmarted themselves.
''Many of the teams used higher air pressure in the right rear tire than we recommend,'' Mehl said.
A tire that's inflated harder has less rolling resistance, and thus more speed. Mehl said that when the teams lowered the air pressure, the problem disappeared.
 
'Push' Factor for Rahal
''We have a backup compound,'' Mehl said, in response to Mayer. ''But racers will not use a backup compound if they fear they will lose too much speed.''
Rahal, who also avoided the tire blisters, said his team had followed Goodyear's inflation recommendations. Also, he said, his car had ''push'' all day, meaning the front end, not the back, was leaning more heavily to the right.
Rahal said another kind of bad tire choice had allowed Luyendyk to pass him on lap 168 and pull away.
''On the last pit stop, we put some old tires on and we lost grip,'' he said.
Rahal and Luyendyk also conserved their tires early in the race by running a slightly slower pace than Fittipaldi did. Luyendyk was usually several seconds behind the leaders while running in the top five. Rahal, who ran second to Fittipaldi most of the time, never really challenged him.
 
Landed the Right Engine
Both Luyendyk and Shierson, who hired him after last season, were helped immeasurably by finally being able to buy the dominant Chevrolet engine this year.
Ilmor Engineering, the British company that builds the turbocharged Chevy racing engine, limits the number of teams it supplies, to be sure it can properly service the dozen or so motors each car needs per season.
When Ilmor decided to add a team last year, it picked Shierson's team.
''I wanted it and felt we deserved it,'' Shierson said. ''We proved we could win.'' And why did he hire Luyendyk? ''Because I thought he was a winner,'' Shierson said. ''And he is.''
Luyendyk said: ''Sometimes you've got to be patient and wait until you get your hands on the right equipment.''
Luyendyk, who now lives in Brookfield, Wis., didn't know that Shierson would get the Chevy when he joined the team, but when he found out, he knew the pressure would be on to finally win a race.
''I thought, 'If you're not going to win races this way, you better look to something else,' '' he said.
Luyendyk's prize money, which should exceed $1 million, will be announced at the victory dinner Monday night.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 31, Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 970 words

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A LEANER MACMILLAN PROFITS IN BEST SELLERS

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
For almost two months, the best-selling hardcover nonfiction book in America has been ''Men At Work,'' a baseball book by George Will.
If that is a surprising topic for a political analyst, some book industry officials are even more surprised that it was published by Macmillan.
''They have a tremendous backlist,'' said Steven West, manager of Chassman & Bem bookstore in Burlington, Vt., ''but I don't think of them as a major force in book publishing.''
Mr. West's assessment is shared by many publishers and editors - and with apparent good reason. A few years ago Macmillan said it was abandoning big-money auctions, in which too often it won the bidding but lost money after publishing the book. 
 
Takeover by Maxwell
 Then, Macmillan's management fought an expensive, unsuccessful war in 1988 to prevent a takeover by Robert Maxwell, the British media entrepreneur. His company, Maxwell Communication, ultimately bought Macmillan for almost $2.6 billion.
At the time, industry executives speculated that Mr. Maxwell would sell Macmillan's most valuable parts, including its reference and children's books, and abandon its small and risky business in trade, or general-interest, books.
Mr. Maxwell could still do so, of course. But he has vowed to be a leading publisher of trade books, and Macmillan's adult trade division has responded with five best sellers over the last nine months: ''Joshua and the Children'' by Joseph F. Girzone, ''Kaffir Boy In America'' by Mark Mathabane, ''Pete Rose: My Story'' with Roger Kahn, ''The Tempting of America'' by Robert Bork and the book by Mr. Will.
''It's the first time in our history we can remember having five best sellers in a row,'' said David Shaffer, president and chief operating officer of Macmillan Inc. He added that the general publishing group, which includes trade books, college texts and computer books, ''had its best year ever in 1989 for sales and profits.''
Sales of the general publishing group totaled $256 million last year, up from $56 million in 1980, and the company is said to have a 16 to 17 percent profit margin. Within the group, trade book profits are running about 9 percent, or about double the industry average. Trade publishing was led by the Free Press, the imprint headed by Erwin A. Glikes that published the Bork book; its profits are thought to have been close to 30 percent.
 
Largely Psychological Influence
 Given the lead time necessary to publish a book, Macmillan's recent best sellers cannot be credited to Mr. Maxwell, who has made few managerial changes at Macmillan.
Rather, the Maxwell influence has been largely psychological. On the day he acquired the company, he told senior staff members that he was committed to publishing good books.
''It was the first time some of them had heard this kind of talk, and it had a tremendous effect on morale,'' said Barry Lippman, president and publisher of Macmillan adult trade division.
For a short while after the takeover, Kevin Maxwell, a managing director of Maxwell Communication and a son of the owner, oversaw Macmillan from its offices in Manhattan. He has since returned to Britain, leaving Mr. Shaffer in command.
But Robert Maxwell's Macmillan is a different company from the one he bought. Burdened by debt, Mr. Maxwell has sold Macmillan's magazine group, the direct-marketing operation, the Michie Company Law Publishing, the Gump's department store chain and the Katherine Gibbs Schools. He will soon put the P. F. Collier Encyclopedia unit on the block. And he merged Macmillan's school publishing division with that of McGraw-Hill, while selling 48 percent of Berlitz in a public offering.
''Yes, some sales were made to pay down the debt,'' Mr. Shaffer acknowleged. ''But we chose to sell businesses that didn't fit what we want to be, or businesses where we could not realize economies of scale.''
The assets that Macmillan retained, he said, are ''the most valuable, the most profitable and the ones we want - basically general publishing, information services, technology and data-base publishing.''
Ivan Obolensky, a publishing analyst with the investment firm Josephthal & Company, said the Maxwell strategy appears to be well thought out. ''Before it was a mishmash of businesses,'' he said. ''Now they're much more focused.''
Macmillan still does not chase expensive books, but it will pay six or seven figures in some cases. It paid $2 million for former Secretary of State George P. Shultz's memoirs and $300,000 for the Pete Rose story.
Even before the Maxwell acquisition, Macmillan's strength was in its children's, reference and computer books, as well as in cookbooks and books about gardening and baseball. These are generally acquired at relatively low cost and have few returns from the stores.
 
Criticism of Macmillan
 Some authors and industry executives, however, are critical of Macmillan's approach, which they say puts profits ahead of editorial vision.
One literary agent notes that while the company makes plenty of money from its backlist of titles by such authors as Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald and Edith Wharton -books originally published by Charles Scribner's Sons, which Macmillan bought in 1985 when it also acquired Atheneum Publishers - it has virtually transformed both imprints into outlets for nonfiction.
''Why don't they use their profits to publish literature or nurture new novelists?'' he asked.
''That's a legitimate criticism,'' responded Harry McQuillen, president of Macmillan Publishing. ''But we're starting to change.''
He said both imprints were re-directing their focus toward fiction.
''We've had to overcome a very, very difficult reputation from a few years ago,'' Mr. McQuillen sad. ''Now that we've done that, it's time to move forward again.''

HEADLINE: Demand in U.S. Lifts Machine Tool Orders

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Orders for American-made machine tools increased 8.9 percent in April from March, rising to their highest level since September, according to a trade association.
Analysts said that the results reflected slight increases in capital spending by domestic manufacturers, especially aircraft companies.
Machine-tool orders climbed to $289.4 million in April, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said in its monthly report, scheduled for release today. That followed a 36.6 percent increase in March, when new orders soared to $265.8 million. 
New orders from domestic manufacturers climbed 39.8 percent in April from the March level. But orders from foreign customers plunged by more than two-thirds.
Officials of the machine-tool companies attributed the rise in domestic orders to more robust demand from aircraft makers and slightly increased demand from auto makers.
Compared with the levels of April 1989, new orders were up 19.3 percent.
Despite the overall increase in machine-tool orders, some economists said the figures reflected the economy's sluggishness, as well as a reluctance by manufacturers to spend more heavily to upgrade plants and equipment.
''The economy has not been generating much profit for companies,'' said Neal M. Soss, the chief economist at the First Boston Corporation. ''And that is not the environment in which you expect buoyant capital spending to occur.''
The strength of tool orders generally reflects the strength of industrial production. Economists consider patterns in machine tool sales to be important indicators of capital spending by manufacturers.
Machine tools are power-driven devices that cut or shape metal parts used in products like appliances, vehicles, aircraft and construction materials.
 
Optimism About Detroit
 In recent months, auto makers sharply curtailed their machine-tool orders because of slumping sales. The auto industry accounts for about a third of domestic machine-tool sales.
But Richard Priebe, a spokesman for the Cross & Trecker Corporation, a Bloomfield Hills, Mich., machine-tool maker, said that Detroit was slightly increasing capital spending and that orders from auto companies should grow the rest of this year.
''Domestic auto companies are looking at the new generation of engines,'' he said. ''And changes in emissions standards mean that there will be considerable expenditures that will affect machine-tool companies.''
Analysts said the sharp decline in foreign orders did not reflect declining interest in American-made machine tools. Rather, they said, the demand in March was unusually high because of a $63 million order to Cross & Trecker from Soviet auto makers.
Indeed, new orders from foreign customers were up 47.6 percent for the first four months of this year, compared with the similar 1989 period. For this year's January-April period, overall new orders declined by 9.1 percent from the 1989 level, and domestic orders were off 16.5 percent.
Since April of last year, new orders from domestic manufacturers have risen 23.3 percent, while orders from foreign customers have fallen 11.2 percent.
Shipments of machine tools declined 10.6 percent in April, to $258.2 million, from $288.9 million in March. The level of shipments was up 3.5 percent from the April 1989 level, however. Also, shipments increased 11.1 percent in the first four months of the year, compared with a year earlier.
 
Cutting Tools
 New orders for metal-cutting tools, which include boring mills and lathes, were up 4.4 percent in April from the previous month and were 35.4 percent higher than in April 1989.
But new orders for metal-cutting tools dropped 12.3 percent for the first four months of this year, compared with the similar period of 1989. Metal-cutting tools typically account for about three-fourths of orders.
Orders for metal-forming tools increased 22.1 percent in April from the March level. But orders for new metal-forming machine tools decreased 8 percent in April, compared with April 1989. For the first four months, new orders for metal-forming tools dropped six-tenths of 1 percent, compared with the similar period of 1989.
The machine-tool order backlog for April was $1.71 billion, up from $1.68 billion in March. The backlog in April 1989 was $2.29 billion.

 Mikhail S. Gorbachev appealed to Soviet citizens to stay calm during a ''tense, difficult and, frankly speaking, dangerous'' period. The total number of subscribers rose only 5.3 percent, to 39.1 million. [31.] A little-noted, but indispensable niche is growing in the $7 billion-a-year publishing industry - escorts for authors. HEADLINE: Homeless Get New Start In Westchester Program

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y.

 BODY:
After eight years of shuffling in and out of welfare motels, Valerie Covel and her three children, ages 11, 13 and 15, are ready to rejoin society. Their launch pad is a transitional housing program designed to help homeless families find the skills, the courage and ultimately the permanent housing to end the cycle of despair.
''I'm never going to be homeless again after this, I can tell you that,'' said Ms. Covel, 38, sitting on a bench in a sun-drenched courtyard here. ''There's nothing like having your own home.'' 
The housing complex on Franklin Street, known as Westhelp and conceived by Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's son, is called transitional because it takes homeless families stuck in Westchester County's network of roadside motels and eases them into apartments.
In contrast to the motels, where families feel more like characters in Sartre's ''No Exit'' than like guests, the complex prepares the families for apartment living by turning them into remedial students of life - it offers a combination of self-help classes and house rules reminiscent of a fairly restrictive college dorm.
 
Fierce Opposition
While Mr. Cuomo already oversees complexes in Albany and Brooklyn, this is the first to open in Westchester, where he has met fierce opposition from residents fearful of drugs, crime and falling home values. The antagonism he had to overcome in Mount Vernon was minor, however, compared with that in nearby Greenburgh, where neighbors have threatened to secede from the town to block a proposed project.
In Mount Vernon, the program seems to be working. Since opening last December, the 46-unit complex has placed 15 families in permanent housing. That is only a dent in the county's homeless population of more than 4,000, but county officials and social-service workers see in the program the glimmer of a solution to the crisis.
The police say they have not received a single complaint from the neighbors, and the brick-clad structure blends in so well with the community that people unaware of its purpose often stop there, hoping to rent an apartment.
''So far, it's a shining star,'' said Norman Shaw, a spokesman for the county's Social Services Department.
''This is not a hotel or motel where visitors are free to come and go,'' said Mount Vernon's Mayor, Ronald A. Blackwood. ''This is a place that is designed to bring order to your life and reschedule your priorities. That's why it's better than any other program I have seen or heard about.''
 
A Full-Time Staff
Westhelp does this several ways. Each arriving family is given a medical examination and a furnished apartment. A full-time staff, including two social workers, two housing specialists and a recreation director, run day care, high school equivalency classes, seminars on finding and keeping a home, weekly discussion groups and other activities.
There are rules, too. Residents must be home by midnight. They are not allowed to bring visitors into their apartments. They can meet with visitors only in the lobby, where a staff member is always on duty. And they must give their destinations on a sign-out sheet when they leave.
By contrast, the motels, many of them far outside the county in rural areas, offer no such support or restrictions. Drugs and fights have been common, and homeless parents there have to concentrate on getting through each day, equipped with only an illegal hot plate, thin walls and cheap door locks.
''This is a sanctuary where the world cannot intrude,'' said Norman Lipton, the director of the Westhelp complex here. ''We're not just giving them a safe complex and letting them fend for themselves, but we're saying, 'We're going to help you get back on your feet.' ''
 
Rankled by Rules
Of course, the rules rankle some of the residents, most of whom are single mothers from Mount Vernon. ''A lot of the other women don't like the fact they can't have visitors, but if everybody has their boyfriend or man coming here, it would be trouble,'' Ms. Covel said. ''I tell them that if your man really cared about you, you wouldn't be here.''
A third of the homeless in the county originate from Mount Vernon, an economically depressed city bordered by the Bronx and Yonkers. Those families get preference at the complex here.
When it comes to finding housing, Westhelp's staff cannot work miracles. They are up against a shortage of affordable housing throughout the county, with a quarter of all rental apartments lost to co-op and condominium conversions in the 1980's. Many landlords will not accept tenants on public assistance. Many homeless mothers will not accept apartments in the city's drug-plagued neighborhoods.
But the housing workers methodically match apartments and families. Janet Robinson teaches a five-session course on the ABC's of housing, covering tenant rights and responsibilities, signing leases and challenging evictions. She also asks the residents to draft ''bare-bones'' budgets for their first year and to distinguish, in writing, between their needs and wants.
After securing the necessary housing subsidies and shelter allowances, Dolores Mitchell gives the residents lists of vacant apartments in their price ranges. When an apartment is too expensive, she will negotiate with the landlord to lower the rent.
 
'Much Easier'
In a course evaluation, one homeless woman in her early 20's wrote that ''finding permanent housing and keeping it is harder than I thought, but with the help of this program it's much easier.'' She and her 3-year-old son have since moved into a one-bedroom apartment in Yonkers.
The program's graduates are to be visited in their apartments every three months during their first year by either Ms. Robinson or Ms. Mitchell and twice during their second year. ''We help you help yourself,'' Ms. Robinson said. ''I will not take anybody by the hand. We are dealing with adults.''
What is perhaps most gratifying to Mr. Cuomo is how cost effective Westhelp has proved.
The county, state and Federal governments together spend from $36,000 to $39,000 a year to house one family in a motel room. But the cost to governments of an annual stay in the Mount Vernon complex, with all its benefits, is only $30,000 a year. That money also helps pay off the mortgage on the building, which after 10 years will be turned over to Mount Vernon for housing for its elderly residents or civil servants.
''It's a better service for the homeless at less cost to the taxpayer, and it doesn't burden the community,'' Mr. Cuomo said.
''We have a real bargain here,'' said John J. Allen, the Commissioner of the County Social Services Department. ''The difference is that the motels are profit-making, and this is not.''
