HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Sacrificial Lambs Are Hard to Find. Wonder Why?

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:

Now, as the night
 began to fall
 a hungry lion
 paid a call.
 He looked Pierre
 right in the eye
 and asked him
 if he'd like to die.
 Pierre said,
 ''I don't care!''*
Like the little boy in Maurice Sendak's cautionary tale, Pierre Rinfret must figure he has nothing much to lose by challenging the king of New York's political jungle, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Mr. Sendak's character was eaten alive without a fight. Mr. Rinfret (pronounced Rin-FRAY), an articulate 66-year-old economist, is a director of a newsprint company, among other businesses, but as a candidate may be only a paper tiger. 
Given New York's fiscal state after nearly 16 years of Democratic governors and voters' disinclination to anoint an officeholder for life, no candidate should be judged invincible.
Five months before the election, though, this two-term Governor appears to be about as close to political invulnerability as most mortals get.
Like the blustery month, Mr. Rinfret may come in emulating a lion, but seems destined to go out as a sacrificial lamb.
Even so, the Republican Party convention that opens in Westchester tomorrow and which is tentatively planning to designate Mr. Rinfret caps an embarrassing search for a challenger to Mr. Cuomo.
In contrast, every time Democrats faced the last elected Republican governor, Nelson A. Rockefeller, no shortage of seemingly respectable candidates fought for the opportunity.
''Sure, I thought it was worth a shot,'' says Robert M. Morgenthau, now the Manhattan District Attorney, who unsuccessfully challenged Mr. Rockefeller in 1962.
''When I went, I think Rockefeller was ready to be taken,'' says Frank O'Connor, who was the Democratic nominee and loser in 1966. ''He was taken by me,'' Mr. O'Connor said, adding that his efforts were damaged by Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.'s spoiler candidacy on the Liberal Party line.
In 1970, Mr. Rockefeller handily dispatched Arthur J. Goldberg, who in his first and last hurrah boasted great credentials but seemed to be under the misapprehension that he was running for the United States Supreme Court.
Yes, public opinion polls suggested that Mr. Rockefeller was more vulnerable than Mr. Cuomo appears to be. But Mr. Rockefeller's singular commingling of financial and political power made him formidible under any circumstances. Why aren't credible Republicans as eager to challenge this governor?
The party's over. Political discipline has declined. The governorship is the glue that holds a state party together; the Republicans last held it in 1974. The only incumbent Republicans elected statewide - Comptroller Edward V. Regan and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato -are largely party poopers out for themselves. Liberal Republicans no longer dominate the party.
The Republican candidate pool is shallow. Democrats, typically more diverse, already controlled most municipal offices in New York City, Albany and Buffalo. Since the 1970's, they have scored inroads in Assembly and county executive races elsewhere. Some might-be Republican candidates for governor, meanwhile, may have stayed out in hopes that Mr. D'Amato can be taken next year.
Mr. Cuomo is flush. His $7 million campaign account seems to be earning nearly as much in annual interest as Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, spent on his Republican race for governor in 1986. (By some estimates, what Mr. Rockefeller spent in 1970 would be the equivalent of $30 million today). Incumbency is tough to overcome.
Mr. Cuomo will win anyway. So, this argument goes, bloody the Governor. But don't give him a credible opponent whose defeat would project Mr. Cuomo as a giant killer whose next target might be President Bush in 1992.
With access to enough money to run a respectable campaign, Mr. Rinfret fits the bill -particularly if Mr. Cuomo agrees to debate. (Forget it, one Cuomo confidant said half-jokingly, unless minor candidates are invited and Mr. Rinfret releases 66 years of tax returns.) The Governor, meanwhile, will be measured against his lofty rhetoric and his record victory four years ago. Which is why, before he enters the fray, at least, this unlucky Pierre might say, ''I don't care.'' *From ''Pierre: A Cautionary Tale,'' copyright c 1962 by Maurice Sendak. Published by Harper & Row. All rights reserved. Used with permission.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
What Kind of Policy?

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
In a Harvard lecture on what he called ''the American Romance,'' Richard Darman recently declared that America ''was founded by risk-takers, expanded by risk-takers and led to the highest standard of living on earth by risk-takers.''
Now, the Bush Admnistration's powerful budget director said, ''we must renew the risk-taking capacities that historically have expanded so many frontiers . . . We must counter the tendency to become a risk-o-phobic society.''
Romance and rosk-o-phobia aside, Mr. Darman's lecture did not mention that the risk-takers who built the American railroads, which made possible vast U.S. economic and geographical expansion in the 19th century, were underwritten by Federal subsidies and lucrative government land grants.
He did not point out that the interstate highway system, a major boon to 20th-century prosperity, was built by the Federal Government, or that the commercial and private traffic on those highways has been subsidized by a low Federal gasoline tax. He did not refer to the nation's airports, largely paid for with Federal funds, or to its commercial aircraft, developed with the aid of Federal research investments. Nor did he recall that much of today's high-tech industry was spun off from federally financed military and space research. 
In sum, Mr. Darman gave no credit at all to the unromantic industrial policy - Federal aid and encouragement to vital enterprises - that at most stages of American economic development has taken some of the risk out of risk-taking. He did not explin that a nation having no positive industrial policy nevertheless follows a negative industrial policy; it's not so much whether it has such a policy, but what kind.
Some economic analysts and members of Congress assert that Mr. Darman, aided and abetted by John Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Michael Boskin, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, has led the Bush Administration into opposition to an industrial policy that would aid U.S. industrial and commercial competitiveness. They believe that as Mr. Darman's Harvard remarks suggest, he and the others consider such a policy to be unwise interference in the free market.
Thus, a letter signed by Republican Senator John Heinz and Democratic Senator Al Gore, among other members of Congress, criticized the recent ''firing and silincing'' of Dr. Craig Fields from the Defence Advanced Research Projects Agency (Darpa) as ''at best short-sighted, at worst a major breach of our future economic security.''
Dr. Field's ''innovative'' use of Federal research funds to support ''cutting-edge technologies'' had made hime, the letter said, ''a symbol of the kind of industry-government cooperation that will be crucial to revitalizing the U.S. industrial base.''
Darpa, over the years, has directed such funds into seminal research in computer science, the design of fast microprocessro chips, ceramics and date transmission, all of which had civilian as well as military payoffs. As director of Darpa, Dr. Fields supported Sematech, a semiconductor-manufacturing research center, and allocated $30 million to high-definition television research, which is touted as having dual potential.
The Administration diverted to other uses $20 million of the HDTV allocation. In April, Dr. Fields was transferred out of Darpa after investing $4 million in a company developing a radiation-resistant gallium arsenide chip as a substitute for silicon. Because of reduced Administration support, moreover, Michael Sekora, who headed a Pentagon project to accumulate data on competitive foreign technologies as a research tool for U.S. technological development, has returned in frustration to the private sector.
''By any measure, the Japanese system works much better than our [in] building and maintaining national economic strength,'' Dr. William Schreiber, an M.I.T. engineering professor and a member of the Pentagon's High-Resolution Systems Task Force, said in a letter to me. ''The belief that the market always gives the right answer is a kind of economic religion based on faith and not on reason.'' Others argue that sensible industrial policy would measure national security properly, in terms of economic stability and industrial wealth as well as military prowess.
As even Richard Darman conceded at Harvard, ''The challenge . . . is to manage risks more rationally, and to select the appropriate risks.'' That's risky, of course, but sound industrial policy.

HEADLINE: Faces of the Summit: 30 Years of High Drama

 BODY:

 
September 1959: President Eisenhower and Nikita S. Khrushchev meet at Camp David, Md. The talks result in the ''spirit of Camp David,'' an effort to press for scientific and cultural exchanges and disarmament.
 
June 1961: Khrushchev and President Kennedy have heated exchanges in Vienna. There are no formal agreements. A year later, the Soviets send nuclear missiles to Cuba; the United States forces their removal. 
 
June 1967: President Johnson meets in Glassboro, N.J., with Aleksei N. Kosygin to discuss the Middle East, the Vietnam War and nuclear arms. They come to no agreement.
 
May 1972: President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhbnev, in Moscow, sign the first treaties setting limits on strategic nuclear arms, known as SALT I, and on curbing antiballistic missile systems. They agree to keep negotiating arms, but regional issues divide them.
 
June 1973: Nixon and Brezhnev meet in Washington. They agree ot try to complete a new arms treaty by 1974.
 
June-July 1974: Nixon and Brezhnev meet in Moscow and Yalta. They agree to a treaty banning underground nuclear-arms tests with yields exceeding 150 kilotons, and they arrange a 10-year economic accord.
 
November 1974: President Ford and Brezhnev, in Vladivostok, reach a tentative deal limiting missile launchers and bombers and lay a base for a second strategic arms treaty. The treaty is not completed before President Carter takes office.
 
June 1979: President Carter and Brezhnev, in Vienna, sign the second treaty limiting strtegic arms, or SALT II. Although the Senate never approves the treaty because of the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in December of 1979, both sides agree informally to observe its limits.
 
November 1985: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet in Geneva for wide-ranging talks on arms control and other subjects. They agree to revive cultural exchanges and to enhance air safety, but no arms-control agreements are achieved.
 
October 1986: Reagan and Gorbachev meet in Reykjavik, Iceland, to provide momentum to arms-control talks. The two sides speak of vast cuts in strategic arms and medium-range missiles, but the accord falls through because of disagreements over the American plan for a space-based missile defense system, or ''Star Wars,'' and over Moscow's insistence on putting all arms issues in one package.
 
December 1987: Reagan and Gorbachev meet in Washington. They sign a treaty to destroy intermediate-range nuclear forces, known as I.N.F., and agree to seek a treaty cugging long-range nuclear arsenals. But ''Star Wars'' remains a sticking point.
 
May-June 1988: Gorbachev and Reagan, in Moscow, ratify the I.N.F. treaty but make no breakthrough on cutting long-range nuclear forces. Reagan says important work has been done but Gorbachev speaks of ''missed opportunities.''
 
December 1988: Gorbachev says farewell to Reagan and greets President-elect George Bush at a two-hour luncheon on Governors Island in New York harbor. Reagan assures Gorbachev of continuity under Bush.
 
December 1989: Bush and Grobachev meet in Malta. They say they will strive to conclude treaties on long-range nuclear weapons and conventional arms in 1990.
''

HEADLINE: MANY STATES CUT FOOD ALLOTMENTS FOR POOR FAMILIES

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28

 BODY:
Because of unexpected increases in food prices in the last eight months, at least half the states have moved to cut government food allotments for poor women and children or to stop the aid altogether for thousands of these people.
The Federal Government, through the states, provides this aid under the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children, or WIC. Under the welfare program, one of the Government's most successful, vouchers to buy food are given to 4.5 million expectant and new mothers and young children who are at high risk of malnutrition. The program serves nearly one-third of all babies born in the United States. 
Many assessments of the program, including several studies financed by the Federal Government, have concluded that it saves lives and improves the health of women and children, reducing infants' mortality and increasing their birth weight. By preventing illnesses, it saves money for Medicaid, the Government's health care program for the poor. So Congress spared WIC when other welfare programs were cut back in the Reagan Administration.
 
Cost-Cutting Choices
But this year the $2.1 billion the Federal Government gives the states has not been enough to cover the increased cost of milk, orange juice, cereal and infant formula, the main items in the WIC food package.
The Federal Food and Nutrition Service had estimated that food prices would rise 4 percent in the current fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, 1989. But states' officials say the cost of items in the basic food package increased 8 percent in just the first half of this fiscal year. In interviews, they said some of the increases were seasonal and would probably level off, but added that they had little hope that prices would decline any time soon.
About a dozen states, including New York, contribute their own money to the program, but they are not obligated to do so and many are under severe fiscal pressures of their own. ''We face two alternatives,'' said Betsy R. Clarke, director of the program in Oregon: ''either cutting the food package or reducing the number of participants.''
Some states are doing both. In a typical cost-saving move, Texas has cut the cereal allowance for year-olds and 2-year-olds to 24 ounces a month, from 36 ounces. It will also drop 27,000 people from the food program. Early this year, it was serving 357,200 women and children.
On June 1, California will halve the monthly juice allowance for children 3 to 5 years old. The state expects to save $1.2 million by providing a monthly allotment of 144 ounces of juice for such children, who have been getting 288 ounces. In addition, California expects to save $6 million by eliminating vouchers for cheese, a major source of calcium.
''At least half the states in the country are cutting back caseloads,'' said Dennis H. Bach of Iowa, president of the National Association of WIC Directors, an organization of state and local officials. ''And many are also putting restrictions on the food package in order to contain costs.''
 
Just Staying Even
At a time when Congress and President Bush are looking for ways to cut Federal spending, it will not be easy to find more money for the WIC program. Tony P. Hall, the Ohio Democrat who is chairman of the House Select Committee on Hunger, and other members of Congress have proposed a $150 million increase for next year. ''Originally, we hoped to reach more mothers and children, but now we find the extra money will be needed just to stay even,'' Mr. Hall said.
Federal officials said they did not know how many people had been removed from the program's rolls by the states' cutbacks. F. Philip Shanholtzer, a spokesman for the Food and Nutrition Service, said inflation in food prices had ''outstripped everyone's predictions,'' adding that he hoped the states would minimize the reductions in benefits by making changes in the food package to save money.
States that are trimming their rolls are focusing on lower-risk cases. Missouri is terminating benefits in April through September for 14,000 children who show no clinical signs of malnutrition despite inadequate diets.
But C. Richard Blount, director of food and nutrition services for the Missouri Health Department, said some of those children would probably qualify for benefits again after a few months when they have symptoms of anemia and malnutrition. If that happens, he said, the state will have to take other steps to save money by restricting eligibility.
Debra C. Stabeno, food program director in the Texas Health Department, said, ''We are reducing our rolls through attrition and we are not enrolling new people'' in certain categories. Among those excluded are pregnant women, breast-feeding women and infants whose diet has been diagnosed as inadequate, but who show no clinical signs of malnutrition.
Lynne McElroy, chief of nutrition service for the Oklahoma Health Department, said, ''We have to reduce our caseload by about 15,000 people, to 40,000.''
Iowa intends to remove 4,000 people from its program, which now serves 49,000 people, Mr. Bach said.
 
Savings Were Eaten Away
New York State, which had an average of 380,000 people on its rolls in the first half of the current fiscal year, is trying to get down to 360,000. New Jersey has curtailed eligibility for people in certain ''low priority'' categories.
Connecticut no longer allows the use of Federal funds to buy orange juice, the most popular source of vitamin C, suggesting instead pineapple, apple or grapefruit juice because they cost less.
The WIC program accounts for one-third of the nation's infant formula sales. In the last two years, many states exploited their market share, demanded competitive bids and won substantial volume discounts from formula makers. States used the savings to provide services to more people, as the Federal Government told them to do.
But food price increases have eaten up the savings. From April 1989 to April 1990, retail prices rose 13.3 percent for fruit juices, 11.1 percent for fresh whole milk and 5.9 percent for cereals. Over all, food prices rose 6.2 percent while the Consumer Price Index for all items increased 4.7 percent.
Ralph L. Parlett, an economist at the Department of Agriculture, said orange juice prices soared because of the freeze that ravaged the Florida citrus crop in December. Dairy prices increased sharply because of a decline in milk production, he added; there was ''less milk per cow'' because the animals were eating poor-quality forage in pastures devastated by the 1988 drought. He noted that Federal policy encourages farmers to slaughter cows to eliminate a longstanding surplus of dairy products.
Harry H. Harp, another economist at the Agriculture Department, said cereal prices had risen in part because of higher grain prices resulting from the 1988 drought. Another factor, he said, was increased consumer demand for cereals, spurred by reports that a high-fiber diet helps to prevent cancer.
Federal officials sometimes defend cuts in the monthly food package by saying that beneficiaries can still get the recommended daily allowance of nutrients like calcium, iron, protein, vitamin A and vitamin C. But Mrs. Stabeno of Texas said, ''You can get 100 percent of the R.D.A. and still be hungry.''

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
IN MOSCOW SHOPS, STOICISM APLENTY

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 28

 BODY:
Moscow stores featured fresh supplies of stoicism today, with shoppers forced to brandish their domestic passports and face a ration list rapidly growing to include everything from light bulbs to socks.
Today, the City Council promulgated limits on dozens of basic items of food, clothing and household needs to combat hoarding and to give Moscow residents priority over the daily caravans of shoppers from the provinces who come here looking for the nation's increasingly scarce goods.
In long lines all over the city, Muscovites obediently held up their internal passports to cashiers to prove their right to buy from the limited range of goods.
''I'm a pessimist and I am afraid of all this,'' said Yelena Averenov, who waited in a sausage line at the crowded Yeliseyev state store. 
''I have only a pensioner's income, and I do not like the way Gorbachev is doing this,'' she said, reflecting confusion and aggravation among shoppers even as they obeyed the rationing. The restriction took effect the day before President Gorbachev was to depart Moscow on his way to meet President Bush in Washington.
Mrs. Averenov clutched her passport and anticipated a deepening of the Soviet shoppers' rut on July 1, when the Gorbachev government has said it will raise bread prices in an opening move to repair the failed, oversubsidized national economy.
Lyudmila Kremlikov, one of the many Muscovites expressing relief that they may now have priority over out-of-towners, said: 'Personally, I do not mind. I hope it improves the situation.''
Her husband, Vladimir, expressing general skepticism that the looming emergency measures would prove effective, said, ''But we still need a true market economy.'' .
 
A Wave of Panic Buying
A wave of panic shopping swept the city and much of the nation last week within minutes of the Kremlin's initial word that prices of bread - the single most symbolically important consumer item - would be tripled July 1, with other food prices to rise six months later.
''Let us not be mistaken and think this is the beginning of a free market,'' said Givi Nebiyeridze, proprietor of the Lavash Cooperative Bakery, where prices are already higher than in state stores. Mr. Nebiyeridze pays more for his ingredients and his customers are willing to pay more for the 800 loaves of flat, round Georgian bread he makes daily.
''All the price rise amounts to is an attempt to cut back the state budget deficit,'' he said, stressing the hesitancy Mr. Gorbachev was showing as he attempted to craft what he calls a ''regulated market economy'' as a centrally planned halfway measure toward a true free market.
 
Halfway Measures Futile
Mr. Nebiyeridze said that halfway measures were futile under Kemlin dictates that neglect such market factors as shoppers' demand for a better product like the more toothsome, traditionally baked bread that attracts people to his shop.
They pay 70 kopecks a loaf, about 11 cents at the current exchange rate for tourists, instead of the 45 kopecks or about 7 cents charged for inferior bread in state stores. But on the other hand they are not required to show a passport, as they now must in state stores.
''Passports?'' he laughed. ''We are interested in making and selling bread, not regulating customers.''
His state ''competitor,'' Vasily V. Molodykh, manager of Bread Factory No. 5 down the block, tended to agree.
''So far, I do not sense the economic essence of a free market,'' he said after noting that many Muscovites agreed that bread has been traditionally so underpriced - as a symbol of the revolution -that the price increase ''should have been done five years ago.''
''Bread is the result of hard work, and a nation's attitude toward bread shows its attitude toward labor itself,'' he said, repeating tales that bread is so cheap it is thrown into the streets or fed to farm animals.
 
'I Think It's Terrible'
Faina Dombkovemaya, a customer lined up outside bread window, put four loaves in her shopping bag and saw little hope in the price rise. ''I think it's terrible,'' she said. ''It's not that I cannot afford to pay more for bread and milk. It's that this will have a negative effect on a situation that is already bad enough. It will deprive us of our future.''
The passport order was issued by the Moscow City Council soon after the bread panic left stores swamped with shoppers. Sales of flour, pasta, cooking oil and other staples increased eightfold and supplies were quickly running out. The city government followed up today with a long list of prescribed purchase limits on specific consumer goods.
Beyond such limits as three pairs of socks and five light bulbs per customer, the ration list ranged from wallpaper (eight rolls) to musical instruments (one) and pencils (five), cigarettes (10 packs) and umbrellas (one).
''How could we be the first with perestroika and now we are lagging behind all the other East European countries?'' Mrs. Kremlikov asked as she waited in the sausage line. ''They had a shorter period of totalitarian government. Our roots go deeper,'' she said, her passport at the ready.

HEADLINE: As Hong Kong Elite Are Leaving, Japanese Investors Are Moving In

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG, May 26

 BODY:
At a time when thousands of Hong Kong's elite are vying for Canadian passports and its oldest companies are registering in the Bahamas, something unexpected is happening. The Japanese, usually among the world's most cautious investors, are moving into town.
As the countdown continues to 1997, when Britain will return Hong Kong to China, money is rapidly flowing out of the colony. Economic growth this year, the Government said last week, has slowed to just above zero.
But this does not seem to bother the Japanese, who - though they acknowledge a glimmer of self-doubt - see a giant buying opportunity, a chance to build a bigger base camp for doing business in China a decade from now. 
 
Filling a Vacuum
Though exact statistics are not available, by most estimates Japan invested about $2 billion here last year, a record. That brings its total investment to roughly $8 billion, more than that of the United States for the first time.
The result is that Japan now has, at least for the time being, power and prestige in Hong Kong on a scale not seen in 45 years. As native businesses and even a few remnants of British colonial power decamp, sped by memories of the Chinese Government's crackdown on the democracy movement in Tiananmen Square last June, Japan is filling the vacuum, a vacuum of both money and power.
Hong Kong's richest and most influential executives are still the Hong Kong Chinese. But today Japanese investors are courted and dined, primarily because their presence is seen as another insurance policy against China's intervention in the city's freewheeling and largely unregulated ways.
The British, by contrast, are viewed as lame ducks, powerless to enforce the guarantees they received from China when they agreed to cede control of the colony.
''Japan is China's biggest provider of foreign aid,'' one prominent Hong Kong executive said the other day. ''We have to hope that China will see that it is not in its interest to anger the Japanese here.'' The Japanese, in turn, tend to view Western nations, particularly the United States, as hopelessly romantic about China, overly enthralled about the country in the 1980's and too quick to flee when the crackdown came.
Traditionally, Japanese and American businesses have regarded Hong Kong as not only a convenient regional trading center but also a steppingstone to China. From Hong Kong, they could commission manufacturing work on the mainland and test Beijing's hospitality to investment. When things turned sour on the mainland, they could retreat to Hong Kong. Now, with each passing month, the colony seems increasingly like an abundantly rich corner of an otherwise poor nation.
So, Japan's approach has been to build up steadily, assuming that liberals and hardliners will come and go but that all will discover the lure of Japanese capital. There are more than 50 Japanese banks here now, with effective veto power over big projects like the $16 billion airport the Hong Kong government is trying to build, and more than 30 Japanese securities firms.
''I think Japan has big confidence that after 1997, Beijing will understand that Hong Kong is special,'' said Hiroshi Zaizen, the chairman of the Mitsubishi Corporation's subsidiary here and one of the city's most influential Japanese executives.
 
Big Money to Be Made
While China is the main reason that Japanese companies come to Hong Kong, there is still big money to be made in the colony itself.
Most Japanese department stores have opened in the tourist centers here to serve Japanese tourists -usually selling them products at lower prices than they could find at the same department stores in Tokyo. But Japan's Yaohan Department Store Company has opened a giant store in a boom town in the New Territories - part of the colony that is near the mainland border - hoping to tap the market for the half-million Hong Kong workers who live in giant new apartment buildings in the area.
The Japanese confidence in Hong Kong's future is hardly ironclad. Japanese companies have for the most part avoided big real estate purchases, preferring more liquid investments. If disaster should strike, much of the money can be pulled out -much the same strategy Japan has pursued on the mainland. ''On June 29, 1997, we can always press a button, I guess,'' Mr. Zaizen said.
Meanwhile, evidence mounts that Hong Kong's natives are already pressing that button. A recent study by the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation showed that the transfer of capital abroad last year increased 10-fold, though no one knows what that figure means because Hong Kong does not measure capital inflows. Putting the best face on things, the Government said the figure was a measure of the health of the economy because it showed Hong Kong companies were investing abroad. The more common explanation is that people are leaving the country and taking their bank accounts with them.
 
Japan's 'Sky High' Investor
But then there are exceptions like Kazuo Wada, the owner of Yaohan. Mr. Wada surprised both Tokyo and Hong Kong when he decided last year to move his corporate empire here.
Earlier this month, in another symbol of the shifting power structurehere, Mr. Wada became the new owner of ''Sky High'' - a palace of turrets, a half acre of floor space and views of the South China Sea from all windows - perched atop ''the Peak,'' the striking hill that dominates Hong Kong Island. The sprawling villa had been built, at exorbitant cost, by Hongkong and Shanghai Banking, one of this city's oldest and richest institutions, as the official residence of its chairman.
But these are more conservative days for Hong Kong institutions, and so the bank company, after three unsuccessful tries, persuaded a reluctant Mr. Wada to buy the house for $11 million. His company said the purchase was mostly intended to cement good relations; Mr. Wada himself plans to live in modest accommodations.
''Perhaps it would make a nice guest house,'' said Yuji Sakuma, the managing director of Yaohan's Hong Kong operations.
 
The Social Whirl
The wedding of Mr. Wada's daughter a few months ago was viewed as an enormous social event in Hong Kong, and it was one example of how mightily Japan has risen in the social pecking order in Hong Kong.
Another was the creation of the Dynasty Club, an exclusive club intended to rival Hong Kong's legendary Jockey Club, a bastion of the British establishment. The wealthy Hong Kong Chinese who started the club asked three people to act as initial ''patrons'' to draw Hong Kong's rich and powerful. The three were the head of the New China News Agency - China's unofficial diplomatic representative - and the senior American and Japanese diplomats here.
The American official declined, but few here missed the symbolism of the fact that the British were not asked.
 
Some Deep Resentments
But if many people in Hong Kong are reassured by Japanese investment, not everyone is pleased. Resentments of World War II run deep, and the city still holds a ceremony each August to mark its liberation from the Japanese forces at the end of World War II, though attendance grows sparser every year.
''The businessmen need Japan, so it is convenient for most of the city to forget,'' said Jack Edwards, who heads a group of former prisoners of war who have mounted a campaign here to recall Japanese war crimes. Older Chinese often refer to the Japanese in derogatory terms, he said, ''and my generation doesn't like their arrival at all.'' He added, ''I guess it was inevitable.''
Today the Peninsula Hotel, once Japan's military headquarters here, swarms with Japanese tourists. Executives in the growing Japanese population here, estimated at 16,000, often leave their families in Hong Kong and spend the week across the Chinese border in Guangdong province, where companies like Sanyo have large factories.
 
Japanese View of the Risk
The risk of investing in Hong Kong is viewed by Japan as no worse than the risk of investing in China itself. And Japanese businesses say they are eager to do more, as soon as World Bank lending resumes and the Japanese Government releases $500 million in economic development assistance that has been withheld since Tiananmen Square.
The World Bank has put forward two loans to China for its board to approve on Tuesday. The United States has said it can support one of the loans - $300 million for tree planting to combat deforestation - because its meets basic human needs. But the United States is opposed to the other loan, $150 million to upgrade roads and inland waterways in Jiangsu province.
''We are still nervous,'' said Fumio Hashimoto, who heads the Bank of Tokyo office here. ''No one would say that we have 100 percent confidence in the future of Hong Kong. But in the medium to long term, we know it is important.''
 
Plans for New Airport
Still, Japan is carefully picking and choosing in its investments. And it is in those choices that Japan's presence is likely to be felt most strikingly in coming years.
Plans for the new airport illustrate the tensions in the relationship. No one questions the need for a far larger airport. Hong Kong's enormous volume of air traffic is currently funneled through a single, short runway. The runway approach comes perilously close to one of Kowloon's densely packed neighborhoods - so close that passengers about to land can see families preparing dinner in nearby apartments.
So last year the Hong Kong government planned a giant airport to be built on an outer island and connected to Hong Kong by a long bridge. Roughly half the $16 billion cost is expected to be picked up by private investors. Japanese engineering and cement companies are eager for a piece of the action; so are companies like the Bechtel Group in the United States, which has been chosen to coordinate the project.
 
Need for China's Blessing
The problem is that the Hong Kong government barely consulted China before laying out details of the plan. The Chinese are suspicious that Hong Kong will use the airport to empty the colony's coffers before 1997. They have signaled general approval of the project, but not enthusiastically.
As a result, the Japanese banks -already burned by lending to hotels on the mainland that today have few guests and little way to pay back debt - say they will be very cautious. Recently, a senior Hong Kong government official went to Tokyo - the first such visit - to drum up support. He got smiles but few commitments. ''We need the Chinese blessing,'' said Mr. Hashimoto of the Bank of Tokyo. ''We still have no detailed studies, and the time is short.''

HEADLINE: Company-Financed Pensions Are Failing to Fulfill Promise

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The company-financed pension, once envisioned as a principal source of retirement income for millions of Americans, is instead an ever-shrinking portion of the money they receive in later years. The trend could force today's generation of wage earners to rely heavily on Social Security and savings.
Among the roughly six million people getting pension checks from former employers, only 7 percent depend on them for half their income, Government surveys show. In fact, a growing number of these people have told the Government that their company pensions have shrunk to less than a fifth of their retirement income.
 
Low-Wage Jobs a Factor
''The hope was that Social Security for the baby-boom generation would be more of a supplement to retirement income and less of the mainstay that it is today,'' said Prof. Olivia Mitchell, a pension specialist at Cornell University. ''Now that hope is fading.'' 
Many changes help to explain the stagnation in company pension benefits, among them a decline in the number of manufacturing jobs and a rise in low-wage, service-sector employment. Manufacturing remains a stronghold of prosperous company pension plans, and many small service companies consider them too costly to provide.
Another problem has been adjustment for inflation. While every Social Security check is increased annually to offset inflation, only one in four company pension checks was so adjusted in the late 1980's, the Labor Department says. Even the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which finances one of the nation's most lucrative pension plans, has increased pensions only twice since 1985 - by 4.3 percent that year and 4.1 percent in 1988. The Consumer Price Index went up 18.3 percent from 1985 to 1989.
A third reason is that many compa-nies are making much greater use of a new type of pension plan, which departs from the old practice in which a company guarantees a monthly retirement check pegged to a worker's wages. The new pension plans provide various ways for workers and employers to save money jointly, without paying taxes until the money is spent.
 
New Plans Paying Less
The companies prefer the new plans because the traditional plans are almost always financed entirely by the employer. In addition, the new plans are not so heavily regulated by the Federal Government.
Companies have been able to adopt these new pension plans in part because of the decline in the power of unions, which are strong advocates of company-financed pensions.
But the pensions that come from these new ''defined contribution'' plans are almost always smaller than those that flow from the traditional, or ''defined benefit,'' plans, according to a survey of 763 corporations by the Wyatt Company, a consulting firm. Under the new plans, the annual pension for a retiree who had been earning $15,000 a year averaged 19 percent of this income, or $2,850. Under a traditional plan, the average pension for the same retiree would have been $4,200 a year, or 28 percent of the old salary.
The Wyatt survey found that similar differences existed elsewhere along the salary scale, up to $100,000.
 
Growth After World War II
Company pension plans grew spectacularly in the years after World War II. By the late 1970's, nearly half of the nation's wage earners were enrolled, double the coverage in 1950. Many were war veterans, and as the first of them retired in the 1960's, company pension payments became an ever large share of the total income going to the over-65 population - reaching 7 percent in 1976, from only 3 percent in 1962.
And then growth stopped. More than a decade later, enrollment in pension plans is still about 46 percent of the nation's wage earners, and the pensions themselves still provide only 7 percent of total income received by people over 65, Government data indicate.
What is more, alone among the principal sources of income for people over 65, company pensions failed to keep up with inflation in the 1980's.
Social Security, pensions paid to retired government employees, interest and dividends on savings, and wages from jobs held by people over 65 all kept pace with or exceeded the inflation rate, the Labor Department says.
These other sources of income did so well that the median income of the nation's over-65 population rose to $20,520 in 1986 for married couples, from $5,358 in 1976 - an increase that exceeded the inflation rate even though the portion from company pension plans fell behind.
 
Counter to Bush Goals
''What we are finding is that the company pension plan is not going to become an integral part of employment in the United States,'' said Joseph Piacentini, a pension specialist at the Employee Benefit Research Institute.
The unfulfilled promise of company pensions runs counter to the Bush Administration's goals, which seek relief from the annual cost-of-living increases in Social Security benefits. ''Our goal is that private pensions should provide a significant share of retirement income, and for many more people,'' said Ann Combs, the Deputy Assistant Secretary of Labor for pension and welfare benefits.
Right now, Social Security payments are far and away the prime source of income among the more than 22 million Americans over age 65. Sixty-two percent of these people receive at least half their income from Social Security.
 
Lack of Current Data
Ms. Combs said the Administration had not taken a ''hard look'' at what is happening to company pensions. One obstacle is outdated Government retirement data. Some information is four years old, and that gathered in 1988 is just now being published by the Census Bureau, the Labor Department and the Social Security Administration. None of that data offer a detailed look at the other income sources for company pensioners.
But the available data and interviews with more than a dozen Government and industry officials lead to the conclusion that in the 1980's, corporate America held back on company-financed pensions. Ms. Combs did not challenge this conclusion, although in the absence of a fresh round of data, she hesitated to accept it. ''It is very difficult to get a handle on corporate pensions,'' she said.
Whatever the shortcomings, the data flash a warning to the generation born between 1946 and 1964, whose members are likely to retire between 2010 and 2030.
 
An Alternative: Keep Working
''If Social Security ceases to provide the same real benefits that it is providing today, then one alternative will be to ask the aging baby-boomers to keep on working,'' said Professor Mitchell of Cornell. That would reverse a current trend. Many corporations encouraged early retirement to shrink staff and cut costs.
What is more, if company pensions provide a smaller share of retirement income, then Congress might re-examine whether they are worth the huge tax deductions that go to corporations and workers channeling income into pension funds. The Joint Committee on Taxation estimates that in the next fiscal year, starting Oct. 1, these deductions will cost the Treasury $52.2 billion in tax revenue. No other category is so costly. The runners-up are deductions for health care, with $33.3 billion in lost taxes, and for home mortgages, $31.9 billion.
''Congress has been tinkering for 15 years with tax incentives to get corporations to improve their pension plans, and we still have not gotten it right,'' said Phyllis Borzi, counsel for employee benefits on the House Subcommittee on Labor-Management Relations. But Ms. Borzi added that Congress is unlikely to ''go after the tax incentives for pension funds in a major way, unless the budget deficit gets really unbearable.''
 
Defined-Contribution Plans
Perhaps the biggest impact on pensions has come from the increasing use of the defined-contribution pension. Most such plans are savings funds built up through profit-sharing or employer and employee contributions to savings accounts, including 401(k) plans, that allow workers to reduce their taxable income by the amount of their contributions.
As of 1988, about 15 percent of the nation's 92 million wage earners were covered by such plans, compared with only 6 percent in 1975. Over the same period, the more standard defined-benefit plan has faded slowly, to 31 percent of all wage earners in 1988, from 39 percent in 1975, the Labor Department reports. These plans are almost always financed by employers, and they typically guarantee that retirees will continue to receive 25 percent or more of their average salary.
Company officials say Federal regulations forced them to promote defined-contribution plans. These plans are far less regulated than defined-benefit plans, largely because they promise to pay only the principal, which a retiree can collect on leaving a job, plus whatever interest is earned on accumulated savings.
 
Defined-Benefit Plans Costlier
Because defined-benefit plans promise a specific monthly payment, the Government requires employers to have pension insurance to guarantee their ability to make payments.
The insurance costs come to $16 to $18 a year for each employee, said Barry Podob, a vice president at the Interpublic Group of Companies, an advertising agency with 4,000 employees enrolled in its pension plans. Many companies say these costs, if passed on as higher prices for their goods or services, can put them at a competitive disadvantage.
The defined-contribution plans are not only less costly for employers, but also tempt workers. Over enough years, these savings pools can grow big enough to provide handsome retirement incomes, and younger workers can watch their savings grow.
 
More Alternatives for Employees
Under Federal rules, when these workers resign from a job they are allowed to cash in the pension savings and either roll it into a retirement fund at a new company or pay the tax on the accumulated savings and spend the money.
''For the younger worker not yet thinking about old age, this is attractive; this is now the 'me' generation,'' said Mr. Podob of Interpublic, whose work force averages 37 years of age.
But there is a danger. A Labor Department survey found that 34 percent of workers with this choice cash in their accumulated savings and use the money for consumer purchases. Eleven percent roll the money into a tax-deferred retirement account, and more than 50 percent invest it in a home, pay off a mortgage or make some other investment.
The upshot is that many workers risk being left short of retirement income. The spending of accumulated pension savings early in life has become enough of a problem that Elizabeth H. Dole, the Secretary of Labor, has asked Congress to strengthen the incentives for rolling over pensions into retirement accounts.
''The single largest source of losses appears to be the simple fact that people are spending their pensions before retirement,'' she said.

PUB-DATE: May 29, 1990,

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 3151 words

HEADLINE: UNEQUAL BURDEN: NEW YORK CITY PROPERTY TAXES - A SPECIAL REPORT:
Some of the Rich Pay Less Tax Than the Other Homeowners

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER with RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
New York City's property-tax system, which has been criticized for a decade for placing a heavier burden on less-affluent homeowners than on wealthier ones, appears to have grown more inequitable.
And the latest and most ambitious attempt at reform missed many of the poorer neighborhoods that have suffered the longest, a computer-assisted study by The New York Times has found.
The disparities are so glaring that owners of expensive houses sometimes pay lower property taxes than owners of much cheaper homes. Owners of houses of similar value often pay wildly different taxes.
A brownstone worth $506,000 at 380 Clinton Street in the Carroll Gardens section of South Brooklyn has a lower tax bill than a small ranch house worth $175,000 at 148-63 Edgewood Street in the working-class neighborhood of Rosedale, Queens. 
A house worth $185,000 at 129-01 Ninth Avenue in College Point, Queens, carries a lower tax than a house worth $157,000 at 191-22 109th Road in St. Albans, Queens.
In general, according to a report in January by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, the victims of the system own homes in poor and working-class sections like Eastchester and Wakefield in the Bronx, East Flatbush and Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn and Rosedale and South Jamaica, Queens.
Those homeowners, most of them black and Hispanic, are taxed more in proportion to the value of their houses than homeowners in wealthier areas.
City officials acknowledge that the system has produced inequities; they have made large-scale efforts to cut excessive tax bills at least three times in the last decade. Most recently, in January, the Finance Department reduced the assessments - the fraction of a property's estimated value, on which real-estate taxes are based -for 70,000 houses. The reductions mean the city will forgo a record total of about $30 million in property taxes.
The Times computer study of the 70,000 reductions found that half went to houses in one borough, Staten Island. Just 15 percent of the one-, two- and three-family houses in the city are on Staten Island. Yet the owners of two of every five houses in the relatively well-to-do borough were awarded reductions. Citywide, taxes were cut for 11 percent of all houses. The disparities Mr. Regan found involved houses, not co-ops, condominiums and rental apartments, which are taxed differently.
The Times analysis, which was based on assessment data provided by the Finance Department, also showed that half the tax cuts went to houses worth at least $200,000.
 
Overtaxed, Before and After
Although the reductions relieved some overburdened areas and some types of overtaxed housing, particularly newer units on Staten Island, they failed to lower taxes for houses in many of the very neighborhoods that have been overtaxed for decades.
The findings of study raise fresh concerns about the fairness of the $7 billion-a-year property tax, the largest source of revenue in the city's $28 billion budget, at a time when New York faces huge budget deficits and will almost certainly be forced to raise property-tax rates.
City and state officials blame history and politics for the inequities. As the value of houses rose over many decades, the city seldom revised its assessments. As a result, the tax on more expensive houses was based on a lower and lower percentage of their actual worth.
In response to a court decision that would have forced the city to raise taxes on underassessed properties, the Legislature decided to protect homeowners. It approved a bill in 1981 that prohibits the city from raising assessments on one-, two- and three-family houses more than 6 percent a year and more than 20 percent over five years.
City officials now say that the law, which the Koch administration supported, severely limited them in doing what was needed to correct inequities: raising assessments on houses that grew rapidly in value in the unprecedented real-estate surge of the 80's.
But the Comptroller and others, including the head of a city commission that studied the tax structure, say the city, too, is responsible for inconsistent assessment practices and for failing to use all the tools available under the state law to make the system fairer.
Finance Commissioner Carol O'Cleireacain said she was determined to address what she called ''the blatant inequalities'' in the property tax. She promised to overhaul the system, but she did not say how.
 
Those Who Benefit Vote
A wholesale revision of the property tax would need the approval of the City Council and the Legislature. But the Dinkins administration is not likely to find much support in either chamber. Both have repeatedly acted in the last 10 years to retain the status quo, in part because the beneficiaries of the system - many of whom would face steep increases if it were made more equitable - are determined to preserve it, and they constitute a large vocal voting bloc.
''Revising the whole system would be a good thing to do, but it is a very long-term venture,'' said Assemblyman George Friedman, Democrat of the Bronx and chairman of the Committee on Real Property Taxation.
Edward L. Sadowsky, former chairman of the Council Finance Committee and the head of the city's Tax Study Commission, said political realities had made the property tax difficult to change.
''My house is exhibit 1,'' said Mr. Sadowsky, who lives in Beechhurst, Queens. ''It has gone up eight-fold in value since I bought it in 1969, while the taxes on the house have maybe gone up 20 or 25 percent. It's a great deal.'' Flaws in the System A Pricier House But a Smaller Tax Every year assessors estimate the market value of each of the nearly 609,000 one-, two- and three-family houses in the city. The assessment is a fraction of that projection, with the fraction set annually by the city.
An examination by The Times of sales of houses in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx in 1989 showed that assessments and tax bills can have little relation to the actual values of the houses.
A four-story brownstone at 380 Clinton Street in Carroll Gardens was sold in November for $506,000. It is assessed at $12,080.
In the less-affluent neighborhood of Rosedale, a small one-story ranch house at 148-63 Edgewood Street was sold in October for $175,000. Its assessment is $12,720, or $640 higher than the Brooklyn house that is worth nearly three times as much.
At the 1990 tax rate for single-family homes - $9.452 for each $100 of assessed value - the tax on the $175,000 house would be $1,202. The tax on the $506,000 house would be $1,141.
Not all the disparities were between well-to-do primarily white neighborhoods and less-wealthy parts, where minorities live. Two houses in similar middle-class areas of Brooklyn with virtually the same assessment were sold last year. One, at 7724 10th Avenue in the Bay Ridge area, was bought for $395,000 and is assessed at $17,040. The other, at 1780 East Ninth Street near Kings Highway sold for $900,000 and is assessed at $17,670. Mapping the Failures Inequities Know No Boundaries If such cases seem extreme, the Comptroller's study indicates that disparities are the rule rather than the exception. The report, based on a review of three years of house sales, found ''a distressing lack of uniformity within every property class and within almost every neighborhood in the city.''
In general, it noted, ''the less valuable the property, the more it is taxed in relation to its market value.'' In 1988, the report found, owners of an average one-family house worth less than $100,000 paid almost twice the property tax per dollar of market value than owners of an average house worth more than $200,000.
Mr. Regan, echoing city officials, placed some of the blame on the law limiting assessment increases. That constrained the city from increasing assessments and taxes as fast as real-estate prices were rising in many desirable neighborhoods like Park Slope and Cobble Hill in Brooklyn and Forest Hills, Queens. That factor gave these areas a relative advantage over stable or declining areas.
Owners of one-family houses in the Fort Greene section, for example, pay twice as much tax in proportion to the values of their houses than nearby homeowners in Brooklyn's most expensive neighborhood, Brooklyn Heights.
 
The Rich May Suffer, Too
The system is so inconsistent that great disparities show up even between affluent communities. Houses in Cobble Hill and the Riverdale section of the Bronx sold for an average of $400,000 in 1984, 1988 and 1989, the years studied by the Comptroller. But Riverdale homeowners paid nearly three times more property tax than those in Cobble Hill.
Assessing is not an exact science. Each one-, two- and three-family house, a total of 608,843 in January, is evaluated every year by assessors. They examine the properties, analyze sale prices and use sophisticated computer programs to determine assessments. The State Board of Equalization, which monitors the property-tax system, says a residential property is properly assessed if the ratio of its assessment to its market value is within 10 percent of the average ratio for such properties citywide.
The Comptroller's study found, however, that in 1988 and 1989 the average assessment error in the city was 43 percent for one-family houses. On a house valued at $200,000, the owner should have paid $1,153 in property tax. But with a 43 percent assessment error, there was an equal chance that the owner paid taxes as high as $1,648 or as low as $658.
The average error was even worse for other properties, the study concluded. In 1988 and 1989, the annual tax on a walk-up apartment building worth $300,000 could have been as little as $982 or as much as $6,100.
Mr. Regan's office documented similar, though less extreme, disparities in a report released in 1981. Still, the new findings surprised the Comptroller's staff, because the city had followed all its major recommendations, including hiring additional assessors and using computers more sophisticatedly.
In another report in 1981, the New York Public Interest Research Group said that two of every three houses that it surveyed were incorrectly assessed and that ''individuals owning less-expensive homes are generally discriminated against.''
The Equalization and Assessment Board has found similar patterns.
The city commissioned researchers from New York University to study the tax. Their report in 1980 stated, ''The present system discriminates substantially in favor of better-off households.''
The report recommended that the city assess all property at full market value. Proponents say that that would let a homeowner judge the accuracy of an assessment and compare it easily with others. The Koch administration never released the report. A 'Remedy' Tried Assessments Cut, But Bias Remained Even within the current system the city can make taxes fairer by lowering assessments on properties that have been overvalued. It tried to do that in January, with the reductions for 70,000 houses.
The Times analysis found that 34,727 of the reductions, or about half, went to Staten Island. That meant that nearly 40 percent of 89,712 one-, two- and three-family houses in the borough received tax cuts. An additional 20,662 reductions went in Queens, or 8 percent of the borough's houses.
Half the reductions citywide went to houses worth at least $200,000, the computer study showed, and 40 percent went to houses built in the last 20 years.
Less expensive houses, particularly in working-class areas of Brooklyn and the Bronx, have historically been among the most overassessed. But the study found that the reductions in January hardly benefited the owners of those homes at all. Just 13,640 houses of all types were awarded reductions in those two boroughs.
 
Some Corrections Made
Finance Department officials said their strategy had been based purely on mathematical calculations. They tried to identify and redress overassessments by lowering the assessment ratio, to 8 percent of market value this year from 8.9 percent last year.
The Times study showed that the strategy apparently succeeded in correcting the tax bills of newer houses. Because of court rulings, newer houses tend to be assessed at higher rates than those for older houses. But the reductions did not succeed in eliminating the other, more longstanding, bias noted by the series of reports on the tax.
''To the extent that it did not address all the inequities, it was a partial solution,'' Jeffrey Schanback, a Deputy Finance Commissioner, said of the city's corrections.
Of course, as the property values soared in the 1980's, the city also increased the assessments on hundreds of thousands of houses each year. Last year, the assessments on 526,800 houses were raised, and in January 537,500 homeowners saw their assessments increase.
A preliminary survey by the Finance Department in 1986 suggested that assessments were going up more than 5 percent a year, close to the legal limit, in many desirable neighborhoods. But neither the department nor outside monitors determined whether the city had increased the assessments on all applicable properties to the full extent allowed by state law. Faulting the City Some of those who have studied the property tax said the city could have done more this year to eliminate inequities. They said the city should have gone further by reducing assessments on more houses or, as a matter of social policy, by concentrating on helping poorer homeowners saddled with unfairly high tax bills.
''It's just as arbitrary as the rest of the system, just as back room and roll of the dice as everything else they do,'' said Gene Russianoff of the New York Public Interest Research Group. ''They should be targeting the low- and moderate-value homes.''
Finance Department officials said they had corrected the assessments that were most out of line.
But others questioned the reliability of the formulas, particularly because they are based on the city's estimates of market values. The Comptroller's study indicated that actual sale prices were often much higher than the city's estimates of market values.
Among the properties examined by The Times, there were sometimes vast discrepancies between sale prices and the city's market-value estimates. The house in the Kings Highway area of Brooklyn that sold for $900,000 was valued by the city at $349,000. Two other houses in Brooklyn sold for $650,000; one was valued by the city at $720,000 and the other at $281,000.
Another two houses were estimated by the city to have the same value, $225,000. One sold for $165,000 and the other for $368,000.
Perhaps the most egregious example was a house in Manhattan that sold last year for $8.3 million. The city subsequently estimated its market value at $4.7 million and, following its formulas, awarded the property a $27,000 cut in its assessment. The new owner will save $2,550 in taxes. A 'Remedy' Avoided When Politics Enters the Equation When Ms. O'Cleireacain, then an economist for District Council 37, the municipal employees' union, testified 10 years ago in Albany on full-market assessment, she said she was in favor of it - and she was spat upon by a spectator.
Now that she is Finance Commissioner, Ms. O'Cleireacain hedges on the issue. But she added in an interview, ''Blatant inequalities are simply, at some point, unacceptable.''
The consensus among outside experts is that the city should move to full-market assessments. Buffalo and Rochester have done so, and Syracuse is shifting to it. But it seems unlikely that New York will follow soon. ''From a practical point of view, you couldn't do it,'' said Assemblyman Friedman.
It is not that lawmakers are unaware of the inequities. Mr. Friedman tells the story of two legislators, one from Staten Island and one from Brooklyn. The Brooklynite's house is more expensive, Mr. Friedman said, but the Staten Islander's house has a higher assessment and tax bill.
 
A Break? Not at All
In a sense, the current system seems almost calculated to perpetuate itself. Its beneficiaries would pay more if the system were made more equitable, and so they fight to retain it. Victims often do not even know they are overtaxed. When they receive a notice of an assessment increase, they see that their home is assessed at a fraction of what it is worth and may think they are getting a break, unaware that others are assessed at far lower rates.
''The tax notices are designed to hoodwink the taxpayers,'' Mr. Russianoff said. ''People are led to believe that somehow they are getting away with something.''
But if some of them are overassessed, as a group owners of houses have received preferential treatment compared with owners of other properties. State law permits the city to assess commercial property at much higher percentages of market values. The law also allows the city to raise assessments on rental apartment buildings, as well as on co-operatives and condominiums, much more quickly than on houses. Impact on Office Buildings In addition, the City Council has been able to raise or lower the share of property-tax revenue borne by the various types of properties by as much as 5 percent a year. In large part because of the Council's actions, the share paid by one-, two- and three-family houses was reduced, from 14.1 percent of the total in 1983 to 11.6 percent last year.
At the same time, the burden on office buildings and factories grew, from 41.6 to 47.8 percent, city records show. Yet the values of one-, two- and three-family houses rose faster than commercial properties.
''It's pure politics, in terms of who votes in this city, and one-, two- and three-family homeowners vote,'' said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.
 
Comparing The Houses
To study patterns of real-estate tax-assessment reductions in New York City, The New York Times obtained computer records of the 70,000 reductions on one- two- and three-family homes from the Finance Department.
The records were used to create a computer database that permitted analysis of the number and extent of reductions by characteristics like location, age and market value.
To allow comparisons to earlier studies by the State Comptroller's office, the records were matched by block and lot number to the Comptroller's definitions of neighborhoods.
 
To Request A Reduction
Homeowners who think their property is overassessed can seek reductions from the New York City Tax Commission. Commission members, who have wide discretion to grant or deny assessment reductions, hold hearings early each spring.
Applicants have to show their assessments are unreasonably high by comparison with houses of similar worth. This year, the city set assessments for one-,> two- and three-family houses at 8 percent of market value.

HEADLINE: Iraqi Takes Harsh Line at Meeting

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 28

 BODY:
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq set a bellicose and anti-American tone for the Arab summit meeting here today, despite efforts by Egypt and Saudi Arabia to mute inflammatory oratory.
As Arab leaders opened the meeting, Mr. Hussein took a hard line against Israel and the United States, apparently in an effort to carve out a new role as a leader among the Arabs.
Mr. Hussein warned again that he would respond to any Israeli use of weapons of mass destruction against his country by using comparable weapons against Israel.
The comments reflect what officials here call Iraq's profound suspicion that Israel is preparing a pre-emptive strike against Baghdad's growing military strength. 
The summit meeting, called by President Hussein and Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, is intended to focus on growing Soviet Jewish immigration to Israel, and also Iraq's attempt to gain support against what Baghdad sees as a Western campaign to thwart its acquisition of advanced weaponry. #5 Leaders Are Absent But its impact has been diluted by the absence of five Arab leaders, particularly President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, one the strongest Arab nations long hostile to President Hussein's Iraqi leadership.
President Hussein identified the United States as the sponsor of Israeli policies. Referring to Israel as ''the Zionist entity'' - a usage abandoned by many Arab countries in recent years - he said it ''would not be able to implement its expansionist policies at the expense of the Arabs were it for the economic and military assistance of the United States.''
''The United States cannot maintain such a policy while professing friendship towards the Arabs,'' he said. Egypt and Saudi Arabia, Arab and Western diplomats said, have sought to avoid an open rift with the United States so as to avert new obstacles in Washington's stalled effort to promote a Palestinian-Israeli discussion.
 
U.S. Responsibility Charged
''The United States,'' the Iraqi leader went on, ''bears major responsibility, even the primary responsibility, for the Israeli aggression directed against the Palestinian people.''
He was apparently alluding to Israeli efforts to crush a Palestinian uprising that has been under way in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip since December 1988.
The impact of the Arab gathering has been diluted, however, by the absence of leaders from Algeria, Lebanon, Morocco, Oman and Syria, among the 21 members of the Arab League, which include the P.L.O.
Of those countries, the most prominent in Arab diplomacy is Syria since it is the strongest Arab military power sharing a border with Israel. Syria has long cast itself as the custodian of militant Arab politics.
However, Syria and Iraq are estranged by long-standing disputes and President Assad declined an invitation to attend the Baghdad meeting.
 
Qaddafi Flew to Syria
The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, flew to Damascus yesterday to try to persuade President Assad to attend, but did not succeed. His stay in the Syrian capital before he flew to Baghdad forced a delay in the opening of the summit.
The meeting is widely regarded by Western and Arab diplomats as part of an effort by President Hussein to carve out a new role as a leader among Arabs following what Iraq depicts as victory in its war with Iran, stilled by a cease-fire in August 1988.
The gathering thus offers the Iraqi leader a platform to appeal directly to many Arabs frustrated by the slow pace of peace efforts, over the heads of their leaders. By promoting himself as a champion of Arab valor, the Iraqi leader is hoping to obtain a broad Arab constituency, diplomats in the region said.
''If attacked and hit, we will strike back forcefully,'' President Hussein declared today. Referring to Israel, he said: ''If it uses weapons of mass destruction, we will use our own.''
 
Iraqis Perceive a Plot
Last month the Iraqi leader announced that his country had developed a binary chemical weapons capability and would use it to ''burn half of Israel'' if Israel attacked with nuclear weapons. The warning drew widespread Arab support, but diplomats here said it did not imply an Iraqi threat to strike first.
Rather, diplomats said, Iraqi leaders have become certain that a Western and Israeli conspiracy is afoot to prepare for an Israeli strike against Baghdad's chemical warfare and missile capability. The suspicions run deep because Israeli planes launched a long-range strike against an Iraqi nuclear reactor in 1981.

HEADLINE: Santa Marta Journal;
The Road Lies Unpaved, in Spite of All Intentions

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA MARTA, El Salvador

 BODY:
When the army came to this isolated town last month and declared an early Christmas, the residents asked for a better road.
The round black stones that stud the twin tracks into town make driving a bit like riding a jackhammer. During the seven-month rainy season, which begins in April, the road is virtually impassable.
Lieut. Col. Juan Carlos Azcunaga, the deputy commander of the district, agreed to cooperate. He struck a deal with the villagers, 3,500 former refugees who returned after tiring of living in camps in Honduras. Under the arrangement, the army would provide engineers and earth-moving equipment; the residents would provide the labor. 
Both sides billed it as a breakthrough; the first step toward cooperation between the army and the refugees, most of whom were driven from their land here by Government bombing and repression in the early 1980's. Three years ago, bearing little more than a few pigs and a heart-rending longing for their homes, they insisted on returning to rebuild.
 
A Dream That Fades
Now, the bulldozers are parked and the refugees are refusing to work with the army. The breakthrough looks more and more like a mirage, one of the countless pipe dreams that for a few moments disguise the harsh realities of life in El Salvador, only to fade away.
The collapse of the road project provides a glimpse into the suspicions and pressures that have fueled a decade of civil war. And it shows how the country's divisions doom many efforts to improve daily life.
''The terrorists are pressing the residents not to work,'' said Col. Rene Arnoldo Majano, the commander of the district, which is one of the most wartorn in the country. By terrorists he meant the left-wing rebels who are fighting the rightist Government.
''We're ready to be helped,'' said a member of the town council, who asked not to be identified. ''But we don't want to be used.''
The dispute is a symptom of the problems that have undermined United States policy here, a policy that has sent $4 billion to San Salvador in the last decade, much of it in military aid. Attempts to build up the army have often clashed with efforts to help the people, fortify the civilian government and establish a democracy.
 
Guns Before Butter
The Reagan Administration gave the army priority, increasing military aid at three times the rate of economic support. The result has been a strengthening of the armed forces and a plunge in the average standard of living.
Civilian government has been especially ineffective in Santa Marta, which is about 70 miles northeast of the capital and 25 miles northwest of the last segment of paved road. When the first refugees arrived here three years ago, the town was little more than a dot on the map.
The refugees did most of the work, with little help from the Government. They opened a school with their own teachers. They planted corn and beans. Each year, more refugees returned. Temporary shacks were turned into homes. Residents began viewing Santa Marta, originally rebuilt as a refugee staging area, as the area's premier municipality.
But the army remained deeply suspicious, fearing that Santa Marta was an effort to rebuild the rebel civilian network, which sustains the guerrillas in the field. The military soon stopped all relief groups from entering the area. Often, the armed forces cordoned off the town, questioning residents as they came and went.
 
Soldiers and Candy
Two months ago, a delegation from the town went to the regional capital, Sensuntepeque, to discuss their problems with Colonel Majano. Despite the qualms of some residents opposed to cooperation with the army, the town council agreed to allow a civic-action program, under which troops distribute candy, food and medicine.
A few hours after the program began, nearby rebels opened fire, military officials say. Residents scattered and program workers scrambled for safety.
The army, accompanied by United States military advisers, decided to return earlier this month. But the day before the program, the patrol in Santa Marta found a one-page letter apparently written by the guerrillas. It blamed the Government for the war and appealed to residents for help oppose the army.
The army retaliated. It distributed fliers accusing the townspeople of working with the guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. ''Militia of the F.M.L.N.,'' the leaflet said. ''By destroying your homeland, you're generating poverty, mourning and pain to your Salvadoran brothers. Reflect. Incorporate yourselves in the process.''
 
'Broken the Barrier'
The residents were furious. The army apologized and once again handed out beans and cooking oil. In a meeting with the town council, Colonel Azcunaga and the residents agreed to work together to rebuild the road. ''We've broken the barrier,'' Colonel Azcunaga said. The next day the radio announced that Santa Marta had rejected the guerrillas and embraced the military. Local news organizations gave prominent display to the civic-action program, giving residents the feeling that they were being used by creating the impression that the community and the military were collaborating.
The road-improvement project collapsed six days later. Last week, one soldier was killed and one was wounded in combat around the town.

Residents and the army have teamed up on a program in which troops distribute food, candy and medicine, but attempts to collaborate to improve the quality of life have largely failed.
