HEADLINE: TOWARD THE SUMMIT;
Negotiations Concluded Over U.S.-Soviet Trade

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28

 BODY:
American and Soviet negotiators have concluded the remaining details of a trade agreement under which enterprises of the two countries would establish deeper footholds in each other's markets.
Among the harder-won provisions obtained by Washington are better copyright protection for American computer software in the Soviet Union, an accelerated process for obtaining commercial representation in Moscow and a start on repayment of 1940's Lend-Lease and other Soviet debts to the United States.
For their part, the Soviets would get the lowest available tariffs in the United States, which would make more furs, vodka, textiles and other Soviet-produced products available here, and eligibility for American Government credit and guarantee programs of Federal agencies like the Export-Import Bank and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. On the Table, or Off? It is uncertain whether the agreement, concluded by the negotiators in the last few weeks, will be signed during the meetings between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. In comments to reporters at Kennebunkport, Me., today, Mr. Bush said the trade agreement was ''not on the table,'' because the Soviets had yet to approve a free emigration law. 
But on Sunday, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation'' that the agreement was ''not off the table. I see where some are suggesting that it's off the table.''
Some of the apparent confusion may reflect political pressures. A resolution adopted by two-thirds of the Senate urges the President not to move forward with a trade agreement while Moscow maintains economic sanctions against Lithuania to compel it to rescind its declaration of independence.
The agreement, which has not yet been published, contains a number of provisions that would ease trade. Each side could open offices to advertise, meet with potential purchasers and otherwise promote commerce. The Soviets could take no longer than 60 days to approve or disapprove commercial accreditation. At first, Moscow had objected to imposing procedural deadlines on its bureaucracy.
Each country's laws and regulations would be made readily available to the other. Such information is already available in the United States, but it is often hard to get in the Soviet Union.
 
Copyright Protection for Software
Specific provision has been made for computer software programs, and the overall protection of copyrights, trademarks, patents and other intellectual property would be greater than now exists. Both sides would be obliged to abide by international conventions in this area.
There is also a so-called safeguard provision, under which each country would have the right to halt imports that flooded its markets.
The two countries last year traded about $5 billion worth of goods and services. Largely because of Soviet grain buying, the United States had a $3.5 billion surplus. The Soviet Union is one of the few countries with which the United States enjoys such a surplus.
Most analysts say opportunities for greatly expanded business are limited, at least in the short term. The Soviets do not make much that the United States wants or needs, and payments as well as political difficulties compound risks for American business.
 
Separate Accord on Debts
An agreement on Soviet debts to the United States was negotiated separately but is to be signed at the same time as the trade agreement. After making small payments in the 1970's, the Soviets still owe the United States $674 million from the Lend-Lease program of World War II.
This represents about half the total Soviet debt to this country, estimated at $1.5 billion. This amount includes $192.6 million that the United States lent to the Government of Alexander Kerensky, who was overthrown by the Bolsheviks in November 1917.
American officials said that United States and Soviet negotiators spent long hours arguing over a new payments schedule, details of which were unavailable. Settlement of the debt issue, by meeting requirements of the 1934 Johnson Debt Default Act, would permit the Soviet Union to borrow money in the American bond market for the first time.
The trade pact would be the first between the two countries since their military alliance ended in 1945. The two Governments negotiated a similar accord during the 1972-74 period of detente, but it was never signed.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Armenia Fighting Levels Off; Toll Is 23

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 28

 BODY:
The death toll from the savage clashes Sunday in the Armenian capital, Yerevan, rose to 23 today, as people in the city reported that a few sporadic clashes between Government troops and civilian bands continued.
The new deaths reported today were all from fighting on Sunday, and there were no reports of deaths or serious injuries from today's clashes. Most of the city and the suburbs, which a day earlier had been the scenes of heavy crossfire, were calm today, residents of Armenia said by telephone, with people stunned by the sudden outbreak and wondering what had provoked it.
Coming as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev prepares to leave for visits to Canada and the United States, the new fighting in the troubled Caucasus region underscores the precarious domestic situation - from ethnic tensions to separatist movements and economic crisis - that the Soviet leader leaves behind. 
 
An Unending Woe for Moscow
Unrest in Armenia has been a problem for Mr. Gorbachev for more than two years, as Armenians continue to press Moscow for control of Nagorno-Karabakh, a mountainous enclave populated mostly by Christian Armenians living on territory isolated within and ruled by Muslim Azerbaijan.
Hundreds of people have died in the disputed territory and in clashes in Azerbaijan and Armenia, and the Kremlin has seemed powerless to bring the seething conflict under control.
The Soviet press agency Tass reported that the fighting Sunday began when a group of about 15 armed militants attacked Soviet troops escorting a train into the Yerevan station just before 9 A.M.
The troops returned fire, killing six of the civilian attackers and wounding dozens of people, Tass said. The Government newspaper Izvestia reported that a number of soldiers and officers were also wounded and that two died.
Later that afternoon, 14 more nationalists and a lieutenant colonel from the Soviet Interior Ministry were killed in a gunfight on the outskirts of the capital, Tass reported.
 
Fighting Around City
The agency's reports were confirmed in telephone interviews with journalists and members of nationalist organizations in Armenia. These people also said a number of clashes had taken place today in pockets around the city.
Leaders of the Karabakh Committee, the most influential nationalist group in Armenia, denied responsibility for the incidents and said they were at a loss to explain what had happened.
They said that reinforcements for Interior Ministry troops had been brought to the area in advance of the republic's independence day, a commemoration of Armenia's two years of independent statehood from 1918 to 1920, that was to have been celebrated today.
Instead of an independence march, more than 100,000 people met on the city's main theater square today to try to sort out the weekend events.
''There are many different versions,'' Rafael Popoyan, a Yerevan resident, said in a telephone interview. ''Who confronted whom and why is just not known.''
 
Graphic Film
Film of some of the fighting that reached Moscow today offered gruesome evidence of heavy fighting and high tension. Footage obtained by CBS News in Moscow showed areas of the Yerevan train station soaked in blood, riddled with bullet holes and showered with broken glass.
The film also pictured dozens of tanks, armored personnel carriers and jeeps riding through the city, and battles with the government troops both in the capital and in nearby suburbs.
The civilian fighters were heavily armed with automatic rifles, bandoliers of ammunition strapped across their chests, pistols and gasoline bombs.
It is not known how the Armenian nationalists got such heavy arms. Officials have accused nationalist groups in the past of stealing from government arsenals and receiving shipments from sympathizers living abroad.
 
Soviet General Assails Leaders
In a report carried by Tass, the commander of the Soviet Interior Ministry troops, Col. Gen. Yuri Shatalin, today called the nationalist fighters ''terrorists,'' and he said that the ''bloodshed in Yerevan'' was brought about by ''open connivance of the republic leadership and law enforcement agencies with illegal armed groups.''
He accused local leaders of ignoring signs that nationalists in the capital were acquiring stolen vehicles and weapons.
General Shatalin, who flew to Yerevan over the weekend, said he had met with ''leaders of illegal armed formations,'' but that they had rejected his request that they voluntarily surrender their arms.
Consequently, he said, ''resolute measures'' were needed to disarm the groups, and he warned that if local law enforcement agencies failed to do this, the task would be carried out by Interior Ministry troops.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Taxes: Pitfall or a Leg Up for Bush?

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28

 BODY:
Is President Bush, who built an imposing victory in 1988 and imposing poll ratings in 1989 and 1990 at least partly on his ''no new taxes'' pledge, starting to fade politically because he has softened that pledge?
Not at all, said a top White House strategist, and added: ''Either there will be a major deal, trading tax increases for real reform in the budget process, with the President coming off as 'Mr. Competence,' or there won't be any deal. Period.''
The President's senior advisers say much of the public resistance to new taxes, which continues strong, is linked to the conviction that a lot of the money collected from current taxes is wasted.
Hence the White House emphasis on ''reforming the process'' - drastically changing the slapdash way budgets and appropriations are written. 
Even if there were some residual blame accruing to the President, the strategist argues, it would provoke no more than a blip on the political radar, which would soon disappear.
But other Republicans, like Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and Edward J. Rollins, the man responsible for trying to elect Republican Congressional candidates this fall, think the party is in danger of losing the main issue differentiating it from the Democrats, now that Communism is fading as a vote-generating specter.
Support for that view is found in a New York Times/CBS News poll, taken last week.
It shows that about as many people think the Republicans are likely to raise taxes as think Democrats are. For a decade, the Republicans benefited from a public perception that their opponents were the tax-and-spenders.
It may be that Mr. Bush, through his repeated, seemingly unqualified pledges not to raise taxes, has raised the stakes, and if he now agrees to an increase, voters will decide his party is no different from the other one.
Bob Beckel, a Democratic campaign specialist, said he thought that Mr. Bush was already suffering with the voters from his decision to join the Democratic leadership on Capitol Hill in the search for a deficit-cutting formula.
''But these guys are smarter than we are,'' Mr. Beckel said of the Republicans. ''They're willing to accept whatever pain and suffering they get out of this, short term, if it helps make victory more likely for the President. Recession in '90, not '92 - that's their motto.''
Two tax changes that have been widely discussed could affect Mr. Bush's strong standing in the polls, in the view of many politicians.
Reducing the rates on capital gains, an idea much cherished by the President, worries some Republicans with populist views, who fear it could help revive the old image of the rich man's party.
And a higher gasoline tax could lead to a rebellion at pumps and polls by the blue-collar voters whom Ronald Reagan attracted to the party. The Times/CBS poll indicates that 57 percent of the public objects to the idea.
But Peter Hart, a Democratic poll taker, thinks the situation is a good deal more complex than that, though not without problems for Mr. Bush. In his view, the President is vulnerable not on the abrogation of his no-new-taxes pledge but on the general question of economic leadership, and he said Mr. Bush needed ''to signal more strongly what his prescription is.''
Clearly Mr. Bush and Richard G. Darman, the budget director, agree that stormy economic weather may lie ahead.
But Mr. Bush is still not willing to sound a public alarm, saying he fears that he might panic the markets. Nor is he ready to put forward a plan for negotiation with the Democrats, preferring to play for time.
In that sense, this week's summit conference with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union comes at exactly the right time for Mr. Bush, focusing attention on foreign policy, the area where he and his party evoke the greatest public confidence, and away from the troubling topic of taxes.

LENGTH: 534 words

HEADLINE: The Biggest Scandal Ever

 BODY:
No less an authority than the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, says the eventual cost of the savings and loan bailout could exceed a half- trillion dollars. A half-trillion. And Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady admits that taxpayers will bear most of that burden. 
It is scandalous, all agree, but unlike any earlier scandal. By any measure, it is the largest by far. Forget the relatively puny bailouts of Chrysler, Lockheed and New York City. (Even the Marshall Plan, which bailed out Western Europe 40 years ago, cost a mere $65 billion in today's dollars.) A greater outrage is that most of the perpetrators will escape. For that, the responsible parties are members of Congress who legislated the thrifts' license to splurge and steal, Reagan Administration officials who ignored the storm warnings and hundreds of incompetent and corrupt S & L owners and managers who dallied with their depositors' trust.
A few politicians have paid, and more may pay as inquiries proceed. Former Representative Fernand St Germain of Rhode Island, co-author of the law that turned the S & L's loose, was defeated for re-election. Speaker Jim Wright's downfall was due partly to his badgering of Federal regulators. Five senators' reputations, if not their seats, are at risk because they intervened with regulators on behalf of a big campaign donor, Charles Keating, and his now-bankrupt Lincoln Savings and Loan.
Some industry high-fliers have paid, too. Close to 50 thrift officials, developers, accountants and others have been convicted, and F.B.I. Director William Sessions says his agents have found fraud ''pervasive'' industrywide. But even if Government prosecutors were more vigorous, most of the funds are gone.
So who really pays? Mostly the taxpayer; to a lesser extent the surviving thrifts, which now pay higher fees for Federal deposit insurance.
Estimates of the damage vary widely because the experts still don't agree on how to measure it. Secretary Brady says the cost might reach $130 billion; the General Accounting Office says $325 billion, and Mr. Greenspan says a half-trillion.
Why the huge differences? Mr. Brady doesn't count most of the huge interest payments for 30 or 40 years on the billions he must borrow to finance the bailout; and no one knows what the interest rates will be. He also omits billions laid out for failed thrifts before last year, when the bailout package was enacted.
Another unknown is what the Government will recoup from selling the immensely varied assets of the thrifts it takes over - real estate, junk bonds, amusement parks. Finally, there is no way to know just how many thrifts will be taken over.
One thing is clear. In 1987, when the Reagan Administration first acknowledged a problem - the deposit insurance fund was running low - it asked Congress for $15 billion. The savings and loan industry, wanting desperately to avoid scrutiny, insisted that $5 billion would be enough. Congress finally voted $11 billion.
Those figures show how easily a lax Administration, an irresponsible Congress and a recklessly deregulated industry played with other people's money. That's why the taxpayer will now pay. Perhaps a half-trillion.

HEADLINE: The Real Red Squirrel Peril

 BODY:
The Sierra Club and several other environmental groups have got themselves on the wrong side of a silly debate. They oppose putting telescopes on Mount Graham in Arizona, contending that the observatory will endanger a population of red squirrels. The greater risk is to the health of the Endangered Species Act. 
Arizona is a center of world astronomy because of its high mountains and fine viewing conditions. But streetlights from expanding cities limit existing observatories. The University of Arizona determined that Mount Graham, in the Coronado National Forest, was the best possible site for a new one and plans advanced and innovative telescopes.
Until the university's decision, no one cared much about the red squirrels on Mount Graham. Much of their habitat had been destroyed by extensive logging. Hunting licenses to shoot them were available from the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. For better sport, the service in fact introduced another squirrel, the Abert squirrel, which competes for food with the red squirrel.
Though the red squirrel is not an endangered species, it is surely threatened on Mount Graham. The university therefore scaled down its plans so that the telescopes and access road will occupy a mere 9 acres, expanding to 24 if all goes well. The red squirrels' present habitat is at least 1,700 acres and more probably 10,000. Also, the university will do reforesting and close off a logging road. The squirrels could be further protected by feeding or by removing the rival Abert squirrel.
Yet instead of working for the coexistence of squirrels and astronomers, the Sierra Club and its allies have chosen confrontation. They have sued to block the observatory, a misguided effort in which the more level-headed Environmental Defense Fund has declined to join.
There is an unattractive absolutism in the environmentalists' arguments. The Endangered Species Act, which protects isolated populations even of unthreatened species, often attracts intense opposition from those whose economic interests are imperiled, as in the cases of the snail darter and the spotted owl. To invoke this helpful act in frivolous causes is to invite its demise.

HEADLINE: Root of Liberia's Crisis Stems From Its President

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I agree with J. Brian Atwood that active diplomacy on the part of the United States is desperately needed to resolve the conflict in the West African nation of Liberia (''Liberian Bloodshed, U.S. Diplomacy,'' Op-Ed, May 11). I also agree that credible, internationally monitored elections should be an important part of our diplomatic effort.
But the root cause of the Liberian crisis is not the absence of elections. The real problem is President Samuel K. Doe himself. His repressive policies over the last 10 years have fueled the rebel insurgency and robbed his government of legitimacy and credibility. 
The Doe Government's response to the recent outbreak of violence in northeastern Liberia is a case in point. When a small group of rebel insurgents entered Nimba County last December, President Doe's troops went on a brutal rampage through the affected region, killing hundreds of unarmed civilians. Many of the victims appear to have been targeted by Government troops merely because of their ethnic ties to the insurgent forces. This small insurgency has now developed into a major uprising that threatens the capital, Monrovia.
The Liberian Government's actions in Nimba County are part of a larger pattern of human rights abuses, economic mismanagement and increasingly oppressive policies. Many forms of legitimate political opposition are not tolerated; press freedoms are denied, and arbitrary arrests are well documented. Only when these abuses have ceased can we assess President Doe's credibility and good faith concerning a free and fair election.
The Congress has taken a keen interest in United States policy toward Liberia. On April 24, the House of Representatives approved legislation, which I introduced, that condemns the Doe Government's brutal human rights abuses. In the Senate, a similar bill has been introduced by Senator Edward Kennedy. Although these bills call on President Doe to honor his commitment to hold elections as scheduled, they place primary attention on the root causes of the crisis - the actions of President Doe himself.
 
TED WEISS
Member of Congress, 17th Dist., N.Y.
 Washington, May 16, 1990

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Vision at the Summit

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

 BODY:
George Bush comes to this week's summit meeting with every political advantage over a Mikhail Gorbachev beset by internal conflict. But in a sense it will be as much of a test for Mr. Bush. It will show whether he can develop a long-term view of policy for a crucial part of the world - and explain his vision to the American people.
Pragmatism has been the hallmark of this President's foreign policy: a day at a time, a problem at a time. On the whole that has worked. Mr. Bush has responded prudently to such delicate issues as Baltic independence, avoiding rigidity, not crying havoc. He takes a close interest in all that is happening in the world: a nice change in the White House. 
But pragmatism has its limits. Without a vision, and public understanding of it, policy cannot meet long-range needs - least of all at a time of fundamental change. Every once in a while the country needs to set a course. This is such a time.
Consider the desperate current state of the Soviet economy. What role does President Bush envisage for The United States in helping to reform that economic system and liberate Soviet public psychology from its deadening legacy?
The idea that America can help the process of change in a Marxist economy is hardly alien to Mr. Bush. He relied on it in justifying his decision to continue most-favored-nation trading status for China despite the cruelties of its tyrannical Government. He extolled the function of U.S. trade in encouraging not only economic reform but ''justice and reason'' in China.
''Economic contacts are the best way to keep the economic reforms going forward,'' he said.
The same argument should apply to the Soviet Union, only more so. This is a moment of economic choice for the Soviet Government and people. Fears of inflation or unemployment are slowing change, perhaps crippling the chance of success. Nothing could do more to ease those fears than growing economic relationships with the United States: trade, investment, training.
Moreover, Soviet citizens can freely debate their economic future, as the Chinese cannot. A McDonald's in Moscow can influence that debate.
The United States has a powerful national interest in the growth of economic hope in the Soviet Union. Hope is the secret of stability. However the current turmoil reshapes the Soviet state, we have to want eventual stability in a country with thousands of nuclear weapons.
Of course there are obstacles to economic cooperation with the U.S.S.R. One is the fact that its liberalized emigration policy has not yet been formalized in law. Another is the Lithuanian independence conflict.
But President Bush could take those into account and still set the objective - the urgent objective - of forging new economic relationships. It is not enough to say, as he did the other day, that Congress would object. He has to tell us where he wants to go, and show us why it is in the American interest to go there as we can. He has to lead.
The advertised agenda of this summit meeting focuses on arms control. But it is more important that the two Presidents at least open up the subject of economics. And that they begin to talk about future political-military arrangements in Europe that could ease understandable Soviet concerns about a united Germany.
President Bush obviously respects Mikhail Gorbachev and understands how far he has gone on a very difficult road. Who could have imagined, a year ago, that a Soviet leader would quietly allow the countries of Eastern Europe to go free? Who could have foreseen the crumbling of the Warsaw Pact as a military threat, or the end of NATO concern about a possible Soviet invasion of Western Europe?
What the President has not done is work those changes into a new concept of Soviet-American relations, less hostile, more cooperative. He has not given us a picture of a post-cold war world. Indeed, he still seems blinkered by such cold war ideas as the notion that we should help an authoritarian China because it is an anti-Soviet force.
George Bush cannot, we cannot, know what the Soviet Union will become. But if we want Mr. Gorbachev to stay on the course of internal freedom and withdrawal from external empire - and we do - we need a policy that will encourage him and his people.
There are Americans on the extreme right who will not be content unless Moscow is ruled by a Romanov restoration or turned into a salt plain. But most of Mr. Bush's public is open-minded about the possibilities for a new relationship with the Soviet Union. It is looking for leadership.

HEADLINE: Conservatives Balk as G.O.P. Prepares to Back Rinfret

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

DATELINE: RYE, N.Y., May 28

 BODY:
The New York State Republican Party suffered a serious setback today when a traditional ally, the Conservative Party, prepared to field its own candidate for governor rather than endorse the Republican leaders' choice.
Conservative leaders said today that they would not support the Republican favorite, Pierre A. Rinfret, because of his stand on abortion and because they questioned his ability to make an issue of the tax and spending policies of the Democratic Governor, Mario M. Cuomo. The Conservatives instead plan to nominate Herbert London, a 51-year-old dean at New York University.
The announcement came after Mr. London met with Republican leaders and Mr. Rinfret, who offered him the Republican nomination for lieutenant governor. Mr. London declined the offer, saying Mr. Rinfret would not be able to make an issue of taxes because Republican state senators were at least partly responsible for the state's fiscal problems. The Republicans also lack a candidate for attorney general. 
Mr. Rinfret, a wealthy Manhattan economics consultant with little political experience, agreed only last week to run for governor after the party had failed to persuade any better-known Republican to take up the challenge of Mr. Cuomo. Mr. Rinfret is expected to receive the nomination when the party's convention begins here Tuesday.
The Republicans, with severe fund-raising problems and scant prospects of help from Washington, saw at least 16 prominent party members rule themselves out as potential candidates before they settled on Mr. Rinfret (pronounced rin-FRAY). Mr. Cuomo has a campaign war chest of at least $8 million and had a 65 percent approval rating in several polls taken last March.
J. Patrick Barrett, the Republican state chairman, had offered Mr. London the lieutenant-governor nomination in a meeting Friday evening in an effort to head off a split with the Conservatives.
Last week, Mr. London, who briefly ran for mayor of New York City last year, was brushed off by Mr. Barrett and State Senator Roy M. Goodman, the Manhattan Republican leader, as a possible gubernatorial candidate because of his opposition to abortion and his lack of funds.
Mr. Rinfret, who is 66 years old, supports a woman's right to an abortion and has told party leaders that he will spend at least $500,000 of his own money on the campaign.
The move by Mr. London and the Conservatives marked Mr. Rinfret's first failure as a potential candidate and could spark a floor fight at the convention at the Hilton Hotel here. Mr. Barrett acknowledged in a telephone interview Sunday from Syracuse that there had been some protests when it became apparent Mr. Rinfret would be nominated. But he said he was fully supporting Mr. Rinfret, who was first suggested by Mr. Goodman. Mr. Barrett and Mr. Goodman have been largely responsible for putting together the state party ticket.
Mr. Rinfret met with Mr. London for two hours today in Mr. Rinfret's apartment in Manhattan to try to convince Mr. London to be his running mate as the candidate for lieutenant governor.
 
Embarrassing Position
When Mr. London turned him down, the Republicans were left in the embarrassing position of having to offer the nomination to an obvious second choice just before the start of their convention. That choice may be Toni Rettaliata, a former assemblywoman defeated for re-election as town supervisor in Huntington, L.I., last November. Another Long Islander, Robert R. McMillan, earlier rejected an offer to be the party's nominee for attorney general.
The split on the political right meant that the Republicans and the Conservatives would waste their ability to jointly criticize Mr. Cuomo on taxes, state spending and crime and be put in the position of sniping at each other on abortion, an issue that is highly emotional but does not seem to have been crucial to New York voters picking state officials in recent years.
Differences over abortion could surface Tuesday in the Republican platform. The state Republican Party, like President Bush and his predecessor, Ronald Reagan, has officially opposed abortion, but at least one group, the New York State Republican Family Committee, has urged that the party support women's abortion rights. Mr. Goodman has also taken this view.
 
Fiscal Policies
The Conservatives' state chairman, Michael R. Long, said supporting Mr. Rinfret would ''jeopardize my party'' because of the candidate's position on abortion and because it would be more difficult for a Republican to make an issue of Mr. Cuomo's fiscal policies. The State Senate Republican majority, like the Assembly Democratic majority, has approved the state budget calling for a record amount in new taxes.
Mr. Long said Mr. Rinfret ''doesn't have an agenda nor ideas to reshape New York State'' and implied that Mr. Rinfret was treating the race too lightly. ''What I picked up very clearly in my conversations with him,'' Mr. Long said, ''was that he liked the idea of running for governor and was going to have a lot of fun.''
In a year in which the governor's race would be close, Mr. Long said, the Conservatives might swallow some of their differences with the Republicans. But he does not expect a close race this year. ''This is a good year to talk about fundamental issues,'' he said.
At a news conference tonight, Mr. Barrett said he had not yet given up on Mr. London and the Conservatives. He added that Mr. Rinfret was ''a conservative on practically every issue except abortion.''
Mr. Rinfret, who operates a Manhattan economic consulting and trading firm, has been unavailable for comment since he first surfaced as a candidate last week. He has never before run for public office and has not been active in the New York Republican Party. He has not even been enrolled in any political party since 1976.
 
New Political Consultant
Mr. London said Mr. Rinfret ''wasn't prepared to discuss issues in depth'' in their lengthy face-to-face conversation today. In another room in the Rinfret apartment was Mr. Rinfret's new political consultant, Eddie Mahe of Washington, who had briefly advised Mr. London in the mayoral campaign last year. Mr. Rinfret's son, Peter, also worked in the London mayoral effort.
That mayoral campaign marked the first signs of the coming apart of the longtime Republican-Conversative alliance as the Conservatives supported Ronald S. Lauder while the Republicans backed Rudolph W. Giuliani. Abortion, which Mr. Lauder opposed, was also a critical issue in that split.
Mr. London said he would make an issue of ''taxes and spending and crime and punishment.'' He said he favored the death penalty, which Republicans have signaled will be a major issue against Mr. Cuomo, who opposes it.

HEADLINE: Shipper of Food for A.I.D. Investigated Over Unfit Milk

BYLINE: By DEAN BAQUET

 BODY:
The affidavit portrays AMG as having a history of fraud. It cited a Federal Maritime Commission ruling in 1987 that accused AMG of defrauding the Government and commercial shippers by mislabeling cargo to obtain a cheaper rate. The document said AMG was embroiled in more than 60 suits in New York with shippers. 
In an interview, Mr. Merritt denied trying to cheat the Sudan. He said that a subcontractor, a supplier in Sri Lanka, had substituted the powder and that he had alerted American officials about the substitution months ago, but had been ignored.
''I didn't want this stuff to get sent out and have people get sick from it,'' said Mr. Merritt, who the Government said was the majority stockholder in AMG. ''But we didn't do anything wrong. We just got caught in the middle.''
By Mr. Merritt's account, most of the money paid to AMG was distributed to subcontractors, including the Sri Lankans. Mr. Merritt said he did not know why the Government had settled on AMG as a subject of the inquiry.
Mr. Merritt's lawyer, Erwin Shustak, said he believed the Government was investigating AMG because of a dispute Mr. Merritt had with an investigator years ago. ''The Government is acting with vindictiveness,'' Mr. Shustak said. ''I'm sure they think he is in international espionage or a wheeler-dealer. But he is just a struggling businessman.''
Prosecutors would not comment. The 15-page affidavit, sworn by an investigator for the Agency for International Development, Mellberth Bowling, portrays AMG as a willing participant that used fake documents to collect money from the Government.
The aid program is intended to provide food for the Sudan while creating economic development in the country. A Government-controlled Sudanese company orders the food and places money for it in a bank account jointly controlled by A.I.D. and the Sudanese Government.
 
Written Assurance
The United States Government then pays for the food, and the money in the account is spent on roads and other improvements. That way, the affidavit said, the United States tries to assure that the Sudan is spending the aid money on development.
The affidavit said that early last year AMG told the Sudanese company that the powder had been loaded on a Dutch ship, the Tonya, and was ready to leave Sri Lanka. After receiving written assurance, the Sudanese company asked the United States to pay for the cargo. AMG received the money.
When the Tonya failed to arrive in the Sudan, the Sudanese company investigated, the affidavit said, reportedly finding that the Tonya had never been loaded with the milk. Even if the milk had been loaded, the ship was so small she would have sunk, the Government asserted.
In its investigation, the Sudanese company also learned that AMG still intended to fulfill the contract, but with a poor-quality powder, the Government contended. The Sudan rejected the shipment after having tested the powder before shipment. The affidavit did not specify the problem.
In the affidavit, Mr. Bowling said his account was based on interviews with former AMG employees and others who knew about the transaction.
Mr. Merritt said that AMG was just supposed to arrange the shipment and that another American company, which he identified as Laura Exports, was to find a supplier for the milk. He said documents subpoenaed by prosecutors would support his contention.

HEADLINE: Racial Unity and Dissent in Brooklyn

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

DATELINE: NEW YORK, May 28

 BODY:
Demonstrating for racial harmony, a small group wended its way through Prospect Park in Brooklyn today, handing out ''unity'' buttons and tying blue ribbons to lampposts and trees.
''Unity means love,'' a black leader of the march, Fred McCray, said as he pinned a button to the T-shirt of a Korean-American boy.
But less than a mile away on Church Avenue, the bitter boycott by a small group of blacks against two Korean greengrocers continued, with both sides trading angry charges.
''Nothing's changed,'' said Capt. Vincent Kennedy of the 70th Police Precinct as he stood between protesters and the Family Red Apple Market. 
The Prospect Park march took place amid a holiday crowd that was breaking out new barbecue grills. The air was filled with Frisbees, volleyballs, the click of camera shutters and the smell of sizzling hot dogs. Holiday revelers, enjoying a pleasant turn in the weather, warmly welcomed the dozen unity marchers.
The march, sponsored by the Brooklyn Women's Political Caucus, was led by Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney, and Mr. McCray, an economics teacher at Erasmus Hall High School, who two weeks ago led 30 students into the Family Red Apple store in defiance of the boycott.
 
Harmony and Haranguing
''We all must get along,'' said Cynthia Moore of East New York, whose family was spread out on five blankets. Adjacent to her black family were whites from the Park Slope section and Hispanic people from the Williamsburg area.
''We have no race problems here,'' said Donna Kelly of Park Slope.
On Church Avenue, however, one protester tapped incessantly with a spoon on a tin can and chanted, ''Boycott! Boycott!'' When, from time to time, a customer entered the Family Red Apple Market, a cry rose from the crowd of about 20 and the chanting increased.
None of the protesters were willing to give their name or say where they were from. One older woman in a brown dress, who seemed to be in charge, shouted: ''We are stronger than ever. We will never give up.''
Inside the store, the owner, Bong Jae Jang, said that none of the good will exhibited in Prospect Park had spilled over to Church Avenue. He said that business was terrible yesterday and that the warm weather was hastening the rotting of his fruits and vegetables, which he continues to buy - and throw out - with the aid of the Korean Produce Association.
The merchants' group has committed itself to keeping open the Red Apple and a second store, Church Fruits, as a sign that Korean shopkeepers cannot be intimidated. Each store receives about $8,000 a month from the association.
Mr. Jang complained that Mayor David N. Dinkins's office, which had set up a negotiating session with a Haitian woman whose assertion that she was assaulted in the store had sparked the protest, canceled the session abruptly last week. The storekeeper, who has said the incident was a misunderstanding, not an assault, said he was angry that the session had not been rescheduled.
''The Mayor only spoke with his mouth to impress people,'' Mr. Jang said.
The Mayor's press officers did not return telephone calls seeking comment.
The Prospect Park unity march was one of several organized in response to the call last week by Mayor Dinkins at a rally in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan to foster better relations in every neighborhood.
It was Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez who promoted the use of the blue ribbons as a sign of racial harmony in the schools, an idea the Mayor readily embraced on a citywide basis.
In his remarks, District Attorney Hynes said the marchers were hoping to work as ''a counterbalance to those forces in the city that seek to divide us.''
Mr. McCray said he was there to ''plant seeds of unity for this summer'' among young people, in the hope of stopping racial incidents. Mr. McCray, who is black, has requested a transfer from Erasmus Hall High School because of threats against him and his family since he defied the boycott. He said, however, that he would continue to speak out against racism.

HEADLINE: Little Icons of Texas' Past Are Auctioned Off

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NEW ULM, Tex., May 28

 BODY:
An auctioneer spent the weekend selling off half of this town. The residents are delighted.
''It couldn't have gone any better, really,'' the auctioneer, A. L. (Buck) Buchanan, said today. The sale included about six and a half acres, 100-year-old log cabins and antique farm equipment and furnishings. 
The auction Saturday, ordered by the Texas Historical Foundation, drew 1,800 people. The properties sold once belonged to Jeanne Blocker, a Houston investor, and her husband, John, who was once an oilman.
Mrs. Blocker had a vision: to create a historic village within New Ulm, which is about 60 miles west of Houston. To carry it out, she acquired nearly every rundown log structure in the area.
The Blockers also bought about half the town's acreage and several old buildings. They even brought in other buildings and furnishings from as far as 50 miles away.
Mrs. Blocker cleared some land, dug a pond and created a small waterfall and restored a handful of buildings. But the collapse of oil prices stalled her big plans in 1984.
After she died in 1988, her husband donated everything except three pieces of land to the Texas Historical Foundation.
''Mrs. Blocker worked very hard on all of this,'' Mr. Buchanan said. ''She did an awful lot of research and planning.''
But for this town of about 100 people, most of them retired, what once promised an economic boom has become a financial drain. Most of the Blockers' half of town is tax-exempt, since they bought it as a nonprofit foundation. But the steep prices paid by the Blockers drove up property values and taxes for everyone else in town.
 
Creamery, Saloon and Shop
The auction's proceeds were still not fully tallied today. Mr. Buchanan said the MacKinsky dogtrot log house, built in the late 18th or early 19th century, fetched the top price: more than $6,000.
Also snatched up were a creamery, a saloon and a Ford Model T repair shop. Mr. Buchanan said some structures would be moved and others would be reopened or renovated.
The historical foundation said it would use the proceeds for an unspecified project elsewhere.

GRAPHIC: Map of half of the village of New Ulm, Tex., was auctioned off Saturday. (NYT)

HEADLINE: As Bias Crime Seems to Rise, Scientists Study Roots of Racism

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
AS racial and ethnic violence erupts throughout the world, psychologists are striving to understand what impels people to acts of hatred, particularly when they act in groups.
Researchers are focusing on who commits such crimes, what motivates them and exactly why people who would not commit violent acts on their own express their hatred so freely in groups.
Scientists studying hate crimes have made these findings:
* They are far more lethal than other kinds of attacks, resulting in the hospitalization of their victims four times more often than is true for other assaults.
* They are crimes of youth: most of those who perpetrate them are in their teens or 20's. But they are not crimes of youthful rebellion: those who carry them out are venting feelings shared by their families, friends and community, researchers say. 
* The large majority are committed by people in groups of four or more. And the more people in the group, the more vicious the crime.
* They reflect the primal emotions aroused by the love of one's own group; these deep feelings of group identity are particularly vivid in times of economic and political uncertainty and among people who suffered emotional neglect as children.
These factors are at play, experts say, as racial, religious and ethnic incidents erupt around the world, in riots between Azerbaijanis and Armenians, anti-Semitism in Russia, the racial killing in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, and the tensions in the borough between blacks and Koreans.
''Everyone who collects data reports a steady increase in hate crimes in the last year or two,'' said Howard Ehrlich, director of the National Institute Against Prejudice and Violence in Baltimore.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation, for instance, reported that last year its civil rights unit had a record number of cases. ''These crimes are certainly on the increase,'' said Mike Kortan, a bureau spokesman.
Although the figures may reflect increased reporting rather than an actual increase in crime, rates for what the police call ''bias crimes'' - acts of violence inspired by racism and other prejudice - are also rising. The Boston Police Department, which had recorded about 150 bias crimes each year from 1986 to 1988, had 202 cases in 1989.
In New York City, such crimes were up 14 percent for the first four months of 1990 compared with the same time last year, said Inspector Paul Sanderson of the Bias Incident Investigation Unit.
For 1989 the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith monitored a 12 percent increase in anti-Semitic incidents from the previous year, including harassment, assaults, desecration and vandalism. ''It's the highest number we've recorded in 11 years,'' said Gail Gans, who works in the league's research office.
Particularly troubling to Ms. Gans and others who track such statistics is the activity on college campuses. In 1989 racial or ethnic incidents were reported on 115 American campuses.
''What's most distressing is that it's spreading,'' said Dr. Erlich. ''Of the 115 campuses, 52 were places where there hadn't been such trouble before.''
 
The Patterns
Whos and Whys Of Bias
Bias crimes vary widely, from a swastika daubed on a synagogue to the beating of a white youth waiting for a bus in a black neighborhood. Certain patterns are particularly common. ''Most hate crimes are matters of turf; the most frequent is an attack on someone who is just passing through a neighborhood where he's seen as out of place,'' said Jack McDevitt, a sociologist at Northeastern Unviversity.
Dr. McDevitt has analyzed 452 cases of bias crime that occurred in Boston from 1983 to 1987. He reported his findings last year at a conference of the American Society of Criminology in Reno, Nev.
Of all bias crimes, Dr. McDevitt found, 57 percent involved issues of turf; they were attacks on someone walking, driving through or working in a neighborhood, or on a family moving into the area or not wanted there.
Typical of those, he said, was what happened to an Asian family that moved into an all-white neighborhood in Boston. On the first night someone broke several windows with rocks; on the second night the walls were spray-painted with racist slurs. On the third night the family moved back to its old neighborhood, leaving an older son to guard its possessions. A mob of 20 youths taunted the son until he came out, then beat him.
Another common pattern is an attack on someone who has wandered into a neighborhood not realizing he or she is ''out of place.'' In one such incident, Dr. McDevitt said, a 12-year-old black girl took a shortcut from her school to a new convenience store nearby. As she was walking there, a group of white youths drove alongside and asked what she was doing in ''their'' neighborhood. They started taunting her, got out, pushed her down and kicked her, breaking a rib.
In Dr. McDevitt's study, most of the perpetrators of racist incidents were young white men, just under two-thirds; one-third were black. Of the total sample, two-thirds were 29 or younger. Virtually none of the perpetrators were women, but women accounted for 29 percent of the victims.
And while most of the crimes by blacks were against whites, Dr. McDevitt said that ''whites attack everybody: blacks, Hispanics, gays, Asians.'' He added that in Boston bias crimes by Asian-Americans and Hispanic Americans were rare, though Vietnamese were the third most frequently victimized group.
Patterns vary, of course, in other cities. In Miami, for instance, tensions are greatest between Hispanic residents and blacks, said Dr. McDevitt.
 
The Ugly Crowd
Viciousness In Numbers
The viciousness of bias incidents is among Dr. McDevitt's most startling findings. Half involved assaults. Of these, the victims were injured in 74 percent of the cases; the national average for injury to an assault victim is 29 percent.
More telling, at least one victim required hospitalization in 30 percent of the prejudice-based assaults, while for other assaults the average rate of injuries that severe is 7 percent.
The usual number of perpetrators in such crimes, Dr. McDevitt found, is four or more. The most common number of victims is one.
''It's a coward's crime,'' said Detective Brian Flynn, who investigates such incidents for the Boston police. ''It takes just 10 seconds to break a window in the dead of night, but they have to get together in numbers to get their guts up.''
Sheer numbers encourage viciousness, new research shows. For instance, Brian Mullen, a psychologist at Syracuse University has analyzed newspaper accounts of 60 lynchings in the United States earlier in this century.
''The larger the mob, the more atrocious and savage the lynching, and the more likely to include burning or mutilating the victim,'' said Dr. Mullen.
One reason crowds draw out a viciousness that the individuals would not display on their own, psychologists say, is that there is a diffusion of responsibility. Being one among many means that no one person need take the blame for what happens.
Anonymity is also a force in unleashing the crowd's viciousness. The hoods and night meetings of the Ku Klux Klan have long taken advantage of this, said Dr. Steven Salmony, a psychologist at the University of North Carolina who has studied the dynamics of Klan violence by observing Klan rallies and by interviewing members, including one who shared secret documents.
But most bias crimes are anonymous in a larger sense: the crowd itself offers anonymity and, in most cases, its members do not know their victim. More than 85 percent of the crimes he analyzed were committed by strangers, Dr. McDevitt found.
Dr. Mullen said, ''The tragedy is that when people in the mob look back afterward, they almost always say they can't believe they did those things. It's like it was someone else doing it.''
That fact is telling, according to Dr. Mullen. ''In the moment that people get carried away by a crowd, they literally forget themselves,'' he said. ''They forget their own sense of what's right and wrong, of the normal limits to what they will do.'' In many cases, those who commit bias crimes have been primed for racist actions by the values expressed by family members. ''When they're sitting around the dinner table at home they hear this racist garbage from their mom and dad,'' said Detective Flynn. ''It makes them feel they have their family's approval.''
 
The Emotional Roots
Primal Feelings Turned Loose
Psychoanalysts see primal feelings at play when prejudice leads to acts of hatred. ''The excitement of a group encourages people to regress to the psychological level of early childhood,'' said Dr. Salmony.
Early childhood, Dr. Salmony said, is a time when the emotional world is split into sharp dichotomies of good and bad, love and hate. ''In adulthood, for some people that becomes an emotional split with intense love for your own group and an intense hatred for another group,'' he said.
That emotional dynamic means that the underside of pride in one's own group is dislike of another.
Most people harbor such feelings lightly, if at all, and can keep the impulse to act on them under control. While these attitudes are revealed, for instance, in ethnic jokes and slurs, they rarely lead to overt acts of bias in most people, Dr. Salmony said.
In fact, psychologists say, ethnic jokes can offer a kind of safety valve for hostilities.
''The racist remarks of stand-up comedians just reflect the fact that ethnic and racial mistrust always exists in the folk culture, and shows up in humor,'' said Dr. Vamik Volkan, a psychiatrist at the University of Virginia. ''But it's not bad: if you can laugh about it, you're not likely to act on it.''
Such humor can even form a positive bond to the ridiculed group. ''If you make the same kind of degrading remarks about yourself, your family and your own group, as many comedians do, then it forms an emotional link to the groups you attack,'' Dr. Volkan said.
But, he said, ''when a comedian's humor is only derisive of the other group, and the comedian is hate-filled, then it adds to the hatred,'' said Dr. Volkan.
Such hostility carries the most emotional intensity, Dr. Salmony said, in people whose parents ignored their basic emotional needs as children.
For such people, said Dr. Salmony, ''being in a crowd where hostile feelings toward a group are being expressed triggers a regression to a primitive level of mental activity. They fall prey to an emotional contagion where they see their own group as they source of all that is good, and those in an opposing group as equally bad. It intensifies their hatred toward those seen as outsiders.''
At that moment, striking out against the hated group has a paradoxical effect: it makes the one who hates feel good about himself. ''The aggression enhances their own sense of identity with a group they love,'' said Dr. Salmony. ''It's a malignant kind of narcissism that fills them with a heightened feeling of their own value.''
 
Economic Factors
Shifting Blame In Troubled Times
The ethnic tensions that are shattering Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union have a similar basis, said Ervin Staub, a psychologist at the University of Massachusetts who is the author of ''The Roots of Evil'' (Cambridge University Press). Of course, the removal of political repression has allowed long-smoldering ethnic resentments to surface. But they have erupted with such intensity for other reasons, Dr. Staub said.
''In times of great economic insecurity and political turmoil, people need to affirm a sense of their own value,'' he said. ''These things shake your identity. You need to recreate a positive view of yourself and the group you are rooted in. But the very definition of yourself as a member of one group includes enmity towards another group.''
Dr. Volkan said: ''Who you are implies, at an emotional level, who you are not, and stress makes you cling all the more stubbornly to your ethnic identity.''
Dr. Staub, who is from Hungary, added, ''In Romania it was the Romanians against the Hungarians, in Czechoslovakia it was the Czechs against the Slovaks, and everyone was against the Jews.''
''These enmities are ancient, but they surface whenever life is in turmoil,'' Dr. Staub said. ''Devaluing the other elevates the self: this feeling that I am good is all the more important when you feel your world is out of control.''
Hatred of another group ''shifts responsibility for your problems to someone else and gives the appearance that life can be controlled if you just can do away with this enemy,'' Dr. Staub said. ''A shared enemy strengthens the group.''
That is why the protection of territory, whether a neighborhood or a province, is so common in ethnic tensions, said Dr. Volkan, who has studied ethnic tensions between Greeks and Turks on his native Cyprus, as well as similar friction in other parts of the world.
''The group's boundaries make each person inside the group feel closer,'' said Dr. Volkan. ''An outsider who pierces that boundary attacks the identity it defines.''
The recent increase in bias incidents in America, social scientists say, is spurred by economic worries. The last such increase, according to many of those interviewed, was during the recession of the late 1970's. However no one has precise figures from that period; widespread tracking of bias crimes began only the mid-1980's.
Nevertheless, those who study hate crimes say shaky economic periods heighten intergroup tensions. ''The last rise in hate crimes in America was during the last economic recession,'' said Ivan Light, a sociologist at University of California at Los Angeles. ''The roots of intergroup conflict are as much in economic competition as it is in negative stereotypes.''
Dr. Salmony said: ''Economic and political uncertainties lead to personal insecurities. For the most vulnerable people, it's a short step to ethnic violence.''
A case in point is the tension between blacks and Koreans, currently so prominent in New York City. According to Dr. Light, who has been studying relations between blacks and Koreans in Los Angeles since 1980, there is an economic undertone to the friction.
''Many blacks see non-black merchants in their communities in a way that heightens tensions,'' said Dr. Light. ''Their theory is that if you spend money with a Korean grocer on the corner, then your money leaves the black community. And that merchant's store blocks the upward mobility of some black who might have had a store of his own there.''
The same economic worries are fueling other intergroup tensions, said Detective Flynn of the Boston police. As part of his duties with the unit that investigates bias crimes, he lectures to high school students. Most of those who commit the crimes are from working-class backgrounds.
''You talk to white kids who feel they can't get any jobs because there's a quota that favors minorities,'' said Detective Flynn. ''You find it just fuels their prejudice and resentment. Then you talk to black kids who feel they're left out of the job market because of their race and you find they have the same animosity toward whites.''
Dr. Light added, ''People get along fine when they have money in their pocket and can pay the rent.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: ''Most hate crimes are matters of turf,'' said Dr. Jack McDevitt of Northeastern University who analyzed 452 bias crimes cases in Boston. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times) (pg. C5)

HEADLINE: Big Science; Is It Worth the Price? - A periodic look at the largest new research projects.;
Supercollider's Rising Cost Provokes Opposition

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
IF America eventually decides it can spare the $8 billion or so needed to build the Superconducting Supercollider, the county-size machine might turn out to be a key to the meaning of physical reality, or it might be a dud. But either way, the project is raising intense debate among scientists and politicians as to whether the new knowledge it generates will be commensurate with the enormous cost.
The huge particle accelerator, to be housed in a 54-mile-long tunnel near Waxahachie, Tex., would hurl counter-rotating beams of protons around a racetrack-shaped course, forcing these subatomic particles to collide head on at combined energies of up to 40 trillion electron-volts. This staggering energy would be some 20 times greater than the energy of particle collisions at any existing accelerator.
Proponents expect the machine to produce a deeper understanding of the fundamental forces and particles that are the building blocks of all matter and believe it will bring mankind a little closer to understanding how the universe began and evolved to its present-day complexity. 
But as the time nears to begin the costly construction phase, some seven years after the collider was first proposed to the Energy Department by leading physicists, critics are raising new questions about the project. The huge accelerator has never been popular with those scientists who view it as a budget-buster destined to starve Federal funds for smaller scientific projects, and the voices of critics have grown louder than ever.
Two years ago, Sigma Xi, the scientific honor society, conducted a national poll that found that only 2 percent of the 3,332 scientists who responded favored construction of the Superconducting Supercollider. Even the widely unpopular Strategic Defense Initiative program scored higher, with 4 percent approval.
The Central Design Group for the collider completed its preliminary plans in 1986, estimating the overall cost of the machine at $5.9 billion. But rancorous disagreements have been heightened by a series of increases in the estimated cost. Builders of the machine learned that larger margins of engineering error were essential to bring the machine up to its intended energy, and this would mean enlarging the diameter of the beam line, redesigning the magnets that confine the beam, and adding a mile or so to the machine's length. The estimated cost now stands at nearly $8 billion.
The accelerator's staff of scientists, engineers, technicians and administrators already numbers some 500, and its leaders hope that an environmental impact survey will be completed in the next few months. Some time thereafter initial site preparation will begin, and the project will begin acquiring land.
But Congress might still close down the project or string out construction to reduce annual payments. Supporters of the project say this might amount to killing it because such delays would increase the long-term cost to an unacceptable level. Delay might also render the current design obsolescent as new approaches to accelerator design and new materials are developed by rival teams of scientists. Many physicists believe that the Superconducting Supercollider represents the highest energy that can be economically produced in a circular accelerator, and that the future of high energy physics lies with linear accelerators. Some opponents argue that even the supercollider will be relatively inefficient, and that builders should abandon it and devote their efforts to developing a new type.
Critics, including many physicists, argue that the fruits of high-energy research, intellectually satisfying though they may be, have become too expensive for a nation fighting for economic position against such technologically powerful competitors as Japan. Moreover, even if the new accelerator works flawlessly, they say, its energy might still be insufficient to meet the main discovery goals set for it.
Two years ago disagreements between high-energy physicists supporting construction of the the project and other physicists not involved in accelerator research led to a schism within the American Physical Society, the nation's preeminent professional association of physicists. Bitter exchanges of letters by supporters and opponents of the collider are published monthly by the society's magazine, Physics Today. At one point, members who said they believed their economic and professional interests were threatened by a small but influential bloc of high-energy physicists considered forming an independent association. The society's officers have smoothed over the rift, but opposing opinions about the project remain strong.
Such leaders of the project as its director, Dr. Roy F. Schwitters, are seeking to convince members of Congress and key Administration officials that the Superconducting Supercollider is essential to maintaining a credible program of high-energy research in the United States. Supporters of the accelerator have sometimes sought to sell the project to members of Congress on the ground that it may lead to important innovations in practical technology and would enhance scientific education at all levels. But most scientists agree that the real object in building the project is essentially intellectual and philosophical (some even say theological) rather than practical. The goal is to recreate primordial forms of matter that have not existed elsewhere in the universe (except perhaps in black holes) since the first ten-quadrillionth of a second after the Big Bang creation event.
According to the prevailing theory, only one fundamental force existed during the first instant after the creation of the universe. But as the universe swiftly expanded and cooled, the supposed original unity split into the puzzling multiplicity of forces and particles we know today. By smashing particles together at stupendous energies and briefly recreating conditions (on a microscopic scale) that existed just after the Big Bang, scientists hope to glimpse parts of the original pristine unity of nature, thereby gaining insights into how and why our complex universe took the form it did, a form that made life itself possible.
Dr. Leon M. Lederman, a Nobel laureate, a former director of Fermilab and the president-elect of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, speaks of giant accelerators as ''telescopes that look backward in time.'' In fact, the rise of accelerators has brought about a merger of high-energy particle physics with astronomy, and astrophysicists now regard large particle accelerators and conventional telescopes as complementary tools for deciphering the workings of stars and galaxies.
In particular, physicists would like to discover why the different types of subnuclear particles have the particular masses they do, why they interact only in certain ways, and why certain numbers governing fundamental relationships in nature (for example, the speed of light, 186,000 miles per second) have the values that they do.
As Dr. Lederman and Dr. Sheldon Glashow, another Nobel laureate who supports the Superconducting Suppercollider, wrote in the March 1985 issue of Physics Today: ''Surely the Creator did not twiddle 17 dials on his black box before initiating the Big Bang and its glorious sequela, mankind.'' The great aspiration of science, they say, is to discover how the seemingly arbitrary ''dial'' settings actually are the logical consequences of an underlying universal principle.
But critics argue that the accelerator has been sold to Congress not for its intellectual appeal but because of the supposed technological and economic spin-offs it might generate. At one time the Defense Department even believed the collider would produce military benefits.
Under the Freedom of Information Act, Dr. Charles Schwartz, a professor of physics at the University of California at Berkeley, recently obtained a copy of a memorandum sent on Jan. 12, 1987, by Robert B. Barker, assistant to the Secretary of Defense, to the White House Domestic Policy Council. The memorandum, which recommended Defense Department endorsement of the supercollider, said:
''The S.S.C. project will have many spinoffs for the Department of Defense, especially in technologies required by the Strategic Defense Initiative, including particle beams, information processing, computer control, pulse power sources and high-energy accelerators. The nuclear weapons community will benefit from the fundamental research on the building blocks of atomic matter.''
Particle physicists backing the accelerator vehemently deny any association of this project or any other high-energy research accelerator with weapons programs. Dr. Robert Wilson, Fermilab's first director, was asked by members of Congress in 1970 whether the new accelerator laboratory would contribute to the development of military technology. He replied: ''It has nothing to do directly with defending our country except to make it worth defending.'' In fact, most physicists see little practical use for the technology in the project, except in high-energy research.
 
The Critics
Losses Feared For Small Projects
Dr. Paul A. Fleury, an officer of the American Physical Society who works as a research director in condensed-matter physics, said he believed that neither Congress nor the public understood what the S.S.C. was intended to do.
''If what the American people really expect of the S.S.C. is an investigation of the ultimate basis of reality, that's fine,'' he said. ''But I'm not sure people realize that what they'll be paying for is nothing more than pure science. Neither the public nor the Congress should deceive themselves by imagining that the S.S.C. will lead to important technological spinoffs. Building the S.S.C., moreover, may exact a heavy economic price, including increasing national neglect of education and a reduction of basic research in fields essential to our competitive position.''
Although overall government support for scientific research is increasing somewhat, he said, the lion's share is going to such ''big science'' projects as the accelerator and on projects with little apparent scientific value, ''such as the projected space station.''
Dr. Fleury added: ''We simply cannot fund these big projects without starving the tens of thousands of smaller research programs conducted by single scientists or small groups. These projects are doing the work that keeps the nation competitive in semiconductors, superconductors and other cutting-edge technology.
''Science and technology in America are in deadly danger. A frog suddenly dropped into a beaker of boiling water jumps out and saves itself, but if the water is heated slowly, the frog fails to notice the heat until it is too late. That's what's happening to most basic research in America,'' Dr. Fleury said, ''and one of the reasons we don't notice it is that we're spending so many research dollars on big-science projects like the S.S.C..''
In a complaint published by Physics Today in July 1988, Dr. John F. Waymouth, retired research director for GTE Electrical Products, asserted that the benefits of the collider were far from certain, and that ''a research director who wants to keep his job will not commit half his budget to the high-risk project while starving the ones that pay the bills.''
Another outspoken critic of ''big science'' who has doubts about the accelerator is Dr. Arno Penzias. He and Dr. Robert Wilson shared in the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1978 for their discovery of a faint microwave signal pervading the entire universe, a discovery accepted by most physicists as confirmation of the Big Bang theory of the origin of the universe.
''I'm no expert on the S.S.C.,'' Dr. Penzias said. ''But if we end up beggaring our universities to build this thing, I think we're on the wrong track. One of the big arguments for the S.S.C. is that it will inspire public interest in science and attract young people to the field. But if we can't educate them properly because we've spent our money on big machines instead of universities, where's the point? As a nation we must take a new look at our scientific priorities and ask ourselves what we really want.''
Some of history's most significant physics experiments actually cost very little, he said, and scientific imagination and creativity are still more important than an expensive apparatus. For example, he cited the famous 1887 light-beam experiment conducted by the American scientists Albert A. Michelson and Edward W. Morley, which paved the way for Einstein's special theory of relativity.
But other scientists note that as any science matures, its hurdles become higher and its research costs greater. The only way to make further advances, they say, is to pay the high costs of the needed machines.
 
The Achievements
The Big Machines: Their Findings
Even high-energy physics was originally cheap, but it has come a long way in 60 years, both in its achievements and its price.
Although several systems for accelerating atomic nuclei and electrons were devised early in the 20th century, serious accelerator experiments began with the invention of the cyclotron in 1929 by Ernest O. Lawrence, an American physicist. Dr. Lawrence, who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1939 for his invention, built his first cyclotron from cheap magnets borrowed from another laboratory along with some sheet brass, glass and wire, all held together with solder and sealing wax. Only four inches in diameter, the device spun hydrogen nuclei around a circular path, boosting them to an energy of 80,000 electron-volts.
Dr. Lawrence's first cyclotron is now a museum piece at Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory in California, one of two major laboratories named after him. According to the Lynn Yarris of the laboratory, records show that the four-inch cyclotron cost less than $10. But the price of subsequent accelerators rapidly increased. Dr. Lawrence's 1940 model, the 184-inch cyclotron (parts of which are still used in research) cost $1.5 million. Besides advancing scientific knowledge, that instrument played a key research role in making the uranium-235 used in the atomic bomb that destroyed Hiroshima.
The methods for accelerating particles have changed since Lawrence's time. Today bunches of subatomic particles surf along on radio waves, confined to pencil-thin beams by ultrapowerful (and in some cases, superconducting) magnets. The most powerful existing proton accelerator, the Tevatron at Fermilab, is four miles in circumference and boosts protons and their antimatter counterparts to a collision energy of two trillion electron-volts.
The largest accelerator in the world, completed last year under the frontier between France and Switzerland, is the Large Electron-Positron collider, some 17 miles in circumference. Built by a consortium of European nations for a cost of $1 billion, the device raises electrons and their antimatter counterparts to a colliding energy of 90 billion electron-volts.
Each increase in accelerator energy has deepened human understanding of the nature of matter. Accelerators of the 1950's and 1960's revealed the existence of hundreds of different types of subatomic particles previously unknown to science. From this bewildering profusion, theorists began to notice patterns in the types and behavior of particles and to realize that different combinations of a small number of fundamental building blocks could account for the entire ''particle zoo.''
Dr. Lederman likens this realization to the discovery by chemists that all the elements can be arranged on a chart called a periodic table that reveals their interrelated properties.
Supplied with data from ever more energetic accelerators, theorists thus arrived at the idea that all matter is ultimately made up of ''quarks,'' ''leptons'' and interacting forces. The ''Standard Model,'' a theory that physicists regard as the most successful attempt ever made to describe the fundamental nature of matter, was the result.
But the Standard Model has some conspicuous gaps and troubling inconsistencies. It predicts the existence of six quarks, of which only five have been found. The sixth, the ''top'' quark, has foiled every effort to find it, even those conducted at the world's largest accelerators. This quark must therefore either be much more massive than anyone had guessed, or it does not exist and the Standard Model is wrong.
 
The Prospects
Riddles Remain For the Collider
The search for the top quark illustrates one of the major uncertainties of high-energy physics: it is impossible to predict the energy range required to make a discovery. In 1977, when the ''bottom'' quark was discovered, physicists calculated that the top quark would have a mass of 13.5 billion electron-volts, a mass that could easily be created by the energy planned for Fermilab's Tevatron. After more than a decade of searching at ever higher energies, however, it is now known that the top quark, if it exists at all, must have a mass greater than 89 billion electron-volts, and no one knows how much greater.
Still more troubling to physicists is the riddle of ''broken symmetry,'' a phenomenon in which some unknown force spontaneously breaks the original symmetrical relationship known to have existed between the electromagnetic force (which gives us visible light, among other things) and the weak nuclear force (which causes certain types of radioactivity). Exploring the nature of this mysterious symmetry-breaking force or mechanism has been rated by planners of the Superconducting Supercollider as the machine's highest research priority.
A closely related project will be the quest for a hidden mechanism by which nature endows particles of matter with mass. An all-encompassing force field (sometimes called the ''Higgs Field'') is believed to be the factor that gives matter mass, and this field might be associated with a hypothetical particle called a Higgs boson. The discovery of a real Higgs boson would be a landmark in science, even opponents of the collider agree.
There is a sporting chance that the accelerator could do this, Dr. Schwitters and his associates believe, but even if no Higgs boson is found, ''something equally exciting is certain to turn up,'' he said.
But to reach the energy required to probe the phenomenon of symmetry-breaking, Dr. Schwitters and his staff assert, some changes in the original design of the machine were needed: a more powerful injector to give protons their initial energy boost, a wider hole through which the beams can circulate, about 200 more huge magnets than the 8,600 originally planned, and an additional mile of length.
All this has increased the estimated cost and fed the flames of debate, leading some analysts to suggest a compromise in the form of a somewhat scaled-down version of the collider. But to reduce the project's energy, said Tsung-dao Lee, a Nobel laureate in physics, ''would be like designing a lunar mission that would fly only a third of the way to the moon.''
Debate over the accelerator seems destined for a long run.
