HEADLINE: Wolves at Park's DoorSet a Test for Wildlife

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO

DATELINE: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo., May 25

 BODY:
Just as the wolf's extermination was among the last violent acts marking the taming of the American West, the predator's return marks a new stage in the often harsh debate over how to manage America's wildlife.
A small population of gray wolves from Canada has fully established itself in northwestern Montana and there are persistent reports of wolves living elsewhere in that state and in central Idaho. The arrival of these wolves from Canada in the last few years has added a sense of immediacy to a long controversy over whether the wolf can coexist with ranchers who have lived happily since it was eliminated it from the West some 60 years ago. The arrival has also focused new attention on proposals to reintroduce the wolf to Yellowstone.
''This is a real test case because it is the wolf and it is Yellowstone, and both are very potent symbols,'' said Hank Fisher, the Northern Rockies representative of Defenders of Wildlife. ''If we succeed here, it will have a major impact on endangered species programs across the country by showing that compromises are possible which make the protection of wildlife fair and acceptable to the public.'' 
Senator James A. McClure, Republican of Idaho, introduced on Tuesday legislation mandating the wolf's return to the park, one day after Congress received a 600-page study concluding that wolf would do no major harm if it were returned to Yellowstone National Park, where it is the only animal species native to the park in modern times that is not represented.
Mr. McClure's proposal was the first action by a major political figure in the northern Rockies in favor of returning the wolf, but some colleagues said they would consider the plan if safeguards were included.
Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, said, ''If you can do it in a way which does not decimate the wildlife of Wyoming and a great part of the economy of Wyoming and part of the uniqueness of Wyoming, do it in a way where if the wolf gets outside the park it can be taken, i.e., shot and killed and then have a compensation fund for livestock owners who can prove depredation by that, then I'm ready to continue to talk.''
 
'A Less Than Pure Position'
In the meantime most of the nation's major conservation groups have accepted aggressive proposals for control of the predator if it leaves designated areas, meaning that ranchers would be allowed to kill wolves that threaten their livestock. It is the first time the groups have agreed to substantial limits to protecting an endangered species to strike a deal that could assure its recovery.
''We've realized that we have to settle for a less than pure position in terms of animal rights so we can achieve a greater good,'' said Renee Askins, who founded The Wolf Fund to gather support for the wolf.
In another concession the Defenders of Wildlife created a fund last year that has already compensated five Montana ranchers for their losses from wolves. Such compensation is already in place in northern Minnesota, the only part of the lower 48 states where the wolf has survived.
But Teddy Thompson, who ranches in Montana just north of Yellowstone, said: ''A compensation system will never work in country this rugged. You can loose livestock and not find the carcasses for months, and by then there isn't enough left to prove whether it was a wolf or something else that killed them.''
Whatever happens, any action is likely to involve new applications of the Endangered Species Act that could potentially affect a variety of other controversies including those involving the spotted owl in the Pacific Northwest and the sea turtle in the Gulf of Mexico.
Mr. McClure's bill would create protected recovery areas for the wolves in the Glacier National Park region of northern Montana where they already roam as well as in Yellowstone and in wilderness areas of central Idaho where they would be reintroduced in limited numbers.
 
Opposition to Bill Expected
But outside of these three zones, the wolf would be immediately removed from the endangered species list, and the states of Idaho, Montana and Wyoming would be free to treat the animals as pests or game animals.
By removing the wolf from Federal protection before its recovery is assured the McClure bill ''will probably meet very strong opposition from the conservation community,'' said Michael Bean, a lawyer with the Environmental Defense Fund.
In the House, Representative Wayne Owens, Democrat of Utah, introduced a bill last year that would keep the wolf under the protection of the Endangered Species Act.
The alternative favored by many conservationists is to work with provisions of the Endangered Species Act which allow for the reintroduction of animals designated as a nonessential experimental population.
In such cases, some of the most stringent provisions of the act are not applied and special regulations are written. The killing of rogue wolves by ranchers could be permitted, and protection of the wolf would not automatically take precedence over other activities on Federal lands like logging in national forests.
If no agreement is reached to reintroduce the wolf into specific park or wilderness areas either through the Endangered Species Act or by sidestepping it, the wolves arriving from Canada may force the issue.
 
Wolves Expected to Keep Coming
Wildlife biologists say the wolves will continue their southerly trek but cannot predict their numbers or the speed at which they will travel.
''The worst thing that could happen is for the wolf to come in on its own and be protected as king of all the animals,'' said Brad Little, vice president of the Idaho Woolgrowers. ''It will be an economic disaster with all the restrictions they can put on the use of public land to protect an endangered species. In comparison, introducing them to core areas and managing them outside is semi-acceptable, and if there is the right kind of education process, people around here may decide it is the best deal they are going to get.''
The challenge of handling a wide-ranging wolf population has sharpened debate on broader questions about the ways that the Federal Government manages its vast lands in the West.
Mr. Little, who raises some 11,000 head of sheep near Emmett, Idaho, said, ''It's not the wolf we're scared of, but the wolf managers and all the rules and regulations they'll bring with them.''
While ranchers complain of red tape and bureaucrats, conservationists argue that artificial jurisdictional boundaries hamper responses to natural phenomena like forest fires and migrating animals.
 
'Nothing to Do With Straight Lines'
''Wolves and their prey live in an ecosystem that has nothing to do with straight lines drawn across a mountain range,'' said Ed Lewis, executive director of the Greater Yellowstone Coalition, a group that advocates the management of the entire Yellowstone region as a single natural entity. Currently the region, covering nearly 13 million acres, is administered by two national parks and seven national forests that are all contiguous.
Mr. McClure's bill would limit protection of the wolf in the region to the 2.2 million acres of Yellowstone Parkitself, and much of that is mountain and high plateau which is abandoned in winter by large numbers of animals, including many of those the wolf is supposed to live on.
''If we are looking at the biological reality rather than the political problems,'' Mr. Lewis said, ''the wolves are going to have to be able to follow their other prey all over the public lands. If we arbitrarily decide there is one appropriate place for them and outside they are vermin, then the recovery will fail biologically and politically it will send people exactly the wrong message.''
Ms. Askins, of The Wolf Fund, said: ''Restoring wolves to Yellowstone would be like planting the flag at Iwo Jima. It would be a tangible victory for a country that is demoralized about its environmental problems.''
But Franklin Rigler, a rancher and hunting guide who lives in Corwin Springs, Mont. on the banks of the Yellowstone River, complained, ''Wolves, wilderness and welfare, that's all there's going to be in this state if this thing goes through.''
A burly man who is proud his land was first settled by his grandfather, Mr. Rigler said: ''The wolf is just the opening wedge for those folks who only see mountains and animals out here and don't care about human beings who need to make a living. As soon as they get the wolf, they'll want something else.''

HEADLINE: As Oil Bounty Drains, Alaska Becomes Uneasy

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEV, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE

 BODY:
Alaskans are used to coping with the cycles of boom and bust inherent in the state's oil-based economy. But now, companies and politicians here are coming to terms with a much more uncertain and unsettling future.
After decades of living off the oil bounty, Alaskans are recognizing that current supplies are draining away and that not enough large new oil fields are being developed or explored to replace the dwindling supplies.
For the first time, oil production began to fall last year at Prudhoe Bay, Alaska's largest field. It generates 75 percent of the state's annual $2.3 billion in revenues from a per-barrel tax and also fuels a good portion of the state's economy through jobs tied directly or indirectly to oil. 
Alaskans had hoped the vast Arctic National Wildlife Refuge would replace at least some of the losses. But since the Exxon Valdez oil spill in the Prince William Sound in March 1989, Congress, under pressure from environmentalists, has put off approving exploration and drilling in the area. And the Government estimates that the chances are slim that enough oil would even be found there to make recovery economical.
To offset the Prudhoe declines, oil industry executives say, the state needs to move more quickly to diversify the economy, to cut state spending and to offer tax incentives to keep oil drillers at work on marginally profitable wells.
The alternative, they say, will be fewer jobs, higher taxes and less prosperity.
''It could take a cold hard splash in the face in the form of dramatic increases in unemployment and a need for a huge tax increase and people voting with their feet before the state says that this has gone beyond a problem to where we are in a crisis and must act,'' said Scott Jones, an oil industry consultant.
William F. Webb, general manager of the Alaska Support Industry Alliance, an oil industry trade group here, said that unless revenue replacements were found, many oil-related companies would begin to suffer within three to five years.
''If something doesn't happen, you will slowly see companies wither away,'' he said.
So far, some state officials acknowledge, the state has done little to forestall or prepare for the economic changes that seem sure to come. They say the oil industry has, at least for now, received enough incentives to work harder to get more oil from marginal wells. Cuts in state spending, always a volatile political issue, have been avoided, partly because the economy appears to be holding up well for now.
But many officials, including Gov. Steve Cowper, agree that Alaska must strengthen its non-oil industries. Unpopular measures like a state income tax must also be considered, they say.
The urgency centers on Prudhoe Bay, which has about 5 billion barrels of oil left in the ground out of an original recoverable reserve of about 11 billion, according to Chuck Logsdon, Alaska's chief oil economist.
 
Projection of Oil Output
With each passing year, as the oil field is further depleted and underground pressure diminishes, less oil can be coaxed to the surface. By the year 2000, Prudhoe Bay production is expected to have fallen below a third of its current level.
Mr. Jones, president of AUS Consultants in Philadelphia, an energy industry consulting firm, estimates that this year's production decline of about 9 percent translates into a 1 percent to 2 percent annual drop in Alaska's economy, mostly from lost wages and reduced taxes.
Perhaps even more threatening, the oil production slowdown is cutting state revenues by 4 percent to 9 percent a year, according to some estimates. This could have a disproportionate effect in Alaska because 30 percent of the population is on the state, local or Federal payroll, higher than in any other state.
Even if annual state spending were held to its current level, a gap of several hundred million dollars a year between spending and revenue could develop in the mid-1990's, according to a study by the Institute of Social and Economic Research at the University of Alaska in Anchorage. By the turn of the century, that gap could grow to more than $1 billion a year.
 
Caution at the Bank
Some Alaskan business executives are already responding to the threat.
At the First National Bank of Anchorage, the lending department has moved to protect itself against a downturn in the economy by cutting the length of some real estate loans it offers to 10 years, down from Alaska's usual 15 years.
''That's to be cautious,'' said David W. Cuddy, senior vice president at the First National Bank of Anchorage. ''We could be looking at a pretty weak start of the next century.''
The threat of a budget deficit and the questions surrounding the future of the oil supply have prompted some Alaskan executives and politicians to call for a search to find for new ways to stimulate the Alaskan economy.
On May 22, Governor Cowper attended an American-Soviet trade conference in Moscow to seek more foreign trade. So far, a spokeswoman for the Democratic Governor said, only a few small deals between Alaska and the Soviets have been struck.
While the Energy Department says the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, a desolate strip of Government-owned land in Alaska's northeast corner, has one of the largest potential oil reserves in the United States, the industry will not know if oil exists there until exploration begins.
The chances that Congress will grant permission for exploration and drilling at the refuge were severely hurt by the Exxon Valdez accident. Under mounting pressure from enivronmental groups, legislators have put off discussing the issue.
There are other promising oil fields on the North Slope of Alaska, including a field discovered by ARCO at Point McIntyre that may hold 300 million barrels of oil.
''That's a big field by any standard, but when you compare it to Prudhoe Bay, it's a real small number in terms of impact,'' said Edward L. Phillips, a petroleum economist with Alaska's Department of Natural Resources.
So far the drive to find new sources of revenues has failed to gain widespread support in Alaska because, for the first time in since an oil-induced depression a few years ago, the economy seems healthy.
''Without a doubt, the decline in Prudhoe Bay is a prospect that is going to result in change of some kind,'' said Mr. Logsdon, the oil economist. ''But people tend to be somewhat myopic. If oil revenues are up and everybody is working and everything looks pretty rosy, you don't want to spend a lot of time thinking about death.''
Last year, the Exxon Valdez cleanup contributed millions of dollars to the state's economy, sparking a recovery that is expected to continue for two more years. Oil prices are higher and real estate values have stabilized. For the next two years, the Alaska Department of Labor forecasts statewide job growth of about 1.5 percent to 2.5 percent.
The state's March unemployment rate of 7.9 percent is the lowest March rate since 1976 when construction on the oil pipeline was at its peak. And Alaskans can expect to receive their annual $1,000 dividends from a $10 billion permanent state oil fund as they have for the last eight years.
''The last 12 months have been pretty good and the next 24 to 36 months will be pretty good, too,'' said Mr. Cuddy of the First National Bank.
While it seems a daunting task to replace a large amount of the oil industry, Governor Cowper said he was optimistic that the economy could diversify. And what expansion cannot provide, he said, tax changes can.
Mr. Cowper, who leaves office in December, said exports of timber, seafood and other non-oil products to the Pacific Rim have rapidly increased since more companies have discovered Anchorage's strategic location between North America and Asia. Last year, the Federal Express Corporation opened an $11 million package-sorting plant, making the city one of its principal hubs.
''I think the Alaskan economy is clearly developing in ways that are not related to oil,'' the Governor said.
Two proposals to build natural gas pipelines from Prudhoe Bay could employ 10,000 to 25,000 people. But Alaskans are skeptical about the plans because the price of the gas in the United States is too low and the supply too plentiful to justify spending many billions in construction costs.
Many economists are wary of such large-scale plans and note that even if all of Alaska's non-oil economy were to double in size, it would still increase the non-oil share of state revenue to only 30 percent.
''There can be replacements for jobs,'' said Holly Stinson, an economist at the Alaska Department of Labor. ''You can find other industries to boost employment by 8,000, But to find industries to bring in what oil brings in, as far as state revenue is concerned, is pretty hard to do.''
That is why the talk sometmes turns to budget cuts, an income tax and a rise in taxes on industry. Much of that talk alarms oil executives, who fear the state will try to make up for the decline in Prudhoe Bay revenues by raising or imposing taxes that will discourage future investment in the state.
''So the future will not be as relatively healthy,'' said Mr. Phillips, the petroleum economist. ''But I'm not worried that Alaska will have a future. It may be smaller, but it will be more diversified and more viable.''

HEADLINE: Japan's Big Banks Shift Strategies

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Japanese banks, which earned a reputation for price-cutting as they become the colossuses of the financial world in the 1980's, are adjusting their strategies to improve profits, an area in which they lag behind American and European banks.
The decline earlier this year in the Tokyo stock market, which coincided with other adverse developments for Japanese banks, was a reminder to Japanese bankers that their huge size and soaring stock prices could be an illusory sign of financial well-being.
The largest Japanese banks continue to have have topnotch credit ratings, but their capital strength has been eroded by the drop in stock prices, and they are changing their business plans.
 
'A Fundamental Shift'
''Japanese banks should undergo a fundamental shift in their management style, toward a more profit-oriented management as opposed to a market share-oriented one,'' said Isamu Koike, general manager of the Industrial Bank of Japan's branch in New York. 
Toyoo Gyohten, a special adviser to Japan's Ministry of Finance, said at a recent Columbia University conference on international competitiveness that a spate of problems for Japanese banks would cause a widespread shift toward ''consolidating their businesses and improving profitability rather than continuing to increase market share.''
Japanese banks announced yesterday their earnings for the fiscal year ended March 31, and as expected most reported lower profits and lower profit margins. [Page D16.] Rise in Rates and Reserves The declining profits make clear why the banks feel they must shift strategies. Rising interest rates in Japan, an increase in reserves for losses on loans to third world countries - to 25 percent of such loans from 15 percent - and the fall in the Tokyo stock market hurt profits.
A chronic problem for the banks has been the narrow profit margins in their domestic market. Recognizing the profit limits on lending to large businesses that can raise money in securities markets, Kyoita Ohmori, deputy general manager at the Mitsubishi Bank, the sixth-largest in Japan and the world, recently told analysts that he was aiming at rapid growth in the consumer banking sector, which he said was underexploited and had profit margins ''significantly better than many existing lines of the banking business in Japan.''
By increasing profits and at the same time reining in growth, Japanese banks can increase their financial strength. Many fall short of the standards agreed to in 1988 by regulators around the world, who said banks should have capital equal to 8 percent of assets, after adjusting for the risk of the assets.
In terms of profit earned as a percentage of assets, Japanese banks have long lagged behind American banks. The return on assets for large banks is commonly less than three-tenths of a percentage point in Japan, or 3 yen per 1,000 yen of assets. In the United States, large banks expect a return on assets of more than six-tenths of a percentage point, or $6 per $1,000, and many earn more than $10 per $1,000.
In the American market, where Japanese banks grew rapidly in the 1980's and now account for an estimated one-eighth of all bank lending to busineses, the emphasis on profits will bring cutbacks in low-margin lending to large companies, Japanese bankers said. Prices for letters of credit and commitments to back the sales of commercial paper by corporations are also expected to rise.
 
No Retreat by Planners
But planners at the American offices of several of Japan's largest banks said they would not retreat from activities with high profit margins, like real estate financing, loans to middle-market companies with sales of $50 million to $250 million, and the financing of leveraged buyouts. In those businesses profit margins are wide enough that Japanese banks could cut prices slightly but still earn handsome returns.
Prices of Japanese bank branch loans to Japanese corporations in overseas markets are expected to rise from rates that have been as low as a sixteenth of a percentage point above the banks' cost of funds.
''The Japanese corporations are shocked to learn they cannot rely on cooperation from the branches, especially for short-term loans,'' said one Japanese banker who asked not to be identified. He added that ''this is a very delicate matter with the home office'' because it has often forced branches to make low-profit loans in the interest of preserving the customer relationship.
Issuing letters of credit as backing for bond issues of American municipalities - a business that Japanese banks came to dominate by the late 1980's - is another activity where Japanese banks say they are raising prices.
 
Rises on Letters of Credit
J. Chester Johnson, president of Government Finance Associates, an adviser to local governments that is based in Princeton, N.J., noted that one-year letters of credit once offered by Japanese banks for 12-hundredths of a percentage point are now offered at 25- or 37-hundredths.
The strategy shift at Japanese banks comes at a time when they face changes on several fronts. In the domestic market they are learning to cope with the elimination of Government controls on deposit rates, which began in 1988, plus a sharp rise in the general level of rates after several years of declines.
While the banks' costs of deposits has risen sharply, interest rates on loans have not. Corporate treasurers are resisting loans pegged to a new prime rate that adjusts according to the banks' costs of money.
There also remains an assumption by corporations that Japanese banks should provide without charge certain advisory services for which American banks charge a fee.
 
Drop in Yen a Factor
The decline in the yen relative to the dollar since early 1989 has hurt the capital adequacy of Japanese banks because they hold many assets denominated in dollars but their capital is denominated in yen.
The decline of more than 20 percent between the end of 1989 and the end of March put a dent in the banks' ''hidden reserves'' - their holdings of stock in Japan's premier industrial companies. Those holdings remain huge, at about $300 billion, for the 23 largest banks, but are down from more than $400 billion a year ago.
 
Unwilling to Sell Stock
After raising more than $16 billion of capital by selling stock when prices were higher in 1989, Japanese bankers say they are unwilling to raise more capital quickly by selling additional stock.
Robin Monroe-Davies, president of IBCA, a London-based bank rating firm, calls the drop in Tokyo stocks and changes in Japanese banking practices ''a blessing in disguise'' for Japanese banks and a welcome development for other large banks.
So long as Japanese banks could take comfort in their ability to profit from securities trading and the steady rise in their hidden reserves, they could afford to be complacent about slack profits in their banking business. Chastened by the drop in the stock market, he added, Japanese banks might restrain their growth and price-cutting.
''If the Japanese stock market had not fallen, it is hard to see how the world's financial community was going to deal with the excessive financial power of the Japanese banks,'' Mr. Monroe-Davies said.

HEADLINE: Farm Subsidies and Textiles Top Trade Meeting Agenda

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 28

 BODY:
Concerned about slow progress in world trade talks, the finance ministers of the industrial world are expected to try to provide some momentum when they gather here on Wednesday.
At the annual meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the ministers of 24 member nations will focus on current snags in trade talks, notably the simmering dispute between the United States and the European Community over agricultural subsidies.
''It's important to show that things are moving forward on trade,'' said a senior official at the O.E.C.D., an association of industrial nations that seeks to spur economic growth through cooperation. 
The world trade talks are known as the Uruguay Round, because their first meeting was held in Uruguay. Their goal is to remove barriers to international trade.
One important point of contention is Washington's demand that all subsidies of farm goods be eliminated within 10 years. European Community officials have resisted the proposal, asserting that it would drive millions of small farmers out of business.
The secretariat of the O.E.C.D., which is based in Paris, estimates that the industrialized nations spend $270 billion a year to subsidize farm products.
The European Community has proposed a compromise in which subsidies would be balanced, with reductions for many products and increases for others. Washington has rejected this idea.
United States officials assert that phasing out subsidies would be a boon to agricultural exports because American farms are so efficient.
American officials say they will not accept a new agreement that includes only minor changes in agricultural policy. At a news conference earlier this month in Paris, the United States Secretary of Agriculture, Clayton K. Yeutter, said, ''We have far too much in the way of blood, sweat and tears in this exercise to settle for modest reforms in agriculture.''
The next set of negotiations in the Uruguay Round is scheduled to begin on July 23 in Geneva. Trade officials say they hope to reach broad agreement on 15 topics at that meeting to allow trade ministers to sign a new agreement when the four-year round of talks ends this December with a meeting in Brussels.
 
A Call to Ease Textile Restrictions
At this week's two-day meeting of the O.E.C.D., finance ministers are expected to debate how to respond to demands from developing nations concerning textile products.
Textiles are not covered by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, and industrialized nations have been able to put far greater restrictions on textile imports than on most other industrial goods.
Some third-world officials are threatening to block the success of the 105-nation G.A.T.T. talks if they conclude that little is being done to remove the trade barriers facing their textiles. Textile exports, they say, are crucial to the economic growth of their countries.
One proposal is for the industrialized nations to agree to a timetable under which textiles would gradually fall under regular trade rules.
 
Group of Seven Meeting
The O.E.C.D. ministers' meeting usually serves as an occasion to help frame the agenda for the annual Group of Seven economic summit meeting, which will be held this year in Houston in July. O.E.C.D. officials said the ministers would discuss how to help the deteriorating environment and how to assist Eastern European countries in their transition to market economies.
On Tuesday, many of the O.E.C.D. ministers will sign an agreement to establish the 42-nation European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which is being created to help Eastern Europe.

HEADLINE: Talking Business; with Morton of Hewlett-Packard;
Looking Ahead At Computers

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Dean O. Morton is executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Hewlett-Packard Company. His main responsibility is the company's computer business, which generated roughly $8 billion in revenues last year. That ranked Hewlett, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., third among American computer makers after the International Business Machines Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation. The company's computer lines include minicomputers, work stations and personal computers. It is a leading maker of printers and also produces calculators, test equipment and medical systems.
Q. How is the computer business? 
A. Not bad. It's strong in our newer systems. Over all, the computer business was up 25 percent last year. So far, it's up 18 percent this year, although that overstates a bit because it includes the acquisition of Apollo Computer. Clearly, mainframes are a slow-growth part of the market. So is the mini. Ninety percent of computer power today is delivered in the form of personal computers.
Q. How has the Apollo acquisition gone? Given that Sun Microsystems has taken the work station market lead, did you pay too much?
A. It is difficult. Trying to converge different computer architectures and designs is a real challenge. But we went into it with our eyes open. As these things go, it was a real bargain. We got a large installed customer base. We got excellent people. We got technology that's going to be quite important to us in the future. I like our situation today much better with Apollo than where we would have been without it.
Q. What's going to be commonplace in computers 10 years from now that is currently experimental?
A. It used to be that you'd get 30 percent more for your dollar each year as computers improved. That was known as Moore's Law, after Gordon Moore at Intel. But today, it's up to 50 percent or more because new designs are so much more efficient. More advanced semiconductor technology is a factor. It's just unbelievable how much can be put on a very small piece of semiconductor real estate today.
The question is how will we use all this power. Less than five years ago, a one-million-instructions-per-second desktop device was a very advanced product. Today, people are talking about desktop machines with 100 million instructions per second at a price of $200 to $500 per million instructions. You may see voice recognition. You are already seeing some handwriting recognition. Artificial intelligence will become more of a factor. You'll see more use of color; you will see 3-D; you'll see smaller size.
Q. Some economists and public officials have Suggested that the United States may have strong companies but not a strong country if businesses continue to move operations overseas. As a company with broad overseas operations, what's your response?
A. I don't see how the U.S. will do well, ultimately, if companies don't do well. Over half of our business is overseas, but we still have two-thirds of our employees here. Over 80 percent of our product development is done here, and we are the 12th-leading exporter. You have to take advantage of the world as a single source of people, a single source of capital. We have to operate in the markets as they exist. Technology crosses borders. Skills move around easily. We develop software in India, China - we just signed contracts to do some in Hungary. We do some of our most creative manufacturing in Malaysia. In our market, you could not survive by being just U.S.-focused.
Q. Do you think it would have been a national setback if Nikon or some other Japanese company had bought the Perkin-Elmer Corporation?
A. No. At some point, you've got to let the market work its will. Staying competitive is a big concern, but the answer is not to pull back within our borders and trade with ourselves. That isn't going to happen.
Q. What has been your experience in Japan?
A. Quite good. We have a $1 billion business there. We have had some problems of access, including some of our own making. We haven't had full kanji character capability throughout the computer business. It's complicated. We are by far the leading supplier of work stations there. That's a business where everything is in Japanese.
Q. Do you see opportunity in Eastern Europe?
A. It will be small for a while, but it's an important opportunity. We did $30 million of business in the Soviet Union last year. Not bad. We did almost another $30 million in Poland, Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Hungary. There could be some flow backward. They have some real software skills.

HEADLINE: California Car Sales Report

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 28

 BODY:
Sales of imported cars in California have rebounded after several months of declines and now account for 56 percent of new-car sales in the state, according to the California Report on Automotive Marketing.
A year ago, imports accounted for 48 percent of the California market, based on new-car registration figures. 
''This is a significant turnaround,'' said John Rettie, the editor of the monthly automotive newsletter, which is published by the automotive market research firm J. D. Power & Associates in Westlake Village, Calif.
California is regarded by many industry analysts and auto executives as a bellwether automotive market. Last year, Californians purchased 1.16 million cars, accounting for nearly 12 percent of the nation's car sales.
''The upsurge in domestic penetration during 1989 had raised some hopes among domestic makes that they had turned the tide of constantly increasing import share of the market,'' Mr. Rettie said. ''The latest registration figures appear to dash those hopes.''
The United States auto makers' market share of the California market reached 51 percent for the eight months that ended in August 1989.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Forecasting Without the Weather

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
In coming weeks, the bond market is likely to get a clearer view of whether the economy is deteriorating, analysts say, as the Government releases economic data that have not been distorted by abnormal weather.
Indeed, weather factors have confused even the Federal Reserve Board. Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, told Congress in February that the central bank would not have a good reading on the economy until early summer.
The unusually cold weather in December caused heating oil prices to rise sharply. And the abnormally warm weather in January and February led to a rise in spring clothing prices and sharply increased construction activity and employment in the early spring. 
''I still think the consumer price numbers may have a bit more noise in them, because the big winter increases in apparel prices have not completely worked their way through,'' said Donald J. Fine, the chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank.
''But the problems that hit the producer price, construction and employment figures earlier in the year are pretty much over,'' he said.
 
Job Figures This Week
The first important test will come on Friday, when employment statistics for May are scheduled to be announced.
After two straight months of generally weak job growth, analysts said, the May figures could resolve a lot of doubts if the numbers are low again.
''An abrupt rebound from recent months' minimal job gains may not clarify the uncertain state of the economy and keep the 30-year Treasury yield trapped in its recent range above 8.5 percent,'' Susan M. Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers, noted in the firm's weekly Comments on Credit.
Late Friday, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent issue was offered at a price to yield 8.66 percent.
''However, a third consecutive weak report may begin to galvanize opinion in favor of modest growth, providing a stiffer test of the bond market's current resistance to lower rates.''
Weather patterns probably did not have much of an effect on job creation last month, but the Government did. Ms. Hering and other analysts estimate that as many as 150,000 people were taken on as census workers in May. Excluding that temporary army, the consensus estimate among analysts is that nonfarm payroll employment rose by about 150,000 jobs.
''The economy is probably growing at a 1.5 percent pace in the second quarter, almost exactly where the Fed wants it,'' Mr. Fine said.
 
Trouble in the Public Sector
Although certain sectors of the economy, most notably exports and capital spending, are expected to produce sufficient growth to ward off a recession, the worsening fiscal condition of state and local governments is beginning to drag down the economy. And the situation is likely to get worse.
The slowdown in corporate profits and sluggish retail sales, among other factors, have cut into tax revenues. As a consequence, budget surpluses, which became the norm during the mid- to late-1980's, have been sharply pared.
''It is probably the worst picture we have seen with the exception of the 1981-82 recession period,'' said Raymond C. Sheppach, executive director of the National Governors' Association. ''Balances are getting razor thin.''
Although a number of states, including New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts, have proposed tax increases along with budget cuts to close deficits, Mr. Sheppach said, few others are likely to follow.
''You aren't going to see a lot of tax increases in an election year,'' he said. ''But you will see a lot of budget cuts unless we go into a fairly serious nose dive.''
In response to the lower tax revenues, debt-ratings agencies have cut their ratings for a number of state and local government securities. But thus far, the decline in credit quality has not pushed up borrowing costs in the tax-exempt municipal bond market.
''If the deterioration in budgets continues on a nationwide basis, I would expect things to change somewhat,'' said George D. Friedlander, a managing director in charge of municipal bond research at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''But right now, the yield differential between AAA-rated credits and Baa's is the narrowest in history.''
The differential between the AAA-rated credits and those rated Baa, the lowest realistic rating for a state government, is currently only about 55 to 60 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, Mr. Friedlander said. In 1983, after a deep recession, the differential was about 200 basis points.
 
Steady Demand
Borrowing costs have not escalated for states experiencing severe budget problems because demand for tax-exempt issues has outstripped the supply of new bonds, Mr. Friedlander said. And beleagured states are shoring up otherwise poor ratings by purchasing guarantees from municipal bond insurance companies. Bonds backed by insurance are almost always rated AAA.
''There is lots of insured paper out there, and that is a factor, '' said Hyman Grossman, the managing director of the municipal bond department at the Standard & Poor's Corporation. ''But we are going to see a lot riskier paper in the next two years. If managers in certain states and cities aren't careful, they could fall off the cliff.''
Mr. Grossman declined to specify which states and localities might be in particularly precarious shape.
In addition to New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Massachusetts, S.& P. said California, Florida and North Carolina may soon face serious problems.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Balancing Teaching and Research

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
GRADUATE business schools are wrestling with the dilemma of how faculty members should divide their time between research and teaching.
Years ago, when business schools were scorned by liberal arts professors as being overly vocational, research was viewed as a way of gaining academic respect. Today, teaching is taking on greater importance as corporate executives and recruiters demand that students be better equipped to handle the challenges of the marketplace.
''Thirty years ago we looked inward, stressing the importance of more research by professors,'' said William K. Laidlaw Jr., the executive vice president of the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business in St. Louis, in an interview last week.
''Now we are moving in the opposite direction toward better teaching,'' he continued, ''and we need to look outward at today's problems - the making of public policy, environmental issues, ethical issues, the internationalizing of courses.'' 
Mr. Laidlaw, whose organization is the governing body for business schools in the United States, said better teaching involved more than having professors spend more time in the classroom. Course content must also be examined. He is of the opinion that business schools should take steps to assure that students have a broader background in liberal arts.
''We want students to know at least one foreign language or to have taken area courses,'' he said. Area courses teach students about a country's culture. Dartmouth College's Tuck School of Business Administration plans to offer intensive language training starting late this fall.
But not every business school is rushing to add language courses. Dr. Scott S. Cowen, dean of the Weatherhead School of Management at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, called language requirements ''misguided wisdom.''
Knowing a language does not make an M.B.A. more successful as a manager, or give the manager a more global outlook, he said. But he added that students who had spent a semester abroad or worked for the Peace Corps ''would offer a nice extra dimension'' in terms of admission to business school.
He likens the trend of business schools adding new courses ''to adding more bumpers to a car when maybe we should consider a basic design change.''
''There have been no serious innovations in business school education since 1950,'' he said, adding that his school, after five years of planning, is making a radical change this fall. About 25 percent of the school's required courses have been dropped and four new courses have been added, he said.
Deleted were one of two required finance courses, an organizational behavior course, and one of two management policy courses. Separate labor and human resources courses have been combined.
If the deletions sound humdrum, the replacements do not.
First, there is an unusual course that helps students assess their weaknesses. Students who find they are weak in mathematics, for example, can then take an elective in that area to improve their skills.
Even more unusual are the ''perspective'' courses. Students are required to take two of the three courses offered and strongly urged to take all three. The courses are new technology, managing in a global economy, and history of industrial development. They are intended to answer the criticism that M.B.A.'s have little or no historical perspective to relate to current events, since such courses are not required, or even offered, at many business schools, Like Mr. Laidlaw, Dr. Cowen said he ''favors more stress on teaching.'' But he added, ''It is unclear to me how much research is needed.'' He said research should tackle big problems and faculty members should ''communicate findings to students and executives, not just do writing for 10 people to read in esoteric publications.''
He noted that there was a good deal of international research at the school, including a study contrasting career paths of Japanese and American engineers.
And cooperating with Belgium's University of Louvain, faculty members at the school are studying differences in labor and management relations in the United States and in Europe. With some Dutch professors, there is a new project researching information systems in a global economy, he said Recently Twente University, in Enschede, the Netherlands, sent its entire business school class of 23, all engineers, plus a journalist, to Case Western Reserve for 10 days of classes in technical management. Case Western Reserve might send students to Twente next year, Dr. Cowen said.
There have also been reciprocal visits by professors in the Soviet Union and at Case Western, he said.

HEADLINE: The Right Engine, A Touch Of Luck

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, May 28

 BODY:
It is arguable that once Arie Luyendyk got the right engine, he didn't need much luck to win the Indianapolis 500. Nonetheless, he had the benefit of a couple of factors any oracle would read the right way.
This morning, the day after Luyendyk won the Indy 500 for his first Indy-car victory ever, a track staff member told of finding a coin from the Netherlands, Luyendyk's native country, while walking along pit lane the day the track opened this month.
Luyendyk's wife, Mieke, wore a pair of earrings on race day that closely resembled the good-luck earrings worn by Emerson Fittipaldi's wife, Teresa, when he won this race last year. 
Mieke said she wasn't aware of any such significance when she got the earrings from Luyendyk on Mother's Day, but she allowed that they may just hold some power.
 
Engine Power
Even if they don't, the Chevrolet engine behind her husband's head has enough for the job.
Before joining Doug Shierson Racing this season, Luyendyk's five-year Indy-car career was spent with a series of noncompetitive teams. He had entered the top rank of American racing with good credentials: several victories in the highly competitive Super Vee class in Europe and the United States. His father, Jaap, had also driven Super Vees.
Aat Groenvelt, who owned an Indy-car team, was attracted by Luyendyk's Dutch background and offered him a full-time Indy-car ride in 1985. He was named rookie of the year on the Indy-car circuit and at the Indy 500. He joined Dick Simon's team, another struggling outfit, in 1988.
''I had some good years with Dick Simon,'' Luyendyk said in the post-race news conference, ''but I didn't have the right equipment. It did give me the opportunity to drive Indy cars and get some experience.''
Luyendyk is not hesitant to put his Dutch heritage to work for him. He acquired one sponsor, Dutch Boy Paints, after Simon realized the close resemblance between the company symbol and Luyendyk's 8-year-old son, Arie Jr. Thoughts on Country ''I think the country will be really excited,'' Luyendyk said of his native land. ''They're aware of my racing at Indy. The race was on cable there, and my parents were watching it live.''
Luyendyk, 36, and his family now live in Scottsdale, Ariz.
For Shierson, the team owner, it was a long-awaited return to glory. In the mid-1980's, before the Chevrolet racing engine took control of Indy-car racing, Shierson's team won a total of six races with Danny Sullivan and Al Unser Jr. as drivers.
Before this season, Shierson's team was the leader among the underclass of Indy-car racing: the teams without the Chevy engine that wanted to buy it. ''As I said yesterday, Chevrolet is the heartbeat of Shierson Racing,'' the car owner said.
''It was discouraging,'' he said standing outside his garage at the Speedway today. ''But they wanted to go slow and make sure the program develops along the lines they want it to,'' he said, alluding to the original decision by the engine's builder to supply only four teams. ''I don't begrudge them that.''
When Chevrolet decided to expand its Indy engine program, however, Shierson's team was the first on its list. ''Probably the foremost thing is he fit most of the criteria we have,'' said Bob Applegate, the program director for the Indy V-8. ''They had the commitment, professionalism, the driver.''
Immediately after the race, Shierson refused to comment on how his team managed to avoid the tire-blistering problems that ruined Emerson Fittipaldi's strong chance to win.
Goodyear said the blistering was caused by overinflating the tires for more speed. Shierson was asked if he had used a different inflation.
''What term did you use?'' he coyly asked the questioner. ''Equation?'' No, inflation. ''Oh, that!'' Shierson said. ''I think we had the proper equation.''
 
Awards Announced
Luyendyk won $1,090,940 in cash and prizes. Eddie Cheever, who finished eighth in the official standing, was named rookie of the year. Stan Fox, who ran 10 laps at an average speed just over 54 miles an hour and finished last, was awarded $108,021.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
YELTSIN IS ELECTED RUSSIAN PRESIDENT ON 3D-ROUND VOTE

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 29

 BODY:
Boris N. Yeltsin, the maverick politician who has spent three years fighting the Communist Party establishment, today became President of the Russian republic, overcoming a last-ditch effort by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to block his election before departing for visits to Canada and the United States.
Mr. Yeltsin, whose popular following makes him a clear threat to Mr. Gorbachev's authority as leader of the Soviet Union, won the presidency of the nation's largest republic on a third round of balloting in the republic's Parliament with a final tally of 535 votes, 4 more than the required majority. His opponent, Aleksandr V. Vlasov, the choice of the party and Mr. Gorbachev, trailed with 467 votes.
 
Standing Ovation in Parliament
When the final count was announced this afternoon to the tense and excited gathering at the Grand Kremlin Palace, deputies rose to their feet to give a standing ovation to Mr. Yeltsin, the former Moscow Communist Party chief who was thrown out of the leadership after a disagreement with Mr. Gorbachev over the pace of change.
Outside the Kremlin gates, hundreds of Yeltsin supporters, waving red-white-and-blue prerevolutionary Russian flags and carrying pictures of the new President, gathered to wait for a glimpse of the tall, 59-year-old Siberian, a popular hero who has become a symbol of the promise of real change. 
Speaking to reporters after his election, Mr. Yeltsin said he wanted to build relations with Mr. Gorbachev ''not on confrontation, but on a businesslike basis, dialogue and talks, on a principled basis, not to the prejudice of Russia's sovereignty and interests.''
 
Gorbachev to 'Wait and See'
Mr. Gorbachev, on his arrival in Ottawa for a stop en route to Washington, was asked about the election. The Soviet President said he applauded reports that Mr. Yeltsin had said he was willing to ''work fruitfully with the President of the Soviet Union,'' and then added: ''If, however, he is indeed playing a political game, then we may be in for a difficult time. So we will wait and see. Life is richer than any teacher.'' [Page A8.] Mr. Yeltsin, asked if he expected to receive a message of congratulation today from his longtime foe, said after a dramatic pause, ''Yesterday I could not imagine it, but today it would be the politically correct step.''
In a brief acceptance speech, Mr. Yeltsin offered to put together a government drawn from different political groups in Parliament, including the conservative Communists who fought so hard to keep him from power.
Members of the Russian Parliament and several journalists in Moscow said that on Monday night, a group of several hundred members of the Communist Party hierarchy were summoned to a meeting with Mr. Gorbachev and other members of the Politburo for final instructions on maintaining party discipline in the face of Mr. Yeltsin's candidacy. The failure of this final appeal, delivered on the eve of Mr. Gorbachev's departure for North America, served to underscore the party's loss of authority and the rise of Mr. Yeltsin as an alternative force.
Mr. Yeltsin's open challenge to Mr. Gorbachev marks the first time that differences have been aired in public by political leaders in the Soviet Union since the 1920's, in the aftermath of the death of Lenin in 1924. Until Stalin consolidated his power in the late 1920's, there were frequent clashes between factions in the party.
 
Personal Attack Last Week
Mr. Gorbachev made a surprise appearance last week before the Russian Parliament and delivered a forceful, personal attack on Mr. Yeltsin, whom he accused of attempting to break up the Soviet Union.
The depth of the obvious antagonism between Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin, dating back to Mr. Yeltsin's break with the party hierarchy in October 1987, could lead to a dangerous political stalemate, some Soviets and foreign observers said today.
One battleground is the Soviet Government's latest program of economic change, which relies heavily on drastic and unpopular price increases. Mr. Yeltsin has criticized the plan, and today he referred to the ''unpopular proposals by the Soviet Government to step up economic reform.''
Mr. Yeltsin's own economic program is not well defined, although many of his supporters are banking on the competence of new Russian President's advisers, a group that includes prominent market economists and liberal intellectuals.
His politics, however, continue to worry some members of the Russian intelligentsia. ''The fact that Yeltsin reduces everything to social-political issues is very alarming to me,'' said Dmitri S. Likhachev, the unofficial dean of Russian literary historians and head of the Russian Cultural Foundation, in an interview in Washington.
Mr. Yeltsin's victory, which three days ago seemed a long shot given the strength and resources of his opposition, was attributed by many deputies today to the surge of popular support that came pouring in over the weekend.
 
Force of Popular Opinion Cited
''The deputies had to take popular opinion into account,'' said Nikolai Vorontsov, a member of Parliament and the Soviet Minister of Environmental Protection. ''There could be no doubt that Yeltsin was supported by a majority of the people.''
Outside the main hall, in the ornate czarist chambers of the Grand Kremlin Palace, members of Democratic Russia, the liberal group that led the lobbying for Mr. Yeltsin, greeted each other with giddy jubilation. ''We won,'' said a delighted delegate from the western Siberian oil capital of Tyumen.
Some Yeltsin supporters also attributed his final success to their candidate's public efforts at conciliation. ''Boris Nikolayevich showed he is ready to move towards a compromise, to take other points of view into account,'' said Anatoly Medvedev, a deputy from Moscow, referring to Mr. Yeltsin by his name and patronymic, in the Russian style.
Others said the Communist Party's misguided tactics had granted Mr. Yeltsin success. The party first put up a hard-liner, Ivan K. Polozkov, a party boss from the region of Krasnodar in southern Russia, in the first round of voting, then switched to Mr. Vlasov, the current Prime Minister of the Russian republic, on the final ballot.
Mr. Vlasov had withdrawn in the first round because of a poor performance in delivering a report on the situation in Russia, politically the most significant of the Soviet republics.
''Mr. Vlasov showed in his report that he is not material to be even Prime Minister,'' said Mr. Medvedev, ''while Mr. Polozkov is, I am sorry to say, a demogogue, more of the Russophile type.''
 
Besieged by Supporters
As Mr. Yeltsin left the Kremlin today, he was besieged by hundreds of supporters, who had kept up a vigil outside the nearby Rossiya Hotel, where many deputies have been staying. Chanting, ''Victory! Victory!'' the crowd swarmed around the new President, who pledged to press forward for ''the renewal of Russia.''
''If he hadn't won, the results would been unpredictable,'' said Alla Podlesnova, a 51-year-old doctor from Moscow. ''Yeltsin is the pride and honor of Russia.''
But many in the crowd disputed the notion that Mr. Yeltsin is a rival to Mr. Gorbachev's power. Instead, they said he would provide a needed counterweight to the Soviet leader, a prod toward more rapid change.
''This is not a defeat for Gorbachev,'' said Sergei Shiskin, a 37-year old translator from Siberia. ''It is a lesson.''

LENGTH: 823 words

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Soviet Stage: Is 2 a Crowd?

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 29

 BODY:
Mikhail S. Gorbachev may not yet face a full-fledged political opposition in this deeply troubled land, but he now certainly has a personal nemesis to haunt his days of power.
Boris N. Yeltsin, the bluff, resilient politician purged from the Gorbachev Government in 1987 for daring to complain about the slow pace of national renewal, has sensationally resurrected himself in the bruising game of Soviet politics.
He has won the chief office in the nation's heart, the Russian republic, and has gained a showcase to establish himself as a kind of president-in-waiting, a choice of the people more than the party and one of the few politicians to rattle Mr. Gorbachev in public.
 
Talent for Self-Promotion
With his booming public statements, tight grin of self-confidence and sometimes bizarre talent for self-promotion, Mr. Yeltsin prevailed by risking himself in the electoral arena so carefully avoided by Mr. Gorbachev. 
Even sweeter for the one-time Gorbachev protege, Mr. Yeltsin won the votes he needed by withstanding Mr. Gorbachev's long and bitter opposition, and probably by benefiting from it too.
Mr. Yeltsin's fresh hurrah could not have come at a worse moment for Mr. Gorbachev. The Soviet leader's failure to enact a program of effective economic renewal these last five years has become the chief anxiety of a Soviet public jaded by overpromise, a fact that Mr. Yeltsin rarely fails to mention in his now global rounds of celebrity.
Mr. Gorbachev must contend with the distracting shadow that the Yeltsin victory now casts over his summit appearance in Washington this week. And the Soviet leader will find the fledgling political insurgency at home newly emboldened by Mr. Yeltsin's success just as the public begins to focus on the important Communist Party congress scheduled for July. Mr. Yeltsin has already called for pluralistic democratic reforms that go beyond anything that Mr. Gorbachev has endorsed.
For all the contrasts of agenda presented by Mr. Yeltsin, it is his style that most wins him public support, support that is unusually fervid for Soviet politics.
 
Playing to the Gallery
From his earliest days as an engineer and party loyalist, the tall, husky politician has shown a taste for playing to the public's enjoyment at seeing an occasional nest of party bureaucrats purged or some profiteering shopkeeper dramatically denounced by Mr. Yeltsin as he walks the streets and chats with the public.
Such flesh-pressing politics are less common to Mr. Gorbachev, who prefers more awkward tableaux in which the public serves as a backdrop for his long, self-assured monologues.
Mr. Yeltsin seems to have a knack for bringing out displays of pettiness in Mr. Gorbachev, like the long and rather sniping critique of Mr. Yeltsin's victory that Mr. Gorbachev gave today in Canada, a performance devoid of any warmth for a man whose political capital has considerably grown.
''My perpetual opponent, the lover of half-measures and half-steps,'' Mr. Yeltsin fairly sneers in describing the Soviet leader, less than three years after Mr. Yeltsin was purged from the Politburo for offering an unscheduled critique of the shortcomings of Mr. Gorbachev's beloved program of economic and political restructuring.
''I didn't last long among them,'' Mr. Yeltsin wrote proudly in his autobiography, ''Against the Grain.''
''I bolted like a caged animal when I could stand it no longer.'' Ballast or Bombast? His critics, including some doubters among his colleagues in the insurgent movement, discount such statements as vintage Yeltsin bombast. But Mr. Yeltsin's public has stuck with him and grown more convinced of his superiority, even through a steady stream of odd personal incidents and endless aspersions from the Kremlin about the depth of his convictions.
The odd incidents include a mysterious river dunking that Mr. Yeltsin first described as a plot on his life, but later waved off as part of his private affairs. There was also his visit last year to the United States, which was followed by newspaper articles quoting critics who attributed a slurred, playful speech to excessive alcohol.
Mr. Yeltsin described it as a plot to discredit him. Such a suggestion of intrigue is one that ordinary citizens remain quite willing to attribute to Kremlin operatives.
 
'Unholy Hullabaloo'
Those odd tangents only make Mr. Yeltsin more of a focus for public delight at his iconoclastic capering through the generally dull, untrustworthy world of party politics. He seems to feed on the public's disbelief in the Government.
He is the reigning master among the growing circle of Communist politicians now running against Communism. As of today he can call himself President of Russia, smiling at the ''unholy hullabaloo'' that the Gorbachev Government has created around him by attempting to end his career.
''I am undergoing personal perestroika,'' he says of his resurrection.

HEADLINE: New York State G.O.P. Supports Abortion Rights for First Time

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RYE, N.Y., May 29

 BODY:
The New York Republican Party, for the first time in its history, approved an abortion platform today that supports ''reproductive rights for women.''
The action, approved unanimously by delegates who gathered here to pick a candidate for governor, follows a national trend in the party, whose leaders have sought to portray the G.O.P. as an umbrella that could encompass various positions on abortion.
The state party acted in part to make sure that it was in step with Pierre A. Rinfret, an economist who is scheduled to be nominated for governor on Wednesday. Mr. Rinfret supports a woman's right to an abortion, according to Republican leaders.
 
Greater Flexibility
In addition, some state party leaders have had a tradition of displaying a liberal posture on abortion dating to 1970, when the Republican-led Legislature and the Republican Governor, Nelson A. Rockefeller, enacted one of the first state laws legalizing abortion. That was three years before the Roe v. Wade decision by the United States Supreme Court permitted abortion. 
The Republican national party platform opposes abortion in most instances, as do some of its leading officeholders, including President Bush and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York.
But top Republican strategists, like Lee Atwater, the party's national chairman, have sought to project greater flexibility on the issue since a Supreme Court decision last year gave states more authority to regulate abortion. Since the ruling, abortion-rights groups have become increasingly active politically. In New York, the party has been pressured to take a more liberal position by some of its public officials and female contributors.
In 1982 and 1986, the New York State party did not take a position on the issue, and both gubernatorial candidates, Lewis E. Lehrman and Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, opposed abortion. The Republicans' move today is almost certain to widen a schism with their traditional ally, the New York Conservative Party, which opposes abortion. But it also provides them with defense against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Democratic legislative candidates, who plan to make an issue of abortion this year.
''Mario Cuomo would like nothing better than to talk about abortion and avoid talking about taxes and spending,'' said Assemblyman George Pataki of Westchester County, who is the chairman of the Republican Platform Committee.
 
Approved Without Debate
The usual passions and emotions surrounding the issue were absent as about 100 Republican State Committee members, about one-third of the total at the party's nominating convention here, approved the plank without debate or dissent.
''State government must not become a 'big brother' regulating people in their personal affairs and lives, and the New York State Republican Party reaffirms its historic commitment to the right of privacy and reproductive rights,'' the platform plank declared.
The word abortion is mentioned only once in the three-paragraph plank in an effort to defuse any anger among anti-abortion Republicans.
Assemblyman Pataki said the New Yorkers were essentially adopting Mr. Atwater's position, providing a ''tent'' for those on both sides of the issue. He said that ''pro-choice people are delighted'' about the abortion plank and that anti-abortion Republicans ''accept that there is diversity in the party.''
But the state's two leading Republicans, Senator D'Amato and State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, reflected the split among Republican officials who depend on a conservative constituency that often opposes abortion.
Mr. D'Amato said at a news conference here that he would have preferred that the party remain neutral on the issue, while Mr. Regan, acknowledging that he was a practicing Catholic, said he favored ''a woman's right to choice.''
 
Hailed as Victory
Tanya Melich, executive director of the New York State Republican Family Life Committee, a leading proponent of abortion rights, hailed the plank as a victory.
Opposition to the party's position on abortion began developing quickly. The Nassau County Comptroller, Peter T. King, who was the party's candidate for attorney general in 1986, said, ''It's bad enough to lose but it's worse to surrender your principles even before the first shot is fired.''
The Republican platform came on the first day of the party's state convention here as top Republican leaders, including Mr. D'Amato and Mr. Regan, met Mr. Rinfret for the first time.
But no one else did as Mr. Rinfret avoided public appearances. He literally sneaked into a Republican leaders' meeting by coming from the rain outside through sliding doors directly into the closed-door meeting at the Hilton Hotel.
 
A Two-Page Biography
The only other sign of Mr. Rinfret was a two-page biography that suddenly appeared in a convention pressroom.
Party leaders were still searching for candidates for lieutenant governor and state attorney general to run with Mr. Rinfret. But they managed to nominate one member of the state ticket, their only incumbent, Mr. Regan, the Comptroller, who will be seeking a fourth term as the state's chief fiscal officer.
Republicans who met Mr. Rinfret for the first time today praised him as articulate and committed to a serious effort to be elected despite admittedly great odds.
Adding to those odds was the position of Mr. D'Amato and Mr. Regan, who steadfastly have refused to criticize Governor Cuomo directly at separate news conferences. Both are known for often distancing themselves from their party and its candidates.
Senator D'Amato, who emphasized the crime issue without mentioning the Governor in a brief speech to a ballroom that was two-thirds empty, said at the news conference that ''it's no secret that the Governor and I work together.''
He added: ''You want me to go out and hit him with a hammer. I'm not going to do that.''
 
'Enough Blame'
Mr. Regan declined to even place blame for the state's fiscal crisis on Governor Cuomo, saying repeatedly that ''there's enough blame to go around.'' He denied that he was already running away from Mr. Rinfret.
The White House has also distanced itself from the New York Republicans' problems in picking a state ticket. One sign of the cool relationship was the New Yorkers' failure to have a national Republican figure make the keynote address as they had hoped.
They had sought to have Jack F. Kemp, a former New York Congressman who is now Housing and Urban Development Secretary, speak, but had to settle for the state's newest Congresswoman, Susan Molinari of Staten Island.
 
Both From Manhattan
As they scrambled to fill their ticket, Republican leaders were conscious that the two candidates already effectively chosen, Mr. Rinfret and Mr. Regan, are both residents of Manhattan, one of the weakest Republican voting areas in the state.
J. Patrick Barrett, the state Republican Party chairman, said he had now ruled out another Manhattan resident, Herbert London, a New York University dean, as a potential lieutenant-governor candidate. Mr. London has already said he would accept the Conservative Party nomination for governor.
The two leading candidates for lieutenant governor are apparently Toni Rettaliata, a former Suffolk County assemblywoman, and the Oneida County Executive, Jack Plumley.

HEADLINE: In Managua, New Rulers and Never-Ending Battles

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 26

 BODY:
When striking Sandinista workers chained themselves inside state buildings this month and set barricades on fire, forcing the new Government to a halt, Yolanda Navarro Castro came to a bitter conclusion about her country.
''I could see that this was never going to end,'' said Mrs. Navarro, who spent long hours getting to work each day after the strikes paralyzed Managua's bus system. ''The conflicts, the fighting, it won't ever stop.''
Like hundreds of thousands of other weary Nicaraguans, Mrs. Navarro, a 39-year-old food vendor, voted in national elections in February in the hope that whatever side won the balloting would mark a clear break with a decade of turmoil and civil war. 
But in dozens of recent interviews, Nicaraguans indicated that their optimism has begun to unravel as political confrontation and economic crisis continue. A month after taking office, the Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro faces almost daily protests from the still-powerful Sandinista Front. The economy, despite the prospect of new American aid, has been battered by drastic currency devaluations and inflation. And deadlines for disbanding the contra army have dissolved in a game of perpetual negotiation.
''We voted so that things would change, but nothing has changed,'' Mrs. Navarro said, watching black marketeers on the street waving stacks of devalued local currency to sell for American dollars. ''We had hope. Everyone had hope. But look what has become of it. Every day, our lives get worse.''
Like Mrs. Navarro, many Nicaraguans blame the Sandinista Front for their unhappiness. ''It's like a plot,'' said Eberto Tapia Tapia, a 40-year-old carpenter, referring to the Sandinistas' aggressive tactics of pressure and protest against Mrs. Chamorro's Government. ''They had it planned so that she would never be able to govern. Everyone sees what they're doing.''
 
Government Viewed as Weak
Although Mrs. Chamorro is usually spared direct criticism, Nicaraguans on all sides are voicing deep pessimism about her Government, calling it weak and without clear direction. Sandinista supporters portray the new Government as a tool of right-wing interests while Mrs. Chamorro's own sympathizers accuse it of failing to hold the line against Sandinista demands.
Government officials say that their compromises are in the spirit of national reconciliation and that criticisms of their performance are premature, that they need time to put their program in place. But few in the diverse ruling coalition agree on what the new program should be.
Nicaraguans from the two political camps appear to agree on the one thing that they believe still offers hope of improvement in their lives: $300 million in American aid that was recently approved by Congress after repeated delays.
''The last devaluations have been too hard on the people,'' said William Antonio Castano Hernandez, a 19-year-old Sandinista supporter who works as a bricklayer in Managua. ''Violeta has promised a lot of things she couldn't fulfill. Maybe if she had the money she could keep her promises.''
 
Sandinistas' New Role
But most Nicaraguans interviewed appear to harbor little hope that even the greatest foreign windfall can overcome the effects of a political conflict that cuts across the heart of Nicaraguan society.
Since their election loss on Feb. 25, Sandinista leaders have repeatedly stated their commitment to act as a constructive opposition in rebuilding the country. But in a remark that is now famous, former President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has also declared that the Sandinistas intend to ''rule from below'' despite their defeat.
The strength of that threat was demonstrated this month when the strike by Sandinista-led Civil Service unions forced Mrs. Chamorro's Government to grant broad concessions on wages and job guarantees.
Sandinista leaders have sharply criticized currency devaluations and inflation under the Chamorro Government, but the Sandinistas' own record in the waning days of their rule has fed a belief that the current crisis was deliberately planned to discredit the new Government.
 
A Stop to Devaluations
Sandinista economists have insisted that no important changes were made in the Government's monetary policy between the February elections and Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration on April 25. But central bank records show that official currency devaluations, which had occurred regularly for years, virtually ceased in that period. At the same time, the amount of currency placed in circulation sharply increased, in what Mrs. Chamorro's advisers have charged was a deliberate move to cause a surge of inflation.
In the same lame-duck period, the Sandinista-controlled National Assembly approved a series of sweeping new laws on the ground of protecting the ''conquests of the revolution.''
One such law, which grants permanent ownership rights to Nicaraguans who had been renting or squatting on Government property, is widely supported. But other measures, like those protecting the jobs of Sandinista bureaucrats or insuring the autonomy of university administrators, have drawn denunciations from many Nicaraguans.
University autonomy, they note, was largely respected even under the former dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle, but in the last decade it was revoked by the Sandinistas themselves as they extended close control over higher education.
 
Strikes Are Criticized
Nicaraguans interviewed also appeared overwhelmingly to criticize the Sandinistas' decision to press their demands against the new Government by means of strikes, a form of protest that was rarely tolerated by the Sandinistas.
''The Sandinistas would never have allowed the kind of strikes that they're using now,'' said Rolando Montiel Castillo, an auto mechanic, who noted that the Sandinista Government had used riot policemen and tear gas to break up strikes as recently as last June. ''They're fighting for turf, not for principle. Do they think we can't remember?''
Sandinista leaders have made clear their determination to fight on each issue as it comes up. They accuse the Government of trying to dismantle 10 years of change and of reinstituting the right-wing policies of the Somozas.
In the resulting atmosphere of conflict, the process of demobilizing some 10,000 contra guerrillas now inside Nicaragua had been one of the few signs of concrete progress. But it too has stalled as contra leaders have stopped handing over their weapons and have demanded new concessions from the Chamorro Government.
In interviews, a striking number of Mrs. Chamorro's supporters said they did not believe the contras should disarm if the political situation was not stabilized. Some went even further.
''If they tell me, I'll go to the mountains in a minute,'' a 34-year-old man said, referring to the contra army with which he fought before accepting amnesty last year. ''This can't go on.''
But most Nicaraguans remain clearly anxious to see the demobilization completed. And to most of those interviewed, the very suggestion of new fighting has only reinforced doubts that their country will ever find its way to lasting stability.
''Nobody should be talking about force,'' said Ricardo Hernandez Aleman, a 46-year-old construction worker. ''That will just put us back into the same trap all over again.''

Black marketeers exchanged the devalued local currency for American dollars recently on the street of Managua. (Mario Tapia for The New York Times) (pg. A3)
