HEADLINE: Bok to Step Aside at Harvard, Ending 20 Years as President

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 29

 BODY:
Derek C. Bok announced today that he would step down next spring as president of Harvard University, ending his 20-year tenure in perhaps the most prestigious post in American higher education.
The resignation of Mr. Bok has been rumored for some time. In an interview today, Mr. Bok, who is 60 years old, said he was leaving partly because ''I've always thought 20 years was a good round number,'' and partly because Harvard is about to begin a $2 billion multi-year fund-raising campaign that he said ''calls for continuity.''
His announcement comes when Harvard is also without a dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, the school's second-most important post. Henry Rosovsky, a popular and highly respected former dean whom Mr. Bok has named to be acting dean next year, had been widely considered a leading candidate to succeed Mr. Bok as president. But Mr. Rosovsky is 62, and he said today that he would not seek the job. 
A search committee will be formed shortly, Harvard officials said today.
 
Two Eventful Decades
Mr. Bok, a graduate of Stanford University and the Harvard Law School, is only the second president since Harvard was founded in 1636 who did not graduate from Harvard College, the undergraduate school. The other was the university's first president, Henry Dunster.
Mr. Bok's years at Harvard have been marked by the creation of the John F. Kennedy School of Government; the effective merger of Harvard with Radcliffe; the development of a new curriculum for undergraduates, and a record of strong financial management.
Mr. Bok oversaw the establishment of the Harvard Management Company, which helped Harvard's endowment grow from $1 billion when he assumed the presidency in 1971 to $5 billion today.
Mr. Bok has come under criticism from some students and alumni for refusing to divest all of Harvard's holdings in companies doing business in South Africa, and he lost a nasty battle with the school's clerical workers in 1988, when they won an election that permitted them to unionize.
 
'What a Wonderful Tour'
But Mr. Bok was widely praised today by faculty members and other university presidents for his advocacy of liberal education, his eloquence in articulating the troubles facing American universities and his decency as a colleague.
''He's just been extraordinary -what a wonderful tour Derek had,'' said Donald Kennedy, the president of Stanford. ''I've found him terrific to talk to about issues in higher education or when I just had a practical problem.''
William G. Bowen, the president of Princeton University from 1972 to 1988 and now the head of the Mellon Foundation in New York, said of Mr. Bok: ''He has been and continues to be a simply extraordinary leader in higher education. He served Harvard's interests very well.''
 
'No Cult of Personality'
It was natural for Mr. Bok to assume a leading national role, Mr. Bowen said, given Harvard's status as the oldest university in the country and its reputation as one of the pre-eminent institutions of higher learning. But Mr. Bowen added that with Mr. Bok, ''There was no cult of personality, no overwhelming ego involved.''
John Kenneth Galbraith, a Harvard professor emeritus in economics, said Mr. Bok ''sets a model for all college presidents in his amiable response to intrusive and even obnoxious professors.'' Professor Galbraith said that whenever he wrote a note of suggestion or complaint, Mr. Bok always wrote back by hand. ''No one in the computer age was so addicted to the pen,'' Professor Galbraith said.
Mr. Kennedy of Stanford, a graduate of Harvard College who also received his Ph.D. in biology from Harvard, said he sees three major challenges for Mr. Bok's successor. The first is insuring Harvard's financial stability, even though it has the largest endowment of any private university in the country, because of rapidly rising costs.
The other problems are reconsidering the unique relationships among Harvard's different schools, including the Medical School, the Law School, the Business School and the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, which are run independently, and improving the quality of undergraduate education.
 
Next Decade's Challenge
James O. Freedman, the president of Dartmouth College and also a graduate of Harvard, said the biggest challenge would be improving teaching for undergraduates, a perpetual student complaint at Harvard. ''It is very hard in a large research institution to place adequate emphasis on undergraduate teaching,'' Mr. Freedman said. ''That's the challenge of Harvard's next decade.''
But Mr. Freedman, who is chairman of the Ivy League Group of Presidents, said Mr. Bok's greatest achievement was his role in revising Harvard's undergraduate curriculum after the student upheavals of the late 1960's. In the late 1970's, Harvard began to return to a ''core curriculum'' of required liberal arts courses, including some newly created classes in what was termed ''moral reasoning,'' or ethics.
Mr. Bok was chosen Harvard's 25th president shortly after anti-Vietnam War demonstrations had disrupted the campus. There were widespread hopes that his expertise as a labor lawyer and his experience as dean of the Harvard Law School would help him calm the university.
After the United States withdrew from Vietnam and the student protests subsided, Mr. Bok was able to preside over a period of sustained growth at Harvard.
 
Turmoil in Law School
Paradoxically, the one Harvard school that has remained beset by unrest is Mr. Bok's own original unit, the law school. It has been embroiled in a controversy over hiring more minority faculty members and divided by a dispute on the proper way of teaching the law.
Mr. Bok's most obvious achievement has been the creation of the Kennedy School of Government. Just as earlier Harvard presidents had founded the medical school and the business school, Mr. Bok had a vision of helping stimulate the growth of a new class of professionally trained experts in government to improve American politics and public service.
Under Mr. Bok's guidance and with a large infusion of funds, the Kennedy School has emerged as one of the most dynamic parts of the university, with popular public lectures by visiting dignitaries, new case studies in public-policy problems and a growing faculty roster that has included a number of senior members of the Reagan and Bush administrations, such as Richard G. Darman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget.
But some professors in other departments have charged that, unlike the law or medical schools, the Kennedy School does not teach any real discipline, and has diverted funds from other parts of the university.
 
Another Leading Candidate
The Kennedy School's dean, Robert D. Putnam, a professor of government, is another leading candidate to succeed Mr. Bok.
Among Mr. Bok's other accomplishments was his reorganization of the university's administration to install a series of powerful vice presidents, a move some professors have criticized as infringing on the faculty's powers. Mr. Bok also set up Harvard's own in-house legal team.
Mr. Rosovsky, who will become acting dean of the faculty this summer, said one of Mr. Bok's real achievements was simply his longevity, at a time when most college presidents burn out after a decade or less because of the demands of fund-raising and faculty disputes.
Moreover, Mr. Rosovsky said, Mr. Bok had been ''very accessible, very pastoral,'' in his contact with professors, and he had taken enormous pleasure in his authority to make all tenured appointments to Harvard's faculty.
''He always said that was the part of the job he enjoyed most,'' Mr. Rosovsky commented. ''It was what kept him intellectually curious.''
The only current presidents of major universities who have served longer than Mr. Bok, according to the Association of American Universities, are Chancellor Charles E. Young of the University of California at Los Angeles, who took office in 1968, and Wesley W. Posvar of the University of Pittsburgh, who assumed his job in 1967. Mr. Posvar has announced he will retire next year.
In the interview today, Mr. Bok insisted he had been too busy to think about what he would do after leaving. The Harvard Corporation, which governs Harvard, has offered him the prestigious job of university professor, the best teaching position at Harvard. But Mr. Bok said, ''I'm not sure if this is what I will do.''

HEADLINE: Toward the Summit;
U.S. Aides See Shackles On Their Soviet Guest

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
The Bush Administration believes that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's domestic problems will not prevent him from completing pending arms control treaties, but it is increasingly concerned that they might become an obstacle on broader issues like the future of Germany, Administration officials said today.
The United States is most anxious to resolve the question of unifying Germany and to persuade Mr. Gorbachev to soften his opposition to allowing Germany to stay in NATO. A senior Administration official said Mr. Bush recognizes that Mr. Gorbachev has ''deep problems'' on this score, stemming from Soviet scars from World War II and strong opposition at home to allowing Germany to remain in the Western alliance.
The official said the United States is considering some gestures to strengthen the role of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe if Mr. Bush believes that might help persuade Mr. Gorbachev to budge on Germany. The official would not say what these gestures might be, but stressed that Mr. Bush will not ease his refusal to grant any military functions for the conference, which is favored by the Soviet Union as the organization to oversee a pan-European security system. 
Administration officials also said they have been sensing an increasing desire by the Soviet leader to attract Western investment. Soviet officials have said they hope the summit meeting will produce economic agreements that Mr. Gorbachev can use to ''demonstrate that he has solidified the relationship with the United States,'' one official said.
 
Strong Figure, Strong Challenges
On the eve of Mr. Gorbachev's arrival in Washington, senior Administration officials said that the Soviet leader seems in firm control of the levers of state, but that there are more challenges to his authority than any superpower leader has faced going into a summit meeting since Richard M. Nixon went to Moscow in 1974 in the middle of the Watergate crisis.
The officials said the upheaval in the Baltics, economic turmoil and political developments like the election of Boris N. Yeltsin as president of the Russian republic have cast a shadow over the summit meeting.
''It doesn't play directly into the talks,'' a senior official said. ''But I think it is part of this image of a man coming here besieged and beleaguered.''
The official said that ''doesn't necessarily mean he will be weak and therefore will roll over to any proposal.''
''It could have the opposite impact,'' the official said. ''He may feel that he can't give an inch.''
Mr. Gorbachev's political troubles have created a turbulent political picture that American analysts are struggling to sort out. ''In terms of Kremlin politics, I think Gorbachev may be as strong as anybody's been in recent memory,'' a senior official said. ''What is different in the Soviet internal political equation is what's going on out there in the society.''
 
Attempts to 'Inoculate' Progress
Another official said, ''Gorbachev has more legal power than any other Soviet leader but his authority seems to be steadily eroding.''
Fearing that Mr. Gorbachev will be tied up by domestic turmoil, Administration officials are talking about trying to ''lock in'' as many specific agreements as possible. A senior official said the United States has ''done the best we can to try to inoculate'' arms control treaties now being negotiated against any future political reversals. But the official said, ''Obviously, Gorbachev is an important part of the equation.''
What concerns the Administration, officials said, is the lingering uncertainty over how much Mr. Gorbachev will be able, or willing, to accomplish, beyond what one called ''last year's treaties and agreements.''
''No one is writing off Gorbachev,'' the official said. ''The question really is whether he's going to be able to deal at this time, or whether his domestic problems and the preoccupation with Germany and the World War II legacy will make this just an important discussion or a breakthrough. Our inclination is to think that it won't be a breakthrough and to hope it might lead to something later this year.''
 
Last-Minute Schedule Changes
On the day before Mr. Gorbachev's arrival, officials were still trying to sort out the details of his schedule.
After 10 days of fevered preparation, officials at the Hoover Institution of War, Revolution and Peace at Stanford University were informed late Monday that Gorbachev will not visit the research institution Monday when he travels to the university campus south of San Francisco.
The official explanation, delivered by Valentin Kamenev, the Soviet Consul General in San Francisco, was that Mr. Gorbachev's schedule was ''too tight.'' But there was speculation in San Francisco that the institute had been removed from the schedule because of its reputation as a bastion of anti-Communism.
Mr. Gorbachev is scheduled to have breakfast on Monday with former President Ronald Reagan at Mr. Kamenev's official residence. The Soviet President and his wife, Raisa, are to visit the Stanford University art gallery and its business school.

HEADLINE: Toward the Summit;
American Fear of Soviets Declines, Survey Finds

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
As President Bush prepares for his summit meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, Americans no longer worry very much about the Soviet Union as a military threat.
While the strategic relationship between the superpowers used to be the prime concern at summit meetings, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll of 1,140 Americans found that the expectation of a nuclear war has fallen far below levels of a decade ago. Fewer than one American in five says a nuclear war is likely in the next 10 years, compared with nearly half when the question was asked almost 10 years ago.
Moreover, one American in five surveyed by phone in the poll from May 22 to 24 now views the United States as superior in military strength to the Soviet Union, the highest number since the Times and CBS News began asking this question in 1978. Another two in five said the superpowers are equal in strength. 
Domestic public opinion forms an important backdrop to summit meetings. Much has been made about how Mr. Gorbachev, more than any of his predecessors, must take such opinion into account, particularly because of rising complaints at home about the Soviet economy. While Mr. Bush's economic troubles are hardly as severe, polling by The Times and CBS News shows that in other ways Mr. Bush is also dealing in a domestic political world drastically different from that of his predecessors.
 
Question of Dominance
This can best be seen by looking at the dramatic long-term change in attitudes among Americans on the question of whether the Soviet Union is trying to dominate the world. In 1950, 81 percent of America said the Soviet Union was trying to do so, when asked their opinion by the Gallup Organization. But when The New York Times and CBS News asked a similiar question in a survey in early April this year, only 33 percent expressed that view.
There are substantial differences among Americans in their attitudes toward East-West relations, but these differences are not based to any large degree on partisan leanings or ideology. Rather, the most important factors appear to be education and how much attention the person pays to the news about the changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
The least educated and least informed are twice as likely to say they expect a nuclear war, are the least enthusiastic about Mr. Gorbachev and are the least likely to trust the Soviets to honor an arms deal.
Both Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev remain popular in the latest survey, although Mr. Bush's standing has slipped slightly from the historically high level he achieved right after the invasion of Panama in December.
Asked if they approve of the job Mr. Bush is doing, 69 percent say yes, down from 76 percent approval in January, but statistically indistinguishable from the 72 percent in April. Approval of Mr. Bush's handling of foreign policy has also slipped since the Panama invasion, with 57 percent expressing approval. That is down from 73 percent in January. The margin of sampling error is plus or minus 3 percentage points in each of the polls.
 
View of Gorbachev Little Changed
In the United States, opinion toward Mr. Gorbachev has not changed much, even though news from the Soviet Union of late has been dominated by the difficulties of the Soviet economy and his opposition to the Baltic independence movement, as well as other ethnic problems. Forty-five percent of Americans say they have a favorable opinion of Mr. Gorbachev and 9 percent say they have an unfavorable opinon. Those number are statistically unchanged from surveys earlier this year and last year.
Six out of ten Americans say it is very important to the interests of the United States for Mr. Gorbachev to remain in power. That may help explain why four out of ten also say it is more important to maintain good relations with Mr. Gorbachev than to support Lithuania's efforts to break away from the Soviet Union.
Attitudes toward Lithuania remain essentially unchanged from earlier polls, with one-third saying it is more important to support the independence movement in the republic, which declared independence from Moscow on March 11 and has since suffered the effects of a partial Soviet economic blockade.
 
Strength of the Powers
On the question of American versus Soviet strength there has been a dramatic shift since 1978, when the Times and CBS News started asking this question. In the latest survey 44 percent of Americans say the two superpowers are about equal, and 26 percent think America is not so strong. In 1978, when 42 percent said America was not as strong, 32 percent said the two powers were about egual in strength and 12 percent said the United States was superior.
In the latest Times CBS News poll, a minority of Americans said they were paying a lot of attention to the changes in Eastern Europe and The Soviet Union.
Asked how much they had read or heard about these changes, 42 percent said a lot, 35 percent said some and 21 percent said not much. The views on relations with the Soviets of the group that has not paid much attention were markedly different from those who have been paying attention.
For example, of those who say they have heard or read a lot about the changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, 74 percent say it is very important to the United States that Mr. Gorbachev stay in power. But among those who say they have not heard or read much, only 38 percent say American interest are tied to Mr. Gorbachev's fate.
 
No Party Differences
By contrast, the poll found no difference between Democrats and Republicans on this question, or between those who call themselves liberal, moderate or conservatives.
Similiarly, education dramatically affects views toward the Soviets. College graduates, who are much more likely to be following the news, have a much better opinion of Mr. Gorbachev, with nearly 7 out of 10 saying they view him favorably. Of those who never finished high school, one out of four said they had a favorable opinion of Gorbachev.
Despite all the changes in the world, a plurality of Americans, 45 percent, say the summit meeting starting Wednesday in Washington still means as much as other summit meetings did before. Thirty percent said they think this summit meeting means less than before, and 18 percent volunteered that they think the summit meeting means more.

HEADLINE: Arab Leaders, Seeking One Voice, Extend Talks

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 29

 BODY:
Arab leaders seeking a common response to Soviet Jewish migration to Israel and other issues extended a two-day summit meeting here today as Egypt and other nations looked for a consensus of moderation in the face of increasing anti-American sentiment.
The gathering of 16 of the Arab League's 21 members is supposed to unify Arab positions in advance of the United States-Soviet summit meeting in Washington this week. But a dispute has surfaced over the extent to which the meeting's public declarations identify the United States as a sponsor of hostile Israeli policies and actions.
Both Iraq, the host, and the Palestine Liberation Organization, which sought the emergency gathering, want to attack the United States for its financial and military support of Israel and for its perceived encouragement of Soviet Jewish immigration. Many Palestinians and some Arab countries, notably Jordan, say the projected arrival of hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews in Israel will ultimately displace Palestinians from the occupied West Bank. 
''What we see in the immigration issue is that it undercuts the two most crucial elements of the Palestinian question,'' a senior Jordanian said. ''One, the land, and two, the people.'' Additionally, Jordan wants the meeting here to renew a pledge of financial and other support because a large displacement of West Bank Palestinians could seriously destabilize the monarchy of King Hussein, whose population is already more than half Palestinian.
''We have reached a point where we might not continue without your cooperation,'' King Hussein told fellow Arab leaders when the meeting opened on Sunday. ''We have drained all our financial resources. Our national commitment should not be a source of punishment to my country.'' Jordan, viewed as pro-Western and seized by economic crisis, is said by Arab diplomats to support an accusatory line toward the United States. Jordanian officials argue that if the United States had not imposed a quota on Soviet Jewish migration to America last year, many Soviet Jews would have headed there rather than to Israel.
Jordan has protested for months that it is the most vulnerable Arab country to the repercussions of Soviet Jewish migration to Israel. Few Arab commentators accept Israeli assurances that the new arrivals will not be settled among the Palestinians of the occupied West Bank. So far, very few of the immigrants have been resetled in the West Bank, where a Palestinian revolt has been under way, as well as in the Gaza Strip, since December 1987. The principal advocate of a less strident line toward Washington is Egypt, the United States' closest Arab ally in Middle East diplomacy and the recipient of $2.3 billion a year in American economic and military aid. Egypt is supported in its efforts by Saudi Arabia and conservative Persian Gulf sheikdoms.
When the meeting opened on Sunday, President Hosni Mubarak urged his fellow Arab leaders to display less alarmism about the Soviet Jewish influx. Arab diplomats said Egypt wanted to avoid a surge of overt anti-Israeli and anti-American sentiment that would further stiffen Israel's resistance to American proposals for a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue.
Since 1979, when Egypt signed the Arab world's only peace treaty with Israel, Cairo has sought to broaden the peace. In recent years that effort has formed the central thrust of its diplomacy. In pressing for less hostile language in the gathering's resolutions, Arab diplomats said, Egypt was also seeking to defend the position it revived in the last two years as the fulcrum of Arab diplomacy.
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, by contrast, is seeking to build a constituency for its advocacy of a more militant Arab readiness to confront both Israel and the United States.
Although the Baghdad meeting was supposed to wind up today, Arab foreign ministers met tonight to try to overcome differences over the phrasing of their resolutions before a late-night session among those leaders who attended. The most prominent of the Arab leaders who did not attend was President Hafez al-Assad of Syria.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Poland to Let Soviet Jews Fly to Israel From Warsaw

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, May 27

 BODY:
Charter flights carrying 500 Soviet Jews a week to Israel will begin moving through Poland next month, marking a new chapter in the complex relationship between Warsaw and Jerusalem.
Maj. Andrzej Dziewulski, the chief of security at the airport here, said the flights were the first step in making Warsaw a major transit point through which thousands of Soviet Jews could travel each week to Israel.
Major Dziewulski said the Soviet airline Aeroflot would be flying one IL-86 charter a week to Warsaw, with passengers then transferred to a waiting El Al jumbo jet. The other flight, from Moscow to Warsaw and then to Tel Aviv, would be handled solely by Lot, the Polish state airline, he said. 
Poland, which only recently resumed full relations with Israel after breaking them as a result of the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, has great hopes for closer ties to Jerusalem, including cooperation in agriculture and science.
 
Poland's Search for Help
Warsaw is also eager for entrepreneurs in Israel, many of whom are of Polish origin and speak the language, to invest in a country that had Europe's largest Jewish population before World War II. Only about 4,000 Jews remain in Poland; there were more than 3 million here before the war.
Martin Wenick, executive director of the National Conference on Soviet Jewry, said Poland's role in the exodus of Soviet Jews was significant because it would open the door for more immigration than now possible. Mr. Wenick said that Bucharest, Romania, and Budapest, the main transit points for the approximately 10,000 Jews who leave the Soviet Union each month, are increasingly overburdened by the flow.
The issue has become sensitive in Eastern Europe since Arab terrorist groups announced that they would retaliate against countries participating in the pipeline. Hungary's state-owned airline, Malev, said soon after that it was dropping out, and although Israel has continued to fly Jews out of Hungary on El Al, it has also been pressing Hungary to resume the Malev flights.
It was against this backdrop that Poland's Prime Minister, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, announced in New York on March 26 that Poland was willing to ease the movement of Soviet Jews. Immediately afterward, two employees of a Polish trade mission in Beirut were shot, and a previously unknown group, the Organization of Revolutionary Action, claimed responsibility while another group in Lebanon, the Islamic Military Front, said it would plan new attacks against Poles.
 
Relations With Israelis
The terrorist threat has prompted Poland to begin new intelligence cooperation with countries that were its adversary only a few months ago. While he was in Washington, Mr. Mazowiecki discussed possible efforts on the issue with William H. Webster, the head of the Central Intelligence Agency, and Mr. Dziewulski said he had developed a close working relationship with his Israeli counterparts.
Mr. Dziewulski said his anti-terrorist unit at the airport had been strengthened. He said Polish authorities had been hit with a barrage of bomb threats and other anonymous phone calls since the announcement of the plans to assist the Soviet Jews. He said that because the airport and Lot facilities were well protected, the main concern of security officials was that terrorists would strike other Polish targets.
 
'A Technical Problem'
Waldyslaw Klaczynski, chief spokesman for the Foreign Ministry, said Poland had taken steps to improve security for its diplomats since the attack in Beirut. Mr. Klaczynski said he had no estimate of how many Soviet Jews would come through Warsaw, but said the Solidarity-led Government had set no limits. ''This is strictly a technical problem for Lot and the airlines,'' he said.
Mr. Klaczynski believes that the new Government here can built strong ties with Israel. ''Jews had a historical role in Poland for centuries,'' he said, ''and the relationship was a good one. Now, we want to built a relationship of economic, scientific, cultural cooperation.''
Mordecai Palzur, the Israeli Ambassador here, declined to discuss the plans for Soviet Jewish immigration. But he said new opportunities were emerging for Israel. Mr. Palzur predicted that trade between the countries would total $100 million this year and said Poland offered Israeli businesses both a chance for investment and a market for their products.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1757 words

HEADLINE: Stirring a Debate on Breaking Racism's Shackles

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif.

 BODY:
Among those who have read or heard his views on race, it is very hard to find anyone, black or white, with a neutral reaction to Shelby Steele.
To many whites and conservative blacks, Mr. Steele has given eloquent voice to painful truths that are almost always left unspoken in the nation's circumscribed public discourse on race. To many black politicians and civil rights figures, he is a turncoat, a privileged black man whose visibility and success stem from his ability to say precisely what white America most wants to hear.
No matter what the reaction, it is clear that Mr. Steele, whose criticism of affirmative action and much of what is usually thought to be the black agenda has gained increasing visibility over the past year, now finds himself at the heart of the nation's increasing anguish over race and the traditional approaches to dealing with the issue.
''The interest is there for one reason that's obvious to everybody,'' said Mr. Steele, whose closely cropped hair, blue blazer, olive slacks, burgundy pin-striped shirt and black tie reflect the button-down cool of his essays. ''As we have come to experience more opportunity in American life, we have fallen further behind. It's one of the biggest sociological contradictions of late 20th century life. It's clear that whatever we're doing isn't working, and I think the audience is there because people on both sides of the racial divide understand what I'm saying.'' 
 
Bursting From Obscurity
Over the past year, Mr. Steele has gone from being an obscure English professor at San Jose State University to an almost ubiquitous commentator on race. He shows up on television news programs like ''Nightline,'' has produced a public-television documentary on the Yusuf K. Hawkins killing in the Bensonhurt section of Brooklyn and has been published in Harper's, The American Scholar, The Washington Post, The New York Times Magazine and Commentary. A collection of his essays on race is to be published later this year.
Mr. Steele's arguments, which in some ways mirror those made for a decade by black conservatives, is more complicated than the point-counterpoint to which it is often reduced on television. It boils down to the assertion that while racism still exists, it is not what is holding back America's black people. Instead, Mr. Steele asserts, the specter of racism has become a crippling fixation of blacks, a way not just to excuse failures but to avoid dealing with real problems.
He says this sense of victimization has led blacks to rely on programs like affirmative action that both stem from and perpetuate their sense of being victims. And he says the insistence on black victimization and white guilt sets in motion a never-ending, and ultimately futile, interracial battle in which attaining a moral high ground counts for more than achieving results.
''This leaves us with an identity that is at war with our best interests, that magnifies our oppression and diminishes our sense of possiblity,'' he wrote in the May issue of Harper's, Expressions of Bitterness Many blacks react angrily to Mr. Steele and his visibility in the mainstream news media. A review of his documentary on Bensonhurst in The Village Voice lambasted what it termed his ''enfeebled and handwringing apologias for the state of American racial discourse.'' Julian Bond, the civil rights figure and former Georgia State Senator, responded to one of Mr. Steele's essays in Harper's by saying it could have been written 30 years ago by Bull Connor or George Wallace.
Critics say he shows no grasp of the problems of the inner city poor and instead shines a harsh light on elements of the psyches of American blacks without offering solutions other than a vague call for self-help.
''I just think the guy's off the wall, really,'' said Representative John Lewis, a black Democrat from Georgia who is a longtime civil rights leader. ''There are these people, Steele in particular, sitting in their ivory towers far removed from the problems of poor, downtrodden black Americans. He's one of those who feels very comfortable articulating the position that the victim is responsible for his own situation.''
 
'A Superb Scholar'
But not all Mr. Steele's approval comes from whites. Although it is hard to find evidence of conservative political strength among blacks, Mr. Steele is only one of a number of black writers and thinkers who in different ways break sharply with the view of race found in the traditional civil rights movement. These include the economists Glenn Loury of Harvard University, Thomas Sowell of the Hoover Institution and Walter Williams of George Mason University; the writer Stanley Crouch, and other academics like Julius Lester of the University of Massachusetts and Anne Wortham of Washington and Lee University.
''I think he's a superb scholar, he's thoughtful, he writes well, he's honest, he's a breath of fresh air,'' said Robert Woodson, the director of the National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise in Washington who is black. ''Some of us have been saying the same things for years, and we're just pleased that someone who challenges the traditional wisdom can get a hearing.''
Mr. Steele, who is 44 years old, grew up in the working-class Chicago suburb of Phoenix. His father, a truck driver, and his mother, a social worker, were devoted to the civil rights movement. He attended Coe College in Iowa, where his heroes included Malcolm X. He headed the black student organization at the height of the black power movement.
But after teaching Afro-American literature at an experimental program for poor blacks in East St. Louis, Ill., he pursued a conventional academic career, eventually getting a Ph.D. in English from the University of Utah and going on to teach at San Jose State.
 
Dislikes Affirmative Action
As Mr. Steele tells it, he began writing on race after he was annoyed by a 1986 radio broadcast on the holiday for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in which a black leader was espousing what Mr. Steele considered the cliches of the civil rights movement.
Mr. Steele says he had not read any of the black conservatives when he began writing on race, and he clearly has both similarities and differences with them. He does not hew to a doctrinaire hostility to government programs. He says many of the programs, particularly those that derive from racial preferences, do not work. He says affirmative action, for example, diminishes the achievements of blacks, whose gains are tainted by the appearance of favoritism, and creates resentment among whites.
Mr. Steele's writing ventures onto perhaps its most emotionally charged turf when he deals with what he sees as a widespread sense of inadequacy among blacks when they enter the economic and social mainstream. He says that feeling plays out in a number of ways:self-enforced separatism by black students on white campuses; an avoidance of many forms of intellectual and academic competition by blacks who fear it is more dangerous to try and fail than not to try at all.
He said this is a bitter legacy of 350 years of oppression that whites as well as blacks have a responsibility to change. But he said it did blacks no good to ignore their real fears and blame racism for all their failings.
''Blacks have tremendous possibilities if they know what they're up against'' he said. ''But if you think you're just up against white racism and you're just a total victim of it, then you can't do anything except be mad.'' Too Far Removed? To his critics, Mr. Steele's message is at best hopelessly oversimplified and at worst deeply harmful. They say it gives whites more reasons not to finance social programs at a time of already scarce resources. Many say Mr. Steele, as a college professor whose wife, Rita, a psychologist, is white, is simply too far removed from the problems faced by most blacks.
Adolph Reed, a black political science professor at Yale University, said Mr. Steele's criticism of affirmative action, for example, made much less sense when applied to programs for working-class blacks.
Eddie N. Williams, president of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a black research organization, said Mr. Steele's apparent indifference to most government programs seemed to deny blacks the government assistance every other group in America has been able to use. He added that the problems of the black poor reflected not the failure of government intervention, but an insufficient moral or financial commitment to make the programs work.
Between the two poles are some blacks who say Mr. Steele has some valid viewpoints that are diminished by a racial naivete.
 
Points of Agreement
''He's big on personal responsibility; he's right,'' said Cornel West, a religion professor and head of the Afro-American studies program at Princeton University. ''He's big on struggling with the badge of inferiority; he's right. He's big on the impact of the quest for white validation and recognition and the difficulty of achieving that by means of affirmative action; he's right. But he trivializes these very valuable insights when he overlooks the degree to which so much of the responsibility also falls on the side on the white, skewed, limited and usually racist perceptions that dictate the quest for black acceptance.''
Still, some critics as well as friends agree that Mr. Steele may contribute something positive if he helps foster a more honest debate on racial issues.
''There's a shrouded quality to our public discourse on racial subjects,'' said Mr. Loury. ''A lot of stuff doesn't get said that people are really thinking. Whites don't want to get called racists. Blacks don't want to be called disloyal. As a result, a genuine critical discourse where a lot of different ideas get put on the table and bandied about never really happens.''
Mr. Steele says he is aware of both the pain his writing evokes and the questions it leaves unanswered.
''James Baldwin used to talk about that a great deal, that one of the real pitfalls of black writers is that they feel they have to speak for all of black America and have all the answers to enormous problems,'' he said.
''I try to avoid that trap. I know I don't have all the answers, but I try to write what I know. Some people say I shine a harsh light on difficult problems. But I never shine a light on anything I haven't experienced or write about fears I don't see in myself first. I'm my own first target. I spill my own blood first.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 24, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 281 words

HEADLINE: Let's Stop Messing With Social Security

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Older Women's League urges change in Social Security for women (news article, May 10), thus seeking to derail the Social Security system by adding more claimants. Women's work in caring for families, the group argues, should entitle them to pension benefits. 
For the 55 years since Social Security legislation was enacted, ''work'' has been defined as ''covered employment,'' meaning the earning of wages that entailed a contribution to financing the system. Work alone has never created an entitlement, and the exertions of millions of men and women have always been excluded.
If work in the home is to be recognized, separate legislation is appropriate. Otherwise, employed workers in covered employment must finance new benefits by paying higher payroll taxes or accepting reduced benefits.
There is an enormous subsidy from men to women in the pension system because women, with greater life expectancy than men, receive the same pension if based on the same wage history, even though they will draw their pensions for a longer period. To the argument that women typically earn less than men, the answer is that there is a further subsidy from higher-paid to lower-paid workers. A worker at age 65 who has contributed the maximum amount will receive a pension equal to about one-fourth of this annual earning before retirement. A low-paid worker will receive more than half.
Congress has made the payroll tax an excessively regressive income tax and should not be encouraged to warp the system more.
 
JOHN MAHER
Hamden, Conn., May 10, 1990
 The writer retired as professor of economics and finance at Southern Connecticut State University.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Shifts And Restores Broom Squad

BYLINE: By LEONARD BUDER

 BODY:
Five days after saying that the city could not afford it, Mayor David N. Dinkins moved yesterday to restore money in his proposed budget to maintain the Sanitation Department Clean Team, a group responsible for manually sweeping streets and emptying trash cans.
Mr. Dinkins acted after receiving pressure from some advisers and stiff criticism from some civic groups. They had voiced concern that eliminating the remaining 300 jobs in the nine-year-old operation would result in dirtier streets and overflowing litter baskets as the city is trying to attract visitors and business, as well as the 1992 Democratic National Convention. At its height in 1987, the Clean Team had 1,382 workers. 
Although shifting or adding money is usual in drawing up the budget, it is unusual for such a reversal within days of submitting a budget, especially after the Mayor declared flatly on Thursday that the team ''is out of business.''
 
'Awful Lot to Do With Morale'
In making the quick reversal, Mr. Dinkins risked seeming to bow to presssure to restore a program whose elimination he and his aides had staunchly defended. On the other hand, after being put in a difficult situation by the delay in the state budget and his resulting wariness, Mr. Dinkins may have hoped to make the best of a potentially damaging situation by demonstrating flexibility in restoring a popular program.
Mr. Dinkins said he had decided to keep the team because ''it has an awful lot to do with morale of people in our town'' and had an ''impact on visitors.'' He also said the cutback could have hurt the efforts to attract the convention.
The reversal was seen, in part, as an attempt to take credit for preserving the team. City Council leaders had said they would keep the teams when they approved the budget.
Mr. Dinkins said the additional money became available when the amount of state aid became clearer. The city would use $6.2 million of a $90 million reserve fund.
Mr. Dinkins added that he was persuaded by arguments at a meeting with his council of economic advisers, which includes Felix G. Rohatyn and David Rockefeller, last Wednesday, the day before he announced the proposed budget.
''At that meeting,'' the Mayor said in a letter to the Council, ''I became convinced by their perspective that the elimination of this service would impair our effort to foster a positive business climate and to encourage our tourism industry. I became particularly concerned that the decline in service could hurt our efforts to bring the Democratic National Convention to our city.''
An associate of Mr. Rockefeller, Peter Johnson, when informed of the Mayor's reversal, said of Mr. Rockefeller, ''I know he would be extremely pleased by that development.''
First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel, a former Sanitation Commissioner, said the administration did not determine until the weekend that money would available for the cleanup group. Eliminating the force, Mr. Steisel said, had been the very last budget cut that Mr. Dinkins agreed to.
When asked whether the switch gave the appearance of an administration in disarray, Mr. Dinkins said, ''I recognize that there might be some that might make that observation, but it is an inaccurate one.''
He later said, ''What is important in the final analysis is to do the right and correct thing, and that's what we have done.'' $90 Million Contingency Fund Mr. Dinkins said it would cost $7.4 million to keep the Clean Team. Part of that, $1.2 million, would will come from eliminating the mobile Neighborhood Intensive Cleanup Squads. Those squads, Mr. Dinkins said, ''were intended to be a ''stopgap emergency response'' after the Clean Team had been eliminated. The squads have a total of 39 sweepers and 4 supervisors who will be assigned to other duties.
The rest of the money for the Clean Team, $6.2 million, as well as $22 million to reduce some planned cuts for the schools, would come from a $90 million contingency fund set aside because of the uncertain state budget.
''After the state budget was released and we were able to analyze it fully,'' the Mayor said in his letter, ''we found that the cost to the city in 1991 was approximately $53 million, or $37 million less than we had assumed in our Expense Budget.''
Even with the added money - for sanitation and education - there is still money in the special reserve. Mr. Dinkins said the possibility that the state may disallow some city reimbursement claims could further raise city costs.
